fields.headline: Hospital case
fields.trailText: Last week's front page claimed that East Surrey Hospital, Redhill, 'probably has the worst A&E department in Britain' - something I strongly deny.
fields.body:
Last week's front page claimed that East Surrey Hospital, Redhill, 'probably has the worst A&E department in Britain' - something I strongly deny. The evidence appears to be drawn from the findings of a Community Health Council (CHC) 'Casualty Watch' of 20 December 1999. The CHC survey was not national and covered only 40 hospitals. This information was omitted from your report.

Your reporter also quoted selectively from a personal interview. He did not mention that when admissions rose significantly in late December the hospital acted swiftly. We told him we had opened extra beds between Christmas and New Year, and following the new year opened an eight-bed admissions ward for patients away from the A&E department while waiting admission.
Isobel Gowan
Chief Executive, Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust,
Redhill

webTitle: English women fall apart in third defeat

fields.headline: English women fall apart in third defeat
fields.trailText: The manager of England's women, Paul Farbrace, called for changes after his team suffered a 10-wicket defeat by Australia yesterday to hand the home side a 3-0 lead in the four-match series.
fields.body:
It is all starting to get serious for England's women. The leafy elm and plane trees of Bowral's Bradman Oval are reminiscent of the days when the English lived where they liked, did what they liked and even imported foliage to remind them of home. But that is no more.

Their 10-wicket defeat by Australia, which gave the home side a 3-0 lead in a four-match series, merely brought home what their male compatriots already knew: the English can no longer do what they like. There is an awful lot of catching up to do. And the manager Paul Farbrace is committed to doing it.

He says: "We have to start identifying who is up to it and bringing in some of the youngsters if we feel we have to. We have five matches in New Zealand next week and a series against South Africa in the summer to help us prepare for the World Cup just before Christmas. It is no good saying we are out of season or we have only been here a week. The excuses have to stop."

This time there were no excuses. England were put in and quickly dismissed - all out for 106. Australia reached that with half their overs and all their breath left. No England bowler took any wickets and none scored any runs worth talking about, although Karen Smithies' 19 and Kathryn Leng's 24 might have prospered on another day against another team.

The team now travel to Newcastle for the final game in Australia tomorrow. At least the left-arm seamer Lucy Pearson, potentially England's best bowler, should have recovered from a thigh strain to bowl on what England's men have usually found to be a lively track.

webTitle: Kick flicks are coming soon to a cinema near you

fields.headline: Kick flicks are coming soon to a cinema near you
fields.trailText: This year promises to a good one for for soccer movies, as Hollywood tries to cash in on the growing popularity of sport. But, asks Martin Kelner, is Hollywood ready for The Glenn Hoddle Story?
fields.body:
Between The Arsenal Stadium Mystery (1939) and When Saturday Comes (1996), nothing. Nothing, that is, except Escape To Victory (1981) which I discount, since any film which plays Michael Caine in midfield and Sylvester Stallone in goal forfeits the right to call itself a serious film about soccer.

Generally the view has been that soccer is not a suitable subject for what Hollywood likes to call a "major motion picture", lacking the intrinsic drama of boxing or baseball and fatally remaining utterly incomprehensible to the Americans. Soccer movies, conventional wisdom told us, would not play in Hard Knob, Illinois (real place, apparently).

Well, yah-boo to conventional wisdom, because there are at least four soccer films scheduled for release this year, as Hollywood tries to cash in on the growing popularity of sport - any sport, even soccer. According to the American Sports Business Journal, sport generated $213bn (£130bn) last year, nearly seven times as much as its closest entertainment rival, the movies themselves.

So the cameras are - or have just finished - turning on an unprecedented roster of sports movies; everything from Celebrity Deathmatch (wrestling) to Psycho Beach Party (surfing). Interestingly, soccer features in these forthcoming attractions as prominently as either boxing or American football.

America may finally be waking up to the extraordinary worldwide appeal of the beautiful game. If you have a hot soccer idea to pitch - Gazza: The Movie, Nightmare On Filbert Street, Horror At The Bates Motel (otherwise known as Chelsea Village) - now could be the time.

I have seen none of the four soccer movies scheduled for imminent release but advance publicity suggests that producers these days want something which gets under the skin of the game rather more than the ludicrous When Saturday Comes, where the rookie Sean Bean is improbably given the responsibility of the last-minute penalty against Manchester United, or even Fever Pitch, for which we were forced not only to accept loveable Cockneys cavorting in the streets to celebrate Arsenal's triumph but to believe in the hirsute Colin Firth as Nick Hornby.

The Cup, for instance, a new film from Bhutan, is the story of two young Tibetans, who escape from the Chinese and join a Tibetan monastery-in-exile in the foothills of the Himalayas, where they find football fever running hot through the hallowed hallways.

The film, directed by Khyentse Norbu, a pre-eminent lama of the Tibetan Buddhist tradition, follows the soccer-mad monks' attempt to hook up a satellite dish to watch the 1998 World Cup. It is said to combine warm irreverent humour and Tibetan wisdom, alongside its insight into the healing, unifying nature of sport. It does sound more interesting than boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl, Arsenal-win-Championship, boy-gets-girl again.

Some of you who have heard of The Cup may be wondering just where Ally McCoist fits in, given that the majority of the cast rose at 4am each day to complete their prayers before the day's shooting, which would leave little time over for Question Of Sport. The truth is that there is an entirely different soccer film, bizarrely also called The Cup, in which the former Rangers star has a small part.

I suspect there might be a title change before the release of this movie, which stars Robert Duvall and in which Alex Ferguson (watch out Kevin Spacey) and Billy Connolly play cameo roles. McCoist plays a washed-up former star who tries to revive his flagging career by signing on for Duvall's struggling small-town club, Kilnockie. No type casting there, then.

Also scheduled for release soon are The Match, featuring a game between two pub teams in another small Scottish town, and Mad About Mambo, a movie set in Ireland said to combine soccer and dance.

Strike while the iron is hot, I say, so here is my pitch for a film which combines the increasingly popular soccer genre (kick flicks as they no doubt will come to be known) with those fantasy movies that never go out of fashion like Heaven Can Wait and Blithe Spirit, in which people return from beyond the grave. Is Hollywood ready for The Glenn Hoddle Story? He's back and this time it's personal.

webTitle: Italy orders anti-fascist snatch squads at Lazio

fields.headline: Italy orders anti-fascist snatch squads at Lazio
fields.trailText: Italian police have been mobilised to storm football stands after Lazio fans unfurled a giant banner praising the Serbian war criminal Arkan, drawing wrath from the government and purrs from Mussolini's granddaughter.
fields.body:
Italian police have been mobilised to storm football stands after Lazio fans unfurled a giant banner praising the Serbian war criminal Arkan, drawing wrath from the government and purrs from Mussolini's granddaughter.

The Rome club and civic authorities vowed yesterday to crack down on a group of fans who have inflamed Serie A games with emblems such as swastikas and Celtic crosses which have been appropriated by the far right.

The display at Sunday's match against Bari of a 20-metre banner, reading Honour to the Tiger Arkan, was the final straw.

Police have been told to search fans thoroughly before entering stadiums. If an offensive banner is successfully smuggled inside and unfurled inside, police are to attempt to weigh into the crowd and make arrests. Matches will be terminated if necesary regardless of the uproar caused.

The latest incident at Lazio's Olympic Stadium has shredded the team's delicate multinational mix. Alen Boksic, the club's Croatian striker, who was not playing due to injury, said he would have left the pitch. "I take this personally," he said.

However his Serbian teammate Sinisa Mihajlovic wrote an obituary in a Belgrade newspaper praising Arkan, who was indicted for war crimes during wars in the former Yugoslavia. Arkan, born Zeljko Raznatovic, was assassinated two weeks ago.

Alessandra Mussolini, granddaughter of Benito Mussolini and a deputy with the far-right National Alliance party, praised the banner-holders. "Honour to the fans," she said. "Now I'm a Lazio fan as well." A portrait of the former dictator was also paraded by Lazio fans on Sunday.

webTitle: Specialist consigns Owen to month on the sidelines

fields.headline: Specialist consigns Owen to month on the sidelines
fields.trailText: Liverpool's Michael Owen suffered another major setback yesterday when he was told he must not kick a ball in anger for at least a month.
fields.body:
Liverpool's Michael Owen suffered another major setback yesterday when he was told he must not kick a ball in anger for at least a month.

After considering specialists' reports on the striker's latest hamstring injury, Liverpool said Owen would follow a special recovery programme at the club's Melwood training complex.

"The programme will involve strengthening exercises for his lower back, stabilisation activities for his pelvis and work to improve both the strength and endurance of his hamstrings," said a Liverpool spokesman. "Michael is expected to be back playing again at the start of March."

The earliest he will return to senior football is March 4, when Liverpool face Manchester United at Old Trafford. If his hamstring muscles do not respond well to another rest, he could be inactive until mid-March, a worrying scenario for his club and for the England coach Kevin Keegan in the lead up to Euro 2000.

Middlesbrough's chairman Steve Gibson has assumed full control of the club after buying ICI's 20% shareholding for an undisclosed amount.

Second Division Cardiff City have parted company with their manager Frank Burrows by mutual consent.

webTitle: Leboeuf banned as Vialli plots comeback

fields.headline: Leboeuf banned as Vialli plots comeback
fields.trailText: Chelsea's options broadened at one end and narrowed at the other yesterday when Gianluca Vialli came out of retirement and Frank Leboeuf was banned for two matches for stamping on Harry Kewell.
fields.body:
Chelsea's options broadened at one end and narrowed at the other yesterday when Gianluca Vialli came out of retirement and Frank Leboeuf was banned for two matches for stamping on Harry Kewell.

Leboeuf pleaded guilty to misconduct at a Football Association disciplinary hearing and apologised for his actions during Chelsea's 2-0 home defeat by Leeds in December.

The defender has already served a two-match suspension after being sent off for two fouls on Kewell. The second, a trip, was followed by the trample.

"I apologised because I know I did something wrong," the Frenchman said. "I have played top football for 12 years and had never done something like that. I said what I thought and I had to tell the truth and the FA treated me fairly."

The 32-year-old is free to play at Tottenham on Saturday and against Wimbledon the following week. He misses Chelsea's FA Cup quarter-final against Gillingham and the league game against Watford.

"He promised that it would never happen again and was aware that it was not the sort of image he wanted to promote to young players," said the FA spokesman Steve Double.

Leboeuf apologised publicly to Kewell. It was his second sending-off of the season and he is one booking from another two-match ban.

"He received what he would have received if the referee Jeff Winter had shown a red card rather than two yellows," said Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson. "We accept the judgment."

Meanwhile Vialli has become a player-manager again, having insisted before the season started that he was retiring to concentrate on coaching. The 35-year-old played 90 minutes for the reserves on Monday, hitting the bar, and has registered himself for domestic and European matches.

The Champions League seems the most likely stage for his comeback, with George Weah ineligible, having played in the competition this season for Milan.

But Vialli will not be free to play until after the next game at Marseille on February 29 because of his abuse of the fourth official at Lazio in December. Uefa said he could not be on the pitch or the touchline in any capacity in France.

Vialli was cleared on January 20 to play in the Premiership and FA Cup but is unlikely to select himself ahead of Chris Sutton, Gianfranco Zola, Tore Andre Flo or Weah. The Italian has not played since the final day of last season at Derby.

Bradford have ended their interest in Stan Collymore. "We have been advised that Aston Villa are holding out for a £3m fee," said the chairman Geoffrey Richmond, who was prepared to do business only if the striker cost nothing.

Danny Wilson has been named Manager of the Month for January only three days after losing at Gillingham in the FA Cup. "I'm just hoping that the manager-of-the-month curse has struck early," said Wilson, whose side beat Bradford and Tottenham, and drew with Arsenal, to climb off the bottom of the table for the first time since August 20.

Three of the FA Cup quarter-finals will be played on Sunday February 20, with Bolton v Charlton the only Saturday match. Tranmere v Newcastle will kick-off at 2pm live on ITV. Everton v Aston Villa will follow at 4pm on Sky.

Chelsea v Gillingham will start at 3pm. At 11.30am that morning Leeds play Manchester United in the Premiership.

fields.headline: Debts force Airdrie into liquidation
fields.trailText: The Scottish First Division club Airdrie have gone into liquidation with debts totalling £750,000.
fields.body:
The Scottish First Division club Airdrie have gone into liquidation with debts totalling £750,000.

An extraordinary general meeting has been arranged for next Monday to discuss a change of constitution which could ensure the club's survival.

Currently no shareholder is allowed to own more than 10% of the shares - a ruling that could be changed at the EGM to allow new investors to become involved.

The club's provisional liquidator, Blair Nimmo of KPMG Corporate Recovery, said: "The club has first-class facilities and is an important institution within Scottish football. It just needs new investment."

Airdrie's problems deepened yesterday when Rangers froze the struggling club's share of the gate receipts for Sunday's Scottish Cup tie at Dundee United. The Ibrox chairman David Murray applied for an interdict on behalf of his company Carnegie for a £30,000 debt owed by Airdrie.

fields.headline: Where the heart is
fields.standfirst: The story of the 20th century ranges  from triumph to disaster. But, John  Perry writes, we've come a long way  in that time
fields.trailText: The story of the 20th century ranges from triumph to disaster. But, John Perry writes, we've come a long way in that time.
fields.body:
What have we achieved in the past 100 years of housing? In the latest Housing Finance Review, Alan Holmans, a former chief housing economist at the DETR, marks the end of the century by asking what progress has been made in improving housing conditions in Britain. The answer seems to be: quite a lot.

The challenge was pretty formidable, for while total population grew by 62%, the number of households tripled. In part, this is because adults formed little over half the population at the start of the 20th century, but three-quarters by the end.

But it was not just the extra adults that led to more separate households. An important new trend began in the 1930s and will continue into the next century: adults now increasingly live alone.

Perhaps surprisingly, the explosion in the number of households was more than matched by the supply of homes. At the start of the century, there was still a crude gap between the two, made worse by two world wars, so that by the beginning of the second half of the century the deficit was at its greatest. Yet within 20 years, the number of homes had been increased by more than half - an unparalleled achievement in which the public sector led the way.

During the 1970s, the crude shortage was eliminated as the number of houses overtook the number of households. The fact that shortages continue is due to many of these houses now being in the wrong places or owned as second homes.

Holmans points out that the first years of the century, marked by the strongest housing boom till then, are an object lesson in the workings of a free market, in which the major suppliers are private landlords. There was a rising vacancy rate on the eve of the first world war, coexisting with massive overcrowding, because many people did not earn enough to rent a house.

Having sufficient houses is one test of progress; their condition is another. If the first big improvement in standards of construction took place before the century began, with the building of the Victorian terraces that still provide us with 15% of our homes, the next - providing proper amenities in every house - followed the first world war.

If the housing market and public policy have failed, it is in the state of disrepair and need for improvement in the stock. There are still 3million families in poor housing. Home owners account for the greatest numbers in this category, but as a proportion it is privately-rented housing which is in worst condition.

Failure to invest has been made worse by the failure to replace. If houses were to last an average of 100 years each, we would be replacing the poorest at a rate of 200,000 every year. In fact, we demolish only a small fraction of that figure. The much-publicised phenomenon of empty housing in parts of the north is one outcome.

Holmans asks whether it was the market or public policy which led to the improvement in housing conditions over the past 100 years. The answer is a bit of both. The amazing expansion of home ownership, from less than 10% then to almost 70% now, transformed conditions for the majority and largely resulted from cheap finance from building societies, aided for the past 30 years by tax relief.

But anyone who regards council housing as a failure now should be reminded about what it achieved. Over 1 million families were without a separate home in 1914. They had to wait until the inter-war period for the massive building of cottage estates at low rents that, by the second half of the century, had enabled the demolition of the worst of the Victorian slums. Post-war clearance and redevelopment completed the job. What a disaster that gross misjudgments in how this was done have led to council housing being discredited.

 John Perry is policy director of the Chartered Institute of Housing. The Housing Finance Review 1999-2000 is published for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation by the CIH and Council of Mortgage Lenders (tel 01203-851752).

If the first big improvement in standards of construction took place before the century began, with the building of the Victorian terraces that still provide us with 15% of our homes, the next - providing proper amenities in every house - followed the first world war. If the housing market and public policy have failed, it is in the state of disrepair and need for improvement in the stock. There are still 3million families in poor housing. Home owners account for the greatest numbers in this category, but as a proportion it is privately-rented housing which is in worst condition. Failure to invest has been made worse by the failure to replace. If houses were to last an average of 100 years each, we would be replacing the poorest at a rate of 200,000 every year. In fact, we demolish only a small fraction of that figure. The much-publicised phenomenon of empty housing in parts of the north is one outcome. Holmans asks whether it was the market or public policy which led to the improvement in housing conditions over the past 100 years. The answer is a bit of both. The amazing expansion of home ownership, from less than 10% then to almost 70% now, transformed conditions for the majority and largely resulted from cheap finance from building societies, aided for the past 30 years by tax relief. But anyone who regards council housing as a failure now should be reminded about what it achieved. Over 1 million families were without a separate home in 1914. They had to wait until the inter-war period for the massive building of cottage estates at low rents that, by the second half of the century, had enabled the demolition of the worst of the Victorian slums. Post-war clearance and redevelopment completed the job. What a disaster that gross misjudgments in how this was done have led to council housing being discredited.  John Perry is policy director of the Chartered Institute of Housing. The Housing Finance Review 1999-2000 is published for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation by the CIH and Council of Mortgage Lenders (tel 01203-851752).

fields.headline: Zimbabwe visit under threat
fields.trailText: The deteriorating political and economic situation in Zimbabwe is being monitored by the management of the England team as they prepare for their visits to Bulawayo and Harare this month.
fields.body:
The deteriorating political and economic situation in Zimbabwe is being monitored by the management of the England team as they prepare for their visits to Bulawayo and Harare this month.

There is widespread civil unrest in Zimbabwe as the country prepares for April's parliamentary elections. Allegations of corruption are equally rife as the president Robert Mugabe clings on to power after 20 years in office.

In the deepening economic crisis half the workforce is unemployed and inflation is running at a record level of about 60%. There is also a shortage of foreign currency, an acute lack of diesel fuel and a growing threat of power cuts.

Phil Neale, the England team's operations manager, said yesterday: "I have been in touch with the Foreign Office and they have assured me we will be okay. But I will be talking to them again and assessing the situation prior to departure."

England are due to leave Johannesburg for Bulawayo on February 13. There they will play two one-day internationals before another two games in Harare. They are scheduled to leave Harare for London, via Johannesburg, on February 24.

It is a long and so far largely unrewarding tour but it can hardly have gone better for Nick Knight.

The Warwickshire opener's success in the triangular one-day series has strengthened his case for a return to the Test team. And Mark Butcher's Test struggles have suggested that a position is available.

"I'm hoping to get back into the Test side this summer," Knight said, "but I suppose I say that every season."

Knight has shone in two hundred partnerships with Nasser Hussain in this series, which resumes here for England against South Africa on Friday. He has made 184 runs and been out only twice in four games.

"This one-day series does not have much relevance to Test cricket," he said. "But it is still important to be doing well; it's important to be scoring runs."

Knight played the last of his 12 Tests against South Africa in 1998, when he replaced the injured Butcher. He enjoyed more success as a one-day opening bat, at least until he hit a rough patch on the Australian tour last winter, but he did not play in the World Cup last year after a slow start to the season.

While Butcher was toiling in South Africa to establish himself as Michael Atherton's partner, Knight was at home working on his technique with the Warwickshire second XI coach Neal Abberley.

He was particularly concerned to play straighter. His initial movement tended to be towards extra cover, leaving him vulnerable to the moving ball.

"I feel I've definitely made an improvement on my technique," he said. "It needs more improvement but it's going in the right direction."

The next step, he said, was to make a strong start to the county season. "Someone like me who's 30, you have to score big hundreds more regularly and say, 'Look I'm still around knocking at the door. I'm still here'."

 South Africa's Daryll Cullinan has been suspended for two games for abusing the Border fast bowler Makhaya Ntini on the final day of the Supersport Series final between Gauteng and Border on Monday. But the ban has been suspended until the end of the season.

fields.headline: Bates blasts 'meddling' ministers
fields.standfirst: Wembley row a 'smokescreen' to avoid finding £2.5bn for Olympic bid
fields.trailText: Ken Bates, the Wembley consortium chairman, accused the government yesterday of using the row over the redevelopment of the stadium as a smokescreen to avoid the real issue of mounting an expensive Olympic bid.
fields.body:
Ken Bates, the Wembley consortium chairman, accused the government yesterday of using the row over the redevelopment of the stadium as a smokescreen to avoid the real issue of mounting an expensive Olympic bid.

"They are dodging the real issue and that is that they would need to spend hard money if they are serious about an Olympic bid," said Bates, who was giving evidence to the House of Commons select committee for culture, media and sport.

"They would need around £2.5bn which would have to be committed by the government. There was a lot of talking going on but no money. In many ways the stadium was entirely irrelevant.

"We have a stunning design for the best new stadium in the world if only the politicians would get off our backs and let us build it."

UK Athletics has been forced to look at alternative sites for the venue for its 2005 world championships bid after the proposal to build a running track at the new Wembley was shelved in December by Chris Smith, the culture secretary.

But Bates, head of Wembley National Stadium Ltd, insisted the original plans for Wembley's redevelopment would have met the needs of both sports. The initial blueprint, unveiled on July 29 , incorporated a 90,000-capacity football stadium plus facilities for a raised athletics running track.

But the following day question marks appeared with the need to repay some of the £120m lottery grant because the scheme did not fulfil the criteria for a multi-sport stadium and there were doubts whether a projected 67,000-capacity athletics stadium would be sufficient to host the Olympics.

Bates said plans for the £475m redevelopment had been on course until the government intervened following concerns raised by the British Olympic Association when Tony Banks was replaced as sports minister by Kate Hoey.

"On July 29 it was the perfect solution. On July 30 it was a walking disaster. Why, I do not know," Bates said. "The uniqueness and the cleverness of the Wembley design is that it is an athletics stadium and then a football stadium - not a combined one.

"There is no reason why athletics could not be staged at Wembley. I think the BOA were being opportunist. UK Athletics have been devastated by all of this. What we have got is the Olympic tail wagging the national stadium dog."

The Football Association, of which WNSL is a subsidiary company, has agreed to repay £20m of the lottery grant to help fund the building of a purpose-built athletics stadium.

Yet Bates said: "I made it clear we had exceeded the brief by providing a stadium that was suitable for athletics and saw no reason why we should give any money back. We have no legal responsibility to pay it back. But I was told it was necessary in the best interest of football. What you are talking about here is politics, not contracts."

Smith, also appearing before the committee, said when he was shown the plans in July he had a "gut instinct" there were problems with the scheme.

Since then, Smith added, "I am completely certain we have made the right decisions. If we had gone ahead putting all our eggs in the Wembley basket, we would have been ruling out effectively the possibility of bringing the Olympics to London".

fields.headline: The farmer's in his den
fields.standfirst:
...feeling besieged and fearing the future


What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: All he had to offer were (pigs') blood, (creditors') sweat and the inevitable tears of those forced to accept the end of a rural way of life. This is not a Churchillian moment in the history of British agriculture and Tony Blair, addressing the National Farmers' Union yesterday, had little more than the obvious advice to offer to an industry where prices are falling: diversify.
fields.body:
All he had to offer were (pigs') blood, (creditors') sweat and the inevitable tears of those forced to accept the end of a rural way of life. This is not a Churchillian moment in the history of British agriculture and Tony Blair, addressing the National Farmers' Union yesterday, had little more than the obvious advice to offer to an industry where prices are falling: diversify.

Another prime minister might have let the designated fall guy (Nick Brown) deal with this clamorous interest group. Mr Blair is different. But the trouble with such high-powered interventions is that they may lift hopes. There is, however, no single rural interest. The government finds it hard even in its own backyard to coordinate the several agencies for housing, planning and countryside. Only a conspiracy theorist would note that the chair of the cabinet committee charged with ensuring coherence in rural policy is Mo Mowlam.

In pursuit of the feel good factor, Mr Blair pulled his punches yesterday. Farmers have to diversify, yes - but in practice, it is now clear, many are doomed to go to the wall. The rest will have to reinvent themselves. Instead of exploiting the fields and animals for commercial gain, some will become paid custodians of landscape, curators of an asset preserved by the taxes of people who live in towns. Those who produce cash crops must also change their identity (as Mr Blair said) and become safe, reliable providers of foodstuffs. Farmers have to be cuddly once again. Of course government should lubricate the transition - the state's fate is to help the casualties of economic change move on and out.

At least they are not alone. Just as farmers here have an interest in reform, so the accession of Poles and others to the European Union also depends on reform in Brussels (which in political terms means in Paris and Munich). But as Ben Gill and other NFU moderates see, the future of British farmers waits on consumers - who have both to force the retail giants to give producers a better deal and to vote at check-outs for the proposition that better quality food produced in sustainable and humane conditions costs more. Farming in these islands has survived crisis before. What must be different this time is the readiness and capacity of the government not just to minimise the social costs of upheaval but to rethink just what is the public's interest in the land.

webTitle: PM tells farmers to be flexible

fields.headline: PM tells farmers to be flexible
fields.standfirst:
Agriculture crisis: Blair ties any extra cash to long-term reform and warns conference that industry must respond quickly to changes

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday outlined a new contract between government and farmers in which any extra cash support would be tied to long-term reform of agriculture.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday outlined a new contract between government and farmers in which any extra cash support would be tied to long-term reform of agriculture.

He promised to work towards a "new direction" for the industry - with farmers developing new businesses alongside food production - but offered some crumbs of comfort in the short term, including hints of limited aid for pig farmers, the dropping of a new pesticides tax and new labelling rules to stop foreign goods being passed off as British simply by being processed here.

Mr Blair said: "Hard as it is now, there can be a healthy future for farming ... I know it is not easy. I also know that if you are suffering right at the moment in a day-to-day crisis where you wake up every morning and wonder whether you will survive for the rest of the day , never mind the rest of the week, never mind the long-term strategy for years, that it is very difficult to console anyone."

He also promised cuts in red tape, even though anti-BSE measures must stay in place, but "the answer is not simply subsidy and compensation". Mr Blair was given a polite reception at the National Farmers' Union conference in London, with only some muted hissing and booing as he left the hall, but outside his audience expressed deep disappointment at his speech and suggested it would give no confidence to the bank managers on which so many farmers depended.

The prime minister acknowledged "the real crisis, at least in part of farming" but said government, farmers and public must build a new partnership. "We all want British agriculture to be prosperous, forward-looking and sustainable. It must be competitive, and flexible enough to respond quickly and effectively to market changes and consumer needs."

Detailing £3.5bn annual government and EU annual support for farmers, plus aid packages worth nearly £800m, Mr Blair did not rule out further cash support. " But it is far easier to justify if it is tied to long-term change and reform."

Afterwards South Devon farmer Richard Haddock said this week alone 12 dairy farmers in the area had given up their businesses. Mr Blair is visiting the south-west this week but "a quick visit here and a quick visit there may look good for the cameras but do nothing for agriculture."

 The hardships facing Britain's farming community were yesterday brought home to the Tory party chairman, Michael Ancram, who witnessed a day-old calf being put down in front of his eyes while campaigning in the Ceredigion byelection in Wales.

John Davies, who runs a herd of 70 dairy cattle on his farm near Lampeter, said he had had to slaughter up to 25 calves during the last six months because the market was so flat.

Collapsing prices cloud dairy prospects in Peak Practice hills

From six in the morning to six at night - and all night too in the lambing season - the 72-year-old farmer is trying to eke a living from his 300 sheep and 70 dairy cattle. "Until last year, I had never had an overdraft. Now we are having to carry out lorry haulage work to supplement the money from the farm," said Mr Priestley, whose two sons and grandson help him out at Field's Farm near Castleton.

"People watch programmes like Peak Practice and see the surroundings up here. It is beautiful countryside, but as my father said : 'You can't live on the view'. The irony is that this land here would not be as beautiful were it not for the farmers."

Local farmers say they get just £3 for calves at local auctions in Bakewell. Two years ago it would have been£100. Milk sold to the dairies at 25p a litre then now brings in 16p. Bill Dilks, former Derbyshire NFU spokesman, and a delegate to this year's annual conference, said: "It now costs more to transport live animals to auction than you can sell the animal for. Most cattle are going straight into the BSE cull because you can't get any more than the £275 you get for them there."

He added: "We are seeing two farmers take their lives every week in the country because they cannot make enough money to put food on the table. There is no-one here who has been touched by the crisis and 300-odd farmers in the Peak District - or about 45% - are now at crisis point.

"People just cannot see any way out."

fields.headline: Hague's big gamble
fields.trailText: William Hague last night astonished Westminster with a snap reshuffle of his top team which pitted his heaviest hitter, Michael Portillo, against the most formidable minister in Tony Blair's government, the chancellor, Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
William Hague last night astonished Westminster with a snap reshuffle of his top team which pitted his heaviest hitter, Michael Portillo, against the most formidable minister in Tony Blair's government, the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

But the real shock for most Conservative MPs was Mr Hague's decision to sack John Redwood as shadow environment spokesman - and official scourge of John Prescott - to make way for his long-time intimate, the multi-millionaire management consultant, Archie Norman.

Hague aides denied that Mr Portillo had been consulted though they admit the two men now have "a lot of contact".

It prompted some shadow ministers to suggest last night that the man widely tipped to succeed Mr Hague one day had demanded Mr Redwood's removal. Bad blood exists between the two ambitious rightwingers since Mr Portillo flunked calls to run against John Major in 1995. Mr Redwood stood instead.

Labour's propaganda machine immediately denounced "a leader with no judgment appointing a shadow chancellor with no judgment", and described the new top team as "the most extreme right wing" ever. Mr Norman's extensive business interests also came under fire.

The musical chairs, known to only a handful of Hague aides until teatime last night, also saw the moderate John Maples dropped as shadow foreign secretary to make way for Francis Maude, the man bumped to bring Mr Portillo into the treasury shadow.

The hyperactive Mr Redwood was said to be "enormously surprised" when his leader called him into his office, praised him for being both loyal and effective in opposition - then told him it was time to make way for a new blood.

Many Tory MPs, even those who suspect he is overrated, were pleased to see Mr Portillo back on the frontbench where he has the experience, as an ex-treasury minister, to take on the formidable Mr Brown who has managed to avoid the recession predicted by Mr Maude.

Tory officials were quick to deny that the Hague-Portillo-Maude-Widdecombe team is what Labour called "hardline, rightwing, Euro-sceptic" by pointing out that Mr Redwood, a Thatcherite, had been dropped. That calculation may have sealed his fate, though he is also seen as a too-visible symbol of the discredited Tory regime.

Mr Hague had been planning to bring back Mr Portillo as soon as possible after his by-election victory in Kensington and Chelsea in November, made possible by the death of Alan Clark, whose memorial service Mr Hague attended yesterday.

It binds him into the shadow cabinet as it heads for what most analysts believe will be another crushing election defeat - one which Mr Hague may not long survive. Last night Hague aides said it was another strengthening of the party, "bringing in people of proven ability which intensifies pressure on Tony Blair's failing administration".

Labour replied with some loud raspberries. In a statement Mr Prescott said he had now seen off three shadow spokesmen since 1997 and hoped that Mr Norman "a director of Railtrack, a hypermarket supremo and a member of Lloyds will be able to bring his experience to bear - provided he can find time to turn up".

Downing Street orchestrated a chorus of jibes against Mr Portillo as a media darling with "woeful judgement. The public will not forget his record in office". Hague aides said simply: "William thought he should put one of our most powerful players against one of theirs."

Potentially more fruitful was the Liberal Democrats' concentration on Mr Norman's spectacular past as a McKinsey management guru - he hired Mr Hague - who recently sold the Asda supermarket chain (Mr Maude was on the board) to the US giant Walmart. Planning consents from Mr Prescott's department are hugely sensitive.

Last night Mr Norman, a less than charismatic Commons performer, said he would "resolve any potential conflict of interest that might arise" by bailing out of companies, notably the Knutsford venture capitalist group of which he is a major shareholder, if he has to.

With Mr Redwood promising to fight for the Eurosceptic cause on the backbenches, the Liberal Democrat deputy leader, Alan Beith, said: "Michael Portillo is now positioned to seize the Tory throne when William Hague falls."

Tory officials were quick to deny that the Hague-Portillo-Maude-Widdecombe team is what Labour called "hardline, rightwing, Euro-sceptic" by pointing out that Mr Redwood, a Thatcherite, had been dropped. That calculation may have sealed his fate, though he is also seen as a too-visible symbol of the discredited Tory regime. Mr Hague had been planning to bring back Mr Portillo as soon as possible after his by-election victory in Kensington and Chelsea in November, made possible by the death of Alan Clark, whose memorial service Mr Hague attended yesterday. It binds him into the shadow cabinet as it heads for what most analysts believe will be another crushing election defeat - one which Mr Hague may not long survive. Last night Hague aides said it was another strengthening of the party, "bringing in people of proven ability which intensifies pressure on Tony Blair's failing administration". Labour replied with some loud raspberries. In a statement Mr Prescott said he had now seen off three shadow spokesmen since 1997 and hoped that Mr Norman "a director of Railtrack, a hypermarket supremo and a member of Lloyds will be able to bring his experience to bear - provided he can find time to turn up". Downing Street orchestrated a chorus of jibes against Mr Portillo as a media darling with "woeful judgement. The public will not forget his record in office". Hague aides said simply: "William thought he should put one of our most powerful players against one of theirs." Potentially more fruitful was the Liberal Democrats' concentration on Mr Norman's spectacular past as a McKinsey management guru - he hired Mr Hague - who recently sold the Asda supermarket chain (Mr Maude was on the board) to the US giant Walmart. Planning consents from Mr Prescott's department are hugely sensitive. Last night Mr Norman, a less than charismatic Commons performer, said he would "resolve any potential conflict of interest that might arise" by bailing out of companies, notably the Knutsford venture capitalist group of which he is a major shareholder, if he has to. With Mr Redwood promising to fight for the Eurosceptic cause on the backbenches, the Liberal Democrat deputy leader, Alan Beith, said: "Michael Portillo is now positioned to seize the Tory throne when William Hague falls."

webTitle: Lions lie in wait for their hobbling hosts

fields.headline: Lions lie in wait for their hobbling hosts
fields.standfirst: The disappearing coach and assorted problems of staging a major tournament in two African countries
fields.trailText: Piers Edwards on the disappearing coach and assorted problems of staging a major tournament in two African countries.
fields.body:
Before the African Cup of Nations began, Togo's coach Gottlieb Göller advised that his team would have no concerns about moving from Ghana to Nigeria "because we will be at home in both countries". In reality, Göller found himself at home in his native Germany before his team had played their second game.

After a row with Togolese officials in an Accra hotel lobby last week, Göller disappeared; everyone knew he had taken a taxi but no one knew where he had gone. The Confederation of African Football joined in the farce by attributing his absence to malaria.

Yet another dispute over bonus payments had sparked his departure, a story all too familiar to African football and particularly to the Nigerians.

As in the last World Cup, the Super Eagles have been squabbling with the Nigerian Football Association, accusing the hierarchy of reneging on agreements. With a proliferation of foreign scouts looking for bargains in the African shop window, it should matter little that the federation offered $2,500 (£1,560) for a win, $500 less than the figure the players claim to have agreed on, but given the events of last Friday the NFA was wise to accede to the players' demands.

Even though their goalless draw with Congo kept the Super Eagles at the top of Group D after two games, supporters were incensed by the inability of a team comprising players from the likes of Juventus, Milan and Arsenal to beat a side composed mainly of players from the lower German and French leagues.

Plastic bottles rained down from the stands, the windows of the team bus were smashed and the players were locked in the dressing room for their own safety for over an hour. CAF fined the federation £1,250 for their supporters' "unruly behaviour" but it remains to be seen whether the fine or the tear gas will prove more effective.

Meanwhile, Ghana are in trouble of a different sort. Claiming that World Cup qualification is more important than winning this competition, Giuseppe Dossena's side lost 2-0 to the Ivory Coast on Monday but scraped into the quarter-finals as Group A runners-up, which means that they must leave Accra and travel north to Kumasi, where they will probably have to play the impressive South Africans on Sunday.

South Africa started badly, conceding an early goal to Gabon's Chiva Nzigou - who, at 16 years and three months, became the youngest player to play and the youngest to score at the Nations Cup finals - but Shaun Bartlett, the tournament's joint top scorer with three goals, propelled Bafana Bafana to a 3-1 win.

Top place in Ghana's quartet went to the Indomitable Lions of Cameroon, a team bolstered by the strong spine of Liverpool's Rigobert Song, West Ham's Marc-Vivien Foé and Cagliari's Patrick Mboma.

"I think we can go a long way," Foé says. "We just need to be stronger and more serious. We have a great chance to win the competition."

Even Roger Milla endorses this view, and the Lions' 3-0 destruction of the Ivory Coast will weigh heavily on the minds of their quarter-final opponents. Unless events in Group B conspire against them today, Algeria seem destined to take this poisoned chalice.

Meanwhile, Hossam Hassan's three goals have steered Egypt through Group C, a flu bug and the Sani Abacha stadium, where a strong Saharan wind has regularly clouded the arena in sand, hampering conditions for the holders and their group rivals Zambia, Senegal and Burkina Faso.

The Pharaohs will meet the runners-up from Nigeria's group, who look likely to be Morocco. Nigeria need only a draw with the Moroccans tomorrow to finish top and earn the right to stay in Lagos.

A draw would also see Morocco through to the quarter-finals, and Tunisia's coach, Francesco "the Professor" Scoglio, has calculated that a degree of collusion could prove profitable to his rivals and end his team's chances of progress.

"Let both teams play a fair game," he appealed. "The sport is for the spectators who pay money, so teams should play matches for their enjoyment and not bring the game into disrepute."

The tournament has other problems. A series of power cuts disrupted Nigeria's telecommunications systems and plunged the Morocco-Congo game into darkness.

The communication problems have hampered attempts to provide and collect information, increasing the distance between the non-neighbouring countries. Ghana's Daily Graphic, the country's leading sports paper, warns that if Africa seriously intends hosting the 2006 World Cup, the continent's tendency towards 11th-hour preparation must cease forthwith.

Then Nigerian officials announced on Sunday that ticket prices would be doubled for the Super Eagles' remaining games. Ghana's organising committee also attempted to hike prices but the resulting outcry and fans' threats to support the Black Stars' opponents soon changed its mind.

The attempt to share the tournament between two nations meets its severest test in the semi-finals, when teams and fans will have to change countries, but Basile Boli, summarising in Accra for French television, already deems the experiment a failure.

"I think this experience is the first and last time in Africa," he said. "It isn't good. The problem is the media don't know who is in charge. It is very, very difficult."

Moreover, the rampant crime that envelopes Lagos threatens the tournament's success, especially when the city hosts the final.

Asked whether he would be changing capitals on Sunday week, the former French international replied: "I don't want to go to Nigeria. I want to see the football; I don't want to lose my life."

fields.headline: Redwood 'shocked' at sacking
fields.trailText: John Redwood, the former shadow secretary of state for the environment, transport and the regions, today released a handwritten letter in which he responded to Mr Hague's decision to replace him with Archie Norman. Below is the full text:
fields.body:
John Redwood, the former shadow secretary of state for the environment, transport and the regions, today released a handwritten letter in which he responded to Mr Hague's decision to replace him with Archie Norman. Below is the full text:

"Dear William,

Thank you for your generous comments about my loyalty and effectiveness in my roles in the Shadow Cabinet.

It came as a great shock to learn that you would now like me to continue my opposition to government from the backbenches. You can be assured that I will be vigorous in exposing Labour mistakes and backing your efforts to win more support for the Conservative cause.

Yours ever, John."

fields.headline: Germany and France condemn Haider
fields.standfirst: Austrian president Thomas Klestil must decide whether to approve new far-right coalition
fields.trailText: Germany and France put their weight behind the EU threat to issue sanctions against Austria if Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom party is brought into a coalition government.
fields.body:
Germany and France put their weight behind the EU threat to issue sanctions against Austria if Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom party is brought into a coalition government.

The German foreign minister Joschka Fischer told journalists in Berlin he would support EU sanctions against the country and warned that a coalition government would be the first step to Mr Haider taking complete power in the country.

"It is clear what Mr Haider's strategy is. He wants to be chancellor," Fischer said, adding it was this threat of "hegemony" by the anti-European far-right distinguished the present Austrian situation from that of other European governments in which small extremist parties participate.

Mr Fischer said he feared that the rise of the nationalistic right could threaten the whole project of EU integration.

France called on the Austrian president, Thomas Klestil, to block any coalition between Mr Haider and the conservative People's party.

"I hope President Klestil will refuse to endorse this coalition project," Jack Lang, chairman of the national assembly's foreign affairs committee, said in a statement. "If he does not veto it, he runs the risk of isolating Austria diplomatically and of severely harming his moral authority."

Mr Haider and Wolfgang Schuessel, leader of the People's party, are seeking Mr Klestil's approval of a coalition pact which could isolate Austria internationally.

But Hungary said it would not join in a plan by European Union countries to cut political ties with Austria if the far right joined a new government.

"In the current situation Hungary does not take and does not plan to take measures similar to those of the EU's 14 member states," foreign minister Janos Martonyi told reporters.

"We share the concerns behind the statement of the 14 states and the Hungarian standpoint matches the European Commission document almost word by word," Martonyi said in comments reported by Hungarian news agency MTI.

Austrian president Thomas Klestil said in an interview published on Wednesday that he would prefer not to appoint a centre-right coalition including Joerg Haider's far-right Freedom party, but had little choice because the parties concerned had a majority in parliament.

"If I were to swear in this government, I would not do it out of personal conviction, because I fear that Austria would suffer internationally," he told NEWS magazine. But he added: "In a democracy, a parliamentary majority has to be respected."

"The Freedom Party is not a Nazi party," the head of state said. "But unfortunately the highest officials of this party continue to use a language which disqualifies them for every political office."

The interview was released as Mr Klestil was meeting Mr Haider and conservative People's party leader Wolfgang Schuessel, who agreed on a coalition pact on Tuesday night that would end 30 years of Social Democratic-led government in Austria.

webTitle: Deserving a chance, Denying a rumour and Delivering a statement

fields.headline: Deserving a chance, Denying a rumour and Delivering a statement
fields.trailText: THE BALLAD OF STAN AND EMILE
fields.body:
THE BALLAD OF STAN AND EMILE

There is a gentle stirring in Stanley Collymore's bedroom. As he's already been to the toilet twice this morning, the Fiver can only assume that he's making preparations for his imminent transfer to Leicester City. However, his agent Tony Finnigan has appeared on Radio 5 to make an unintentionally amusing speech about how much his client still wants to play for Aston Villa. So God alone knows what's going to happen when Stanley finally comes out.

"He deserves another chance to play for the club of his dreams," began Finnigan to stifled giggles. "I don't understand the difference between him and a European or Italian player. They run off home to Italy, or wherever, but when they come back they get another chance," he went on, battling against the odd guffaw. "This guy - homegrown and a great player, maverick personality but a great footballer - deserves another opportunity to play for Asto..." At which point his voice was drowned out by a torrent of derisory belly-laughs.

All this risible bombast puts a question mark over Collymore's proposed £3m move to Leicester. City chairman John Elsom felt the need to keep everybody in the Leicester area abreast of latest developments, so he made an announcement on Radio 4 - he was told this was the best way to reach middle England. "We are possibly still interested but it's not the most important thing in the land," he informed Filbert Street fans in his best laid-back voice.

All very cool. However, if, as some people are suggesting, a Foxy defeat in tonight's Worthington Cup tie sees Emile Heskey immediately leave for Liverpool, the Fiver will be extremely impressed if Elsom manages to keep up his Peter Ridsdale act.

HOW TO IMPRESS YOUR BOSS WITH FOOTBALL UNLIMITED

Stay up to date with the very latest football news by keeping our desktop headlines window visibly open on your workstation all day. Go to http://www.footballunlimited.co.uk and a rise is yours for the taking!

BECKHAM NOT GOING TO ARSENAL FOR SQUILLIONS OF QUIDS SHOCK

If only the Fiver wasn't so gullible. Then it wouldn't have staked all its money (and the contents of Granny Fiver's Socialist Savings Account) on David Beckham going to Arsenal for £30m, or was it £40m, at the end of the season at odds of 97-1 on. But we did, and now we've been left with egg on our face. And no way of paying the milkman come Saturday.

Reports of David's departure, which surfaced on wobbling Danny Kelly's Football365 and then (a whole 48 hours later) on the back page of the Daily Mail, were substantiated by nothing more than the old chestnut about Posh wanting Dave to move South and Dave being under the thumb and that. Not a mention was made of why Arsenal would want to spend a world record fee on someone who wouldn't fit into their style of play. But still, it got everybody talking.

Talking so much, in fact, that Arsene Wenger himself had to come out today and insist: "We have not made a bid for David Beckham and we do not plan to make a bid for him." He then denied that the Arsenal board were set to sell out to a Martian consortium and that Stephen Hughes was any cop - just for good measure. Meanwhile in not-glamorous-enough-for-Dave Manchester, United club secretary Ken Ramsden exclusively revealed: "We don't feel the story is worth commenting on."

* Wobbly Danny's stock-exchange quoted 365 Corp is, according to analysts, "a convergence-focused content creator with a proven track record." Internet bubble, what internet bubble?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"By changing the size of the pitch, obviously you think does light get in? Does wind get in? All the things that grass needs to grow? We just cut it and think it should grow! But it needs some help sometimes." - Ageing hippy Kelvin Koogan is asked about the pitch at Old Trafford and gets himself into a right state.

FOREIGNERS OUT! WELL, SOME OF THEM ANYWAY

For most Britons the word quota summons up images of a crazed Brussels bureaucrat trying to limit the amount of British fish in Albania, or banning the good old fry up, or something. But today the word got a different spin, when the FA announced plans to limit the number of foreigners allowed into the British game.

"The FA, the Premier League and the Football League believe a quota system could be in the best interests of the game," said the FA in a statement delivered to a Department of Education and Employment inquiry into work permits. "Top-quality overseas players benefit our game. The concern lies in the value of overseas players who fail to make regular first team appearances." At this point, Mikkel Beck left the room. "With a fixed quota system, clubs would not seek to recruit players who are anything other than of the highest quality."

While not pointing the finger at anyone, especially Chelsea, PFA chief Gordon Taylor suggested today that "a situation where a Premiership team had a side which didn't include one player from the UK sends out the wrong signals." Surprisingly enough, Gianluca Vialli doesn't quite agree. "If you want to protect the English young players then [a quota] might be the right thing to do," said Luca after hearing the news. "But if we want to compete when we play in Europe, there's no way we can do that. The other teams would simply be too good for us." Gabriele Ambrosetti was unavailable for comment.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal have been alerted after Ronald De Boer was given a month off "to find himself" by Barcelona boss Louis Van Gaal.

According to his agent, Jorge Cadete has agreed to join Bradford on loan until the end of the season.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Swindon have been placed in administration. The club are reported to be losing £25,000 a week and have failed to meet a deadline set by creditors. Chairman Cliff Puffett explained he had no choice but to call in administrators "if League football was to remain at the County Ground."

Uefa have confirmed that the winners of the Worthington Cup will qualify for next season's Uefa Cup.

Tottenham have released Italian full-back Paolo Tramezzani, paying up his contract which had more than a year to run.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm)

Honduras. Albania. Chad. Three things which make this programme nod and say "yes".

Scottish Football Live (7pm, 12.45am)

Not for much longer if Rangers (who visit Dundee United) keep winning the title.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.45pm, 3.30am SS2)

Our efforts to find a corporate sponsor for McCaff continue. Black & Decker, who know all there is to know about noisy tools, weren't interested.

Sky Sports 2: Worthington Cup Football Live (7pm, 1.45am SS1)

Aston Villa, an average Premiership side expected to play like an average Premiership side, travel to Leicester, an average Premiership side suddenly expected to play like Real Madrid circa 1960.

Sky Sports 3: Premiership Classics (10pm)

Starring a pre-zany Alan Shearer.

British Eurosport: Football (6pm)

British and European in a kind of African way.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

"If they didn't go to Brazil they wouldn't have a game in hand and I wouldn't be sitting on a freezing gantry in Sheffield. I'm going to blow a gasket in a minute, me!"

Meanwhile in not-glamorous-enough-for-Dave Manchester, United club secretary Ken Ramsden exclusively revealed: "We don't feel the story is worth commenting on." * Wobbly Danny's stock-exchange quoted 365 Corp is, according to analysts, "a convergence-focused content creator with a proven track record." Internet bubble, what internet bubble? QUOTE OF THE DAY "By changing the size of the pitch, obviously you think does light get in? Does wind get in? All the things that grass needs to grow? We just cut it and think it should grow! But it needs some help sometimes." - Ageing hippy Kelvin Koogan is asked about the pitch at Old Trafford and gets himself into a right state. FOREIGNERS OUT! "The FA, the Premier League and the Football League believe a quota system could be in the best interests of the game," said the FA in a statement delivered to a Department of Education and Employment inquiry into work permits. "With a fixed quota system, clubs would not seek to recruit players who are anything other than of the highest quality." According to his agent, Jorge Cadete has agreed to join Bradford on loan until the end of the season. NEWS IN BRIEF Swindon have been placed in administration. The club are reported to be losing £25,000 a week and have failed to meet a deadline set by creditors. Chairman Cliff Puffett explained he had no choice but to call in administrators "if League football was to remain at the County Ground." Uefa have confirmed that the winners of the Worthington Cup will qualify for next season's Uefa Cup. Tottenham have released Italian full-back Paolo Tramezzani, paying up his contract which had more than a year to run. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (6.30pm) Honduras. Albania. Chad. Three things which make this programme nod and say "yes". Scottish Football Live (7pm, 12.45am) Not for much longer if Rangers (who visit Dundee United) keep winning the title. You're On Sky Sports! (10.45pm, 3.30am SS2) Our efforts to find a corporate sponsor for McCaff continue. Black & Decker, who know all there is to know about noisy tools, weren't interested. Sky Sports 3: Premiership Classics (10pm) Starring a pre-zany Alan Shearer. British Eurosport: Football (6pm) British and European in a kind of African way. Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm) "If they didn't go to Brazil they wouldn't have a game in hand and I wouldn't be sitting on a freezing gantry in Sheffield. I'm going to blow a gasket in a minute, me!"

webTitle: Lawyer's record payout after race bias at CPS

fields.headline: Lawyer's record payout after race bias at CPS
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A senior lawyer who suffered race discrimination and victimisation by the crown prosecution service has been awarded a record £30,000 for injury to her feelings after an employment tribunal found that the CPS wanted to "rub her face in the dirt".
fields.body:
A senior lawyer who suffered race discrimination and victimisation by the crown prosecution service has been awarded a record £30,000 for injury to her feelings after an employment tribunal found that the CPS wanted to "rub her face in the dirt".

The award to Maria Bamieh includes aggravated damages which the tribunal puts at between £10,000 and £15,000 - an unusually high figure to mark its strong disapproval of the service's conduct, which fell below the standard "we would have expected of a corner shop".

With interest of nearly £4,500 and compensation of £3,862 for loss of opportunity of promotion, Ms Bamieh's total award of more than £38,000 is a particularly large one for someone who has remained in her job.

A senior crown prosecutor who earns £23,000 a year from her part-time job, she won two claims of discrimination and victimisation after failing to get promotion.

The Bedford tribunal was scathing about the way the CPS responded to her grievances. She was offered £110,000 compensation if she agreed to leave the service, which she turned down because she was determined to keep her job. "Ms Bamieh alleged that the CPS wished to 'rub her face in the dirt'. We agree. We find the conduct of the respondents to have amounted to a most serious form of aggravation."

webTitle: Race team joins hanging inquiry into Telford deaths

fields.headline: Race team joins hanging inquiry into Telford deaths
fields.trailText: The McGowan family last night won a promise from West Mercia police that the deaths by hanging of two black men in Telford would be reinvestigated.
fields.body:
The McGowan family last night won a promise from West Mercia police that the deaths by hanging of two black men in Telford would be reinvestigated.

The force agreed to start afresh in determining how Harold McGowan and his nephew Jason died within six months of each other. Their family suspects the pair might have been "lynched" by racists and accused detectives of being too quick in assuming suicide.

The development came after five hours of talks with the chief constable, Peter Hampson, senior detectives, family members and their lawyers, in which West Mercia also agreed to investigate allegations that the two were subjected to racial harassment.

West Mercia also agreed to call in Scotland Yard's race and violent crimes task force, CO24, for help. The unit is headed by deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, a former head of the anti-terrorist squad.

Clifton McGowan, brother of Harold, welcomed the agreement and said: "It confirms what we were saying, that we felt we weren't listened to and taken seriously. Mistakes were made; they realise this, and want to make sure that these are not repeated."

In a statement supported by police, the McGowans' solicitor, Errol Robinson, said: "We have made a number of agree ments with West Mercia police service in relation to full disclosure of all information relevant to the deaths of Errol and Jason.

"The family's earnest hope is that a new investigation will finally uncover the truth behind the deaths of the family members. We therefore await the findings of both the review of the previous investigation and any evidence uncovered by the new investigation.

"We welcome West Mercia's agreement to seek the support and assistance of the Metropolitan police race and violent crimes task force."

Harold McGowan, 34, was found hanging from a five foot high door knob in a friend's house in July. His family was told he was on a far-right death list after clashing with white youths while working as a doorman.

Jason McGowan, 20, was found hanging from five-foot high railings by a roadside on New Year's Day.

The family said neither had any reason to commit suicide, and that Jason had been investigating his uncle's death when he himself died.

Yesterday, however, Jason's father, Robert King, said he continued to believe his son had taken his life, and dismissed as "lies and rumours" claims he had been murdered by a racist lynch mob.

Jason's mother, Doreen, replied by saying that Mr King, whom she said she had been separated from for almost 15 years, was distant from their son: "His son got married last summer and he was not even invited to the wedding."

Jason's uncle, Leroy McGowan, said he believed Mr King had seen his son only twice in the six months before his death, and added that Jason had changed his surname by deedpoll from King to McGowan.

Mr King, 42, a doorman at the pub in Telford where Harold McGowan also worked as a bouncer, said the two deaths had been "manipulated" to spread rumours that a racist death squad was operating in the Shropshire town.

He said: "This is my son, let him rest in peace, please give him some dignity. My son was much-loved and I know will be sorely missed by all, but why leave his memories scarred by this hype?

"There is very little evidence to support this racist lynch mob theory - some people believe that if they shout rumours loud enough and often enough to the media, then eventually it will be believed. There is no lynch mob and never has been. There are just local lads with a racial problem.

"If anyone knows differently, then come forward and contact the police with evidence.

"I would have been one of the first to know if Jason had experienced any racial abuse. I do believe in my own heart that my son committed suicide for whatever reason - I will never know the answer."

webTitle: Father of hanged Telford man dismisses race murder claims

fields.headline: Father of hanged Telford man dismisses race murder claims
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The father of Jason McGowan yesterday dismissed claims that a racist lynch mob had killed his son.
fields.body:
The father of Jason McGowan yesterday dismissed claims that a racist lynch mob had killed his son.

Robert King said he believed that his son, found hanging from railings in Telford on New Year's Day, had committed suicide.

Mr King branded as "lies and rumours" claims that Jason, 20, had been killed.

Jason's death came six months after his uncle, Harold "Errol" McGowan, was found hanging in a house in Telford. His family claimed he had been subjected to a racist hate campaign.

The McGowans said Jason had been investigating his uncle's death and threats had been received warning the family to stop its inquiries.

Yesterday Mr King, a doorman at the Charlton Arms pub in Telford where Harold McGowan had also worked as a bouncer, said the two deaths had been "manipulated" to spread rumours that a racist death squad was operating in the Shropshire town.

Mr King, 42, said: "I am his father, I have watched this terrible tragedy unfold from a personal loss of a young much-loved son [and] be manipulated by the press and certain family members into a 'racist lynch mob', connecting it to Errol.

"But why? I ask myself when I hear all these lies and rumours. I understand why we all want answers. I am left here on the sidelines asking questions to put together the pieces left by this personal tragedy.

"Why is this being linked to the death of his uncle? Where is the evidence? Where have the facts gone?"

Mr King has been separated from Doreen McGowan, his former common-law wife and Jason's mother, for almost 15 years, but had developed a relationship with his son in the past six years.

West Mercia police have denied the McGowan's family claims that they had bungled the investigation into the two deaths and had been too quick to assume Harold McGowan, 34, had committed suicide.

Mr King said: "I have had to watch as this media hype has unfolded from a very private loss to a very public national event.

"Why? This is my son, let him rest in peace, please give him some dignity.

"There is very little evidence to support this racist lynch mob theory - some people believe that if they shout rumours loud enough and often enough to the media, then eventually it will be believed.

"There is no lynch mob and never has been. There are just local lads with a racial problem. If anyone knows differently, then come forward and contact the police with evidence.

"I would have been one of the first to know if Jason had experienced any racial abuse. I do believe in my own heart that my son committed suicide for whatever reason, I will never know the answer."

Members of the families of the two black men found hanged yesterday met Peter Hampson, West Mercia's chief constable, and senior investigating officers.

The force said the meeting had been arranged to update the family on the investigation.

fields.headline: Shock exchange
fields.standfirst:
Trading on the stock market has never been so easy - but the rise in day traders and online brokers could have unforeseen consequences

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Stock markets: once it was top hats, blue buttons and Black Mondays; Eton meets the East End. Now it is denims, "day" traders and dotcoms. Technology is changing how dealing is conducted. A once cosy world faces a revolution. Traditional players are having to fight nimbler rivals.
fields.body:
Stock markets: once it was top hats, blue buttons and Black Mondays; Eton meets the East End. Now it is denims, "day" traders and dotcoms. Technology is changing how dealing is conducted. A once cosy world faces a revolution. Traditional players are having to fight nimbler rivals.

Even relative newcomers in the derivatives markets - not so long ago at the cutting edge of financial market development - are having to bow to change. On London's International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (LIFFE) traders have hung up their garishly striped jackets and quit the manic, noisy pits of the old trading floor in the City of London for quieter quarters in places such as Islington.

The changes are affecting the big financial institutions which trade billions of pounds worth of shares a year and small investors alike. One casualty could be British government revenue in the shape of stamp duty. At 0.5% it is higher in the United Kingdom than in other European financial centres. In the days of defined national markets the relative higher cost of doing business in London was not a crucial factor. But it could become one in the new technology driven environment. Hence this week's initiative from the Stock Exchange to get rid of the tax, with the argument that the government would benefit from higher yields from capital gains tax.

Traditionally stock exchanges allowed companies to offer investors their shares. They listed the standards companies had to meet to be granted a quotation. They supervised, making sure everyone played by the rules when shares were traded. Market professionals were intermediaries and in London one group, market makers, put up their own capital to facilitate trading.

Technology has changed all that. Trading floors, physical embodiment of the market, have been replaced by networks of computers; investors sit in offices using banks of screens both as a source of information and a mechanism for dealing. Walking into a dealing room now is like entering Dixons and seeing all the television screens showing Teletext.

That did not matter as long as the established stock exchanges still controlled the new electronic trading networks. But alternatives aplenty are springing up, rivals such as London's Tradepoint and Easdaq, a Brussels-based exchange aiming to replicate the success of Nasdaq in the United States, listing such companies as Microsoft and Dell.

Groups of big investors, investment banks and fund managers are finding new ways to trade. They are backing alternative trading "platforms" where at set times every day an investor who want to unload a block of shares in one company can explore, electronically and anonymously, whether there is another institution prepared to buy.

A combination of globalisation, technology and the advent of the euro have made institutions hungry to trade across borders and jurisdictions. City-based investors, including American and Japanese houses for which the Square Mile is their European base, want to trade in the shares of (say) German or French companies as easily as they can in British ones. The established European exchanges spotted the danger and for the past 18 months have been planning an eight-member alliance.

Progress has been slow. Old rivalries die hard. Ownership of the exchanges has proved a problem, too. The London Stock Exchange is demutualising - switching from being owned by its members to a corporate structure. Frankfurt is pondering changes to allow foreign members a greater say in what is happening. The French bourse has already demutualised and is now planning to list itself. The threat of invasion by Nasdaq (which plans to launch its own European trading scheme later this year) is another spur. Frankfurt has sought, successfully, to be competitive in attracting hi-tech companies to its Neuer Markt. Paris has just listed its first pure dot com company. London has its techMark.

For small investors technology has arrived in the form of the internet. Even those who would never be described as seriously rich are being wooed. Share dealing via the internet is booming. The number of internet share deals hit 371,000 in the last quarter of 1999 - more than double the previous quarter's figure. The Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers calculates there are now more than 100,000 on-line accounts; it expects the internet to account for almost one in five of all execution-only trades by the end of March.

The American phenomenon of the "day trader" is arriving here. While most small investors are content to either squirrel away a modest portfolio as a form of saving and others seek to dip in and out of the market from time to time, day traders look to make money through dealing heavily and rapidly every day. In the UK Deal4free.com provides a service which allows those with the money and the nerve to trade share price movements, rather than the shares themselves.

As use of the internet grows more effort will be made to promote services to attract yet more retail investors. The number of UK brokers offering online dealing trebled in the past year.

Big investors have already discovered competition gives the customer more clout. Small investors may get the same message.

 Mark Milner is the Guardian's deputy financial editor
