webTitle: Blair peace plea as talks continue

fields.headline: Blair peace plea as talks continue
fields.trailText: The government was today making a last-ditch attempt to save the peace process in Northern Ireland  as it emerged that General John de   Chastelain would meet the IRA once   again over the decommissioning issue.
fields.body:
The government was today making a last-ditch attempt to save the peace process in Northern Ireland as it emerged that General John de Chastelain would meet the IRA once again over the decommissioning issue.

General de Chastelain, whose report on the failure of the IRA to begin decommissioning their weapons triggered the current crisis, is likely to hold fresh talks with the IRA over the coming days.

In the Commons, Tony Blair told MPs decommissioning was a critical part of the Good Friday Agreement. "There has to be progress on this issue. At the present time, bluntly, there is insufficient progress for General de Chastelain to make the report that he has to make."

He appeared to be urging Sinn Fein to make a move towards decommissioning, saying: "This is, on this issue, the moment when we have to know where we stand."

The prime minister admitted: "There is no doubt at all there is a serious problem and if there is not substantial progress we have a serious difficulty on our hands." But he was still hopeful of persuading parties to make progress.

Responding to a Tory shout that the government had done nothing to find peace in Ulster, Mr Blair said: "For all the difficulties in Northern Ireland today we have the best chance of peace we have had for generations.

"There is investment pouring in, there is peace in place that may not be perfect but it is a million miles better than what was there before.

"I simply say to you, to dismiss everything that has happened in Northern Ireland is wrong and we are not putting unfair pressure on people, we are trying to make sure that we find a way through that allows peace and stability for the future, because at the heart of this deal in the Good Friday agreement is a good deal for both sides Let no one doubt how far we have come and therefore how important it is to try and save it."

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson was holding meetings in Belfast, while Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams was talking to Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister.

Mr Ahern acknowledged that if the De Chastelain report shows no progress, "we are in major difficulties". He had no doubt that First Minister David Trimble would resign if progress was not made on disarmament.

"We have to keep on trying. It is disappointing, quite frankly, that we have lost so much time," he said.

United States president Bill Clinton is also involved in the frenetic shuttle diplomacy aimed at rescuing the eight-week-old Stormont administration and preventing a return to direct rule from London. He urged all sides to find agreement on the issue, saying the Good Friday agreement "is working and it would be a tragedy if it was derailed".

Mr Adams insisted yesterday he made no promises over decommissioning during last year's Mitchell review of the Good Friday agreement.

But Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble is adamant that Sinn Fein defaulted on its obligations on arms, and that suspension of the executive and a review were "regrettable but inevitable".

webTitle: Haider: son of Nazis who defies labels

fields.headline: Haider: son of Nazis who defies labels
fields.standfirst:
Austria's political star changes views as often as his suits
The issue explained: the far-right in Austria
fields.trailText: From pariah to prince in just a few months, Jörg Haider has leapt on to the international stage. But attempts to label the politician who changes his opinions as regularly as his designer suits almost always fail.
fields.body:
From pariah to prince in just a few months, Jörg Haider has leapt on to the international stage. But attempts to label the politician who changes his opinions as regularly as his designer suits almost always fail.

"I'd call him a neo-fascist because of the authoritarian structure of his party and the political goals he has expressed," said Armin Thurnher, editor of the left-liberal Austrian weekly Falter. "But any attempt to define him is useless because he will prove to you that he's not that at all."

In a recent biography, Christa Zoechling said that he is "hard to pin down because at some point every popular opinion finds a home with him. He likes to see himself as a victim of circumstance. At one time or another he said that he feels he has been treated like a Kurd, a Palestinian, or even a Jew."

Mr Haider was born in Bad Goisern, upper Austria, on January 26 1950 to a shoemaker father and a mother who was a teacher. They joined the Nazi party in 1929, when it was illegal, nine years before Hitler annexed Austria.

After the war the couple returned to Bad Goisern to find their home in ruins. As a former Nazi, Dorothea was forbidden to teach and they were officially ostracised. The couple claimed to know nothing about the concentration camps. "We were stamped as criminals just because we did our duty," his mother once said. "We had no idea of concentration camps."

While other Nazi party members were sucked into the Socialist party or disappeared underground, people like Mr Haider's parents who got caught felt that they had been unjustly persecuted. "That sense of injustice defines where Haider is coming from," said Mr Thurnher. It also explains his eagerness to play the role of Robin Hood.

He spent much of his childhood fighting for recognition, as if making up for his parents' fall from grace.

Although other pupils made fun of his plumpness at school, he did better at sport than fitter counterparts and, without really trying, was almost always top of the class, according to teachers. He joined a far-right sports organisation, the Austrian Sports Union, and a fraternity of male uniformed students where he learned to fence. Within that group, led by old Nazi members who supervised beer-drinking and outdoor activities, he formed many of his ideas.

The young Haider became a proficient fencer. According to a friend, Thomas Huemer, he used to practise on a straw doll to which was pinned the name of the Nazi-hunter Simon Wiesenthal.

The fraternity was an effective way for Jörg to regain the respectability that his parents had before the war. "Jörg had a burning ambition to break out of his restrictive social milieu," a school friend said. "He was keen to get rid of the 'poor people' smell that clung to us."

His political life began at 16 when he won a debating contest with the theme: "Are we Austrians Germans?" After holding various posts in the Freedom Party, a breakaway from the Union of Independents (VdU) where former Nazis found a home after the war, Mr Haider moved to the province of Carinthia to become party secretary in 1976. In 1979 he became an MP.

The defining moment came in 1986 when he overthrew the party's liberal wing in a leadership battle. In 1989 he became governor of Carinthia.

In October 1990 he said he "appreciated" the efforts of Waffen SS officers in "a struggle for freedom and democracy in Europe". A year later, he was ousted as Carinthian governor for saying: "During the Third Reich they had a proper employment policy."

In 1995 he told a meeting of SS officers that he was glad "there are still decent people in this world, people of character who have the courage of their convictions". That year he referred to concentration camps as "penal camps".

The following years he spent working on softening his image, and in 1999 he regained his post as Carinthia governor.

After his party won more than 27% of the vote in October's election he apologised for his pro-Nazi remarks, and declared that he aimed to become chancellor by 2003.

Mr Haider is "greedy for prestige, power-hungry and lonely," said Mr Huemer. "He doesn't sense that the avalanche he has triggered will end up destroying him."

fields.headline: Austria defies isolation threats
fields.standfirst:
EU members fail to halt coalition talks with far right
The issue explained: the far-right in Austria
Haider profiled
fields.trailText: Government negotiations with Austria's far-right Freedom party were continuing in Vienna last night in the face of controversial threats by all other European Union governments to isolate the Alpine country.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and  Kate Connolly in Vienna
fields.body:
Government negotiations with Austria's far-right Freedom party were continuing in Vienna last night in the face of controversial threats by all other European Union governments to isolate the Alpine country.

With the US joining EU allies in warning Austria not to form a coalition with Jörg Haider and his colleagues, Wolfgang Schüssel, the leader of the conservative People's party, showed no sign of backing down.

Sources close to the Austrian president, Thomas Klestil, hinted that an all-party government could be formed, thus minimising the role of the Freedom party, though with 52 seats in the 183-seat parliament, it could not be totally excluded.

Austrians were shocked and angered by Monday's unprecedented collective threat from 14 EU capitals to cut off bilateral contacts with Vienna, and there were warnings of a backlash against the EU. But as the political horse-trading drew to a close, the barrage continued across Europe .

France's prime minister, Lionel Jospin, yesterday described the Freedom party as a "xenophobic, far-right" group.

Gerhard Schröder, the German chancellor, insisted: "If we make it clear that we want nothing to do with politicians like Herr Haider, that is not interfering in another country's affairs.

"It is an expression that we stand for a Europe based on values and that Herr Haider has constantly violated those values."

Italy's prime minister, Massimo D'Alema, said: "Europe has certain criteria and values that unite it."

In the US, a Washington spokesman said: "The entry of the Freedom party in the Austrian government would affect our bilateral relationship."

In Brussels, however, the European commission president, Romano Prodi, said that although the commission shared the "concerns" of member states, Austria's working relations with the EU were not affected "at this stage".

There was no disguising the embarrassment about the fact that Mr Prodi had not been consulted when the diplomatic bombshell was dropped.

Legally, action has only been taken by individual states, though confusion has arisen over the fact that the warning was issued by Portugal, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency.

Mr Schüssel, who is acting foreign minister, said he took international worries seriously, but argued that the best way to counter them was to present a "reasonable government programme".

Mr Haider is notorious for remarks playing down the crimes of the Nazis, comments for which he has apologised several times. The Freedom party has campaigned against "overpopulation by foreigners" and against EU expansion, although its leader says now he supports the principle of enlargement.

The Freedom party and the People's party each have 52 seats in the 183-seat parliament after October's inconclusive general election.

The caretaker chancellor, Viktor Klima, who heads the Social Democrats, Austria's largest party with 65 seats, tried in vain to put together a grand coalition with Mr Schüssel's conservatives.

webTitle: A rich state riddled with hatreds

fields.headline: A rich state riddled with hatreds
fields.standfirst:
Jorg Haider's Freedom party holds the balance of power in Austria

The issue explained: the far-right in Austria
Haider profiled
fields.trailText: For the first time since the 30s a party of the far right is on the brink of power in the heart of Europe. By the end of this week Jorg Haider's Freedom party is likely to have joined the conservative People's party in forming a government in Austria.
fields.body:
For the first time since the 30s a party of the far right is on the brink of power in the heart of Europe. By the end of this week Jorg Haider's Freedom party is likely to have joined the conservative People's party in forming a government in Austria.

If the coalition goes ahead it will have an impact that goes far beyond central Europe. A far-right coalition in Austria will put in question the belief that liberal values are safe in Europe. Since the second world war conventional wisdom has held that prosperity and respect for human rights go hand in hand. Haider's surging popularity has overturned that comforting belief.

Austria is one of Europe's richest countries: it has very low rates of unemployment and a flourishing hi-tech economy. It faces nothing that remotely resembles an economic crisis. Yet, according to one recent poll, a third of Austria's voters intend to vote for Haider's party in coming elections.

Has Austria become once again a testing ground for the politics of xenophobia and hatred of minorities? At the start of the 20th century Vienna was dominated by Karl Lueger, its charismatic mayor, who combined a bold experiment in municipal socialism with virulent anti-semitism. A century later, are we witnessing a trial run for a new kind of fascism?

It could be argued that the alarm felt throughout the international community at the prospect of a government containing Haider's Freedom party is exaggerated. In part, Haider's popularity can be accounted for by the unravelling of the post-war political settlement in Europe that has destroyed the Italian Christian Democrats and which underlies some of the troubles of former Chancellor Kohl. The Freedom party is benefiting from the volatile political environment that has developed over the past decade. The end of the cold war has inaugurated a period of crumbling parties, fickle electorates and, in some countries, renascent extremism.

The Freedom party is doing all it can to persuade the world that its policies have nothing in common with the Nazi era. During the past week or so, Haider - who notoriously praised Hitler's employment policies - has gone to ground in the province of Carinthia. In the event of his party entering government there are no plans for him to take a seat in the Austrian cabinet: he will remain governor of Carinthia, though it is rumoured that his sister may be offered a post. Officially, Haider is not even taking part in coalition negotiations. Everything is being done to represent the party as being of the moderate right and its leader as just another populist politician. There has been no talk - in public - of "rootless cosmopolitans".

Not yet. But there are far too many ominous echoes in the rise of Haider for the concerns that are being expressed to be in any way overblown. In its strategy of demonising outsiders, the Freedom party is no different from parties of the hard right in other European countries. In France, Denmark, Switzerland and Italy, far-right parties have achieved a high degree of political visibility by using much the same rhetoric. But none has the pivotal importance of Haider's Freedom party.

A government in which Haider held the balance of power could put at risk the progress that has been achieved in the most successful of the post communist states. Austria's neighbours have based all their policies on the expectation that they will soon be fully accepted into the European fold. Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic look to EU membership as an essential step in becoming normal European countries like any other. With a far-right coalition in power in Austria the political consensus on speedy admission of these countries can no longer be taken for granted. A government in which Haider and his party have a powerful voice could well seek to block EU enlargement to the east.

Part of being a full member of the EU is having an open labour market with other EU countries. It is hard to see the Freedom party - which has come so close to power by exploiting hostility to foreigners - accepting open borders with Austria's poorer neighbours.

There can be few parts of the world where the belief that history has ended is more ludicrous, or more pernicious, than it is in central Europe. Yet Europe's leaders have been lulled into complacency by the faith that growing wealth is enough to make Europe safe for liberal values. Haider's rise shows that this is an illusion. Human rights do not come in a package deal along with rising incomes, low unemployment and mobile phones. Despite its growing prosperity, Europe's capacity for bigotry, hatred and contempt for minorities is far from being exhausted.

The European Union was founded in order to ensure that liberal values are secure. What hope is there for it if it cannot protect human rights?

 John Gray is professor of European thought at the LSE

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Actress Catherine Zeta Jones has suffered terrible morning sickness - as lots of pregnant women do. Can anything be done to relieve it?
fields.trailText: The Question: Actress Catherine Zeta Jones has suffered terrible morning sickness - as lots of pregnant women do. Can anything be done to relieve it?
fields.body:
Zita West
Midwife and acupuncturist

Acupuncture has been shown in trials to help with all kinds of nausea, including pregnancy sickness. The relevant point is called pericardium 6, or P6, and it's three fingers' breadth in from the wrist crease, between the two tendons you have there. I use a needle at that point, but you can feel better just by putting pressure on it with the thumb of your other hand, or by wearing a wristband. Taking extra vitamin B6 and zinc can help, and a lot of women say eating grapefruit is good as well. It's well worth trying these things - pregnancy sickness can be really debilitating.
Verdict: Yes

Melanie Every
Royal College of Midwives

It's important not to let your stomach get really empty. It's called "morning sickness" because that's when many women get it worst, because their stomach is empty. But it's common at the end of the day, too, if women haven't eaten a lot. It's best to eat little and often, and to avoid sickly or fatty foods. We don't fully understand morning sickness, but it's almost certainly to do with increasing hormone levels. That's why women having twins often get it badly. Their hormone levels are higher. The good news is that it usually disappears after four months, and sometimes sooner.
Verdict: Yes

Stuart Korth
Osteopath who treats pregnant women

Osteopathy can help some women, but not all. There are a lot of mysteries to morning sickness, and I wouldn't say we've got the answer - though we probably have part of the jigsaw. I'd look at a woman's whole body system, and I'd be looking at the changes in her body shape. This can contribute to morning sickness where it's caused by mechanical factors, such as the irritation of nerves. In these case, skilful manipulation by an osteopath to allow the accommodation of the pregnancy within the body can be helpful, and some women will report feeling better as a result.
Verdict: In some cases

Sylvia Baddeley
Midwife and reflexologist

Many women report that pregnancy nausea responds to reflexology - it relaxes the digestive tract, which alleviates symptoms. There is research being done, but at the moment the proof is mostly anecdotal. Another thing I advise is ginger, which you can drink as tea or use in cooking - it seems to help a lot of people. But it's important that women go to their doctor or midwife if they've got really bad morning sickness, because a small percentage can become seriously dehydrated. If you are losing weight and you really can't keep anything down, seek medical help at once.
Verdict: In some cases

Dr Deborah McManners
Naturopath and homeopath who runs women's clinic

Homeopathic remedies can be very useful. What you give depends on the sort of nausea the woman has. If she's actually throwing up nux vomica can help, if she's just feeling sick ipecac might be good. I'd also suggest relaxation as a technique for dealing with it. Early pregnancy can be very stressful, and feeling stressed doesn't help at all when you're feeling nauseous. Look at how you live and try to find ways of reducing the stress - there might be ways of reducing the pressure at work, or of getting your other children looked after occasionally to give you a break.
Verdict: Yes

Verdict: Yes Melanie Every Royal College of Midwives It's important not to let your stomach get really empty. It's called "morning sickness" because that's when many women get it worst, because their stomach is empty. But it's common at the end of the day, too, if women haven't eaten a lot. It's best to eat little and often, and to avoid sickly or fatty foods. We don't fully understand morning sickness, but it's almost certainly to do with increasing hormone levels. That's why women having twins often get it badly. Their hormone levels are higher. The good news is that it usually disappears after four months, and sometimes sooner. Verdict: Yes Stuart Korth Osteopath who treats pregnant women Osteopathy can help some women, but not all. There are a lot of mysteries to morning sickness, and I wouldn't say we've got the answer - though we probably have part of the jigsaw. I'd look at a woman's whole body system, and I'd be looking at the changes in her body shape. This can contribute to morning sickness where it's caused by mechanical factors, such as the irritation of nerves. In these case, skilful manipulation by an osteopath to allow the accommodation of the pregnancy within the body can be helpful, and some women will report feeling better as a result. Verdict: In some cases Sylvia Baddeley Midwife and reflexologist Many women report that pregnancy nausea responds to reflexology - it relaxes the digestive tract, which alleviates symptoms. There is research being done, but at the moment the proof is mostly anecdotal. Another thing I advise is ginger, which you can drink as tea or use in cooking - it seems to help a lot of people. But it's important that women go to their doctor or midwife if they've got really bad morning sickness, because a small percentage can become seriously dehydrated. If you are losing weight and you really can't keep anything down, seek medical help at once. If she's actually throwing up nux vomica can help, if she's just feeling sick ipecac might be good. I'd also suggest relaxation as a technique for dealing with it. Early pregnancy can be very stressful, and feeling stressed doesn't help at all when you're feeling nauseous. Look at how you live and try to find ways of reducing the stress - there might be ways of reducing the pressure at work, or of getting your other children looked after occasionally to give you a break. Verdict: Yes

webTitle: On your own head be it

fields.headline: On your own head be it
fields.standfirst: Catching nits from your kids is a mortifying experience. But keeping it under your hat will only make the problem worse, says  Helen Hague:  The bug stops here
fields.trailText: There's nothing quite like arriving for a cut, blow-dry and restorative scalp massage for lifting the spirits. Unless, of course, you're infested and the hairdresser breaks the news.
fields.body:
There's nothing quite like arriving for a cut, blow-dry and restorative scalp massage for lifting the spirits. Unless, of course, you're infested and the hairdresser breaks the news.

I know. I've been there. I hadn't even sipped my coffee or opened Vogue when Sally the hairdresser expertly plucked out a split end. It had a tiny white globule stuck to the shaft. "Nits," she said, sotto voce . "You've got children. You've got nits. They love clean hair. It's no big deal" - a model of hairdressing tact. But I still left feeling queasy and revolted, ready to buy whatever disgusting gunk it took to nuke the nits.

Anyone with school-age children will know a thing or two about head infestation. But if nits do arrive in the family, do you speak out, risking ridicule and social ostracism, or keep quiet and help the bugs colonise a few more heads?

I was determined to keep my revolting secret. I was not, however, totally antisocial. I scoured my sons' heads for bugs, and got busy with nit comb and conditioner. They were then whisked off for haircuts that wouldn't have looked out of place on the Millwall terraces back in the early 70s.

But at work, coming out as lousy is a definite no-no for those intent on career advancement. Mention lice over lunch and work colleagues will probably start Pavlovian head-scratching and push aside their plates. One working mother even feigned food poisoning so she could leave bug-killing lotion in her hair for eight hours, as recommended. She had a glitzy product launch next day. Rather dodgy guts than lice, she reasoned.

Given the "yuk" factor that naturally attaches to nits, reticence at work is understandable and it's not really the stuff of dinner-party chit-chat either. The case for keeping quiet, even in the age of Oprah, is overwhelming.

But in the playground and at the school gates, parents' embarrassed silence is helping the little blighters breed. Joanna Ibarra is programme coordinator for Community Health Hygiene, a charity which has developed a kit to bust bugs without chemicals. Rigorous treatment with conditioner and special combs can help keep heads bug-free and empower parents to take control.

Ibarra says 50% of parents won't tell anyone they know that they have head lice in the family. Fear of social stigma is good news for bugs. But the charity has helped draft a new Department of Health leaflet on bug busting, out next week, giving advice on how to detect and deal with the parasites without resorting to expensive and questionable chemicals. Admitting to infestation need not equal social death, I now realise. In fact, it could well come to be seen as a pivotal parenting rite of passage. Maybe. Get a bunch of mothers together and when they start talking about head lice, you've soon got a bonding session, laced with groans of recognition. Everyone has a horror story. And bugs do have their uses. One enterprising mother plucked one from her daughter's louse-infested tresses and shoved it under the microscope. And if you're ever being pestered by a Neanderthal with no sense of personal body space, mentioning you've got nits can, I've heard, be most effective.

The more people who are prepared to stick their lousy heads above the parapet in the drive to destigmatise bugs the better, I reckon. And for a government intent on addressing social exclusion, ministers should be queueing up to out themselves as one-time nitwits on Frost or GMTV. Has Tony Blair ever had them? Perhaps we should be told. Alas, poor William. With not much hair and no children, he can't even pitch to the lousy parent floating voter.

There are many options for treatment: lotions and rinses, insecticides or fine-combing hair drenched in conditioner.

Community Hygiene Concern's Bug Busting kit (£4.95) aims to remove lice by systematic combing with specially designed combs. Success depends on a painstaking approach: four sessions over two weeks are required to clear lice.

Lotions containing pesticides should not be used unless you find live louse. Some "superbugs" have developed resistance to particular insecticides. "Natural" medications like tea tree, are gaining popularity.

All treatments should be used with caution for infants, pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers.

Schools round the country have adopted a "whole-school approach" where the whole family check each other on the same evening. This is done by wet combing and the family should seek treatment the same day if lice are found. Coordinated "Bug Busting" days can help stop lice circulating, and also help lessen stigma. CHC can be contacted on www.nits.net. Fax: 0181 292 7208. Nits helpline: 0181 341 7167.

fields.headline: Dangerous liaisons
fields.standfirst: As Princess Anne prepares to meet the new man in her daughter Zara's life,  Maureen Freely  relives the stresses of this most hazardous rite of passage
fields.trailText: How will Princess Anne act when she meets Angus Murray, the hunk her daughter Zara is bringing back from Australia? Chances are she won't be sure how to act - beyond the iron determination not to repeat the appalling mistakes of her own parents.
fields.body:
How will Princess Anne act when she meets Angus Murray, the hunk her daughter Zara is bringing back from Australia? Chances are she won't be sure how to act - beyond the iron determination not to repeat the appalling mistakes of her own parents.

Perhaps I am assuming too much from too little, but I doubt it. I can't think of anyone our age who wasn't totally traumatised by the way their mother or father bungled this, the most delicate moment of a child's passage into adulthood. I mean, how would you have liked to be in my shoes? I have the misfortune of coming from a family of mimics. By the time I took my first serious boyfriend home to meet them - and I put it off as long as I could - they could already do his telephone voice perfectly.

So I knew there was a danger they might see this meeting as material. Then I said to myself: "No, how could anyone be so cruel?" And I walked us right into the trap and spent the next three years paying for it. So, the one thing I'm sure about is that no child of mine is ever going to have to endure that kind of teasing.

Neither should they have to endure what my friends and I went through at the hands of our boyfriends' parents. When we exchange memories, we can't decide which parents were worse: the ones who immediately assumed you were destined to carry their grandchildren and looked you up and down like a DNA map, or the ones who had barely finished saying hello when they added: "I know you've been living together for two years, but I've put you in separate bedrooms at opposite ends of the house."

That is not to say a kinder reception can't be awful. The biggest welcome I ever got was when I went to meet the parents of a close male friend who had not yet worked up the courage to tell them he was gay. After he saw how happy they were to meet me (and I mean happy - I was this close to getting a free BMW) he lost heart, and decided they would never accept him for what he was. It took him another 10 years to break the news.

It would be unfair to hold the parents responsible, coming as they do from a generation that just doesn't have a clue when it comes to teenagers and sex. You can't say the same about our generation, which is why so many of us are so keen to manage this rite of passage with greater sensitivity.

My friend Io once went so far as to say that there could be no moment more important. "Think of it from their point of view," she said. "They must be terrified. The way parents react will determine the quality of the relationship for years to come."

But that was before the fact, when her sons were still little. They're not any more. The other day, when I asked Io how she met her sons' girlfriends for the first time, her voice, usually so rich and authoritative, grew rather small. "Oh, it's always the same," she said with a nervous laugh. "It's two heads on the pillow instead of one. A fait accompli!"

After another nervous laugh, she said: "They always have such blissful expressions on their faces, and that does warm my heart. I do wonder, though, if I'll be quite as light-hearted when it's my daughter in the bed, or if I go into any of their bedrooms and see two heads of the same sex."

One thing she is sure about: if that moment ever arrived, they would not be embarrassed. Or, for that matter, afraid. As far as I can see, this is the main difference between our generation and theirs. The idea that a parent might be an object of awe has clearly never occurred to them. Here, for example, is how my son introduced me to his first girlfriend.

I was sitting in the kitchen late one Sunday morning with my mother, who was visiting, and he just marched into the kitchen with a blanket around his middle instead of pyjamas - and not one, but two girls dressed only in T-shirts. My mother almost had a heart attack. On her behalf, I almost did, too. I tried to imagine what she and my father would have done if I'd done something like this at his age. But I couldn't. It was inconceivable.

Later, when I asked my son if, in future, he would mind giving me a little advance notice, his response was: "Advance notice for what?" At the time, his question floored me. Now I've heard it so many times, I'm almost numb to it. I mean, I wouldn't even have known my daughter had a boyfriend unless I'd encouraged my son to snoop around and rat on her. I'm not the only one swinging in the wind like this, either. My friends and I talk about it all the time.

And then we talk tactics. For my friend Stella, the last straw was when she walked into her son's bedroom one morning, and when the other head on the pillow saw her, she screamed and jumped out of the window. "I was furious," Stella recalls. "I marched my son downstairs and really gave it to him. I told him he could do what he wanted in his room, but on one condition. He had to make them come in and say hello before they leave. They have to have tea with me, and tell me their name, and act like civilised adults. We are not a brothel! Is that too much to ask?"

Well, I don't think so, but I can't think of a single teenager I know who would agree. Take this close friend of mine, who had been dropping helpful hints and providing easy openings for years without his son giving him the slightest hint about a girlfriend. He was determined to be different from his own father, who had been in the habit of giving his girlfriends a two-second look-over and then assigning them a number between one and 10.

When this boy finally told him there was a girlfriend in the picture, and that he was planning to bring her back for the night, he fell over himself assuring his son that he would do everything to make them feel at home. But when the moment arrived for the big introduction, the boy made sure his father was standing on one side of a wall, and the girl on the other. He planted himself in the doorway - that's how determined he was to keep things from getting any more intimate. So forget etiquette. Forget sensitive feelings, and tender rites of passage. When Zara comes home with Angus, Princess Anne should count herself lucky if she even gets to see his face.

webTitle: Oliver prefers to play with the girls. So the boys call him gay. Why?

fields.headline: Oliver prefers to play with the girls. So the boys call him gay. Why?
fields.standfirst:
New research shows that the gender divide is as rigid as ever among schoolkids. Dave Hill on the playground prejudice that makes boys prisoners of their sex

Section 28 explained
fields.trailText: Oliver is a 12-year-old boy who likes to hang around with girls. And why not? Girls, Oliver reckons, are more fun. He thinks other boys are idle, immature and only interested in football. "I hate football," Oliver says. "What's the point of 11 men running up and down a bit of grass, kickin' a ball?" He'd far sooner spend his school breaktime "talkin' about interesting stuff with the girls".
fields.body:
Oliver is a 12-year-old boy who likes to hang around with girls. And why not? Girls, Oliver reckons, are more fun. He thinks other boys are idle, immature and only interested in football. "I hate football," Oliver says. "What's the point of 11 men running up and down a bit of grass, kickin' a ball?" He'd far sooner spend his school breaktime "talkin' about interesting stuff with the girls".

And the girls, for their part, like talking to Oliver. He says, with satisfaction, that when he is around them they "treat me like I am a girl". The only trouble is that other boys make Oliver pay a price. They tease him by walking past when he's with his female friends and sneering: "All right, girls?" Oliver hates that: "It feels really rotten to be called a girl." And maybe other things they call him make him feel more rotten still. Do they also call him "gay"?

Oliver went silent when that question was asked. It was a silence that said "yes" more eloquently than the word itself and, furthermore, exposed a dimension of homophobia's power that has barely been acknowledged in the section 28 debate. The point about Oliver is that he has probably never experienced homosexual desire, let alone acted on it. He likes having girls as friends, but if one of his girl friends wanted to become his girlfriend, he wouldn't mind at all.

Indeed, he relates the one romantic relationship he has had with a girl, how he'd asked her if she'd mind if he bought some condoms, and even when might be a good time for them to try intercourse. Oliver's crime in the eyes of other boys is not a suspected attraction to boys, but being attracted to girls in the wrong way. For this, Oliver must be punished by being designated "gay".

Oliver's story has emerged from interviews with dozens of secondary schoolboys aged from 11 to 14 conducted by researchers at the department of psychology at Birkbeck college, University of London. The aim of the project, which is now being written up and will be published next year, is to examine how boys strive to construct and inhabit particular masculine identities as they enter adolescence and pass through it. Like previous research along similar lines, the interviews repeatedly reveal the central role of homophobia in this often exacting social process.

Top priority for a majority of boys is to define themselves in stark and direct opposition to any human quality that they perceive as feminine. Hence the scorn they habitually heap on girls, typically derided as silly, weak, subordinate, emotionally brittle and physically inept by unflattering contrast with sporty, funny, resilient, superior boys who know how to have "a laugh".

Sadly and predictably, it follows that any glimpse of "the feminine" in a boy (or man) is liable to be treated with comparable contempt. And because "femininity" in a male person is still widely regarded as a sign of homosexuality, any boy who fails to meet the standard of masculine normality becomes vulnerable to homophobic abuse or worse - whatever his sexual preference, imagined or real. The direct and conscious bullying of known or suspected gay children in schools is not, therefore, the only good reason for combating homophobia. The same fearful prejudice also threatens the wellbeing of any boy (or girl) who offends against the conventions of a rigid gender order which boys themselves police with unrelenting rigour.

The findings of the Birkbeck team tease out the many subtle and often contradictory ways in which this policing works. Sometimes the consequences for a boy can be directly linked to romance. Oliver observes that being friends with girls appears to rule out any sort of erotic liaison with them; if he asked one of his girl friends out, he says, "They'd fink that I'd be joking."

Ironically, though, boys can also find themselves put down as being gay if they associate only with other boys, such as the ones from a boys-only school who reported being taunted by boys who went to mixed schools. In another case, the language of homophobia - the most ubiquitous of pejorative playground terms - was directed at boys who chose to shower communally after PE. Then there were the boys deemed guilty of the girlish crime of having a small number of quiet fellow boy friends, or simply for sitting at the front of class. It seems that almost any way in which a boy differs from loud, "hard" or funny boys is likely to make him unpopular, and if unpopular he is a candidate to be denounced as "poof", "wuss", "pussy", "batty boy", "wimp" or "queer".

The part played by homophobic attitudes in maintaining a wider regime of gender conformity is acknowledged by Angela Mason, executive director of Stonewall: "Somehow, among young people, words like 'poof' or 'lezzie' have become generic terms of abuse used against absolutely anybody who is a little bit different," she says. The comment confirms that, of course, homophobia also hurts girls. The stigma of lesbianism threatens those who have passionate close friendships with other girls, who enjoy sport, or who do not display sexual interest in male pop stars or boys.

Among boys, though, the jockeying for position in the masculine hierarchy is particularly frantic, demonstrating the crucial place of heterosexual mastery in the masculine mystique and revealing that, although being born male automatically confers privilege over women, it also brings a sense of loss.

Many boys in the Birkbeck project spoke of regret over the limitations and anxieties that arose from the need to prove themselves properly heterosexual. One group explained that even complimenting one another on their appearance could be risky. As one boy put it: "I'm talkin' to my mate [and] if I say to him, 'Do I look nice,' and he says, 'Yes,' all you'd be saying, 'Queer.'" Laughter all round. Boys bonded cheerily around their supposed detection and disapproval of "suspect" sexual leanings, and dismissed most homophobic taunting as light-hearted "cussing" which never really hurt anyone because, they were quite certain, nobody in their school could possibly really be gay!

But even the most successfully masculine also expressed misgivings over what can be seen as the underlying costs to them of their homophobic performances. Some criticised the unfeelingness of boyish behaviour by comparison with that of girls. The flipside of their misogyny was their veneration of feminine tenderness, and it was to girls that some said they turned when they were feeling low. Yet the paradox disclosed is still poignant: on the one hand, boys praised the girlish virtues of empathy and sensitivity and revealed their own yearnings for them; on the other, they remained adamant that such qualities would be completely out of order in a boy.

What conclusions can be drawn from these intricate yet resilient patterns of gender differentiation? Rob Pattman, the member of the Birkbeck team who did most of the interviews, writes: "Recognising that homophobia is linked to the idealisation and not just the denigration of girls has important implications in relation to anti-homophobic educational practices with boys." Perhaps the key implication is that boys often do value those virtues defined as feminine, yet deny them in themselves and to one another because they fear the label "queer". The trick is to help boys acquire cultural permission to value those same virtues. However, as Pattman also observes, the need to encourage this is becoming more urgent as boys take umbrage at girls' burgeoning self-confidence and academic success by retreating still more deeply into machismo. The lesson is clear: boys' desperation to drive out "the feminine" extracts a price from all of them, as well as from girls and from any child of either sex who may be gay. It is that same desperation that underpins so much of the behaviour that causes concern over boys, and prevents them from developing the full emotional repertoire they feel is off limits for them. Homophobia is both a cause and a consequence of this sorry deprivation. Those who oppose the repeal of section 28 insist that they're not acting out of prejudice or hate. Yet how like cruel, bitter, frightened schoolboys they so often sound.
fields.bodyText: Oliver is a 12-year-old boy who likes to hang around with girls. And why not? Girls, Oliver reckons, are more fun. He thinks other boys are idle, immature and only interested in football. "I hate football," Oliver says. "What's the point of 11 men running up and down a bit of grass, kickin' a ball?" He'd far sooner spend his school breaktime "talkin' about interesting stuff with the girls". And the girls, for their part, like talking to Oliver. He says, with satisfaction, that when he is around them they "treat me like I am a girl". The only trouble is that other boys make Oliver pay a price. They tease him by walking past when he's with his female friends and sneering: "All right, girls?" Oliver hates that: "It feels really rotten to be called a girl." And maybe other things they call him make him feel more rotten still. Do they also call him "gay"? Oliver went silent when that question was asked. It was a silence that said "yes" more eloquently than the word itself and, furthermore, exposed a dimension of homophobia's power that has barely been acknowledged in the section 28 debate. The point about Oliver is that he has probably never experienced homosexual desire, let alone acted on it. He likes having girls as friends, but if one of his girl friends wanted to become his girlfriend, he wouldn't mind at all. Indeed, he relates the one romantic relationship he has had with a girl, how he'd asked her if she'd mind if he bought some condoms, and even when might be a good time for them to try intercourse. Oliver's crime in the eyes of other boys is not a suspected attraction to boys, but being attracted to girls in the wrong way. For this, Oliver must be punished by being designated "gay". Oliver's story has emerged from interviews with dozens of secondary schoolboys aged from 11 to 14 conducted by researchers at the department of psychology at Birkbeck college, University of London. The aim of the project, which is now being written up and will be published next year, is to examine how boys strive to construct and inhabit particular masculine identities as they enter adolescence and pass through it. Like previous research along similar lines, the interviews repeatedly reveal the central role of homophobia in this often exacting social process. Top priority for a majority of boys is to define themselves in stark and direct opposition to any human quality that they perceive as feminine. Hence the scorn they habitually heap on girls, typically derided as silly, weak, subordinate, emotionally brittle and physically inept by unflattering contrast with sporty, funny, resilient, superior boys who know how to have "a laugh". Sadly and predictably, it follows that any glimpse of "the feminine" in a boy (or man) is liable to be treated with comparable contempt. And because "femininity" in a male person is still widely regarded as a sign of homosexuality, any boy who fails to meet the standard of masculine normality becomes vulnerable to homophobic abuse or worse - whatever his sexual preference, imagined or real. The direct and conscious bullying of known or suspected gay children in schools is not, therefore, the only good reason for combating homophobia. The same fearful prejudice also threatens the wellbeing of any boy (or girl) who offends against the conventions of a rigid gender order which boys themselves police with unrelenting rigour. The findings of the Birkbeck team tease out the many subtle and often contradictory ways in which this policing works. Sometimes the consequences for a boy can be directly linked to romance. Oliver observes that being friends with girls appears to rule out any sort of erotic liaison with them; if he asked one of his girl friends out, he says, "They'd fink that I'd be joking." Ironically, though, boys can also find themselves put down as being gay if they associate only with other boys, such as the ones from a boys-only school who reported being taunted by boys who went to mixed schools. In another case, the language of homophobia - the most ubiquitous of pejorative playground terms - was directed at boys who chose to shower communally after PE. Then there were the boys deemed guilty of the girlish crime of having a small number of quiet fellow boy friends, or simply for sitting at the front of class. It seems that almost any way in which a boy differs from loud, "hard" or funny boys is likely to make him unpopular, and if unpopular he is a candidate to be denounced as "poof", "wuss", "pussy", "batty boy", "wimp" or "queer". The part played by homophobic attitudes in maintaining a wider regime of gender conformity is acknowledged by Angela Mason, executive director of Stonewall: "Somehow, among young people, words like 'poof' or 'lezzie' have become generic terms of abuse used against absolutely anybody who is a little bit different," she says. The comment confirms that, of course, homophobia also hurts girls. The stigma of lesbianism threatens those who have passionate close friendships with other girls, who enjoy sport, or who do not display sexual interest in male pop stars or boys. Among boys, though, the jockeying for position in the masculine hierarchy is particularly frantic, demonstrating the crucial place of heterosexual mastery in the masculine mystique and revealing that, although being born male automatically confers privilege over women, it also brings a sense of loss. Many boys in the Birkbeck project spoke of regret over the limitations and anxieties that arose from the need to prove themselves properly heterosexual. One group explained that even complimenting one another on their appearance could be risky. As one boy put it: "I'm talkin' to my mate [and] if I say to him, 'Do I look nice,' and he says, 'Yes,' all you'd be saying, 'Queer.'" Laughter all round. Boys bonded cheerily around their supposed detection and disapproval of "suspect" sexual leanings, and dismissed most homophobic taunting as light-hearted "cussing" which never really hurt anyone because, they were quite certain, nobody in their school could possibly really be gay! But even the most successfully masculine also expressed misgivings over what can be seen as the underlying costs to them of their homophobic performances. Some criticised the unfeelingness of boyish behaviour by comparison with that of girls. The flipside of their misogyny was their veneration of feminine tenderness, and it was to girls that some said they turned when they were feeling low. Yet the paradox disclosed is still poignant: on the one hand, boys praised the girlish virtues of empathy and sensitivity and revealed their own yearnings for them; on the other, they remained adamant that such qualities would be completely out of order in a boy. What conclusions can be drawn from these intricate yet resilient patterns of gender differentiation? Rob Pattman, the member of the Birkbeck team who did most of the interviews, writes: "Recognising that homophobia is linked to the idealisation and not just the denigration of girls has important implications in relation to anti-homophobic educational practices with boys." Perhaps the key implication is that boys often do value those virtues defined as feminine, yet deny them in themselves and to one another because they fear the label "queer". The trick is to help boys acquire cultural permission to value those same virtues. However, as Pattman also observes, the need to encourage this is becoming more urgent as boys take umbrage at girls' burgeoning self-confidence and academic success by retreating still more deeply into machismo. The lesson is clear: boys' desperation to drive out "the feminine" extracts a price from all of them, as well as from girls and from any child of either sex who may be gay. It is that same desperation that underpins so much of the behaviour that causes concern over boys, and prevents them from developing the full emotional repertoire they feel is off limits for them. Homophobia is both a cause and a consequence of this sorry deprivation. Those who oppose the repeal of section 28 insist that they're not acting out of prejudice or hate. Yet how like cruel, bitter, frightened schoolboys they so often sound.

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: Filters, blockers and cybersnoopers
fields.trailText: If your children like Boyzone, how do you keep them away from the Boyzone website www.boyzone.com? It might not be the sort of thing you want them to see. A child net-surfing should always be accompanied by a responsible adult. The alternative is to install a "filter" or censorship program that can tell the difference between, say, the US White House www.whitehouse.gov and an invitation to hardcore pornography www.whitehouse.com
fields.body:
If your children like Boyzone, how do you keep them away from the Boyzone website www.boyzone.com? It might not be the sort of thing you want them to see. A child net-surfing should always be accompanied by a responsible adult. The alternative is to install a "filter" or censorship program that can tell the difference between, say, the US White House www.whitehouse.gov and an invitation to hardcore pornography www.whitehouse.com

You can download a censorship program from a website. And pornography is only the beginning. There is also violence, criminal activity, hate, persecution, drugs, alcohol, gambling and weaponry - all can be blocked by a program called WeBlocker. But for some, even that may not be enough. What about sex education, birth control, abortion, and religion? Or animal rights and militant vegetarianism?

Censorship programs try to solve these problems by blocking any site that falls foul of a list of key words, to which you can add your own. They may also block access to a list of "bad" sites and allow "good" sites. Again, you should be able to add to either list. US civil liberties groups have attacked these for banning legitimate websites, such as the National Organization for Women (for radical lesbianism, apparently) to kids' sports pages ("12-year-old girls"). Self-regulation using Pics, Platform for Internet Content Selection, should avoid this. It is built into some browsers including Microsoft's Internet Explorer. In theory, you can set the level of censorship on a 10-point scale. But so few publishers have rated their sites, it's not worth the effort.

Alternatively, snoop on your kids and confront them later. Most browsers have snooping facilities built in: just check the "history" section for sites visited. Programs such as Kid Control take that idea a lot further, capturing keystrokes so you can look at them later. Kid Control will even store a snapshot of what's on the screen at intervals of 30 seconds to 15 minutes.

Net Nanny 3.1 (Net Nanny Software International, $26.95)
http://www.netnanny.com/

Looking cuddly got Net Nanny off to a good start, and I was impressed when it objected to some of the file names on my PC's hard disk before I even logged on to the net (it didn't say which). But in use it seemed slow to react, and the lists of banned sites included a lot that didn't work anyway (oh irony - to block porn, you provide a list of porn sites). It also seemed a bit rich to blacklist individual email addresses such as liz@ai.mit.edu (Liz Highleyman from MIT's Artificial Intelligence laboratory) for reasons that were not explained.
Rating 3/10

WeBlocker (We-WebCorp.com, no cost)
www.weblocker.com/

This was the easiest to get working adequately. It lets you select an age range from pre-school to 65+ (handy if your kids are 25-34). It also lets you tick boxes for subjects like drugs, alcohol and gambling. WeBlocker is Draconian: it blocked an educational toy site - The Cabaret Mechanical Theatre (http://www.cabaret.co.uk/), in Covent Garden - for gambling; and it censored drug-related parts of a humour magazine. Still, at least it let the kids read Thresh's Firing Squad www.firingsquad.com/ computer gaming site, for those who are seriously into killing virtual people.
Rating 6/10

KidControl (Tybee Software, $29.95)
http://www.kidcontrol.com/

By being a snoop program rather than censorware, and by avoiding fancy graphics, KidControl has stayed impressively small (817KB). It can hide in the background and keep a log of daily activities on a PC, and can also capture and store screen-shots at pre-set intervals. This is a powerful feature with sites that don't have obvious web addresses like www.xxxhardporn.com Kids can try to evade a keystroke recording system by, for example, copying texts and web addresses from a file and pasting them into the browser, but the visual evidence is incontrovertible.
Rating 6/10

Cybersnoop 3.0 (Pearl Software $49.95)
http://www.pearlsw.com/

This is a powerful program, but it's a hefty download (8,117KB) and not the easiest to set up and use. Cybersnoop keeps an audit trail and activity logs, so you know what people have been up to, and it offers access to three blocking system: RSACi (PICS), SafeSurf and Weburbia. You can put extra websites on an allow list or a block list, and Cybersnoop covers email, chat systems, newsgroups and file transfers, too. The only problem is that you may have to get your kids to show you how to use it . . .
Rating 5/10

Cyberpatrol 4.0 (The Learning Company $29.95, UKP24.95 UK)
http://www.cyberpatrol.com/

This Mac and Windows program is designed to lay down the law in today's wild wild web, and you can even badge a deputy to step in when you're away. The range of blockable topics includes sex education, violence, profanity, and "satanic or cult" (Yee har!). However, it costs money to subscribe to the CyberNOT blacklist, which currently has 161,914 entries. Cyberpatrol is always on duty with a time management section that lets you block net access at different times of day, and it can restrict access to 16 different programs, not just the net. Big brother would love it.
Rating 6/10

America Online (subscription service)
http://www.aol.com

AOL isn't a blocking program, but there's no doubt that its ease of use and "parental controls" feature have helped its popularity. Each account can have up to five "screen names" so kids can have their own private email, chat and internet access. However, the master account can control access to the various facilities just by clicking in the Parental Controls box. There are pre-sets for Kids Only (under 12), Teen (ages 13-15), Young Adult (ages 16-17), and General Access (ages 18 and older), and they can be fine-tuned. It's like training wheels for the net.
Rating 6/10

webTitle: Hague attacks Blair over asylum seekers

fields.headline: Hague attacks Blair over asylum seekers
fields.trailText: Tony Blair came under attack over the government's handling of asylum seekers today with accusations from the opposition benches that it was a "national scandal".
fields.body:
Tony Blair came under attack over the government's handling of asylum seekers today with accusations from the opposition benches that it was a "national scandal".

Tory Leader William Hague said the number of asylum seekers had risen since Labour came to power and that less than a third of the 19,000 people served orders to leave the country last year actually left.

"Decision after decision by his government has weakened the asylum laws," he told MPs.

"Some councils now spend more on bogus asylum seekers than they spend on looking after elderly people," he added.

He quoted home secretary Jack Straw as saying in 1986 that if a labour government did not speed up applications, they would have failed.

"Will you now confirm that the home secretary has failed?" he demanded.

But the prime minister rejected accusations that his government had dismantled immigration controls. "We have tightened them up, in the face of opposition from the Tory party," he insisted.

Mr Hague maintained that the total number of asylum seekers had risen by 140% since Mr Blair became prime minister. "He's made this country a soft touch for asylum seekers," he said. "It's a national scandal."

Conflict in the Balkans had increased the number of asylum seekers in Britain and in Europe, the prime minister said, but new benefit rules and holding centres scheduled for April would bring the figures down, he added.

The government had been left a backlog of tens of thousands of cases, he said. "We have been clearing up the mess you left us," he added.

Other business

Nothern Ireland: The prime minister conceded that no decommissioning had taken place. "It has to happen but let no one doubt how far we have come and how important it is to save it," he said. "There has to be progress on this issue. At the present time, bluntly, there is insufficient progress for General de Chastelain to make the report that he has to make."

Euro: Mr Blair insisted that keeping open the option of joining, subject to a referendum, was in the best interests of the British economy. He claimed that Mr Hague's decision not to join the euro in the life of the next parliament was "borne out of the fact that you have subcontracted your leadership to the extreme right in your party".

fields.headline: Portillo sets out his stall
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown on the appointment of Michael Portillo as new shadow chancellor
Plus: Sticking to their guns
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo is wasting no time. He wants to be leader of the Conservative party after the next election, and he is going for the little-England vote which is now that party's strongest card.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo is wasting no time. He wants to be leader of the Conservative party after the next election, and he is going for the little-England vote which is now that party's strongest card.

On the Today programme this morning, scarcely 12 hours after his appointment as shadow chancellor, he expressed support for William Hague's policy of delaying a decision on British membership of a single European currency. "The proper position is for us in the next manifesto to be against the euro, so that people know that if they want to save the pound, there is only one way to do it, and that is to vote for the Conservative party," he said.

The significant phrase is "save the pound". What Portillo is saying, and what Hague dare not say out loud, is that the Tories stand for sterling. Full stop.

Both men, and those around them, haver about conditions perhaps being more conducive in the next parliament; about needing time to sort out the constitutional and political implications of Britain joining the euro. But that is a rather thin veil over the misplaced patriotism which informs current Tory thinking.

They know that the British public, woefully misinformed, is all too prepared to think about Europe in terms of Them and Us. Absurd myths flourish in the saloon bars of England - and we are correctly talking of England here - about France and Germany ganging up on Britain; of a malevolent anti-British spirit in the EU commission; and of Britain being consistently suckered in its dealings with the continent.

This nonsense has been fostered by successive governments which have not had the guts to be positive about Europe. At best, they drone on about the jobs and trade benefit of membership. Occasionally, they mutter about the pleasures of free movement and neighbourly good relations.

They seem to forget all too easily that the EU is about the small matter of two savage wars in our continent in the 20th century and the glorious impossibility of a third one in the 21st. Compared with that central truth, all the Tory bluster and all the New Labour poll watching seem rather petty.

The insistence of both parties that British national interests must be safeguarded at all costs is intrinsically anti-European. We have interests as Britons, sure, but we also have vital interests as Europeans. The notion of unqualified national sovereignty is a sham. Even if we keep our pound, and the right to set interest and exchange rates, we will be obliged to set those rates according to international - and multinational - conditions.

Portillo told his BBC listeners this morning that a single exchange rate and interest rate "would almost certainly not be right for Britain most of the time". Of course they will not be right for Britain. Or for France. Or for Luxembourg. The important thing is that they be right for Europe, and for all of us who belong to an enterprise infinitely greater than the looming power struggle in the Tory party.

Related documentaries
The Tories: special report
Economic and Monetary Union: special report

Sticking to their guns

Spare a thought for General John de Chastelain, the head of the Northern Ireland arms decommissioning body. In the new era of peace, he is supposed to be counting and cataloguing paramilitary weapons which are no longer needed. Instead, he is today desperately trying to convince members of the IRA that since they are no longer fighting a war, they might consider handing over a few guns or maybe a pound or two of Semtex.

As we approach the 59th minute of the 11th hour, other men are trying to pound the same simple proposition into the Provisionals' minds. Tony Blair, Peter Mandelson, Bill Clinton, Irish Taoiseach Bertie Ahern and countless others are all trying to save a peace deal which has been in existence all of eight weeks. All manner of ingenious formulae will no doubt be mooted, but only one will suit the need of the moment. Gen de Chastelain must be taken off negotiating duties, and given the work he was hired for.

Related documentary
Northern Ireland: special report

fields.headline: New Hampshire: the reaction
fields.standfirst: How the US commentators saw it
fields.trailText:
The combined ranks of pundits and pollsters and big-money donors could neither predict nor prevent John McCain's striking victory. New Hampshire has a way of favoring mavericks who go on to defeat in subsequent primaries, so it would be wrong to suggest that Mr McCain has attained front-runner status. This is even truer this year than previously, since Mr McCain got a major boost from independent voters, who are allowed to take part in New Hampshire's Republican primary but not in those of many other states. Moreover, Mr Bush retains a daunting advantage in organisation and money.
Washington Post editorial

This is even truer this year than previously, since Mr McCain got a major boost from independent voters, who are allowed to take part in New Hampshire's Republican primary but not in those of many other states. Moreover, Mr Bush retains a daunting advantage in organisation and money.
Washington Post editorial

A few weeks ago, it seemed at least possible that Mr Bush and Mr Gore could dispatch their rivals in short order, bringing the entire process to an end when only a few hundred thousand Americans, living in small states, had had a chance to vote. That clearly will not happen.
R W Apple, New York Times

McCain's huge win enters the pantheon of New Hampshire verdicts past. It ratifies New Hampshire's status as the primary primary; nowhere else can a distant underdog grab the frontrunner by the lapels and rattle his dental work.
David Nyhan, Globe columnist

"The world has turned upside-down. It's horrible for Bush. McCain is connecting with Republicans, which means he has the potential to win in states where independents can't vote."
Pollster John Zogby

"This is the end of the 'Gentleman's C' campaign for George W - they've got to get off cruise control."
Republican analyst Rich Galen

"Bush is still the front-runner, but now that his aura of inevitability is gone, he has to prove himself and show how he handles adversity. Aides say he'll start informal Q&A town meetings, just like McCain. McCain is riding a magic carpet of momentum, but it'll still be an uphill fight - he's short of cash and organization, and might not even get on the ballot in much of New York state."
Deborah Orin, New York Post

"Clearly, the inevitability of a Bush nomination and a general election victory have been cast in doubt and that's a major problem for the governor since that was his ace in the hole. The size of the McCain victory has to be jarring to the Republican political establishment, not only here in New Hampshire but nationally. As for the Democratic contest, Bradley ducked a bullet, For a while it looked like Gore would finish things off with a quick, clear, decisive victory. The fact it was so close gives Bradley reason to fight another day."
Stuart Rothenberg, independent political analyst.

fields.headline: Whittard
fields.standfirst: Whittard of Chelsea
fields.trailText: The craze for dotcom may not be everyone's cup of tea but for Whittard of Chelsea, purveyors of the finest leaf, it has left an agreeable aftertaste.
fields.body:
The craze for dotcom may not be everyone's cup of tea but for Whittard of Chelsea, purveyors of the finest leaf, it has left an agreeable aftertaste.

The company's stock leapt almost 40% to 92p as it was unveiled that Antfactory - a European internet development company - would invest £2m in Whittard for the development of an e-commerce capability. What was ignored was Whittard's slump in 1999 pre-tax profitability from £2.8m to £210,000 and a decision last year to pass on its final dividend. It blamed a poor product line and over expansion for the decline.

The company which has 114 UK stores and 12 overseas has seen its shares dip as low as 30p in the past year. The group floated in 1996 at 148p a share. Whittard's decision to turn to the internet to revive its fortunes - it already sells tea and coffee online - offers an interesting comparison with superstore Tesco. On forecasts of 6p in earnings for 2000, Whittard is trading on a price-to-earnings per share multiple of 16 times which is almost equivalent to Tesco. While Whittard's on-line sales are small, Tesco boasts $200m in grocery sales from its website.

Antfactory, which has a shareholding in another internet investment company Jelly Works as a shareholder and vice-versa, has only been up and running since October.

Like most internet debutants, Antfactory has a few investments but has yet to get any runs on the board. Antfactory will provide Whittard with the working capital to develop its e-commerce activities and also the management expertise. In return its secures a 16.9% stake in Whittard at 60p a share.

In addition, Whittard shareholders will also be asked to approve the issue of warrants to antfactory for a further 2.1m shares and two non-executive board seats.

Yet Whittard's failure to explain yesterday what its new e-commerce offering would be or how Antfactory would improve its fortunes prompted caution from analysts who want more detail.

webTitle: Arlington reveals Packer backing to boost listing

fields.headline: Arlington reveals Packer backing to boost listing
fields.standfirst:
Arlington group
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A clutch of high profile investors led by Australian media magnate Kerry Packer, entrepreneur Luke Johnson and the manager of one of the world's largest hedge funds have emerged as the backers of an Ofex-listed hi-tech investment fund with ambitious expansion plans.
fields.body:
A clutch of high profile investors led by Australian media magnate Kerry Packer, entrepreneur Luke Johnson and the manager of one of the world's largest hedge funds have emerged as the backers of an Ofex-listed hi-tech investment fund with ambitious expansion plans.

Arlington Group, which is examining ways of obtaining a full stock market listing, is also thought to count the Bamford family, owners of the JCB digger firm, and veteran wheeler-dealer David Rowland among its shareholders. Mr Rowland's son Jonathan is chief executive of fledgling internet investment house JellyWorks.

Louis Bacon, manager of the Moore Capital hedge fund in New York, is also a significant private investor in Arlington.

Nicholas Barham, Arlington's chairman and Mr Packer's son-in-law, said yesterday that although the group had support from wealthy private shareholders he wanted to attract more institutional investors. It is thought his preferred route is through a flotation on a big international stock market or a takeover of a listed company. "It is our intention to generate a significant re-rating of the shares, create additional liquidity in the stock and maximise shareholder value," Mr Barham said.

Arlington is valued at about £120m on the lightly regulated Ofex market. Its portfolio includes stakes in 365 Corporation, on-line auctioneer i-collector, Boxman, TalkCast and Greenchip Investments, a technology company backed by former British & Commonwealth chief executive John Gunn.

In the six months to September 30 Arlington had £7.4m in fixed assets and £9.1m in shareholder equity. Shares in Arlington, which was listed on Ofex nearly three years ago with paid-up capital of £50,000, closed up 5p at 225.5p.

fields.headline: 365 Corporation prepares to score
fields.standfirst:
365 Corp
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: For all the pre-match hype about the float of 365 Corporation at the end of last year the sports and entertainment digital content provider's share price failed to perform as many investors had hoped.
fields.body:
For all the pre-match hype about the float of 365 Corporation at the end of last year the sports and entertainment digital content provider's share price failed to perform as many investors had hoped.

Placed at 160p at the beginning of December, the shares showed early internet-style promise, racing to a high of 275p. Enthusiasm quickly subsided, however, and they fell back to 192p. Dealers say profit-taking among private investors seeking to bank early gains was to blame.

365's long term ability to compete against rivals including Sports Internet and Sportal is also thought to have prompted selling.

Since the start of this year 365 shares have bobbed around 200p and showed lit tle sign of further advancement. Now, however, the word in the market suggests 365 shares could be about to perform as many had hoped.

Third-quarter results this month are likely to show strong growth among 365's users. In November the company said it had 944,267 unique users, a 130% increase on June.

Some bulls believe if that growth continues 365's user numbers may not be far off those of Freeserve, at 1.7m.

Analysts believe the news could help cure one of 365's biggest problems - its lack of visibility. They point to the pre-Christmas acquisition of a US rugby website company marketed to 65m homes via an exclusive agreement with the Fox broadcasting network as evidence that 365 has not handled its public relations ideally.

The deal was announced on Christmas Eve and almost missed by the stock market.

The position of 365 as a "convergence focused" content creator with a proven track record should not be underestimated, say analysts. It is already working on delivering content over multiple platforms. Mobile applications will throw up new revenue streams but with all the content originating from a common source, the cost base will be low.

The portents for 365 are good. Shares in Freeserve, Exchange Holdings and QXL, the three largest internet floats in Britain so far, endured sluggish early trading; 365 could be about to score.

fields.headline: Tories to jettison Archer
fields.trailText: Former mayoral candidate Lord Archer is to be thrown out of the Tory party, it was reported today.
fields.body:
Former mayoral candidate Lord Archer is to be thrown out of the Tory party, it was reported today.

A friend of Lord Archer said that the novelist and ex-party chairman was 'devastated' by the letter he had received from the Conservative party's Ethics and Integrity committee. It reportedly gave him notice of expulsion and allowed him a week to respond to the charge that he had brought the party into disrepute.

Lord Archer dropped out of the mayoral race in November after newspaper reports that he asked a friend to lie about a dinner date which could have formed part of the evidence in his 1987 libel trial.

Neither the committee nor party headquarters would comment on the matter today. Conservative central office said: "The committee is still in the process of conducting its inquiry... We cannot confirm or deny any speculation about [its] progress."

Lord Archer's spokesman, Stephan Shakespeare, commented: "Jeffrey has a cast-iron agreement with Elizabeth Appleby QC [the committee chair] not to discuss this process at all, and he at least is keeping to the agreement. We will neither confirm nor deny today's reports."

A final decision on Lord Archer's fate will not be made until after his response is received. But his expulsion now looks inevitable.
