fields.headline: Seeds of doubt
fields.standfirst: A new word has entered the Canadian prairie lexicon.  Cathryn Atkinson meets the farmers who fear that crop cops are enforcing 'bio-serfdom'
fields.trailText: A new word has entered the Canadian prairie lexicon. Cathryn Atkinson meets the farmers who fear that crop cops are enforcing 'bio-serfdom'.
fields.body:
It all began with a few stubborn weeds in a ditch. Percy Schmeiser, a 68-year-old Canadian farmer, was puzzled by the poor result of his annual herbicide spraying in the spring of 1997. As in previous years, he used Roundup, Monsanto's weed killer, to burn off the plants along the outskirts of his 1,400-acre farm near the hamlet of Bruno, in Saskatchewan.

Despite saturating the area with herbicide, he found rogue oilseed rape plants thriving in ditches and around telephone poles. Having crossbred his own seed for 35 years, he wondered if he had accidentally created some kind of mutant.

So he sprayed Roundup from the edge of his field inward, a full 80 feet into his own flourishing crop of oilseed rape. It should have killed everything but, to his alarm, over 60% of the plants survived. Only Roundup Ready oilseed rape - genetically modified by Monsanto to create a mutually exclusive relationship between their seeds and their herbicide - can survive.

Some time later, Monsanto was tipped off by a call to its (now defunct) freephone "sneak" line that Schmeiser was, allegedly, growing Roundup Ready GM oilseed rape. Monsanto asked Robinson Investigations, retained by them throughout Canada to gather information on errant farmers, to take samples from the Schmeiser farm.

Schmeiser's crop possessed Monsanto's gene, and Robinson's also visited the local mill, which chemically cleaned Schmeiser's seeds for planting, to retrieve a sample. Again, the gene was found.

Although Schmeiser says he had never bought seed from Monsanto or signed a contract, the corporation sued him for cultivating their gene, demanding all profits from the crop and unspecified punitive damages. Schmeiser argued that any number of potential contaminants could have infiltrated his seed - such as blow-offs from passing trucks laden with Roundup Ready oilseed rape, insects, wind or cross-germination, - and that further contamination could have occurred when he kept back seed to plant.

Last August, the two parties met to resolve the dispute. They failed, so Monsanto's case now goes to the supreme court of Canada in June.

Meanwhile, a furious Schmeiser has launched a suit against them, for allegedly contaminating his seed stock, for defamation and trespass, and the theft of seeds and plants. He is asking for punitive damages of C$10m (£4.2m).

Schmeiser is one of more than 1,000 Canadian farmers investigated by Monsanto in the past three years for allegedly growing its patented GM crops and breaking the conditions of the company's technology use agreement (TUA). This gives the farmers the right, for a price of £6.30 an acre, to grow GM crops, and allows Monsanto unlimited access to their fields, seed stores and crops for up to three years. Farmers must also agree to destroy any leftover seed each year in order to protect Monsanto's patent. If they wish to buy the seed the following year, they must sign the TUA and again pay the fee.

Monsanto say that 400,000 North American farmers have signed the TUA (20,000 in Canada) and over 17 million acres in Canada and 62 million in the US were covered by Monsanto's GM seed by 1999.

Monsanto Canada's Adele Pelland says 65% of the oilseed rape grown in Canada in 1999 was Roundup Ready, and stresses that farmers encourage Monsanto to prosecute under the TUA, adding that they "all want a level playing field".

Schmeiser's case is gaining worldwide attention, but it is, perhaps, most closely watched by those farmers who fear Monsanto's legal wrath for violations of the TUA. A new term, "bio-serfdom", has entered the Canadian prairie lexicon.

Edward Zielinski traded wheat seed for canola seed with another farmer in 1997. Unknown to him, the canola he planted on his farm in Mikado, Saskatchewan was contaminated with Roundup Ready seed. Monsanto set his fine at C$115 (£48.32) an acre or C$28,750 (£12,079). He has no intention of paying, arguing that farmers have traded seed for centuries.

And 400 miles east, in Arden, Manitoba, Ed Sulz is facing ruin. As a strong supporter of GM crops, he very much wanted to test Roundup Ready oilseed rape. In 1996, he was one of the first farmers in western Canada to try. The seed dealer asked him to sign the TUA. Having left his cheque book at home, Sulz left with the seed, but without the document. "I just initialled it (the TUA) and said I'd get the cheque to him," he says. Once the dealer received the cheque, the TUA was faxed to Sulz, but since the terms and conditions were on the back of the page, he never received a copy outlining its vital stipulations.

When, the following spring, Sulz had enough seed left over to plant a further 75 acres, he did so in ignorance of the conditions of his contract. Monsanto's crop cops were on to him by July, faxing a letter outlining the transgression and demanding £141,807 in fines. They included a copy of terms and conditions.

"The investigator said I had to sign the fax as proof that he had delivered it, so I initialled it," says Sulz. Five days later, two official copies of the letter arrived by post. But, with time to reflect, Sulz changed his mind and offered to pay the TUA fee of C$1,125 (£473) for the 75 acres in the hope of settling the dispute. Monsanto took this payment but rejected settlement, stating that the initials on the fax were legal and binding.

The company took Sulz to court in December 1998, but the judge called their fine "outrageous" and rejected the initialled fax as a legal document. Monsanto is now appealing and Sulz has launched a counter-suit, but with legal fees of at least $100,000 before getting to court, he cannot afford to continue.

Ironically, Sulz remains a supporter of GM. He has grown GM canola produced by other bio-agricultural companies in the past two years, but is now considering a change to organic farming because of the backlash against GM food.

Since April, the price of oilseed rape has dropped from C$9 to C$4 a bushel. And Eastern Manitoban farmers say they are losing up to C$10 a tonne because Europe and an increasing number of companies won't buy it. Buyers are now paying a premium for crops guaranteed non-GM. And a recently launched anti-GM food initiative, led by the respected biotechnology scientist Dr David Suzuki, is leading the growing debate in Canada.

 For more details on Percy Schmeiser's case against Monsanto visit: www.fightfrankenfood.com

fields.headline: Top-down turmoil
fields.standfirst: Wally Harbert urges the government to think again on community life
fields.trailText: Wally Harbert urges the government to think again on community life.
fields.body:
It is not often that a government inquiry gets it totally wrong, but Lord Warner's working group on the active community succeeds in doing just that. If the government accepts the advice it offers, in the report Giving Time, Getting Involved, the cause it espouses will be set back by many years and development opportunities will be lost.

The group was asked to prepare a three to five year strategy for increasing public involvement in community life through volunteering. The report makes many familiar and bland statements - about the need for support, better publicity, a coherent approach across government, a reduction in attitudinal barriers, better management, recognition of the skills of potential volunteers, strengthening the infrastructure, testing new approaches, increased government money, etc, etc. It is, however, short in offering effective strategies to deal with them.

The present bottleneck relates to identifying, and then supporting, volunteer organisers. That must be addressed if progress is to be made. Fortunately, there are successful models in existence that can be replicated. In recent years, a plethora of organisations have been created, many supported and funded by government, employing staff to promote volunteering. This is a growth industry mainly composed of recruits with no relevant training. Child-care work has lost its appeal after so many adverse and high-profile cases. Community work is more attractive and is a haven for those who want to improve society but who do not accept the professional discipline which paid work in this field requires.

The government wants to rejuvenate run-down inner city estates. To win the active support of local people, who are often suspicious of public authorities, requires great skill and understanding. Getting the best out of volunteers in damaged communities needs the same level of skill as child abuse work. It is not clear that members of the working group understand this.

Unlike most other committees considering public services, no member of the group was drawn from a relevant academic background.

The report refers to the need for management training for volunteer managers. It ignores the fact that large numbers of administrative and professional staff retire early or are made redundant at the peak of their careers. Instead of recruiting and training paid managers we should provide an infrastructure that utilises the skills and enthusiasms of retired managers and professional people who are desperate to use their talents as volunteers. We already have enough paid volunteer managers.

But, worse. Although this is a report about volunteering, apart from the chairman, the group appears to be composed solely of paid staff. Doubtless, all of them will claim to undertake volunteering of various kinds, but their perceptions are not those of volunteers but of heads of services. A reference group of volunteers to provide advice would have been a nod in the right direction.

The proposed strategy does nothing to ensure that ethnic minority groups are better represented among volunteers and that opportunities are created for volunteers from all racial groups to work together to improve their local communities. Yet good examples about how this can be achieved already exist. Similarly, there is evidence that people with disabilities have a good deal to offer as volunteers.

There is a limited need for local schemes to receive central government funding. If volunteers really improve literacy in schools, and if they support community care policies, this should be quantified so that local service providers can make rational choices when they are deciding budget strategies.

Parachuting money in from the government only complicates local relationships, distorts decision-making, fragments responsibility and hinders genuine cross-agency understanding. A central plank of government policy should be to promote a programme of independent evaluation. Warm feelings are not enough. It would be easier for new projects to obtain funds from local public services if cast-iron proof were available of the financial benefits of investing in volunteering. Similarly, corporate support for volunteering would be more readily provided if evidence were available about the proven benefits to employees, to retirees and to companies. Too often, volunteer organisers are made to feel like second-hand car salesmen who have no MOT certificate for the product they are selling.

Sadly, this report represents a top-down understanding of the issues and responds with top- down solutions. It embraces out-of-date concepts of volunteering, in which volunteers are seen but not heard. One way forward would be for the active community unit of the home office to launch barnstorming sessions with volunteers and then prepare a strategy based on the outcome.

 Wally Harbert is a former director of social services who now serves as a volunteer.

fields.headline: Suspects rounded up
fields.standfirst: Jan Rocha and  Sue Branford report from Brazil on the state government that has unilaterally declared war on biotechnology
fields.trailText: Jan Rocha and Sue Branford report from Brazil on the state government that has unilaterally declared war on biotechnology.
fields.body:
Teams of agricultural inspectors have been crisscrossing the vast soybean fields of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil's southernmost state, raiding fields and storehouses in the search for illegal GM crops or seeds. They are the frontline of a battle to keep Brazil GM free, which has pitched the leftwing state government against the biotechnology giant Monsanto and powerful sectors of the federal government.

The inspectors carry portable kits which can identify Monsanto's Roundup Ready soya - both plants and seeds - within a few minutes. Each kit, imported from the US at a cost of $980, can test 100 samples. The inspectors follow up tip-offs received on a special GM hotline set up by the state government. In the first week of the operation, 3,500 bags of GM seed were seized.

Some farmers have reacted angrily: inspectors have been threatened, had dogs set on them and been chased away. In Tupancireta, 300 members of the local farmers' club, Amigos da Terra (Friends of the Earth), made a pact to defy the inspectors, claiming their actions were illegal.

For the moment, Monsanto's Roundup Ready soybeans are banned throughout Brazil following a court order obtained by the Brazilian consumer protection organisation, IDEC, and by Greenpeace, on the grounds that no environmental impact study had been carried out. Instead, the government's advisory body on biosafety, CTN-Bio, had accepted Monsanto's assurances that all would be well. Monsanto has appealed to have the ban overturned.

What is at stake in the rolling fields of Rio Grande do Sul is Monsanto's plan to make Brazil its HQ for seed and herbicide production in Latin America. It has already begun building a $55m plant for making Roundup and other herbicides in the Brazilian state of Bahia. This will be the largest herbicide raw material plant outside the US. The Brazilian government is investing $140m in the plant, which promises 1,400 new jobs.

Before the court ban, Monsanto had stockpiled 300,000 50kg bags of GM seeds in Rio Grande do Sul, confident that Brazil - the world's second largest soybean producer, after the US - would go GM. But the unexpected election in Rio Grande do Sul last year of a leftwing governor, Olivio Dutra, of the PT (Workers' Party), threw a spanner in the works. Dutra, ideologically hostile to multinational companies for health and environmental reasons, wants farmers to go organic.

Monsanto's plans to turn the state into an extension of neighbouring Argentina, where already 80% of all the soybeans grown are GM, were abruptly interrupted by a state ban on GM crops, even before the court ruling in Brasilia. But the struggle has only just begun. Up to 2.5 milion of the 9 million tonnes of soya beans grown annually in Rio Grande do Sul are exported, mostly to Europe. And there is a strong rumour - though nothing is proven - that up to a third of the state's soybean area had been planted with GM seed smuggled in from Argentina.

The rumours are having an effect. A recent contract for 150,000 tonnes of Brazilian soybeans by a group of European importers stipulated that none of it was to come from Rio Grande do Sul for fear of contamination with the GM product. The state has engaged a French scientist to carry out traceability tests, though it rejects the need for a purity seal.

"It's going to be a tough battle", says Lino de David, director of the state's rural extension service, Emater. "Monsanto was banking on the farmers' ignorance and lack of information. It was their bad luck that a green government took office here."

fields.headline: Struggle to live
fields.standfirst: John Perry on a community which has lost its  purpose after being battered by a hurricane
fields.trailText: John Perry on a community which has lost its purpose after being battered by a hurricane.
fields.body:
Last month's emergency in Venezuela is a reminder not only that such disasters seem to be happening more frequently but also that most are never fully solved. I recently revisited the scene of a similar Latin American disaster - the area hit in October 1998 by Hurricane Mitch. As in Venezuela, in the Posoltega district of Nicaragua a mud slide did the most spectacular damage, killing 2,500 people, rendering 5,000 homeless and devastating farmland.

Hurricane Mitch provoked a massive response, with more than £10 million raised in private donations in Britain alone. Five months after the disaster President Clinton himself visited Posoltega, met hurricane victims and promised help. A major conference took place last year in Stockholm to coordinate aid and debt-relief to the four most affected central American countries.

Approaching Posoltega on the main highway, the scars created by the mud slide are being covered by vegetation, all but one of the bridges swept away in floods have been replaced, and the road itself is new. But the changes are superficial. A talk to the mayor, Felicita Zeledon, quickly establishes that this is a community struggling to find a future for itself. Most of the 1,000 or more displaced families will soon have houses, but what they lack is the means to support themselves. Some have already left the area or even emigrated to seek work elsewhere; the majority can only find casual jobs and a few have returned to farm the very slopes that remain unstable on the side of the volcano.

Posoltega has seen little help from the Nicaraguan government or indeed from the US (despite the Clinton visit). The aid from international agencies has built houses but is not providing the land which the people need to feed themselves. The cost of land has rocketed and this has put off agencies unwilling to pay high prices. The government has refused to intervene and buy land.

The problems of drainage, soil stability and effective monitor-ing of seismic dangers are still unresolved. As if to remind those living in this hazardous area of the dangers they face, while I was there the neighbouring Concepcion volcano began throwing large boulders into the air.

Medical agencies have helped hurricane victims deal with the trauma of the disaster and the loss of loved ones, but such problems are not solved quickly and the agencies have now moved on. Señora Zeledon is trying to fill the gaps, but the devastated local economy is paying fewer taxes than before. Her town hall has received no extra government funding and expectations far exceed results.

I managed to track down a woman called Inez Vanegas, about whom I wrote in this diary column a year ago. She lives with her children in a plastic-walled shelter about 12 metres square with a dirt floor, in a camp provided by the Spanish Red Cross. She now has a few clothes and other belongings to replace what was lost. She is waiting for one of the new houses being built, but each has only a tiny piece of land - insufficient to plant crops. She borrowed $30 to buy hens, and is struggling to pay it back. Casual work is available on local farms, but only in return for food - not cash. And because the rest of her family died, there is no one with whom to leave the children if she does find work.

Her 12-year-old daughter carries the wounds from being hit by a tree in the mud slide, and recently had an operation to remove a piece of barbed wire from near her spine. But the psychological problems are deeper. She suffers from fits in which she seems about to die. The community collected $300 towards her medical costs, but she clearly needs longer-term help and there is now no one to give it.

That the survivors have preserved their lives, but have yet to find a viable future, is brought home by the isolated location of the refugee camp and the nearby new homes.

Miles from the nearest town, one mile even from the main road and served only by a dirt track, the well-built but small houses with few community facilities await their unwilling owners. They seem to symbolise a community which has lost its purpose. Inez smiles when she recollects how lucky she and her children were to escape the mud. But as the land turns green again, it fails to bring her any hope.

 John Perry is director of policy at the Chartered Institute of Housing.

fields.headline: Hidden heroes
fields.standfirst: You'll find them in schools, town halls,  hospitals - and even police stations.  Janet Snell on the unsung men and  women who keep society moving
fields.trailText: You'll find them in schools, town halls, hospitals - and even police stations. Janet Snell on the unsung men and women who keep society moving.
fields.body:
Research has shown it can lower your blood pressure and reduce cholesterol and that people who do it claim they get a new perspective on life. Volunteering is becoming popular again after losing recruits following the return of women to the workplace.

But a report published this week aims to highlight the contribution of the UK's army of so-called "hidden volunteers" - people such as magistrates, school governors, special constables and local councillors - who underpin many public services but whose efforts often go unrecognised as they operate outside the areas traditionally associated with volunteering.

The report has been published by Community Service Volunteers, which has calculated that, exclud ing carers, there are some 700,000 hidden volunteers in the UK. The charity estimates that they put in over 18 million working days annually and if they were paid it would cost the country almost £1.4bn a year.

Based on the findings of the report, CSV is recommending the setting of target numbers of volunteers in public services. The charity also wants to see more flexible and rewarding voluntary opportunities plus more widespread sharing of good practice in the use of volunteers in public services. Elisabeth Hoodless, CSV executive director, believes that not enough is being done to encourage more involvement in volunteering outside the charity sector.

"The public often just doesn't realise that people like lay magistrates and special constables are unpaid. We need more widespread recognition by society of the value of volunteering, we need to involve greater numbers and we need to look seriously at how we can open up new opportunities for volunteers, especially in our public services."

The CSV is targeting the NHS and libraries as two areas where recruiting more volunteers could make a real difference. Hoodless says: "Half of our NHS trusts use no volunteers at all, while the potential for libraries is even greater. Why are we talking about closing libraries? If volunteers were brought in our libraries could run more initiatives such as homework clubs for school children. They could become vibrant places open in the evening and at weekends.

"I know there are some reservations among those employed in areas where volunteers are brought in. But people like special constables and volunteer librarians aren't after staff jobs. They just want more children to be able to read and more crimes to be prevented."

So who exactly are these hidden volunteers?

The CSV report focuses on lay magistrates, local councillors, carers, parent teacher associations, community health councils, special police constables, hospital DJs, lay visitors, worker representatives, including trade union reps, school governors and boards of visitors.

Steve Wood, who works in higher education administration, is one of the UK's 16,500 special constables who operate alongside the regular force and have the same powers of arrest.

He says: "You do one day a week training for 20 weeks and then you're out there in uniform, walking the beat or driving a police car. It's a big responsibility but very stimulating. One night you might deal with a burglary, the next a domestic dispute. What I like about it is that you have more time than regular officers to talk to victims."

Melvyn Butcher is an education consultant who volunteers as a lay visitor in Bedfordshire. He can make unannounced visits to police custody suites, day or night, to see detainees and report on their welfare.

He says: "You ask people if they've been fed, if they're warm enough, if they need you to contact anyone for them. If they have a bruised eye, you ask how they got it.

"On the whole, we get a good welcome from the police. They realise we're also there to protect them against false accusations. We go in pairs for our own safety, but I've never had any problem. Most of the time all is well and there's nothing to report. If you came in thinking it was going to be like The Bill, you'd be very disappointed".

Ex-teacher Joyce Struthers is chair of the Association of Community Health Councils in England and Wales (Achew) and also a member of her local CHC in North Bedfordshire. There are just over 4,000 CHC members in all and they devote 10 to 20 hours a week.

She says: "Our role is to monitor local health services. We can visit any NHS premises and we talk to staff and patients, look at the general state of the place and then make a report. If we're unhappy, we can take the matter right up to secretary of state level. I've never regarded myself as a committee woman or a 'joiner', but I find this work immensely satisfying."

 Hidden Volunteers: Evaluating The Extent And Impact Of Unrecognised Volunteering In The UK is published by CSV, 237 Pentonville Rd, London N1 9NJ. Tel 0207-278 6601.

fields.headline: Deep roots of revival
fields.standfirst: There are no quick fixes to neighbourhood decline, warns Aaron Cahill
fields.trailText: There are no quick fixes to neighbourhood decline, warns Aaron Cahill.
fields.body:
Hear the words "social exclusion" on a government minister's lips, and soon after it will be followed by the words "New Deal for Communities" - the panacea for neighbourhood decline. Last week, this flagship programme took another step when the green light and £370m was given to partnerships operating in eight neighbourhoods scattered around England. This is in addition to the two announced last year.

But almost 18 months after the social exclusion unit's report on deprived neighbourhoods was launched, along with bidding guidance for the New Deal for Communities (NDC) pathfinder programme, it is clear that there are no quick hits in this process. Reversing neighbourhood decline is no small business - and if we accept that it is deep rooted, then the solutions need deep roots too.

The first two schemes to be approved were from Beswick and Openshaw, east Manchester, which was granted £52m, and Shoreditch, in Hackney, east London, which received £37m. So are there some common strands between the two, or are the solutions for the north different from those in the south?

The population statistics show that the demographic make-up of the two areas is similar, but there are differences. In Beswick and Openshaw, 54% of the working population is in full-time employment, whereas for Shoreditch the figure is only 39%.

And while housing isn't one of the major priorities of the NDC programme - unlike crime, unemployment, poor health and educational underachievement - it has inevitably emerged as an issue for both pathfinders.

webTitle: Social care: Cue for the check-out

fields.headline: Cue for the check-out
fields.standfirst: Whenever a new superstore opens, it attracts local authority  care staff seeking jobs with more money and less stress.  Kendra Inman reports on the national staffing crisis
fields.trailText: Whenever a new superstore opens, it attracts local authority care staff seeking jobs with more money and less stress. Kendra Inman reports on the national staffing crisis.
fields.body:
There is a dramatic staffing crisis in social care, probably worse than at any time since the war, that will leave local authorities unable to provide support for thousands of elderly and vulnerable people and children unless urgent action is taken within the next few months, say employers and training chiefs.

There have been concerns about falling numbers of social work students for some time. Last week, Essex county council confirmed managers were recruiting social workers from as far away as South Africa in a bid to fill empty posts. In addition, councils are struggling to attract or retain the mainstay of the workforce - mature women - as residential and home care workers.

Out of town superstores, the scourge of the high street retailer, are also hitting social care economy. The opening of a new Tesco is often accompanied by a mass exodus of social care staff as they quit for the less stressful - and mostly better paid - world of retail.

According to Peter Gilroy, strategic director responsible for social services for Kent, one of the country's largest purchasers of care, a few years ago when home care meant a bit of housework and cooking, women were happy to take the jobs which then fitted in with school hours. Now demands made on staff are greater, service users need a higher level of care and have greater needs and require round the clock support.

"Our aspirations for the homecare workforce - better trained and more skilled - is not matched by the money on offer," he says. "They can earn £6.25 an hour in Tesco in Kent. Social care wages for part-time and unqualified staff range from the minimum wage up to £5 per hour."

In many areas, councils are also struggling to recruit qualified social workers. Kent has recruited from New Zealand, Australia and the Republic of Ireland for some time. Developments like the Quality Protects initiative, which aims to raise standards in children's services, have created more posts and led to councils poaching each other's staff to fill them.

Jennifer Bernard, chief executive of the social work training council, CCETSW, sees more problems on the horizon. "Because of the age profile of the workforce, we are expecting a large bulk of retirements soon, and not enough are coming forward to take their places," she says.

The number of students applying for social work courses fell by 55% between 1995 and 1999. Social work courses tend to attract older people; the average age of someone finishing a diploma in social work is in the mid-30s. The switch from grants to student loans is believed to have acted as a major disincentive to mature students, who may have families and mortgages and are reluctant to take on new debts.

When the Tories were in power the then health secretary, Virginia Bottomley, famously called for armies of streetwise grannies to enter social work. Now may be the time to challenge the assumption that older people are the best social workers, says Bernard. "Young people, too, need to see social care as a positive career choice," she says.

Social work's image problem is also contributing to the recruitment difficulties. Countless inquiries and scandals have rightly highlighted bad practice and mistakes, but not enough has been done to promote social work as a satisfying and rewarding career, says Tony Smith, of the local government group, the Improvement and Development Agency.

Ian White, director of Hertfordshire social services, points out that, in a booming economy, people have more jobs to choose from and leave the sector "because they are worn down by the sheer intractability of some of the work".

Smith adds that the fact that the majority of social care staff are unqualified speaks volumes "about the value that is attached to the workforce".

There are moves afoot to market social care in a more positive light. Last month, the health minister, John Hutton, announced the winners of the first social care awards scheme. A post-qualifying award for child care is being piloted, and plans for the establishment of a regulatory body, the General Social Care Council, are underway. Training needs are being tackled through the national organisations, employer-led bodies set up to identify and tackle skill shortages. But it takes five years to attract, train and prepare social workers, and authorities need to address shortages now, Gilroy warns.

Councils will need to make working conditions more attractive. Kent, for example, has produced an employment package designed to retain qualified staff in front line services, rather than lose them to management posts.

White, who chairs the social and health care workforce group, believes local authorities will have to recruit unqualified but properly supervised staff to work alongside qualified staff much more clearly than they have done in the past. "It may mean more secondments to diploma in social work courses," he says. "It may mean bringing more people in via the NVQ route and offering them a structured career path."

All agree that the whole sector needs to work together to address the current staffing crisis, but that the department of health needs to take the lead. There are calls for a government-backed recruitment campaign similar to the one aimed at bringing nurse returners back into the NHS. White argues that tackling the shortage "needs high level leadership rather than the fragmented approach that characterises the personnel agenda at the moment".

fields.headline: Free fall
fields.standfirst:
With congregations continuing to shrink, organised religion has never been in such bad shape. So why are the 'godless' freethinkers of humanism now reluctant to stand up and be counted? James Meek investigates
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: With congregations continuing to shrink, organised religion has never been in such bad shape. So why are the 'godless' freethinkers of humanism now reluctant to stand up and be counted? James Meek investigates.
fields.body:
At the end of the funeral, the family requested the Vera Lynn song, We'll Meet Again. "Of course, as humanists, we don't believe we will," says Ted Stroud, one of about 170 non-religious officiants in the UK presiding over atheist funerals, baby-naming ceremonies and weddings. "But we respected their wishes."

Each year, the number of humanist ceremonies goes up. Yet they are still pitifully few. The national secular movement, which once boasted a hall in every large town in Britain, has shrunk to a tiny cluster of full-time atheists and their supporters, working and campaigning out of their historic base in Holborn, central London. For a society which often remarks on its own godlessness, we are curiously reluctant to stand up and declare how godless we are.

It is a fact that organised religion has never had it so bad. Only 3.7 million people now regularly attend church on Sunday; anecdotally, mosques and synagogues have the same problems of declining attendance and ageing congregations. The country ought to be fertile territory for organised atheism. But it isn't.

As the tide of religious observance has retreated, the humanists have retreated in step. Instead of embracing atheism after renouncing regular worship of God, Britons have lapsed into a Hollywood-fuelled dalliance with non-threatening ghosts and angels, an occasional nod to God at weddings or on Christmas Eve, and an all-embracing metaphysics which encourages any religion to speak without being heard. In politics, Anglo-Catholic Tories square off against Christian Socialist Labour.

"Paradoxically, religious influence in public life - now at its highest for a generation or more - seems to have risen in inverse proportion to the decline in Christianity," says Keith Porteous Wood, general secretary of the National Secular Society. "One gets the impression that non-religious views are off-message in New Labour, and I've yet to meet a Conservative politician who will tell me on the record that they don't believe. It's much easier for a member of parliament to come out as gay than come out as an atheist. That suggests we have a very long way to go."

Parents who would recoil from the thought of getting up every Sunday morning to eat and drink the flesh and blood of Christ in a draughty stone hall still baptise their children and fight tooth and nail to get them into the growing number of church schools. Voters who would flee from a party which pledged to rule Britain in accordance with biblical law shrug at the presence of unelected bishops in the House of Lords and acknowledge the existence of God from the first word of the national anthem.

"I think an awful lot of people are humanists without being aware of it," says Marilyn Mason, education officer at the British Humanist Association. "They don't call themselves humanists and they don't feel any need to join a humanist association. Humanism is essentially an intellectual commitment which can be made in private, without joining anything. That's our problem, really."

The public, popular face of humanism has ridden a bell curve since 1842, when George Holyoake, a powerful campaigner for secularism, became the last person in England to be imprisoned for being an atheist. His crime was to declare at a public meeting in Cheltenham, at a time of recession and spending cuts: "If I could have my way, I would place the deity on half pay as the government of this country did its subaltern officers."

As the 19th century wore on and the ideas of Charles Darwin and sceptical German theologians began to eat into the certainties of Christian faith, Holyoake and the founder of the National Secular Society, Charles Bradlaugh, toured the country, addressing crowds of thousands of people at tumultuous meetings which could last for days. The authorities, eager to shore up the ideological might of the then powerful Church of England, fought them every inch of the way. At one point, Bradlaugh addressed an audience from a barge moored a few feet off Devonport so as to be outside the jurisdiction of the local police.

Now-forgotten battles followed over universal access to contraception and the rights of non-Christian families to adopt; in the first half of the last century, engaged atheist philosophers such as Bertrand Russell and AJ Ayer took up the baton of crusading humanism.

What remains of a once-mighty movement, further winnowed by the tarnishing of atheist socialism's reputation in Stalin and Brezhnev's USSR, is spread between a group of organisations based in and around Red Lion Square in Holborn.

There is the South Place Ethical Society, owner of the Conway Hall, one of the last big venues for public meetings in the centre of the capital. They have only 350 members.

The British Humanist Association, round the corner in Theobald's Road, claims around 3,600, with two dozen affiliates countrywide.

Silence should not be taken as an admission of despair, but the third bastion of British atheism, the National Secular Society, refuses to discuss membership at all.

"I think the church and us have one problem in common," says Porteous Wood. "Young people and, as society goes on, people in general aren't interested in joining organisations, especially those with a moral or political dimension. There isn't the kind of communal idealism we saw at the turn of the previous century.

"I'm not going around trying to change people who believe. All I'm trying to do is make sure that what the religions are doing is not impinging on other people."

The humanist organisations don't lack prominent supporters. Among the honorary associates of the NSS are Iain Banks, Francis Crick, Richard Dawkins, Michael Foot, Ludovic Kennedy, George Melly, Jonathan Miller, Harold Pinter and Claire Rayner. What seems to be missing is the zealous footsoldiers to campaign on issues like the blurring of religion and ethics in the classroom.

Campus philosophers, too, are conspicuous by their reluctance to apply their disdain for religion to real life. "Philosophy departments are sometimes a little bit unwilling to participate in public debate, to try to live by their philosophies or even to admit they have any great contribution to make to the way we live," says Mason.

The BHA is trying to set up a philosophers' think tank to counter the pronouncements of religious leaders on moral issues. It takes comfort from polls showing that 40% of under-35s don't believe in God and almost two-thirds of teenagers aged 13 to 15 call themselves atheist or agnostic.

Yet polls can be fickle, and on issues of belief, it seems, the nature of the question and the context can cause particularly wild statistical swings. One 1999 survey found that 67% of people believed in God.

One problem for the atheists is that, much as priests may rant against the materialist society, it actually favours their vision of an afterlife. The more people come to value their possessions, personal identity and consumer comforts, the harder it is to imagine them vanishing into nothing. It is easy to see why the faint hope of a benign - or at least interesting - afterlife is more attractive than the certainty of nothingness after death. It's like the difference between having a one in 20 million chance of winning the lottery and not having a lottery ticket at all.

Another problem, pointed out by Jennifer Jeynes, of the South Place Ethical Society, is that humanists -by their very nature - are freethinkers. They don't want to bully people.

"We don't want to browbeat people into belief or frighten them with ideas of hell," she says. "That's part of the way the church became powerful in this country. Our aim is to make everybody's life as fulfilling as possible and not look for rewards in heaven.

"Part of the problem is that people aren't too interested in thinking, in intellectual pursuits. I think we've become a more pictorial age."

The growth in demand for non-religious ceremonies is, for now, the only sign that atheism as a worked-out ideology has a grip on British society. Last year, through its network of trained celebrants, the BHA arranged more than 2,500 funerals (24% up on the previous year), 200 weddings and 150 baby-naming ceremonies.

Of the baby-namings, Alan Marshall, a London humanist celebrant, says: "We will provide a solemn and dignified centrepiece to a family piss-up. It should be a party atmosphere but with just that little moment in the middle of the party when there's a moment of seriousness."

The funerals are correspondingly more sober. For an £80 fee, a BHA celebrant will interview the family of the deceased and compose a funeral oration. Dressed in ordinary black clothes, the celebrant introduces the occasion, makes a speech honouring the dead person's life, calls for a few minutes' reflection and, after the commital of the body, says a few concluding words.

"We don't just take a book off the shelf like a vicar does," says Marshall. "Each one is a piece of creative writing, and that takes a lot of time and mental energy."

The lack of atheist "converts", he says, is only natural; after all, people who aren't Manchester United fans don't feel that they need to join the Not Manchester United fan club. Marshall says: "People never see a reason to join up for something just because they're not members of something else."

The lack of atheist "converts", he says, is only natural; after all, people who aren't Manchester United fans don't feel that they need to join the Not Manchester United fan club. Marshall says: "People never see a reason to join up for something just because they're not members of something else."

fields.body:

French beef: Tourists visiting Norwich from France are being handed old travel guides that include a swimming pool that has been demolished and a museum that shut down four years ago.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
In 1916, the founder of the Italian futurist movement, Filippo Marinetti, breathlessly announced that "the magnificence of the world has been enriched by a new beauty, the beauty of speed". Speed could become the new religion of humanity, a faith to free us from the "decay caused by memory, analysis, repose and habit".

This year has already seen the publication of two academic texts arguing from different perspectives, but with equal passion, that many of us have already unwittingly converted to Marinetti's religion and regard speed as not merely a practical necessity but an unqualified good.

In a report to be published next month by the OECD, John Adams, professor of geography at University College London, uses the term "hypermobility" to capture our pathological desire to travel further and faster. Whereas in 1950 the average person in western Europe travelled only five miles a day, that figure has now grown to 28 miles a day, with the highest status being accorded to those citizens who can travel the greatest distance in the shortest amount of time.

Speed is also the villain of a new book, Ritalin Nation: Rapid-Fire Culture And The Transformation Of Human Consciousness, by an American psychologist, Richard DeGrandpre. The title refers to the drug which is used to treat attention deficit disorder (Add). In America, more than 2 million children are taking Ritalin and prescriptions in this country have soared from 2,000 in 1991 to 92,000 in 1997.

DeGrandpre scoffs at the idea that there is a biological basis to Add and argues instead that the widespread inability to concentrate found among American children (and adults) is entirely due to life in a "rapid-fire" culture in which they are constantly enjoined to find faster and faster ways of living, more and more ways to accumulate sensory experiences.

Marinetti could only be delighted at finding "analysis, repose and habit" so ruthlessly banished. In today's busy world, as Woody Allen once complained, there's hardly time for one's own suicide: "I'm going to kill myself. I should go to Paris and jump off the Eiffel Tower. I'll be dead. You know, in fact, if I get Concorde I could be dead three hours earlier, which would be perfect. Or wait a minute. With the time change, I could be alive for six hours in New York but dead three hours in Paris. I could get things done, and I could also be dead."

 Laurie Taylor presents Thinking Allowed on Radio 4 every Wednesday at 4pm.

fields.headline: A lawyer writes...
fields.trailText: What's in a name? The news that Monsanto is soon to be known as Pharmacia is part of an old Monsanto strategy, intended to allow a fresh start.
fields.body:
What's in a name? The news that Monsanto is soon to be known as Pharmacia is part of an old Monsanto strategy, intended to allow a fresh start. Other sales divisions of the corporation will now be known as Searle and Upjohn, with the name Monsanto retained solely for an independent agricultural subsidiary.

In 1997, I was in the process of issuing legal proceedings against Monsanto plc (the UK arm of the US-based multinational) for 165 neighbours of a rubber chemical factory. We had settled claims for about 120 neighbours who suffered chemical poisoning following a leak of hydrogen sulphide gas. Monsanto refused to settle any further claims and so litigation was inevitable.

My final check for the address for service of the writ revealed the alarming fact that Monsanto plc was in liquidation and had changed its name to Globalstrike plc. The liquidator told me that it was a company reorganisation. I threatened to intervene and disrupt the liquidation unless we were told who would meet the claims.

The next day, I was informed that Monsanto Chemicals UK Ltd would be responsible. A company search revealed that this company was a "shelf" company called Flextrex Ltd, created on December 20, 1996. A "shelf" company is created by company agents so it can be sold on to anyone in the future who wants a company. It saves them the time of creating one themselves.

The shelf company was bought by Monsanto International Holdings Inc, of St Louis, US, in March 1997. The company changed its name to Monsanto Chemicals UK Ltd on March 14, 1997. By September, its name had changed to Solutia UK Ltd.

The share transfer documentation on company records states that Monsanto Int. Holdings Inc paid for the shares with "assets transferred to the company pursuant to the Business Transfer Agreement between (1) Monsanto plc [another shelf company], (2) Globalstrike plc [the old Monsanto plc which had changed its name], and (3) Monsanto Chemicals UK Ltd [subsequently Solutia]".

Company records revealed that Solutia did not own anything except for responsibility for this legal action and any other legal actions brought against the non-life science divisions of the "old" Monsanto. The "new" Monsanto owned only the life science/GM business.

And so our case progressed against Solutia, with the company eventually agreeing to settle all but four of the 165 claims. A further claim we brought for a later leak at the same chemical factory is brought against Flexsys, which now owns all the rubber chemical factories in the UK that Monsanto used to run. It was also a shelf company and is also ultimately owned by Monsanto. This claim against Flexsys should come to trial this summer for 306 people.

 Dan Bennett is a lawyer with the London solicitors Leigh Day and Co, who act for individuals against corporations. www.leighday.co.uk

fields.headline: Back to basics
fields.standfirst: Peter Kendall on a GM backlash tilting the balance in Illinois
fields.trailText: Peter Kendall on a GM backlash tilting the balance in Illinois.
fields.body:
Last spring, Terry Wolf planted half of his central Illinois farm with GM soya seeds and they gave him, he says, an edge in the never-ending battle with weeds. This year, he'll plant none of the hi-tech beans. As Wolf and other farmers across the state prepare for spring planting, many are turning away from GM for the first time since the crops stormed the market in 1995.

They fear that the crops they sow might be hard to sell if controversy over GM organisms grows along with their corn and soybeans. "The issue is going to be too volatile to take that risk," Wolf says.

Farmers in the US are pinned in a scientific, political and emotional debate. The crops have raised environmental and health concerns, leading to a backlash against GM foods in Europe and Japan. No one can now predict whether a similar, though currently much smaller, backlash might grow into something big in the US.

The seed companies have staked their futures on the technology and say sales are on par with last year, and in some cases are stronger. But across Illinois, grain elevators, mills and corn processors are telling farmers there is no guarantee the crops grown from the seeds will fetch top dollar in the autumn.

Some, including Frito-Lay Inc, have begun telling their Illinois farmers not to plant any GM crops at all. Last year, 168 million lb of corn - some of it genetically engineered - was processed through Frito-Lay's main plant. This year, none of it will be GM.

"There is some consumer confusion out there, so we thought it was an appropriate time to step back and wait and see," says Lynn Markley, a spokeswoman for Texas-based Frito-Lay. Illinois Cereal Mills, owned by Cargill Inc, is increasing its contracts for non-GM crops. And Decatur's Archer Daniels Midland Co, one of the world's largest grain buyers, is paying premiums on every bushel of certain varieties of corn and soybeans that aren't GM.

The Illinois Corn Growers Association surveyed river terminals, processors and mills to see if companies had set policies for buying or handling GM grain. Many declined to respond, others wouldn't commit one way or the other. Mark Lambert, a spokesman for the association, says: "That is not what farmers want to hear. That sent a pretty strong message. We have definitely gotten the impression that, compared to last year, you are going to see less [GM] corn."

The federal government, too, is signalling that regulations might tighten on engineered crops. The Food and Drug Administration has been holding hearings on GM foods, and this month, the Environmental Protection Agency, in consultation with seed companies, placed new restrictions on plantings.

Farmers are seeing plenty of indicators that the marketplace might have a bias against GM crops by the time the harvest comes in. "We plant in April and May, but the marketplace has until October or November until it has to decide," says Ken Dalenberg, a farmer in Mansfield, Illinois. He will plant about half as much GM corn as last year.

Doug Whittaker, a seed dealer in Peoria county, says that farmers are buying about half as much geneti cally engineered corn as they did last spring. "They don't want to be stuck with a crop the market doesn't want," he says. Instead, the farmers are going back to varieties that have been bred and developed through more traditional means.

To some extent, Illinois farmers are a special case. Illinois is hooked into international markets more than many other Corn Belt states, exposing the state's farmers to the vagaries of the European and Japanese markets. "They are reading the tea leaves and seeing that there are not many advantages to genetically engineered crops, so they will perhaps go the other way," says Emerson Nafziger, a crop scientist at the University of Illinois.

 Peter Kendall is a reporter with the Chicago Tribune.

fields.headline: The best baby-sitting scene
fields.standfirst: Wonderland
fields.trailText: London. Nadia (Gina McKee) is babysitting for her nephew, Darren, the son of her sister Debbie (Shirley Henderson). As she wanders past his bedroom, she notices that, although he's in bed, he's still wide awake.
fields.body:
London. Nadia (Gina McKee) is babysitting for her nephew, Darren, the son of her sister Debbie (Shirley Henderson). As she wanders past his bedroom, she notices that, although he's in bed, he's still wide awake.

"You alright?" she enquires.

The answer is forlorn.

"Can't sleep."

"What's wrong?"

"I dunno," he shrugs. "Just can't sleep."

He fiddles with something beneath the covers.

"Well, you shouldn't be reading! What is it?"

Nervously, he pulls out a book. Nadia glances at the cover.

"What's that girl's name again?"

"Lara Croft."

Nadia smiles.

"Do you like her then?"

"She's alright."

Nadia gives him a playful nudge in the ribs. The pair of them start laughing.

"You've got to get some rest," she insists. "What are you doing tomorrow?"

"Going to the football match with me dad."

"That'll be nice. You'll need all the rest you can get then."

She moves towards the doorway.

"Come on. Put your head down."

See also: Don't Bother To Knock

Don't see also: Jack and Sarah, Don't Tell Mom The Babysitter's Dead, The Crazysitter

Pointless trivia: Gina McKee made her screen debut in the 1985 TV comedy series An Actor's Life For Me

fields.headline: Going fast
fields.standfirst: If the transfer of council property to associations  continues at today's rate, there could be none left  in 14 years. Matt Weaver on the end of an era
fields.trailText: If the transfer of council property to associations continues at today's rate, there could be none left in 14 years. Matt Weaver on the end of an era.
fields.body:
Until recently, the idea that council housing might one day be remembered as almost entirely a 20th-century phenomenon would have been regarded as right-wing fantasy, but now no one is quite so sure. The reason is that Labour-led councils, once the stout defenders of municipal control, are queuing up to transfer vast numbers of homes to housing associations and companies.

When the option of transfer was first introduced in 1988 it seemed an unlikely assassin of council housing. Under the policy, if tenants vote in favour of transfer, ownership of their homes switches to a housing association, which can then raise private funds.

Despite the apparent attraction of escaping from the constraints of the public borrowing rules, only true blue Tory shires took up the policy. For the first few years, only around 30,000 homes were hived off each year. Two inner-city Labour-controlled councils were eventually tempted, but not until 1996 and then only to switch a very small proportion of their stock. The vast majority of Labour councils regarded transfer as privatisation by the back-door.

They were holding out for a Labour government that would either put more money into housing, or relax the borrowing rules to allow councils to borrow themselves - or preferably both.

To get things moving, the Conservative housing minister, David Curry, proposed to force councils to switch 100,000 homes a year by threatening to withdraw funds if they did not. The current housing minister, Nick Raynsford, described the policy then as "the last desperate convulsions of a dying government". He added: "Simply transferring stock from one landlord to another does nothing to make up the shortage of resources, which everyone knows is acute."

Now, three years later, councils have been given a bit more housing money with the release of capital receipts from right-to-buy sales, but the borrowing rules are still firmly in place. And it is now Labour-led councils that dominate the list bidding to switch homes.

The two biggest social landlords in Britain - Glasgow and Birmingham - are heading the queue, and the number of homes involved is more than Curry ever dreamed of. In England alone, councils owning nearly 300,000 homes are bidding to transfer next year. This is more homes than the last six years of transfers put together, and it will increase the housing association sector by a quarter in one go.

One of the councils bidding is Labour-led Blackburn with Darwen. Steve Greenwood, chair of housing and community services, says: "In a ideal world, we would want to keep control, but we recognise that, in reality, that is not possible. We can see no other way to get access to the finance we need. Under Labour, our housing money has doubled, but it is not enough."

The government has made transfer possible for councils like Blackburn with Darwen by agreeing to write off their housing debts if the sell-off price from transfer does not cover those debts.

Greenwood says he is grateful for this, but says that he and other Labour councillors were hoping for more. "There was some expectation that there would be new methods of funding council housing under Labour," he says. "People were holding on." But with the backlog of repairs mounting up, many councils can't hold on any longer. "We need urgent access to big resources," says Greenwood.

Given the current level of interest, transfer will arguably have more impact than the Conserva tives' right-to-buy policy. Around 1.7 million council homes have been bought under right-to-buy, but the figures are no longer rising steeply. The number of homes transferred will soon overtake this number. And if it carries on at this rate, there will be virtually no council housing left in 14 years.

I t is now David Curry's turn to mock. Writing in last week's Housing Today, he blamed councils' previous opposition to transfer on their "Stalinist mind-set" and he gleefully noted that those now bidding to switch read like a "roll-call of municipal empires".

But before council housing is written off completely it is worth remembering that councillors themselves are still very reluctant to transfer. When Housing Today polled 100 Labour housing chairs, 70 said they expected to keep the ownership of their homes under council control. Will they only change their minds if funds are squeezed in future? More importantly, there is a growing minority of councils which have attempted to transfer but have been blocked by tenants voting against the plan. This group of councils, which is bound to grow as more attempt transfer, poses an awkward problem for government: will they be forced to ballot tenants again and again until they come up with the right answer?

For other councils with poor quality stock and high debts, transfer will not be financially viable even after a debt write-off from government. Will these authorities be left on the shelf?

In 10 years, the ownership of social housing will be unrecognisable from what we have known for the better part of a century. But there are some tricky questions for government to answer along the way.

 Matt Weaver is a reporter on Housing Today.

The government has made transfer possible for councils like Blackburn with Darwen by agreeing to write off their housing debts if the sell-off price from transfer does not cover those debts. Greenwood says he is grateful for this, but says that he and other Labour councillors were hoping for more. "There was some expectation that there would be new methods of funding council housing under Labour," he says. "People were holding on." But with the backlog of repairs mounting up, many councils can't hold on any longer. "We need urgent access to big resources," says Greenwood. Given the current level of interest, transfer will arguably have more impact than the Conserva tives' right-to-buy policy. Around 1.7 million council homes have been bought under right-to-buy, but the figures are no longer rising steeply. The number of homes transferred will soon overtake this number. And if it carries on at this rate, there will be virtually no council housing left in 14 years. I t is now David Curry's turn to mock. Writing in last week's Housing Today, he blamed councils' previous opposition to transfer on their "Stalinist mind-set" and he gleefully noted that those now bidding to switch read like a "roll-call of municipal empires". But before council housing is written off completely it is worth remembering that councillors themselves are still very reluctant to transfer. When Housing Today polled 100 Labour housing chairs, 70 said they expected to keep the ownership of their homes under council control. Will they only change their minds if funds are squeezed in future? More importantly, there is a growing minority of councils which have attempted to transfer but have been blocked by tenants voting against the plan. This group of councils, which is bound to grow as more attempt transfer, poses an awkward problem for government: will they be forced to ballot tenants again and again until they come up with the right answer? For other councils with poor quality stock and high debts, transfer will not be financially viable even after a debt write-off from government. Will these authorities be left on the shelf? In 10 years, the ownership of social housing will be unrecognisable from what we have known for the better part of a century. But there are some tricky questions for government to answer along the way.  Matt Weaver is a reporter on Housing Today.

webTitle: Mirror editor faces inquiry over shares

fields.headline: Mirror editor faces inquiry over shares
fields.trailText: Mirror editor Piers Morgan faces an inquiry over whether he broke the newspaper code of practice by buying a stake in a company the day before his paper predicted its shares would be sent "soaring" by the launch of a new internet division.
fields.body:
Mirror editor Piers Morgan faces an inquiry over whether he broke the newspaper code of practice by buying a stake in a company the day before his paper predicted its shares would be sent "soaring" by the launch of a new internet division.

According to reports, on January 17 Mr Morgan bought about £20,000 worth of shares in Viglen Technology, a company owned by Sir Alan Sugar.

The next day the Mirror's "City Slickers" column unveiled plans for Viglen's new internet business, under the headline "Sugar to join net goldrush". Sir Alan also writes an occasional column in the Mirror.

Viglen shares jumped from 181p to 366p that day. Today the shares were trading at 231p.

The chairman of the press complaints commission, Lord Wakeham, said he had received a complaint about Mr Morgan. "We will be dealing with this complaint in the normal manner under the code of practice, unless any other form of investigation prevents us from doing so."

Lord Wakeham also set out the code's provisions relating to financial journalism. He said they made clear that:

  • Even where the law does not prohibit it, journalists must not use for their own profit financial information they receive in advance of its general publication, nor should they pass such information to others.
  • Journalists must not write about shares or securities in whose performance they know that they or their close families have a significant financial interest, without disclosing the interest to the editor or financial editor.
  • Journalists must not buy or sell, either directly or through nominees or agents, shares or securities about which they have written recently or about which they intend to write in the future.

    The story was gleefully picked up by the Sun, its main competitor, who this morning called on Mr Morgan to be sacked. But Mr Morgan told the Daily Telegraph: "It was nothing to do with the column. I never see the City column before the market shuts, the first I see of it is around 6.30 or 7.00 p.m. in the evening." He said he had been amused by the price rise but added: "I was going to buy them anyway."

    Mr Morgan said: "I would never do anything improper. I do not go sneaking over to see what The Mirror's tip of the day was."

webTitle: Talks resume to stop Stormont suspension

fields.headline: Talks resume to stop Stormont suspension
fields.trailText: The government is making a last-ditch attempt to save the peace process in Northern Ireland by holding talks in Belfast today, as it emerged that General John de Chastelain would meet the IRA once again over the decommissioning issue.
fields.body:
The government is making a last-ditch attempt to save the peace process in Northern Ireland by holding talks in Belfast today, as it emerged that General John de Chastelain would meet the IRA once again over the decommissioning issue.

General de Chastelain, whose report on the failure of the IRA to begin decommissioning their weapons triggered the current crisis, is likely to hold fresh talks with the IRA over the coming days.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson will meet republicans and unionists, while Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams talks to Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister.

Mr Ahern acknowledged that if the de Chastelain report shows no progress, "we are in major difficulties".

"We have to keep on trying. It is disappointing, quite frankly, that we have lost so much time," he said.

United States president Bill Clinton is also involved in the frenetic shuttle diplomacy aimed at rescuing the eight-week-old Stormont administration and preventing a return to direct rule from London. He urged all sides to find agreement on the issue, saying the Good Friday agreement "is working and it would be a tragedy if it was derailed".

Mr Adams insisted yesterday he made no promises over decommissioning during last year's Mitchell review of the Good Friday agreement.

But Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble is adamant that Sinn Fein defaulted on its obligations on arms, and that suspension of the executive and a review were "regrettable but inevitable".

Sinn Fein continued to caution against abandoning the power-sharing government in the new assembly despite the failure of the IRA to begin decommissioning. Putting Northern Ireland's new government on hold would be a "disaster of enormous proportions", Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness warned.

He warned the Ulster Unionists: "To be part of anything that would see the destruction of the hard-gotten gains of recent times would be seen by the vast majority of our community as very, very poor leadership," he said.

"The ordinary people out there that support the Good Friday Agreement do think it's absolutely crazy for anyone to contemplate the destruction of the executive."

The British government is thought to consider that the suspension of the fledgling power-sharing executive the lesser of two evils to stop Mr Trimble quitting as first minister.

Mr Mandelson suggested a cooling off period for the province's overheated politicians.

"I think everyone needs a bit of breathing space, however short, in order to see whether we can't find a breakthrough at this stage," he told reporters.

webTitle: 'Delighted' Portillo pledges loyalty to Hague and sterling

fields.headline: 'Delighted' Portillo pledges loyalty to Hague and sterling
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo sealed his comeback to the Tory front bench today with a declaration of loyalty to the leader many people believe he wants to replace.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo sealed his comeback to the Tory front bench today with a declaration of loyalty to the leader many people believe he wants to replace.

The new shadow chancellor said he had been "building up quite a friendship" with Conservative leader William Hague over recent years.

"It has been a strengthening relationship," Mr Portillo. "I don't know two Conservatives who think more closely together."

Mr Hague dramatically brought in the former defence secretary to his team last night in a mini-reshuffle which also saw the sacking of environment spokesman John Redwood and shadow foreign secretary John Maples.

Mr Portillo, who might well have become Tory leader after the last election if he had not lost his Enfield Southgate seat, denied that his new job - effectively number two in the shadow cabinet -was "a poisoned chalice".

Though he has been more hardline in his opposition to a European single currency than Mr Hague, who has only ruled out joining for the duration of the next parliament, Mr Portillo said his views on the euro were "entirely consistent" with his leader. But he added that Britain was unlikely to join the euro - which was performing "spectacularly badly" - because the European exchange rate "will almost certainly not be right for Britain all of the time".

"People who favour the euro say that these constitutional implications can be handled, that they are not as important as we think they might be," Mr Portillo told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "I think this is where people are driven mad by the government - the government pretending that if control of monetary policy passes away from Britain, that that doesn't have constitutional implications. Of course it does."

He defended the party's current position, saying: "What William Hague has said - with commendable modesty - is, 'Alright, I am prepared to believe that one day you might be able to resolve these problems. I can't see how you could, but what's for sure is that all these problems couldn't be sorted out in the coming parliament.'

"The proper position is for us in the next manifesto to be against the euro, so that people know that if they want to save the pound, there is only one way to do it and that is to vote for the Conservative Party."

After his return to parliament in the Kensington and Chelsea by-election two months ago, Mr Portillo would have been happy to remain on the backbenchers, Mr Portillo said. But his friendship with Mr Hague meant that he was "obviously pleased but perhaps not quite as surprised as some other people". He was "very pleased and very flattered and delighted to be in the Hague team".

He backed Mr Hague's promises to cut taxes and increase spending on public services in the next Tory administration. "The burden of taxation can be reduced as long as you don't have a profligate government.

"When the economy is growing, why does the government feel that it has got to help itself to the same proportion of the increase in wealth and take more money out of people's pockets? If you have a government that is careful with taxpayers' money, that won't happen."

Former Asda supermarket chairman Archie Norman has taken over Mr Redwood's former job, but faces problems divesting of potential conflicts of interests in his business dealings. Shadow chancellor Francis Maude moves to foreign affairs.

Mr Redwood let it be known he took more than 100 calls from Conservative MPs on Tuesday night, all offering support.

Education and employment secretary David Blunkett said the new Tory team was the most right-wing group ever to have held the top jobs.

fields.headline: 'Do I look like Mrs Doyle?'
fields.standfirst: From a tea-toting old bat in Father Ted to a novelist who commands a six-figure advance.  Emma Brockes  meets Pauline McLynn
fields.trailText: Even Pauline McLynn's anecdotes have subplots. The 37-year-old who plays Mrs Doyle, tea-bearing old bat in Father Ted, can talk. Blimey, she can talk; leaning forward in a hotel armchair, hands working a circuit, she goes at it like a swimmer at the underwater record. "Normally people recognise my voice, in the post office or at the vet's - which is very chi-chi, it takes American Express - and they say, 'You know, you sound exactly like Mrs Doyle.' I was going up Brixton Road on a sunny morning - I was dressed as me - and a young fellow went by on a bike and yelled, 'Hey, Mrs Doyle!' I dragged myself into rehearsals saying, 'Do I look old today? Do I look really raddled?'"
fields.body:
Even Pauline McLynn's anecdotes have subplots. The 37-year-old who plays Mrs Doyle, tea-bearing old bat in Father Ted, can talk. Blimey, she can talk; leaning forward in a hotel armchair, hands working a circuit, she goes at it like a swimmer at the underwater record. "Normally people recognise my voice, in the post office or at the vet's - which is very chi-chi, it takes American Express - and they say, 'You know, you sound exactly like Mrs Doyle.' I was going up Brixton Road on a sunny morning - I was dressed as me - and a young fellow went by on a bike and yelled, 'Hey, Mrs Doyle!' I dragged myself into rehearsals saying, 'Do I look old today? Do I look really raddled?'"

She's small and slightly myopic, dressed in brown, breathlessly chasing recollections in an Irish lilt that trembles with suppressed laughter. McLynn continues the tradition of young women who have kick-started their careers by playing dotty old dames: Julie Walters' Mrs Overall, Caroline Aherne's Mrs Merton. After three series of loyal service to Father Ted, it is starting to pay off.

She can currently be seen in Angela's Ashes, playing Aunt Aggie, but more importantly has a first novel out this week and is writing a second. Something for the Weekend is a pastiche of several styles that tells of a 30-year-old private detective from Dublin on the trail of a philandering aristocrat. Melodrama mingles with modern self-parody and some odd lyrical asides. "Who spirits these gentle giants from place to place?" muses the heroine at one point. "And where do they go to when they're not needed any more?" She is referring to construction cranes.

This should not detract from the admirable breeziness with which McLynn nailed a six-figure advance and wrote the book in the gaps between filming. "I'm not at the literature end of things, so I get a bit worried that people will think I'm pretentious," she says. Her aversion to purple prose is a theme to which she frequently returns. "I love reading novels and I tried to write the sort of book that I like to read."

It had not been her lifelong ambition to write; she didn't fret away at the manuscript for years. McLynn looked around her, noted the number of actors - including Father Ted co-star Ardal O'Hanlon - who were knocking out novels, and thought, "Damn, I could do that." And she did. "I just had a go. I did it to see if I could. Then the publishing deal got done and that was even better because I love a deadline."

McLynn settled down at her laptop and, with businesslike application, wrote up to 2,000 words a day. Until then, her experience of writing had been limited to a degree in English and art history at Trinity college, Dublin. She approached her studies with much the same attitude as the novel: "I thought, 'I've read loads of books, I'll be able to do this.' I was the worst student ever. I didn't want to analyse things."

Instead of bothering herself with academic work, McLynn spent her time organising student productions. "I was very bossy when I was a student. Everybody thought I would go into arts administration, but I didn't know anything about organising money." After graduation, she got a job at a fringe theatre in Dublin, a ramshackle introduction to acting which seduced her nonetheless. "At lunchtime, they'd do Yeats for the tourists. Happily, I never had to be in a Yeats production, because I'd rather poke out my eyes with a pointy stick."

Voiceover work kept her solvent and let her indulge in her first love: theatre. From the start of her career, however, McLynn's fidgety manner and snubby features rec ommended her for character parts. She is relaxed about it now, but in the early days it was a source of sensitivity. "I never got the romantic leads," she says, wringing her hands. "I was a bit touchy about it in the beginning. I'd always get the daft-old-lady part. Even now, people say to me, 'Are you not done with cranky old bats?' And I'll say, 'No, they're great.'"

Father Ted was the great transformer. For weeks, producers resisted casting her because they thought she was too young for the part, but eventually she joined the team. McLynn is proud of the work they did together, but prouder of the fact that when Alan Parker auditioned her for Angela's Ashes, he had never seen it. "I read for a small part, a day's work. I didn't realise when I went to see Alan Parker that the part of Aunt Aggie was up for grabs. He doesn't really speak to you, which is a good thing."

Good, because her inclination to embark on runaway anecdotes when nervous is something she suspects has cost her serious roles. "I have often gone in for a straight reading and there'll be a silence afterwards, which I'll feel obliged to fill and will talk myself out of the part. By the time you are leav ing you want to say, 'I know, there's no need to call.'"

In spite of the grim subject-matter - Frank McCourt's recollections of his poverty-stricken upbringing in Limerick - McLynn found the five weeks on set with Emily Watson, Robert Carlyle et al an uplifting time. The story reminded her of her own parents' lives. Both grew up in Sligo, north-west Ireland, where her father still sells car parts and her mother is a bookkeeper.

"The film is beautiful. There's a moment where me and Emily are washing little Frank and it's like a Caravaggio. Even though my parents hadn't experienced that level of poverty, they knew people that had. It's the story of a generation."

Storytelling, says McLynn, is now a main focus of her career. She is knuckling down at her Dublin and Kilkenny homes, which she shares with producer husband Richard Cook, to concentrate on the sequel to Something for the Weekend. The narrative is detailed to the point of stage directions, and film rights cannot be a far-off possibility.

McLynn is uncharacteristically intimidated about converting the book into a screenplay, however. "I would never presume to be a screenwriter. You have to be born with a certain genius for that." Her genius is perhaps rarer: for following through idle plans to a very satisfactory conclusion.

 Something for the Weekend, by Pauline McLynn, is published by Headline, priced £9.99, tomorrow.
