webTitle: How to shop for Valentine's Day online

fields.headline: How to shop for Valentine's Day online
fields.standfirst: If you're taking the plunge and shopping for that special love token on the net this year, Jim McClellan has some advice on how to avoid the heartbreak
fields.trailText: If you can manage the basics of browsing the web, you'll be fine at the online shops.
fields.body:
If you can manage the basics of browsing the web, you'll be fine at the online shops.

At most places, you can find what you're after either by using the site's search engine or by browsing more generally through a directory of products. When you've found something suitable, you usually click a 'Buy' button, which adds the item in question to your online 'shopping basket'. If you want to pay, you then have to go to the 'Checkout', where you fill out an order form, give your name, address, credit/debit card details and the rest.

Security

Obviously, security is a big concern for many. To a certain extent, the risks of shopping online have been exaggerated. However, you do need to take precautions. Don't buy at an online store that doesn't offer you 'secure' shopping. Most net shops use something called Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) encryption technology to keep your personal details safe. Simplifying things a little, your personal information is scrambled so no one can read it as it moves over the net.

There are various ways you can check you're shopping at a secure site. When you have to enter your credit card details, you should be moved into the secure part of the site. A little padlock should appear in the bottom right-hand frame of your browser (in older browsers you may see a key - if the key is broken, your connection isn't secure). Alternatively, the web address in the location bar at the top of the browser will start with 'https' and not 'http' as usual.

Secure shopping is important - and you should never send credit card details via unencrypted email. But it's perfectly possible for a determined fraudster to set up a secure shopping site and then fail to deliver the goods. So the other thing you should do before you spend money is check out the site. Look for a real-world address and telephone number. Don't shop at sites that only give email contact addresses. If something looks dubious, give the site a call. See what they have to say about security. Many reputable online retailers now offer to cover costs if credit card fraud results from purchases made at their sites. And the card companies themselves will usually cover losses incurred through fraud (after the first £50).

During the order process, you're usually shown a summary screen at some point. This will have all the details of your purchase. Save it and print it out. It's your receipt. Many of the best online retailers will also send you an email after you order, confirming all the details of the transaction that has just taken place. You should also save and print this.

Delivery

Before you buy anything, check out delivery costs and times (look for details in the 'Help' or 'Customer Service' sections of a site). Sometimes sites with the cheapest prices try to claw back something via delivery charges.

As for delivery times, although new net retailers pride themselves on speedy delivery, many of the old-style mail order firms now online take rather longer (a couple of weeks is not unheard of). Obviously you want your Valentine's cards and gifts to arrive on the day (or just before). So check things out before you place an order.

Many sites seem to be guaranteeing a February 14 delivery if you order early enough. Some list deadlines, beyond which goods will not arrive. If you're unsure, double check with the site itself. Remember (especially if you're buying books or CDs) to check product availability (where possible) and take that into account. For example, on many sites, it will say whether a particular item is available to be dispatched in 24 hours or a few days. You need to then add this time to the promised delivery time to get a real idea of when your goods will arrive.

General Tips

Shop around. It's easy to do on the net - other shops are, as the ecommerce gurus say, just a click away. If one store doesn't have what you want or seems rather pricey or can't deliver in time, another place may be able to help you out. There are sites that will research the best prices on books, CDs and videos for you. You just enter the name of the thing you want to buy and they come back with a list of prices and links. However, at the moment, they don't cover chocolates and flowers. So if you want to save money as you pledge your undying love, you'll have to click around yourself.

Plan ahead. As many people discovered at Christmas, it's definitely a good idea to start shopping early online. Goods go out of stock and, as business peaks, sites need more time to get things to you. With Valentine's Day, it's hard to say how busy online retailers will be. But it's still worth starting early, especially if you're looking for something out of the ordinary at one of the auction sites.

Many sites are offering special gift services, in which they will wrap a present for you, enclose a card with a personal message and send it all on to the one you love - anonymously, if you wish, which is convenient.

Ask the site If there's anything you don't understand as you're browsing a site. If you can't figure out how to get what you want, if you need a little advice, email the site in question. Many net shops are trying to establish a reputation for good customer service, to show that they can compete with real-world shops.

Take your time. OK, the telephone bill is running. But an extra five or ten minutes isn't going to hurt. Online shopping is a new thing. It's easy to make mistakes - over delivery times and availability especially. It's much better to be sure you've got everything right, especially where Valentine's messages are concerned. So take it slowly as you go through filling out the forms. Make sure the message and wrapping paper are the kind of things you want.

Check before you shop from work If you're net shopping at the office, make sure it's OK with the boss. People have been sacked for spending too much time bargain hunting online. Ten minutes spent quickly ordering some flowers probably isn't going to be a problem. And it's much better than leaving the office for an hour to do it in the real world. But check anyway.

Use your real-world shopping skills. This is an all-purpose tip, good for any time of the year really. Whatever people say, the net isn't that different from the real world. The shopping smarts you've built up from years of pounding the high street still work online. If a deal looks too good to be true, it probably is.

webTitle: Spike Jonze to direct F Scott Fitzgerald adaptation

fields.headline: Spike Jonze to direct F Scott Fitzgerald adaptation
fields.trailText: The Being John Malkovich could have found another surreal project to suit his talents
fields.body:
Beastie Boys video director turned surrealist film-maker Spike Jonze is in final negotiations to direct Benjamin Button, a film based on F Scott Fitzgerald's absurdist short story, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button. Charting much the same bizarre territory as Jonze's latest film, Being John Malkovich, Benjamin Button is about a man who physically regresses as those around him age. At 50 he falls in love with a 30-year-old woman and must reap the consequences as he begins to grow younger as she grows old.

The project, which has been in development for more than a decade, with directors such as Ron Howard, Phil Alden Robinson and Agnieszka Holland all showing interest, will now probably be developed by Jonze and Charlie Kaufman who wrote Being John Malkovich.

 Being John Malkovich is released in the UK on March 17, but Spike Jonze can be seen before then as the redneck soldier in Three Kings, released on March 3.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.standfirst: The secrets behind the stars' odd clauses • Could The Matrix 2 and 3 be filmed in the UK • Whitney Houston to be the Diva
fields.trailText: The secrets behind the stars' odd clauses • Could The Matrix 2 and 3 be filmed in the UK • Whitney Houston to be the Diva
fields.body:
The stars' odd clauses

The late Steve McQueen would only make a movie if he could take his clothes off, according to an American survey into contract clauses of the stars. The not-so-self-effacing star would not sign a new deal for a movie unless he could strip off, reckoning that women only watched his films to see his body (he may have had a point there).

Woody Allen, on the other hand, will not do love scenes with his shoes off, just in case there is a fire on the set. Other odd contract clauses include Peter Lorre's insistence that he never be examined by a film company doctor and Peter Sellers' demand that he should not be put in a purple dressing room and that all hotel beds must face east to west.

In brief

Joel Silver, the producer of The Matrix, has been seen sniffing around Pinewood and Leavesden studios enquiring about booking space for a 300-day shoot - just the timespan to film Matrix 2 and Matrix 3 - according to a rumour on Dark Horizons.

Chow Yun Fat, who stars opposite Jodie Foster in the film Anna and the King, will join old blubber queen Gwyneth Paltrow as one of the presenters of this year's Oscars ceremony.

Billy Crystal and Jamie Lee Curtis are to be honoured with the Hasty Pudding awards at Harvard university. The award is America's oldest, given out by an undergraduate drama group. As tradition dictates, Curtis will lead a parade through the streets of Harvard Square accompanied by male students dressed in drag. A week later Crystal will be the guest at a roast dinner and will have to don bra and wig for the occasion. Past winners of the award include Jodie Foster, Meg Ryan, Julia Roberts, Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks.

Casting couch

 Whitney Houston is to play the title role in a remake of the French thriller, Diva. Will Smith's production company, Overbrook Entertainment, has bought the rights to the 1981 film about a postman who makes an illegal recording of an opera diva and finds himself mixed up with some very nasty criminals.

fields.headline: The US primaries
fields.trailText:
What's the fuss about in New Hampshire?
Supporters of the Democrat and Republican parties have been choosing who they want to be their parties presidential candidate in the November election. The Democrat frontrunner, vice-president Al Gore beat Bill Bradley, the former New Jersey senator and basketball star. That was good for Gore because a few months ago he looked in trouble in New Hampshire and was tipped to lose. John McCain, an Arizona senator and war hero, heavily beat George W. Bush, son of the former US president. That result throws the race open although Bush is still the favourite.
fields.body:
What's the fuss about in New Hampshire?
Supporters of the Democrat and Republican parties have been choosing who they want to be their parties presidential candidate in the November election. The Democrat frontrunner, vice-president Al Gore beat Bill Bradley, the former New Jersey senator and basketball star. That was good for Gore because a few months ago he looked in trouble in New Hampshire and was tipped to lose. John McCain, an Arizona senator and war hero, heavily beat George W. Bush, son of the former US president. That result throws the race open although Bush is still the favourite.

Why is New Hampshire so important?
It has long been regarded as a crucial marker in the presidential campaign. The tiny state is determined to hold on to its place in the election calendar - when other states move their primaries forward, New Hampshire just moves its contest even further forward. Any candidate with a realistic chance of winning their party's nomination has to do well in New Hampshire. That doesn't mean they have to come first: Bill Clinton came second in 1992, but it was better than expected after a sex scandal and he coined himself the "Comeback Kid". The election gives candidates "bounce" to go on to fight contests in other states. Some outsider candidates like the Republicans Alan Keyes and Gary Bauer may find it hard to raise money and could drop out. Steve Forbes is very unlikely to become the Republican candidate but is a multi-millionaire so will probably battle on to the bitter end.

Is it a good thing that New Hampshire is so important?
Some people complain that the New Hampshire - small, rural, conservative, overwhelmingly white - is not a proper reflection of America and has too much power. Others say it is good for candidates to have to meet small groups of voters and listen to their concerns - what Americans call "retail politics", rather than fighting the kind of remote, mass-market , big-money election campaign they will end up with later.

Do all the states have a primary or a caucus?
Yes. Delegates from the states will go to their party's conventions in the summer and cast their votes on behalf of their chosen candidate, and the winner takes the party's nomination. The states get a certain number of delegates in proportion to their population. Before the primary system was set up, these conventions used to be much more nerve-wracking. In recent years the result has been a foregone conclusion by the time the conventions come around and the parties try and use the conventions as a stage-managed rally to launch their election campaign.

Who can vote in a primary?
US parties don't have members as such, but registered supporters. They don't have to pay subscription but are marked as supporters on the electoral roll. In most primaries, only Republicans can vote in the Republican primary and only Democrats in the Democrat primary. In New Hampshire, confusingly, independent voters - that is, voters not registered for either party - can choose to vote in one of the primaries. They can't vote in both.

So what happened in Iowa last week?
That was a caucus, where supporters had to attend a meeting to cast their votes. That was important too, but not quite as important. Bush and Gore won well. McCain didn't bother campaigning there, preferring instead to pick and choose the states he fights in. Partly this is tactical, partly because he is short of money compared to Bush.

What happens next?
Bush is contesting the Delaware primary next week, but not McCain. They next square up in South Carolina on February 19. Bush is ahead there but a good showing by McCain again could be very damaging to him. Democrats go on to "Super Tuesday" - what Bill Bradley calls "the first national primary" - primaries and caucus in 14 states including heavily-populated California, New York and Ohio. Bradley is doing well in New York.

When does it all wind up?
The final primaries are on June 6 in Alabama, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota. The Republican National Convention will be held on July 31-August 3 in Philadelphia; the Democrats equivalent on August 14-17 in Los Angeles. Then it's full steam ahead until presidential election day proper, November 7, 2000.

fields.headline: Lockerbie suspects plead not guilty
fields.trailText:
The two Libyan suspects in the Lockerbie bombing today pleaded
innocent at a pretrial hearing, the first time a plea has been formally taken in this landmark prosecution.
fields.body:
The two Libyan suspects in the Lockerbie bombing today pleaded innocent at a pretrial hearing, the first time a plea has been formally taken in this landmark prosecution.

The two defendants, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, 47, and Al Ami Khalifa Fhimah, 43, were absent and their plea was entered by their defence counsel, Bill Taylor, at the high court in Edinburgh.

The trial itself is scheduled to begin May 3 at a former US air base in the Netherlands under an unprecedented arrangement that transplants a Scottish court system on to Dutch soil. The carefully crafted arrangement was designed to meet Libyan demands for impartiality.

The not guilty plea came amid reports of difficulties in the prosecution's case. Last month, the Scotland on Sunday newspaper reported that the prosecution's star witness had watered down his testimony that he saw Al-Megrahi placing a suspicious suitcase on the luggage carousel at Malta airport, where both of them worked. That suitcase allegedly made its way to Frankfurt and then London, where prosecutors say it was placed aboard Pan Am 103.

When defence attorneys recently interviewed the witness, identified as Libyan defector Abu Maged Jiacha, in the US, he said he saw someone who looked like Al Megrahi take the suitcase off the carousel. Prosecutors may request a further postponement of the trial, due to serious difficulties with their case.

But further delays are unlikely as the trial has been postponed twice already, at the defence team's request, since Libya surrendered the suspects last April. Today's hearing was a continuation of an earlier procedural hearing in December at Camp Zeist in Holland, which had ended amid legal arguments over a bid by the Crown for prosecution witnesses to disguise their identities.

In December, prosecutors requested permission to have witnesses appear in disguises. They argued that identification by the public would jeopardise the lives and livelihoods and the witnesses. Many among the more than 1,000 prosecution witnesses are present or former employees of US and European intelligence agencies.

In a surreal touch, Mr Jiacha wore a blonde woman's wig and heavy makeup during his encounter with defence lawyers, held in the back of a van travelling through suburban Washington.

fields.headline: Crowe goes plum crazy
fields.standfirst: Today, Russell Crowe may soon star in Foster's new film | Being Benjamin Button | The stars' odd clauses | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Today, Russell Crowe may soon star in Foster's new film | Being Benjamin Button | The stars' odd clauses | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.body:
The reason behind Russell Crowe and Jodie Foster's very public display of affection at this year's Golden Globes, where the couple were seen smooching on and off the dance floor, can now be revealed. Crowe is in negotiations to star in Foster's new film, Flora Plum.

If the talks go according to plan, the Australian star, who has had numerous plaudits heaped upon him for his role as the whistle-blower in The Insider, will play a circus "freak" who falls desperately in love with an orphan girl during the Depression. Foster's protege Claire Danes will play the waif who wants to become famous.

Steven Rodgers, who penned the Sandra Bullock/Harry Connick Jnr romantic comedy Hope Floats, has written the script, which Foster's company, Egg Productions, will produce with Sixth Sense producer Barry Mendel.

Foster's fourth directorial outing had been scheduled for a spring start, but as Crowe is signed up for two projects - an untitled film with Meg Ryan, and an adaptation of a Vanity Fair article, called Adventures in the Ransom Trade - the starting date has been put back until late summer or early autumn, which begs the question: does Foster now have time to reprise her role of FBI agent Clarice Starling in Hannibal after all?

fields.headline: Wide of the Mark
fields.standfirst: WSC thinks that Football Focus isn't the place to air old-fashioned prejudices. Mark Lawrenson stands accused.
fields.trailText: WSC thinks that Football Focus isn't the place to air old-fashioned prejudices. Mark Lawrenson stands accused.
fields.body:
And there were we, thinking the Premier League's new "leniency" policy for referees was about letting the game flow. Something to do with more football being played and less players being sent off unnecessarily.

But then along came Mark Lawrenson to put us straight. Discussing the performance of Paul Durkin in last month's Manchester United v Arsenal game on Football Focus, Lawrenson waxed lyrical about the new licence given to the top professional players. And why? "Because it's not a little girls' game, is it?"

To his credit, Ray Stubbs had the decency to be embarrassed on behalf of the BBC, attempting to point out that in these modern times, it was meant to be a game for everyone, wasn't it. But Lawrenson had a ready riposte. "Yes, Ray, but you know what I mean. Manchester United v Arsenal is not a game for little girls."

I think we probably do know what he means. Could be wrong, but let's hazard a guess. Our guess is that what he means is really two things. The first is that the game's a better game when players are allowed to get away with a certain amount of low-key physical violence, provided it doesn't get out of hand. And you could make a reasonable argument that that is true, although in the Seventies they were saying the same kind of thing and then they meant you could go round kicking lumps out of everything that moved.

The second thing is that you don't really think football is a game for girls, little or big. Which is a shame, when the most successful women's World Cup took place last year and football clubs everywhere are, in theory, welcoming new customers of all ages and both genders.

Talking about refereeing and Manchester United v Arsenal isn't necessarily the time and place to do something positive to encourage a broader audience for football. But it should be at least required of BBC pundits that they rein in their most old-fashioned prejudices for the duration of a popular Saturday lunchtime football show.

It's not about political correctness, it's about recognising your responsibilities and spotting any chances that come your way to make football more inclusive and less of a boys' club. Lawrenson missed his - and frankly my one-year-old daughter could have put that one away.

webTitle: Eclectic squad pays tribute to Clark

fields.headline: Eclectic squad pays tribute to Clark
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText:
Last week I attended the memorial service for the former Guardian editor, Alastair Hetherington. It was a gathering of herbivores, clustered for safety around the water hole. 

Yesterday I attended the corresponding service for Alan Clark, and found myself surrounded by so many red-blooded carnivores
fields.body:
Last week I attended the memorial service for the former Guardian editor, Alastair Hetherington. It was a gathering of herbivores, clustered for safety around the water hole.

Yesterday I attended the corresponding service for Alan Clark, and found myself surrounded by so many red-blooded carnivores: Lords Tebbit and Lamont, Michael Portillo, Michael Howard, and Sir Denis Thatcher, who in her absence abroad was the continuation of his wife by other means. But Clark was such an eclectic, protean figure that the guests spanned most of British politics, including the wettest of wet Tories - George Young, Nicholas Scott and Peter Bottomley.

There too were many of Labour's awkward squad: Tam Dalyell, Mark Fisher, and "Gorgeous" George Galloway. And at the last minute in came Lord Longford, who was already an Oxford MA when Alan Clark was born and is now as familiar a figure at these occasions as the grim reaper himself.

It was a strangely conventional service for such a determinedly eccentric man. Perhaps that was the point. Clark was always an iconoclastic traditionalist, a revolutionary conservative, a man whose views verged on fascism yet who delivered one of the finest defences of democracy I have heard, a philanderer who was utterly devoted to his wife, and a man who loved the idea of not caring what anyone else thought, yet who actually minded desperately what other people thought.

What terrified him most was the fear of being found boring. Almost the last thing I heard him say, before he left the Commons forever with his final illness, was: "Good God, am I the only person in this house who supports Milosevic?" Did he mean it? Possibly, or just as probably he wanted to play with the idea, to watch the shock on people's faces, to throw the intellectual sticks in the air and watch everybody scramble to pick them up.

The service was full of hints of his life. His son James read Wilfred Owen's Anthem For Doomed Youth, reflecting Clark's work as a military historian; an extract from A Shropshire Lad for his love of nature (though "the cherry now ... stands about the woodland ride, wearing white for Eastertide" is rather mimsier than the wind-scoured Highlands where he preferred to walk.)

One of his oldest friends, Euan Graham, recalled meeting him for the first time at Oxford. Clark had wanted him to drive his 1947 chromium-plated Buick Roadmaster. "He was banned at the time, for letting a girl drive, sitting on his lap while he operated the pedals."

This was the only direct reference to Clark and women, apart from what he had said of his wife, Jane: "My utter dependence on her throughout the years." It was, Mr Graham said, "an invulnerable companionship". It needed to be, and so it was.

Later I amused myself checking some of the guests in the index to his famous diaries. Most of those thoroughly insulted had stayed away, such as Michael Heseltine, Edwina Currie, Ken Clarke ("lazy, flawed, podgy puffball") and David Mellor ("everyone loathes him".)

A few people who were mildly abused turned up, such as Norman Tebbit ("schizophrenic"), and his tremendous friend Nicholas Soames ("uncomfortable, what Soames and I can spend between us on a single lunch at Wilton's"), who once spent agriculture question time describing "an incredible new aphrodisiac" he had obtained, later giving him a handy phial.

At the end a piper played a lament over the beat of a snare drum. It sounded like one imagines a Hispano-Suiza pinking, a noise which I think Alan Clark would have enjoyed.

fields.headline: Pitching for better wickets
fields.trailText: Curtly Ambrose is not given to saying much, so his comments about the state of pitches in the Caribbean carry more weight than the big man himself. They're too friendly, he seemed to be saying. Not to honest toilers like himself, but to the batsmen. In what was surely a swipe at recent West Indian batting failures - most notably on the New Zealand tour which he mercifully missed through injury - he said batsmen reared on these pitches think they're ready for Test cricket but find themselves unable to cope. Groundsmen in the Caribbean, he went on, needed to prepare pitches that provide a better balance between bowlers and batsmen.
fields.body:
Curtly Ambrose is not given to saying much, so his comments about the state of pitches in the Caribbean carry more weight than the big man himself. They're too friendly, he seemed to be saying. Not to honest toilers like himself, but to the batsmen. In what was surely a swipe at recent West Indian batting failures - most notably on the New Zealand tour which he mercifully missed through injury - he said batsmen reared on these pitches think they're ready for Test cricket but find themselves unable to cope. Groundsmen in the Caribbean, he went on, needed to prepare pitches that provide a better balance between bowlers and batsmen.

His remarks were widely interpreted as meaning that pitches are too flat and slow, but Tony Cozier, the region's leading cricket writer, disagrees. What Ambrose really means, he told me, is that the pitches are of unreliable bounce. The batsmen are unable to play their shots, and they can't develop confidence. Ambrose himself backed up Cozier's point when he almost bowled the Leeward Islands to victory over Guyana in the West Indies' premier first-class competition, the Busta Cup. He took 5 for 39 in the second innings of a game in which only a few batsmen imposed themselves - the sort of low-scoring match that's become typical of the competition. Guyana's winning target was 154; they scored 157 for 8. Eighteen wickets fell on the first day of another match between Jamaica and Trinidad in Jamaica. At least seven batsmen who have played Test and one-day cricket for the West Indies in the past year and a half appeared in that game, including two regulars, Brian Lara and Jimmy Adams.

The debate about pitches is heating up in the Caribbean, as it has in England on occasions. Cozier is in no doubt that the quality of the wickets is linked to recent performances. The former coach Rohan Kanhai has also made the point about sending batsmen to face Glenn McGrath and company without the faintest notion of what constitutes proper bounce. To watch Sherwin Campbell, one of the Windies' senior batsmen, is to understand the argument. Campbell had a very good tour of England in 1995, playing well in the conditions and eventually being signed by Durham. Yet his batting deteriorated badly afterwards, with his once assured movement of the feet being replaced by a leaden prod. It was as if he filled his boots with concrete every time he went out into the middle. Imagine, say, Michael Vaughan suddenly transformed into a flat-footed wafter, and you get the picture. Good scores against New Zealand over Christmas restored his confidence and his technique, but Wasim Akram (and possibly Henry Olonga) will provide an interesting examination of him and others when Zimbabwe and then Pakistan visit the Caribbean over the coming weeks.

In the meantime it's difficult to see a quick solution. There has not been another "sonofapitch" like the one at Sabina Park on the last tour by England. Even Ambrose looked embarrassed when his less-than-lethal deliveries took off like exocet missiles. Alec Stewart, a good man in a terrible situation, would probably agree with the pitch assessments. I won't be surprised if he still has a faint bruise somewhere to remind him.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, lives and works in London, and currently works as a broadcast journalist

webTitle: Vietnam's losing battle against the tobacco smugglers

fields.headline: Vietnam's losing battle against the tobacco smugglers
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: In the years since the end of the war, Vietnam had fought a seemingly losing battle against smugglers. Until 1990, the "transit" or smuggled market into Vietnam was estimated by BAT to be 12-18 billion cigarettes a year. Then, after a clampdown that September, "smuggling was virtually eliminated for 18 months", according to a report to Paul Adams, Asia-Pacific regional director.
fields.body:
In the years since the end of the war, Vietnam had fought a seemingly losing battle against smugglers. Until 1990, the "transit" or smuggled market into Vietnam was estimated by BAT to be 12-18 billion cigarettes a year. Then, after a clampdown that September, "smuggling was virtually eliminated for 18 months", according to a report to Paul Adams, Asia-Pacific regional director.

The hiatus did not last long. As border conditions relaxed, contraband routes again appeared, particularly through Cambodia. In 1992, the company's Cambodia business plan referred to this situation as, apparently, a temporary contingency: "Cambodia will continue to service the Vietnamese market until the [Vietnamese cigarette import] ban is lifted".

Soon, contraband into Vietnam was climbing to pre-1990 levels. In 1992, Mr Adams was told that BAT's State Express 555 brand cigarettes was the "major smuggled brand in the area ... there is no doubt it has a tremendous image and sales potential". Sales of smuggled SE555 were then estimated to be about one billion cigarettes, worth roughly £10m a year.

A series of company papers showed that from 1991, BAT pursued a twin-track strategy to maximise earnings from Vietnam. One track was to negotiate with the Vietnamese government and its tobacco monopoly, Vintaba, to produce international brand cigarettes locally. The other track was monitored from BAT's Asia-Pacific Regional Business Unit, where one executive made notes on "the high margins on illegal product [being] justified on grounds of risk. The amount of handling associated with imported distribution [is] coupled with the requirement of frequent concealment".

Both projects went ahead. By mid-1993, BAT State Express 555 brand cigarettes were being sold as "Made in Vietnam".

Meanwhile, back in Britain, executives in BAT's Far East Support Unit (FESU) juggled complex calculations to assess what balance of trade channels would deliver maximum profit.

In a document suggesting the clarity and precision of BAT's understanding of pricing in the GT trade, Brookes was told that: "Ex-factory price should be such that retail price falls at parity with GT (not fully controllable). GT price structure is: BATUKE to SUTL, $245, SUTL to importer, $290, Importer to Wholesaler, $348, Wholesaler to Trader (Cambodian border) $350". In other words - and in recognition of the independence of smugglers - BAT staff in Britain seemed to wish to adjust the sale price of their cigarettes to their agent to set the final end-market price in Vietnam.

BAT's records suggest that Vietnamese officials treated the company's conduct with suspicion - and told them so. Company executives had a series of meetings with Le Dinh Thuy, director general of the Vietnamese Vintaba tobacco company. A letter from Singapore to BAT's headquarters, then in Staines, Middlesex, reported that at a June 1991 meeting "Mr Thuy was obviously fully aware of both BATUKE's and SUTL's activities in Vietnam, stating 'what are these people doing visiting Vietnam when the import of cigarettes is banned?' It is a point I think should be taken very seriously".

Similar enterprises took place across Asia. In Taiwan, BAT reckoned in the early 1990s that it had about a one billion share of the four billion a year "transit" market. In Thailand, the market was more than 555 million a year. In Vietnam, it was one billion.

In 1993, BAT employed a single senior executive to take charge of GT sales around the world. The post of "senior regional export manager" was based at BATCo's HQ in Staines. Although the job was to co-ordinate sales in Asia and the Pacific, the executive's second task was "co-ordinator of GT worldwide".

In this capacity, the manager was made "responsible to all five regional directors for the co-ordination of all BATCo general trade sales worldwide". This person was charged with the "maintenance of profiles of all main dealers, and monitoring of supply routes; negotiation of trans-regional accounts, [for example] SUTL".

But there was a special warning "due to the nature of export general trade business, the distributors handling this are not easy to manage and difficult to motivate. Their loyalty is sometimes questionable. Due to the type of business and the sums involved, bribery attempts are frequent ... [The person appointed] must be permanently alert to the confidentiality needed in some areas of the business".

The executive had to be on continual alert for new trade by conducting a "proactive search for new GT business".

The report concluded, without any apparent irony, that "integrity is an absolute must".

The disclosed BAT documents indicate that "GT", "transit" or, more plainly, smuggling, seemed to be seen by BAT Industries in the early 1990s as a necessary and substantial part of being competitive and successful in the international tobacco business. Its directors were told in a 1993 paper that "a significant proportion of the world export trade is transit. It exists wherever there are widely different excise rates and trade restrictions, and is expected to continue.

Sales of smuggled SE555 were then estimated to be about one billion cigarettes, worth roughly £10m a year. A series of company papers showed that from 1991, BAT pursued a twin-track strategy to maximise earnings from Vietnam. One track was to negotiate with the Vietnamese government and its tobacco monopoly, Vintaba, to produce international brand cigarettes locally. The other track was monitored from BAT's Asia-Pacific Regional Business Unit, where one executive made notes on "the high margins on illegal product [being] justified on grounds of risk. The amount of handling associated with imported distribution [is] coupled with the requirement of frequent concealment". Both projects went ahead. By mid-1993, BAT State Express 555 brand cigarettes were being sold as "Made in Vietnam". Meanwhile, back in Britain, executives in BAT's Far East Support Unit (FESU) juggled complex calculations to assess what balance of trade channels would deliver maximum profit. In a document suggesting the clarity and precision of BAT's understanding of pricing in the GT trade, Brookes was told that: "Ex-factory price should be such that retail price falls at parity with GT (not fully controllable). GT price structure is: BATUKE to SUTL, $245, SUTL to importer, $290, Importer to Wholesaler, $348, Wholesaler to Trader (Cambodian border) $350". In other words - and in recognition of the independence of smugglers - BAT staff in Britain seemed to wish to adjust the sale price of their cigarettes to their agent to set the final end-market price in Vietnam. BAT's records suggest that Vietnamese officials treated the company's conduct with suspicion - and told them so. Company executives had a series of meetings with Le Dinh Thuy, director general of the Vietnamese Vintaba tobacco company. A letter from Singapore to BAT's headquarters, then in Staines, Middlesex, reported that at a June 1991 meeting "Mr Thuy was obviously fully aware of both BATUKE's and SUTL's activities in Vietnam, stating 'what are these people doing visiting Vietnam when the import of cigarettes is banned?' It is a point I think should be taken very seriously". Similar enterprises took place across Asia. In Taiwan, BAT reckoned in the early 1990s that it had about a one billion share of the four billion a year "transit" market. In Thailand, the market was more than 555 million a year. In Vietnam, it was one billion. In 1993, BAT employed a single senior executive to take charge of GT sales around the world. The post of "senior regional export manager" was based at BATCo's HQ in Staines. Although the job was to co-ordinate sales in Asia and the Pacific, the executive's second task was "co-ordinator of GT worldwide". In this capacity, the manager was made "responsible to all five regional directors for the co-ordination of all BATCo general trade sales worldwide". This person was charged with the "maintenance of profiles of all main dealers, and monitoring of supply routes; negotiation of trans-regional accounts, [for example] SUTL". But there was a special warning "due to the nature of export general trade business, the distributors handling this are not easy to manage and difficult to motivate. Their loyalty is sometimes questionable. Due to the type of business and the sums involved, bribery attempts are frequent ... [The person appointed] must be permanently alert to the confidentiality needed in some areas of the business". The executive had to be on continual alert for new trade by conducting a "proactive search for new GT business". The report concluded, without any apparent irony, that "integrity is an absolute must". The disclosed BAT documents indicate that "GT", "transit" or, more plainly, smuggling, seemed to be seen by BAT Industries in the early 1990s as a necessary and substantial part of being competitive and successful in the international tobacco business. Its directors were told in a 1993 paper that "a significant proportion of the world export trade is transit. It exists wherever there are widely different excise rates and trade restrictions, and is expected to continue.

webTitle: Paper trail to markets of the East

fields.headline: Paper trail to markets of the East
fields.standfirst:
Papers leave little doubt that company's top directors and executives were far from blind to smuggling activities

Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Papers leave little doubt that company's top directors and executives were far from blind to smuggling activities
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell, Maud S Beelman  and Erik J Schelzig
fields.body:
British American Tobacco's Southampton complex is one of the most modern tobacco plants in the world and will soon be capable of churning out 96bn cigarettes a year.

Virtually all the tobacco is exported, with 20 huge containers loaded most days on to ships bound for the Middle East, the Far East and Asia.

Many go to Singapore, a key hub in Asian distribution routes, and to Hong Kong and Dubai.

In their search to maintain and enlarge cigarette markets, BAT exploited a sophisticated network of smuggling routes operated by others in Asia and the Near East, company documents reveal.

Unlike in Latin America, where company executives commonly used the euphemism "DNP", meaning duty not paid to denote smuggled goods, BAT documents discussing Asian operations mainly used a different term, "GT" or general trade. Company documents repeatedly contrast legal export sales with GT, and break down the total trade into particular countries into the categories of legal or "GT". One plan for Singapore refers to how "the legal market fell but the shortfall was taken up by GT product". Another plan, for Taiwan, showed "the split between Legal and GT."

Legal routes

Other pointers to the meaning of GT in company documents include references to difficulties with customs or closed borders, indicating that the reason why GT trade was illegal was because it involved smuggling. In relation to moving cigarettes into Myanmar (formerly Burma) from Thailand, a fax of November 30, 1992 from BAT's Singapore subsidiary warns: "Duty-paid sales to Myanmar had been strong but the political situation had closed all legal routes in from Thailand, leaving only GT trade..."

The report added: "This closure coincided with the monsoon season and the consequent redeployment of security forces from rebel engagements to internal security activities. The GT route thereby became more difficult."

A large part of BAT's GT sales in Asia were handled by one Singapore distributor Singapura United Trading Limited (Sutl). According to company papers, Sutl handled both legal and GT products in the region. Its normal market channels were broken down into domestic sales, duty paid exports, which were legal, duty free sales in airports and to ships and GT. A document of December 10, 1991 identified risks to the company's GT business "Sutl appreciate that dependency on GT leaves them very vulnerable to market liberalisation (Thailand) and market closure (Vietnam), therefore they are seeking to move that core business to long-term legal ventures involving ownership interest."

Other company documents from Latin America and Asia used GT interchangeably with DNP and "transit", internal euphemisms which also appeared on BAT papers in place of direct references to smuggling. This and other similar evidence from the BAT papers leads to the conclusion that, within British American Tobacco, references to GT in the papers of directors and managers were references to smuggled cigarettes.

Network of agents

The documents from their Guildford depository do not suggest that BAT employees themselves ever transported contraband across borders. But they took advantage of smuggling markets around the world, using a network of agents who on an annual basis transferred billions of cigarettes into the hands of smugglers.

But so large was the role of GT that, according to the most recent information available, a plan covering the period from 1993 to 1997, more than one fifth of the output of BAT's UK factories were made for this market. From their factory at Southampton billions of cigarettes are made annually by BAT (UK and Export) Ltd (Batuke).

The information appears in the Batuke company plan for 1993 to 1997. This was one of thousands of documents examined by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, part of the Centre for Public Integrity (CPI) based in Washington DC in the course of their BAT investigation.

The copy of this document obtained by CPI and seen by the Guardian is identified as being the copy provided to the then chairman of the BAT Company Ltd, Barry Bramley.

Batuke was then the main UK tobacco manufacturing subsidiary of BAT Industries plc. It is marked "Secret".

According to the plan, Batuke operates in 125 different markets, shipping tobacco products to these markets through 360 agents. The markets are broken down into "domestic", "duty free" and "general trade (GT)".

During the period covered by the disclosed documents, extending to 1995, BAT anticipated that over one fifth of its UK and export production would be "GT". Under the heading "General Trade", it states that "two key General Trade markets "will account for 4.7bn units or 22% of Batuke's total shipments".

The two key centres identified in the report are Sutl and "Unit 1". Sutl covered countries from Afghanistan to the Philippines, while Unit 1 was involved with Africa. Other centres which can be identified as playing a major role in BAT's GT trade are Dubai, and Hong Kong.

The company plan suggests that BAT then proposed to invest in expanding its utilisation of GT methods to reach its end markets. The company "strategy [focuses] on maximising the GT market opportunities to provide funds to build a stable volume/profit base for the long term ... via investment in duty free and domestic markets". It added that "£3.8[m] will be invested to grow our business in the GT markets".

BAT has refused to comment on the meaning of terms like GT, or to discuss the implications of any particular document. The company's public affairs director, Michael Prideaux, said in response to earlier allegations that "if people wish to draw the inference that we are turning a blind eye to smuggling, they are free to do so. Deterring smuggling is a matter for the governments concerned. The only sure way is to cut tobacco taxes".

But the hundreds of documents in BAT's files on marketing activities in Asia and around the world leave little doubt that some of BAT's top directors and executives were far from blind to smuggling activities. They received reports about new opportunities in GT trade, as well as regular assessments of sales levels that went through legal and GT channels.

Important markets in the region for GT cigarettes, according to a report prepare by Fred Coombe, Batuke area manager for Far East, were Bangladesh, Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, Indonesia, Philippines, North Korea, Afghanistan, and Taiwan. The largest potential market was mainland China. Evidence from Hong Kong suggests that BAT cigarettes worth more than £490m were smuggled into China during the 1990s.

Floating corpse

In the late 1980s, competition between Hong Kong based rival traders smuggling BAT cigarettes into China became so intense that bribes were paid to the BAT local director whose job was to deal with them.

After one jilted trader exposed the system to Hong Kong's anti-corruption commission, former BAT (HK) export director Jerry Lui was extradited from the United States. BAT itself was not charged with any offence.

The case against Lui nearly foundered after the chief witness against him, trader Tommy Chui, was murdered. In 1995 his body was found floating in Singapore harbour. His corpse had been placed in a rubbish bag, with tape over his mouth.

The warning to other witnesses could hardly have been clearer. Another potential witness committed suicide. Nevertheless, in June 1998, Lui was convicted and sentenced to three years and 8 months imprisonment. He later launched an ultimately unsuccessful appeal and awaits the outcome of a continuing appeal application.

BAT company documents disclosed during Lui's trial led judge Mr Justice Wally Yeung Chun-kuen to comment: "The evidence suggests that management of BAT (HK) was aware duty-not-paid cigarettes ... would ultimately be smuggled in China and other countries. There could be no other explanation for this enormous quantity of duty-not-paid cigarettes worth billions and billions of [Hong Kong] dollars.

"To some extent such irresponsible behaviour amounted to assisting criminals in trans-national crime".

The company claimed at the time that the smuggling was the work of "rogue employees", and replied "British American Tobacco does not smuggle. It does not condone smuggling and its business is entirely lawful".

But the documents now disclosed show that in many Asian countries BAT not merely tolerated GT trade channels, but exploited traditional smuggling routes when they would maximise sales. The documents also trace the rise and fall of Mr Lui within BAT ranks.

fields.headline: Ex-minister under pressure over BAT
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Kenneth Clarke was under growing pressure last night to investigate fresh evidence that British American Tobacco exploited cigarette smuggling.
fields.body:
Kenneth Clarke was under growing pressure last night to investigate fresh evidence that British American Tobacco exploited cigarette smuggling.

The former chancellor and health secretary, now the London-based multinational's deputy chairman, has a legal duty to protect the company's integrity.

BAT documents reveal that huge numbers of cigarettes produced in Southampton, one of the most modern tobacco plants in the world, and other factories were made for the Far East, Middle East and Asia - markets which are dominated by black marketeers.

Mr Clarke, paid nearly £68,000 for the part-time post, yesterday failed to respond to repeated requests for a comment about the serious allegations.

When pressed, Michael Prideaux, BAT's director of corporate and regulatory affairs, said: "We don't propose to answer any questions."

Mr Prideaux, a member of the company's management board, said it would reply at an unspecified time in the future.

Today's revelations about the exploitation of smuggling in the Far East, Middle East and Asia follow Monday's disclosure in the Guardian of how the company benefited from black marketeering in Latin America.

BAT stonewalled as Labour MPs demanded explanations from the world's second largest tobacco company.

Kevin Barron, the chairman of the all-party group on smoking and health, said: "Ken Clarke holds his position within BAT because of his past office as chancellor and health secretary.

"He has a wider public duty to answer what are very serious allegations about smuggling."

Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton & Washington East, said: "The company cannot bury its head in the sand and hope all this will go away.

"Very serious allegations have been made and Kenneth Clarke and his fellow directors have a responsibility to answer them now."

The all-party Commons health committee is considering whether to recall BAT's non-smoking chairman, Martin Broughton, or ask for fresh evidence as part of its inquiry into the tobacco industry.

On Monday night, a senior World Health Organisation official promised a clampdown on powerful tobacco companies with an international treaty planned to curb their activities.

BAT sells 900bn cigarettes a year and is challenging US-based Philip Morris for pole position in the global tobacco business.

fields.headline: Notes from New Hampshire
fields.trailText: Guardian correspondent Martin Kettle (left) reports exclusively for News Unlimited from John McCain's victory party
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in New Hampshire for News Unlimited
fields.body:
On Monday night, John McCain stood on the snow-covered steps of New Hampshire's lovely Bedford Town Hall and looked out over an enthusiastic crowd of supporters, poetically summoning his "dear friends" to "one last mission" - getting the vote out in yesterday's first-in-the-nation presidential primary.

Just twenty-four hours later, McCain stood triumphant - indoors in Nashua this time - before elated campaign workers celebrating his extraordinary win in the Republican contest. McCain did not just get out the vote yesterday. By defeating George W Bush by 49 per cent to 31, he also overturned all the pre-existing assumptions about the 2000 Republican race. Mission accomplished - and then some.

Yet McCain knows better than anyone that last night's spectacular is both a beginning and an end - as wins in New Hampshire primaries often are. McCain's win was an absolute corker. But who now remembers Paul Tsongas, who corkingly defeated Bill Clinton here in 1992? McCain seems to understand that things are different from now on. "My friends," he said in his Nashua victory speech, "a wonderful New Hampshire campaign has come to an end, but a great national crusade has just begun."

McCain's win changes many, many things, not just for himself but also for the defeated George W Bush. McCain has shown he can throw a punch. Bush must now prove he can take one. New Hampshire has badly dented Bush's great assets - the reputation as a winner, and the sense of irresistibility that surrounds his cash-heavy campaign - but it has not destroyed them. Bush prides himself on having a "50-state strategy" - and there are still 48 more to go.

In any event, the next phase of the Republican nomination race will necessarily be very different. The saturation tactics which saw the Arizona senator spend 73 campaigning days in New Hampshire, addressing 114 town meetings around the state and shaking, it is said, 60,000 hands, will not be seen again. Increasingly, the campaign battleground will now be on the television airwaves, where money counts. Bush has nearly $68 million already in the bank. McCain is suddenly scrambling to raise funds.

Never again will McCain have the luxury of that kind of grass-roots campaigning at which, as anyone who travelled with him over the past few weeks will attest, he absolutely excels. The pace quickens over the coming weeks, with primaries in Delaware next week (which McCain is ignoring), in South Carolina on February 19 (which he is not), and in Arizona and Michigan on February 22. Then, another two weeks later, the biggest test of all - Super Tuesday, March 7, when eleven states including massive California and New York, hold their contests. From today on, this is a national contest.

At the end of his victory rally, the backdrop banner behind McCain slipped to the ground, revealing a fresh campaign message - "Next Stop South Carolina". And South Carolina, where McCain will attempt to repeat yesterday's triumph, is a very different state from New Hampshire. Where New Hampshire is white, modern and Yankee, South Carolina is racially divided, reactionary and flies the Confederate flag over its state house. Same country, different issues.

McCain recognises that he will campaign differently in South Carolina. Last night, he already began to attack "the truth twisting politics of Bill Clinton and Al Gore", trying to erect a defence against Bush's inevitable counter-attack that McCain is the next worst thing to a Democrat. It will help McCain that his South Carolina campaign is fronted by Congressman Lindsey Graham, another Republican maverick, who established a national reputation as a scathing Clinton-baiter during last year's impeachment trial. McCain won a lot of liberal admiration in New Hampshire. It will be interesting to see how it survives South Carolina.

Last night at least raised the possibility that the war hero McCain can carry his guerrilla campaign to the kind of victory they don't teach in the textbooks of modern politics. If that happens, then the consequences could be momentous, not least for Al Gore, who last night dug out another important though narrower than expected victory over Bill Bradley in the New Hampshire Democratic contest.

McCain is not easily classifiable. He is a radical conservative, and a reforming traditionalist. On television last night, Newt Gingrich called him a Theodore Roosevelt Republican, which is nearly right. Not since Ronald Reagan has a dreamer and idealist challenged for the Republican nomination, but the party that embraced the genial Reagan has not embraced McCain, the enemy of big tobacco and the other special interests on which the modern Republican Party rests. An article on McCain in the New Republic magazine last week carried the headline "This Man Is Not A Republican". But if he goes on winning like he did last night, then that's the kind of detail that his victory hungry party may be willing to ignore.

fields.body:
The government yesterday agreed a 3.3% pay increase for all teachers in England and Wales, but offered to raise this to more than 11% for experienced staff who pass a performance review to move on to a higher salary scale from September.

Ministers said 220,000 senior teachers would be eligible to apply for the first round of the experiment in performance pay in schools. At least half are expected to qualify for an additional £2,000, followed by four annual £1,000 increments, taking the classroom maximum to about £30,000.

But the teaching unions said most of the 450,000 teachers in England and Wales would not get a performance increase and for them the 3.3% offer was less than the going rate for increases in average earnings, currently 4.6%.

Union leaders said the starting salary for honours graduates would slip further behind other professions. The pay for newly qualified teachers will rise by £513 to £16,050.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, accepted the recommendations of the School Teachers' Review Body, which gave the green light to his plans for performance-related promotion.

The package included no further information about how performance would be assessed, although the process is certain to include measurements of pupils' progress. Details will be published later this month.

Mr Blunkett dismissed claims by local education authorities that they would not be able to afford the basic 3.3% rise. It would cost £420m, but the councils' education spending assessments had already been raised by £1,103m, he said. The government has set aside £1bn over two years to fund performance pay.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said confidential drafts of the criteria for performance pay showed it "threatens to turn the whole process into a bullshitter's charter".

Although the 3.3% rise beat inflation, it fell below the average earnings rise "and so takes teaching down a further notch or two in the salaries league table. Every government is the same. They all want a Rolls-Royce education service powered by a Mini Metro engine."

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "This minimal increase offers no hope of overcoming the recruitment crisis and leaves existing teachers underpaid, under-valued and overwhelmed by their ever-increasing workload and the excessive demands of government."

Headteachers' leaders and the Professional Association of Teachers also said the rise was not enough to solve recruitment difficulties.

But Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said: "The new pay threshold will be an opportunity for the great majority of experienced teachers to earn more."

Graham Lane, education chairman of the Local Government Association, said the government funded local authorities for a teachers' pay award of 2.5%. He called on ministers to make up a shortfall of £110m. Without that authorities could not afford the settlement unless they pulled out of government initiatives to raise standards in schools.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, said: "I wish the unions would recognise that teachers went into teaching to work with children and raise standards. The age-old complaint was that society did not reward that. This settlement does."

webTitle: McCain win leaves US race wide open

fields.headline: McCain win leaves US race wide open
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Senator John McCain threw the American presidential contest wide open by winning a runaway victory over the Republican favourite Governor George W Bush in the New Hampshire presidential primary last night.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Concord, New Hampshire
fields.body:
Senator John McCain threw the American presidential contest wide open by winning a runaway victory over the Republican favourite Governor George W Bush in the New Hampshire presidential primary last night.

Early exit polls showed Mr McCain, a Vietnam war hero, winning by 15-20 points over Mr Bush, the Texas governor and pre-primary Republican frontrunner.

In the Democratic race, the vice-president, Al Gore, and Senator Bill Bradley were locked in a contest that was too close to call, the polls predicted.

Mr McCain's devastating win over Mr Bush left political observers gasping in disbelief. He not only captured two-thirds of the support of independent voters but led Mr Bush by 10 points among registered Republicans, polls suggested.

Within hours of his historic win, Mr McCain flew to South Carolina, where the next Republican primary takes place on February 19.

fields.headline: Jean-Claude Izzo
fields.standfirst: Catching the Mediterranean tragedy in tales of old Marseille
fields.trailText: "By birth, I am a pure Marsellais. That's to say I'm half Italian and half Spanish, with a touch of Arab blood." So the writer Jean-Claude Izzo, who has died of lung cancer aged 54, described himself.
fields.body:
"By birth, I am a pure Marsellais. That's to say I'm half Italian and half Spanish, with a touch of Arab blood." So the writer Jean-Claude Izzo, who has died of lung cancer aged 54, described himself.

And he was an aggressively Mediterranean man. He liked to quote his fellow Frenchman Flaubert, who, arriving in Cairo, noted that what was expected rarely happened. This, according to Izzo, was because, in the Mediterran- ean light, one never found what one was seeking; the discovery of its beauty changed everything.

Yet last September, when his latest novel, Le Soleil Des Mourants (The Sun Of The Dying), was among the seasonal bestsellers, and his name was listed alongside the accepted successful writers of France, he told interviewers that he was growing tired of Marseille. He no longer wanted to be its accepted spokesman. He spoke of going to live in Laos.

It had been a long time before Izzo had decided to become a writer. Trained as a metal worker, he volunteered to do his military service early in Djibouti before going to live for some time in Ethiopia.

On returning to Marseille he joined the Communist party, and started to do odd jobs on the local party newspaper, La Marseillais. He was put off literature by the "new novel" and by prevailing literary ideas, such as structuralism. He believed in social realism, and this was what he wrote about in his newspaper. The only exceptions were poetry - he published a volume in 1971 - and working on cinema and television scripts.

During the 1970s, he hoped that a socialist-communist alliance would come to power in France and wrote a number of editorials in favour of this coalition. But in 1978 the alliance broke down, leaving the conservative government of Raymond Barre in power. Izzo had had enough. He resigned from the newspaper, sent back his party card and started to live on the edge of literature as a bookseller, librarian and organiser of literary conferences. The most important of these was the annual festival of adventure travel writers, held at St Malo, with its emphasis on exploration and discovery.

Izzo himself went in for this sort of writing when he told of his journeys from Tangiers to Istanbul, Naples to Barcelona, and Marseille to Alexandria, and of climbing the hill of Le Planteur, behind Oran. But he published these in reviews and newspapers. He did not turn wholeheartedly to books until he had absorbed the implications of the American crime thriller, which he discovered surprisingly late.

In 1995, at the age of 50, Izzo produced his first novel, Total Kheops - the title, taken from a rap group song, means "total catastrophe". Published in the Série Noire, it was a great success, as were its two successors, Chourma (1996) and Solea (1998), and was translated into many languages.

The books invoke a tired and disillusioned Marseille detective, Fabio Montale, whose melancholy is tempered by a love for women and good food, and whose pessimism is put in its place by his horror of injustice, racism and violence. But in the final volume, Solea, the policeman hero is still looking for reasons to live in a Marseille where the smell of death predominates in a city surrounded by fire. Izzo turned the detective novel into tragedy.

He accepted, however, that he could not continue in the same vein. He went on to publish some poetry, and another bestseller about sailors who could not put to sea, Les Marins Perdus. His last novel, Le Soleil Des Mourants, was about the excluded - the homeless, refugees and people on the run.

Izzo claimed that in writing about the horrors of everyday life, he was in the Mediterranean tradition. The novelist Jean Giono, known for his stories of peasant life and who lived in the Basses Alpes, once said that under the light of the sun, there was no mystery, only tragedy; and Izzo always claimed that what he had written was the fatalist acceptance of the drama which began when Cain killed Abel - on one of the coasts of the Mediterranean.

He is survived by his wife and son.

 Jean-Claude Izzo, novelist, poet and travel writer, born 1945; died January 26 2000

webTitle: Canteen a health risk says head

fields.headline: Canteen a health risk says head
fields.trailText: A headteacher is planning to report his school canteen to the health and safety executive as a health hazard in an attempt to force the local council to close it down and build a new one.
fields.body:
A headteacher is planning to report his school canteen to the health and safety executive as a health hazard in an attempt to force the local council to close it down and build a new one.

The canteen at the Abbey School in Faversham, Kent, was built in the 1940s. It has an asbestos roof which has grown a thick layer of moss, damp causes paint to peel off the walls, and the ceiling is so damp that mould can be seen from the inside.

Peter Walker, the headteacher, will ask the school governors tomorrow night to support his bid to get the building, which is used by 500 pupils every lunchtime, condemned and replaced.

Mr Walker said that within the food preparation area there were signs of damp on the walls and there was an open drain on the floor. "I would not consider it safe to store food in there at all."

He praised the caterers for managing to prepare food at all in the circumstances. "In this modern day and age I do not consider the canteen a proper place for young people to be asked to eat their food. It is a health hazard."

Mark Dance, chairman of the school governors, who is supporting the head teacher's campaign, described the canteen as being "like an open shower".

Mr Walker said two Ofsted reports in February 1995 and in December last year criticised the canteen and toilet facilities at the school as being inadequate.

He wants Kent county council to form a partnership with local businesses to build a community hall on the school site, which could be used as a canteen during the day and used by other groups in evenings and during school holidays.

Paul Carter, the county council's director of education, said the canteen had not been replaced as there were more pressing concerns in the county.

"In Kent we have a poor quality stock and need £200m to bring all our schools up to an acceptable standard.

"This year we hope to get funding of £7m. It comes down to priorities and making the best use of resources."

fields.headline: A step up for teachers
fields.standfirst:
But much more needed to restore respect

Education Unlimited
Teaching Reforms site (Department of Education)
School teacher's Review Body (Department of Education)
fields.trailText: Is there nothing that will make teachers' leaders smile? Yesterday's much-leaked pay award contained several cherries which in earlier years would have been greeted with enthusiasm.
fields.body:
Is there nothing that will make teachers' leaders smile? Yesterday's much-leaked pay award contained several cherries which in earlier years would have been greeted with enthusiasm: an above-inflation, across-the-board rise (3.3%, compared to a 2.2% rise in prices) which is not staged; accelerated promotion for high-flying new entrants, allowing them to jump two points a year on the pay scale, rather than one; and from September, a £2,000 performance increase for effective classroom teachers at the top of the present scale, giving them an 11% increase this year and lifting their ultimate pay ceiling by £7,000 to £30,000.

Yet the response to this cheery news was the same old thumbs down from most leaders. The NUT said it meant teachers would remain "underpaid, undervalued, and overwhelmed"; the NASUWT thought "every government is the same - they all want a Rolls Royce education service powered by a Mini Metro engine"; while even the traditionally more moderate PAT thought the award was "an insult". Part of this opposition was prompted by the worst of motives: knee-jerk dislike of performance-related pay. But part is justified by the dire state of the teaching profession: applications for primary school teacher training courses have fallen by more than a quarter this year; the new £5,000 "golden hellos" to attract students in areas of greatest shortage - maths and science - which worked last year have not been effective this; and even before this decline in numbers, education degree courses were demanding the lowest of all entry requirements: an average of one C and two Ds at A level.

Although these problems were inherited, not created, ministers have got to solve them if their ambitious education goals are to be achieved. Starting salaries next time will have to be raised. Ministers had to push performance pay, but a basic rate which is rising less than average earnings needs urgent attention too.

webTitle: Sex education? It should be top of the class by now

fields.headline: Sex education? It should be top of the class by now
fields.standfirst:
The government ought to stop squabbling about symbols and face facts
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sex never should have been a problem for Labour. Yet here they are with their knickers in a needless twist for all the bad old hypocritical reasons. Repealing homophobic Section 28 was a simple matter, a pre-election promise, no problem. Confronted with a rowdy campaign by a handful of unrepresentative bigots, the government made matters worse by dragging sex education into the debate, promising tough new teachers' guidelines firmly promoting "marriage and traditional families". In a hole, they are just digging deeper.
fields.body:
Sex never should have been a problem for Labour. Yet here they are with their knickers in a needless twist for all the bad old hypocritical reasons. Repealing homophobic Section 28 was a simple matter, a pre-election promise, no problem. Confronted with a rowdy campaign by a handful of unrepresentative bigots, the government made matters worse by dragging sex education into the debate, promising tough new teachers' guidelines firmly promoting "marriage and traditional families". In a hole, they are just digging deeper.

Since December David Blunkett, the secretary of state for education, has had on his desk the new draft guidance to schools on the teaching of sex education. It was drawn up by a sub- committee of the national curriculum advisory group on personal and social health education and citizenship. It is an enlightened and sensible framework for schools, which should have been out for public consultation two months ago. The committee that drafted it begins to fear the worst. The education department says ominously that officials are working on it. They say religious leaders are still coming in for consultations, though the religious leaders were all consulted in depth by the advisory committee. Will the basic principles survive this Blunkett rewrite?

Sex education should "promote sexual self-acceptance and a positive and open view of sex and sexuality", was the fine first principle they laid down. Will that sentiment still guide the Blunkett version?

The draft says that sex education should begin well before puberty, but Blunkett is opposed to making it compulsory in primary schools. It calls for sex education to be closely linked to local contraceptive services, so all children are told about their nearest clinic. Will that still be there? The draft does have to pass through health minister Yvette Cooper's teenage pregnancy unit before publication: if it is skewered by unrealistic marriage exhortation, expect a fight. All along the education department has been the force of conservatism, the health department the force of progress. "What works is all we care about," says health pragmatically, while education still doesn't really think sex is its business.

Repeal of Section 28 will now fall in the Lords. Chief whip Ann Taylor is being accused of conspiracy, not just bungling: she and Blunkett were the only cabinet ministers to vote against lowering the gay age of consent. Why did she start the legislation in the Lords, allowing them to kill it? Her defenders say she wasn't there, she had flu. But however often the word "marriage" peppers Blunkett's sex education guidance, he will not stop the Tories seizing a shabby victory.

It will at least offer a cast-iron reason why all religious leaders should be kept out of government in any reformed Lords, as we watch law being made by a horrible caucus of unrepresentative cardinals, bishops, rabbis and mullahs.

Is important policy on sex really going to be made by some of the country's nastiest people? Will Labour really be dictated to by the likes of Stuart Bell, Baroness Young, Cardinal Winning, Victoria Gillick, Brian Souter and the editor of the Daily Mail?

Give in to this bunch and they will be on Labour's back for ever. Stand up to them and see how fast their artificial power will wither and die. They do not represent the country. They only thrive as paper tigers, the creation of an ultra-conservative media out of tune with a tolerant and sensible people. But battered by mad tabloid stories of gay sex and porn in the classroom, tolerance doesn't stand much of a chance. Section 28 may not matter much as a practical issue: no one's ever been prosecuted. But in politics symbols sometimes matter more than reality. This was an evil-minded piece of legislation, passed in the same foetid atmosphere that has been resurrected now.

The government can't afford to appease these forces of conservatism because there will be many other difficult sexual issues that will require Labour to be brave. Today Levonelle, a new emergency contraceptive, is launched which is better than the one in current use. Taken within 72 hours of unprotected sex it will prevent conception or prevent implantation in the womb to stop pregnancy beginning. This new progestogen-only pill has no side effects, no nausea and is no stronger than the contraceptive pills women used to take every day. Apart from confusing menstrual cycles, there is no medical reason why a woman shouldn't take one frequently. There is no reason why any woman shouldn't keep one at home in case of emergency. No reason why women of any age shouldn't buy them over the counter or from slot machines - like condoms. There is no particular danger, no great mystique. Universally available and well advertised, it could prevent most unwanted pregnancies. It's easy.

Why do women still allow their sexuality to be guarded by impertinent doctors? Who makes men take counselling with their sex? There is no valid medical reason for prescriptions for any contraceptives: doctors can't possibly do proper risk assessments. This paternalism springs from atavistic fears of letting women's sexuality go free. Wouldn't 14-year-olds turn nymphomaniac if they could just pop a pill afterwards?

Unease at girls having it easy underpins the medical excuses. Surely the image of the feckless female should have died with the news of the Blairs' own unexpected pregnancy? It can and does happen to 40% of women and they don't need a wigging from doctors.

In Glasgow, Boots has a walk-in family planning clinic especially designed for the young: it has been picketted by religious fanatics every week. Going one step further, the Manchester Health Action Zone has a brilliant pilot in 16 pharmacies where chemists give out emergency contraception without a doctor at all. Maybe it was the public protests in Glasgow that led the health department to hamstring the Manchester experiment with an edict banning them from advertising.

But what is the point of handing out emergency morning-after pills without telling anyone who might need it, for fear the Daily Mail will find out? (They did anyway and blasted away at it.) Now Manchester is asking for the advertising ban to be lifted, but this is the kind of double-think the government has to abandon.

The shambles over Section 28 should be a salutary lesson to Labour. There are times when there is no third way, no appeasing both sides in a confrontation between liberal tolerance and hysterical bigotry. The moral right has to be faced down if Labour really wants to make a difference to Britain's primitive levels of unwanted pregnancy. Time Labour followed its own sex education advice: resist peer pressure, maintain self-respect and just say "no" to the Daily Mail.
