fields.trailText: Rosie Millard (What a song and dance, January 29) criticises the Royal Opera House for not putting on enough classic opera. In fact Michael Kaiser inherited a programme which includes: Falstaff (Verdi), Roméo et Juliette (Gounod) La Bohème (Puccini), Des Rosenkavalier (Strauss), The Flying Dutchman (Wagner) and The Meistersinger (Wagner).

Rosie Millard (What a song and dance, January 29) criticises the Royal Opera House for not putting on enough classic opera. In fact Michael Kaiser inherited a programme which includes: Falstaff (Verdi), Roméo et Juliette (Gounod) La Bohème (Puccini), Des Rosenkavalier (Strauss), The Flying Dutchman (Wagner) and The Meistersinger (Wagner).

These "classics" are balance by Gawain (Birtwhistle) and The Greek Passion (Martinu). Many would see this as a wonderful mixture of well-known and well-loved operas together with two great modern operas. So far, all my opera-loving friends from France, Italy, Germany, USA and Canada are green with envy.

Roger Guedalla London

fields.headline: Signal failure on tube cash
fields.trailText: You report that UCL researchers have questioned both Ken Livingstone's and our own approach to funding London Underground investment (Tube bond plan will save £1bn, January 31).
fields.body:
You report that UCL researchers have questioned both Ken Livingstone's and our own approach to funding London Underground investment (Tube bond plan will save £1bn, January 31).

London Transport's advisors have shown that the Private Public Partnership (PPP) could be £4.5 bn cheaper over 15 years than the bond option because under the PPP, the private sector bears the risk, not the passenger or the taxpayer. The private sector has a powerful incentive to avoid cost overruns. We shall check which is better value: the PPP as bid for or public sector finance, raised both conventionally and through bonds. The results will be published and scrutinised by the National Audit Office.

We will not foist massive fare increases on Londoners. The PPP will deliver what London needs - an Underground that is more reliable and less crowded, publicly owned, publicly run, and properly financed.

Lord MacDonald of Tradeston
Minister for transport

 The Green party supports the bond option. As a growing body of academics, trade unionists and politicians of a variety of political colours, as well as Londoners themselves, oppose the government's semi-privatisation plans, how long will it be before the government finally listens?

Darren Johnson
Green party candidate for London mayor
DJohnson@greenparty.org.uk

fields.headline: Poetic truth
fields.trailText: The term "Frankenstein foods" to describe genetically modified crops is not, as Mark Atkinson writes (Economics, January 31), a "crude caricature".  In the novel a clever young man who sees living creatures mechanistically as collections of working parts makes one by cobbling together bits of others. But the creature breaks free and interacts with the world around in ways its creator could not foresee. It does harm. Invoking Frankenstein is an expression of poetic truth.

fields.headline: Mr Hague's last throw
fields.standfirst:
Unless this one too fails to satisfy

The Tories: special report
Hague's new cabinet
Michael Portillo official biography
fields.trailText: Last summer a smiling William Hague told us he had now assembled the frontbench team which would take the Conservative party into the next election.  Last November, as Michael Portillo returned to the Commons, we were solemnly assured he would not be whistled straight back into a senior job.  Both forecasts were left looking pretty silly yesterday as Mr Portillo was abruptly installed as shadow chancellor, while Francis Maude was shouldered aside, John Maples was deprived of his foreign affairs brief and hustled off into obscurity, and John Redwood was dismissed.
fields.body:
Last summer a smiling William Hague told us he had now assembled the frontbench team which would take the Conservative party into the next election. Last November, as Michael Portillo returned to the Commons, we were solemnly assured he would not be whistled straight back into a senior job. Both forecasts were left looking pretty silly yesterday as Mr Portillo was abruptly installed as shadow chancellor, while Francis Maude was shouldered aside, John Maples was deprived of his foreign affairs brief and hustled off into obscurity, and John Redwood was dismissed.

These are desperate measures. But then the Conservatives party has plenty to be desperate about. The extent of its irrelevance in today's political battles has been underlined by the doubts and difficulties which have swept over Tony Blair and his colleagues since Christmas. On all sorts of subordinate questions - how warm they feel towards Mr Blair personally, what they make of his stewardship of the NHS - the voters have been registering disaffection. Yet asked how they would vote in a general election tomorrow, they continue to give their backing to Labour on a scale unprecedented in the middle of a parliamentary term in peacetime politics. Their judgment is clear: there is, as someone once said, No Alternative.

Both the promotion of Mr Portillo and the relegation of Mr Redwood are risky. Mr Portillo is a big league player, one of the very few the Tories have got, and perhaps the only one they can credibly pitch against the formidable Gordon Brown. There is also a down side. He is plainly ambitious and whatever his protestations, it would be surprising if he did not have one eye on Mr Hague's job. Though undoubtedly clever, he has suffered from unsettling lapses of judgment, from his tasteless conference rants to the constituency "birthday" party to celebrate 10 years in parliament. His capacity to generate new ideas and then to sock them across far outweighs Mr Maude's; yet unless Mr Hague can be tempted into a spectacular U-turn, he comes to the job shackled to his party's ludicrous conference pledge to cut taxes whatever the state of the economy.

Mr Maude replaces Mr Maples, whose performance in the foreign affairs role has been little better than those which preceded it at health and defence. But an even bigger casualty, and a potentially dangerous one, is Mr Redwood. Let me, said Julius Caesar, have men about me who are fat. He might almost have been thinking of the lean and slippery Mr Redwood. He is not a team player, not one whom a leader can feel is deeply, unswervingly loyal to the project. He also has the mark of the old Major team upon him (though so does Mr Portillo: the evening of May 1 1997 is indelibly stamped on him). Yet many in the Westminster party and outside will be sorry to see him go. Whatever his defects, they may say to themselves, at least he knew how to bite. Mr Hague may feel that bite in time to come. Not everyone takes a spectacular fall from grace as calmly and uncomplainingly as Peter Lilley.

Archie Norman, the supermarket king, is an intriguing choice to face John Prescott at environment: energetic and competent, though not so far a good Commons performer, and close enough to Mr Hague to get the charges of cronyism directed at Tony Blair batted back by the other side. Other changes will no doubt follow. They need to. How, for instance, the Tories can go on fielding Andrew Mackay in a slot as crucial and sensitive as spokesman on Northern Ireland is one of the age's great mysteries.

webTitle: The way out for gay Catholic priests

fields.headline: The way out for gay Catholic priests
fields.trailText: As a former Roman Catholic priest who is gay, I sympathise very much with the dilemma of the anonymous priest from Scotland (Letters, February 1). My own solution was to leave the church because honesty with myself was far preferable to fear and secrecy. Gay Catholic priests are whistling in the dark waiting for change to happen. The church has not moved one millimetre on gay issues. And it won't until gay priests celebrate their sexuality openly and challenge the brutal and inhuman language of arrogant prelates like Cardinal Winning. There is no way of mitigating teachings which describe gay people as subhuman and inferior. They are just plain wrong. Far too few Roman Catholic priests have had the courage to stand up and say this. Since a   substantial proportion of them is gay, it is high time they did.
fields.body:
As a former Roman Catholic priest who is gay, I sympathise very much with the dilemma of the anonymous priest from Scotland (Letters, February 1). My own solution was to leave the church because honesty with myself was far preferable to fear and secrecy. Gay Catholic priests are whistling in the dark waiting for change to happen. The church has not moved one millimetre on gay issues. And it won't until gay priests celebrate their sexuality openly and challenge the brutal and inhuman language of arrogant prelates like Cardinal Winning. There is no way of mitigating teachings which describe gay people as subhuman and inferior. They are just plain wrong. Far too few Roman Catholic priests have had the courage to stand up and say this. Since a substantial proportion of them is gay, it is high time they did.

Fear cripples the human spirit. Leaving monastic life after 11 years was not the end of the world; far better than obedient silence.

Andrew Pearson
Aberystwyth

 I too served as a Catholic priest. When my desired lifestyle became incompatible with that calling I laid down the ministry rather than compromise the message I should preach. This was not easy; it is not easy to be at mass each Sunday knowing that my life is out of tune with the ideal the church preaches.

I am bemused by the correspondence regarding the Christian Church's attitude to section 28. Just how do people expect followers of Christ to respond? It seems as if we are expected to preach a wishy-washy love that demands no growth, no effort and no thought. Should I expect her to change that teaching to accommodate my needs? Or should I try to live as close to the ideal as is possible?

Name and address supplied

 Section 28 sends a message to society that one group is of less value than others. It sends that message to gay and bisexual young people at a particularly vulnerable stage of their lives - hence the homophobic bullying and the suicides and that is not just unacceptable, it is criminal.

Jenny Broughton
FFLAG (Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays) Jenny@swfflag.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: Voters in US primary boost McCain

fields.headline: Voters in US primary boost McCain
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The most heavily courted voters in the United States handed Senator John McCain an early lead in the New Hampshire Republican presidential primary yesterday.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Concord, New Hampshire
fields.body:
The most heavily courted voters in the United States handed Senator John McCain an early lead in the New Hampshire Republican presidential primary yesterday, adding a colourful touch to more reliable signs that the maverick Vietnam war veteran was heading for a state-wide victory that would throw this year's contest with the party frontrunner, George W Bush, wide open.

In the New Hampshire mountain hamlets of Dixville Notch (registered electorate 29) and Hart's Location (electorate 27), inhabitants held their time-honoured and internationally reported race to declare the first results of the battle for the White House in the early hours of yesterday morning.

Within minutes of the polls opening in the two villages they closed again, with all the votes in, giving Mr McCain 19 votes to Mr Bush's 17. In the Democratic contest, former Senator Bill Bradley led Vice-President Al Gore by 13 votes to five.

"The landslide has started. "Timber!" Mr McCain joked in a radio interview before the candidates fanned out across New Hampshire to greet voters.

With fine weather, the signs were of a high turnout of around 70%, far higher than is expected in November's presidential election.

"I'm going to win," a confident Mr Bush announced, as he made his first appearance of a day that could make or - just possibly - begin to break his presidential ambitions. Coffee in hand, the Texas governor arrived at a Manchester polling station shortly before 6.30am.

The Gore camp was equally upbeat about the contest with Mr Bradley. "We feel we've done just about everything we possibly could," Mr Gore's wife, Tipper, said on ABC television. "We feel like the energy is moving definitely to our campaign."

"I hope you will feel if you cast that vote that you're part of something new and fresh that is part of a new beginning," Mr Bradley said as he headed to a Concord factory.

The final New Hampshire opinion polls showed Mr McCain on course for a remarkable win over Mr Bush in the Republican race, and Mr Gore set to score a second victory over Mr Bradley in the Democratic contest, after defeating him in Iowa last week.

Mr McCain entered polling day with a final poll average of 43% against Mr Bush's 35%, millionaire conservative Steve Forbes's 14%, Alan Keyes's 8% and Gary Bauer's 1%.

In the Democratic race, Mr Gore had a poll average of 54% against Mr Bradley's 45%.

Mr Bradley has five weeks to re-energise his campaign before the next Democratic contests in the March 7 "Super Tuesday" primaries, when 16 states hold primaries or caucuses, including California and New York.

Mr Bradley's best hope of a significant win is in New York, where he is remembered for his decade as a basketball star with the New York Knicks. But Mr Gore lost no time in taking his victorious message to New York last night and was due to hold a 3am rally there.

The Republican contenders face a weekly succession of contests before Super Tuesday, with primaries in Delaware next week, South Carolina on February 19 and Arizona and Montana three days later.

fields.headline: Ambulance 'used to taxi partygoers'
fields.trailText: An ambulance trust is investigating claims that one of its vehicles was used to taxi off-duty staff from a private party in a 16-mile trip.
fields.body:
An ambulance trust is investigating claims that one of its vehicles was used to taxi off-duty staff from a private party in a 16-mile trip.

A spokesman for the Tees, East and North Yorkshire ambulance service NHS Trust confirmed that three staff had been suspended pending an inquiry into the alleged misuse of trust property.

The staff are alleged to have phoned for the ambulance from the party in Middlesbrough on January 20 when they could not get a taxi.

The ambulance is said to have driven 16 miles from its station in Middlesbrough to pick up the group and take them to destination. The alleged incident is not thought to have caused any disruption to the service, although the vehicle was one of only two emergency ambulances on call in Middlesbrough.

Peter Johnson, chief officer for the South Tees community health council, said: "If these allegations are true they are shocking and scandalous. I can't imagine what anybody in the service was thinking to do something like this, especially since there has been a major flu epidemic which has left us stretched."

fields.headline: Six-month delay for CSA reform
fields.trailText: Reform of the child support agency was deferred yesterday for a further six months until 2002 amid growing signs of anxiety about a computer intended to make the changes.
fields.body:
Reform of the child support agency was deferred yesterday for a further six months until 2002 amid growing signs of anxiety about a computer intended to make the changes.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, said the change was being put back to avoid "unacceptable risks" in the changeover.

The deferral means a simplified child support formula will be applied to new cases in April 2002. Last summer the operative date had been late 2001.

Existing cases will not be transferred from the present, deeply unpopular formula until later - some possibly not before 2004 - by which time many fathers will no longer have maintenance liability.

The postponement came days after the Commons social security committee voiced concern about spending plans for the computer system.

In the first use of a new ministerial power, Mr Darling had notified the committee of his intention to spend money developing the computer system before parliament approved the bill setting out the agency changes.

The committee was first told he wished to spend £60m before royal assent was granted, enabling the Affinity consortium - led by a US computer company, EDS - to start development. Subsequently however, this figure was revised to £6m.

Although the committee did not oppose the spending, it said it was worried that the proposal "bore little or no relation to the likely final version" and called for a review of how the ministerial power should be used in future.

Steve Webb, Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, said the apparent confusion over the computer did not bode well. It was sensible to have a further delay to avoid repeating mistakes made when the agency was established - "it would be a fiasco if they did try to do that".

One of the agency's worst problems has been the running of its complex maintenance formula with an off-the-shelf computer from the US. The new formula will not only be simpler, but will mean lower average payments and will allow lone parents on income support benefit to keep £10 a week of maintenance. - David Brindle

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, said the change was being put back to avoid "unacceptable risks" in the changeover. Existing cases will not be transferred from the present, deeply unpopular formula until later - some possibly not before 2004 - by which time many fathers will no longer have maintenance liability. The postponement came days after the Commons social security committee voiced concern about spending plans for the computer system. In the first use of a new ministerial power, Mr Darling had notified the committee of his intention to spend money developing the computer system before parliament approved the bill setting out the agency changes. The committee was first told he wished to spend £60m before royal assent was granted, enabling the Affinity consortium - led by a US computer company, EDS - to start development. fields.headline: Cutter crisis
fields.trailText: The clipper Cutty Sark, a landmark in Greenwich, London, since 1954, is being ripped apart by its corroding Victorian iron frame and might have to close to the public unless £5.5m can be raised for repairs.
fields.body:
The clipper Cutty Sark, a landmark in Greenwich, London, since 1954, is being ripped apart by its corroding Victorian iron frame and might have to close to the public unless £5.5m can be raised for repairs.

The ship, built on the Clyde in 1869 for the annual race to bring tea back from China, was the fastest in the world and regarded as the most beautiful of the tea clippers.

The charitable trust which operates it has restored the three masts but learned from an engineering survey that repairs are needed urgently on the frame.

"Ships are ephemeral and never intended to last," said Cutty Sark's captain, Simon Waite, yesterday. "We are trying to do something unnatural, to hold back the tide." - Maev Kennedy

webTitle: Womb op ruling was not first

fields.headline: Womb op ruling was not first
fields.trailText: A judge whose go-ahead for a hysterectomy on a woman with learning disabilities provoked an outcry last week was following in the path of a similar ruling weeks before.
fields.body:
A judge whose go-ahead for a hysterectomy on a woman with learning disabilities provoked an outcry last week was following in the path of a similar ruling weeks before.

The first ruling, on a 19-year-old with Down's syndrome, had not been made public. Normally in the high court family division, where such cases are dealt with, hearings are in private and judgments not released unless the judge decides an issue is of sufficient public interest to warrant it.

Last week's case, a 28-year-old known as SL whose widowed mother wanted to prevent her from getting pregnant, came to light because the judge who sanctioned the hysterectomy, Mr Justice Wall, decided his ruling should be made public.

In the unpublished judgment Mr Justice Bennett ruled in November that the 19-year-old, named as Z, should have a hysterectomy. She is in a relationship with a Down's syndrome man. The judge was told that her periods were painful and distressing to her.

The revelation that SL's case is not isolated caused anger yesterday among charities campaigning for the rights of people with severe learning disabilities. David Congden of Mencap said: "It's unacceptable to carry out major invasive surgery and only justifiable if there are overriding medical reasons."

Judi Clements, director of Mind, said: "I'm horrified that major surgery is being given without medical justification to young women when there are methods of contraception which are less invasive." A hysterectomy was a "heavy-handed and crude" method of preventing pregnancy.

In both cases the woman's mother applied for court approval for a hysterectomy. - Clare Dyer

webTitle: Royal Opera cuts top seat prices

fields.headline: Royal Opera cuts top seat prices
fields.standfirst: Royal Opera House
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera House is cutting the price of some of its most expensive seats in a bid to counter claims that it is still too snooty.
fields.body:
The Royal Opera House is cutting the price of some of its most expensive seats in a bid to counter claims that it is still too snooty.

The concession may go some way to placate the government, which last week warned that there was not enough of a "social mix", particularly in the best seats that were still the exclusive domain of the rich and corporate clients.

Some stalls seats for top-price ballets such as Coppelia will now cost £20, while the same seats for Wagner's opera Die Meistersinger have been halved in price to £50.

Although the scope of the change is limited, the reductions include 23 seats in the rear of the amphitheatre that had got more expensive when the house reopened in December, despite management assurances that prices would fall.

The tradition of day tickets, where 69 seats are held back to be sold on the morning of a performance, will also be restored.

The changes come into effect at the start of the next booking period on February 16.

A spokesman for the opera house, in Covent Garden, central London, said yesterday that it was conducting a wider review of prices for operas and ballets that would take effect on bookings from September.

Fiachra Gibbons

webTitle: Musicians rage over move to dismantle library

fields.headline: Musicians rage over move to dismantle library
fields.trailText: Manchester city council was accused of "unimaginable cultural vandalism" yesterday after announcing plans to dismantle one of the country's top music libraries.
fields.body:
Manchester city council was accused of "unimaginable cultural vandalism" yesterday after announcing plans to dismantle one of the country's top music libraries.

Leading members of the classical music world, including composer and conductor Sir Peter Maxwell Davies, Sir Simon Rattle, Sir Harrison Birtwistle and Sir Edward Downes, have attacked the proposed cutbacks to the Henry Watson music library which, they say, will devastate "a jewel in our cultural heritage".

Under the proposals the collection at Manchester's central library is to lose its specialist librarian, while the 600,000 books and scores will be rehoused within a general reading library or transferred onto new media technology.

Sir Peter, who grew up in Manchester, said: "Without the Henry Watson music library and its excellent, well-trained and knowledgeable staff, I simply wouldn't be here today.

"It was essential for me to be free to burrow among the shelves and to be able to seek advice when necessary, both as a schoolboy and as a student. There is nowhere else with the breadth and richness of this collection."

Henry Watson left his collection, which includes rare Handel and Vivaldi manuscripts, to the city council in 1902 for the "citizens of a free library of music worthy of the musical reputation of Manchester".

Edward Gregson, principal of the Northern College of Music, said: "I am afraid it is another example of dumbing-down. If we no longer have music libraries we will not be able to foster the kind of talent we have produced in the past. It is a vital resource for music students and music-lovers in the north. I know these things cost money but a music library does not cost a fortune to maintain."

Paul Catcheside, the council's director of libraries, said the priority had to be to cut costs. "The Henry Watson collection is a wonderful resource. But it is quite expensive and we have to look at other ways of doing things. At the moment the city council spends over £20 a head every year on library services - which is just too much.

"We are overstretched at present and it would be unfair to expect the city council to continue funding a resource available to everyone in the north-west."

The Henry Watson library includes the Aylesford collection, left to the city in 1965, which contains manuscripts originally belonging to Charles Jennens, Handel's librettist.

In 1972 the library discovered that it also had five previously unknown violin sonatas, signed by Vivaldi. They are now known as Vivaldi's Manchester Violin Sonatas.

The library also has pop, jazz and rock sections and examination scores for those learning instruments.

The planned cutbacks are set to be approved by Manchester city council over the next two weeks.

Other subject departments within Manchester central library, including social sciences, IT, language and literature, arts, and Chinese, will also be merged with the general reading collection under the proposals.

Frustrated musicians are threatening to disrupt the next council meeting by playing recordings of Vivaldi at full volume.

"We are not going to let them get away with this one," said a violinist.

fields.headline: Payout ends GCHQ dispute
fields.trailText: The final issue in the long dispute at the GCHQ intelligence-gathering centre was resolved yesterday when staff sacked for refusing to accept a ban on union membership were compensated for their loss of pension rights.
fields.body:
The final issue in the long dispute at the GCHQ intelligence-gathering centre was resolved yesterday when staff sacked for refusing to accept a ban on union membership were compensated for their loss of pension rights.

Robin Cook told the Commons 14 former workers would receive compensation in a scheme that will cost up to £550,000 after tax. Eight have retired, three have returned to GCHQ, and three have taken jobs elsewhere.

The 14 acquired almost iconic status in the union movement following the 1984 ban imposed by the government; Lady Thatcher, then prime minister, claimed the unions were a security threat, although there was no evidence to support this.

Mike Grindley, their spokesman, said yesterday: "We are relieved that at long last our pension rights have been sorted. We have not got everything back we were owed, but we have written that off. It has been a long, hard struggle".

Charlie Cochrane, secretary of the council of civil service unions, said goodwill had finally settled a complex legal issue. Shortly after it came to power in 1997 the government honoured its pledge to restore union rights, albeit with conditions attached, at GCHQ, which is based near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire. - Richard Norton-Taylor

webTitle: Parents 'ignoring advice' on cot death prevention

fields.headline: Parents 'ignoring advice' on cot death prevention
fields.standfirst: The Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths
fields.trailText: Most parents of babies do not follow advice such as not to smoke near their child nor put it to sleep on its back, according to a report into cot deaths published today.
fields.body:
Most parents of babies do not follow advice such as not to smoke near their child nor put it to sleep on its back, according to a report into cot deaths published today.

The report, compiled by paediatricians and funded by the department of health, also said that routines for investigating when a baby died unexpectedly were "inadequate and in need of revision".

Both natural and unnatural causes of death were not being spotted, said the authors, due to poor investigation and the application of the blanket definition of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), or cot death.

The report was undertaken by a monitoring scheme set up by the government some years ago - the Confidential Enquiry Into Stillbirths and Deaths in Infancy, and by the Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths.

Researchers looked at the deaths of 450 babies aged one week to one year between 1993 and 1996, of which 325 were categorised as cot deaths.

In 60% the researchers decided that poor care was involved - usually parents failing to follow advice widely put out for safeguarding infants, such as putting them to sleep on their backs, avoiding duvets or quilts, and maintaining a smoke-free zone at all times.

In 6% of cases they found that the baby had been maltreated, but the maltreatment had not been discovered. This included deliberate harm and neglect or extremely poor care.

There was no evidence to sustain some of the theories around cot death - airline flights and mattress types were not a risk factor. Breathing monitors showed no value in preventing deaths.

The authors were critical of the way baby deaths are investigated.

Postmortems were not always thorough, they found. Medical and family histories that might be important were not always available to those who were deciding the cause of death and signing the death certificate.

"As a result it was believed that causes of death, both natural and unnatural, may be unrecognised," the report said. Consequently, parents did not receive the proper support and advice and "uninformed speculation concerning maltreatment may arise".

The authors recommended stronger procedures. All families where an infant death occurred should be visited at home within 48 hours by a paediatrician or another health professional who would liaise with a specially trained police officer to gather information about the baby, family, and circumstances of the death, and to offer support.

Postmortems should be done by a paediatric pathologist trained in examining babies, who should have the information from the home visit. All the professionals should meet to pool their information and decide what caused the death and how best to help the family.

The study found that there were no ethnic differences between families likely to experience a cot death, but social and economic factors were evident.

Many of the families whose babies died inexplicably in the 1990s lived in overcrowded, damp and mouldy housing, their parents were unemployed, and they had a low income.

Many cot death babies were found to have had medical problems from birth, and their mothers were found to be more likely to have had a stillbirth or another child die in infancy.

Cot deaths were found to be more common in boys (63%). Such babies often weighed less than average at birth and had been delivered early. Twins were at higher risk.

webTitle: Teenager fails to win son back

fields.headline: Teenager fails to win son back
fields.trailText: A teenage mother who changed her mind after putting her new-born son up for adoption failed to win him back yesterday.
fields.body:
A teenage mother who changed her mind after putting her new-born son up for adoption failed to win him back yesterday.

The 19-year-old, who had been at university for two weeks when she found she was pregnant, was told she could not remove her son, who is a year old tomorrow, from the couple he has been with since last April after they were approved as adopters.

Mr Justice Sumner ruled in the high court family division that the natural mother had been unreasonable in changing her mind, and that the couple he is with can adopt him despite her objections.

Describing his judgment as a "fearful" one, the judge said he was satisfied that to return the boy, identified as A, to his natural mother now would pose too great a risk of disturbance and lasting damage to him.

The ruling makes clear to mothers giving up children that if they change their minds it could be too late.

"The risks to his health and future development are too great," said Mr Justice Sumner. "It would be traumatic in the short run and likely to be damaging in the long run. Any hypothetically reasonable mother would see the strength of this and give her consent to the adoption.

"This is one of the most heartfelt cases I have had to decide. It is a dispute between two good families. The strength of feeling has been intense, but it is a tribute to the parties that the hearing was conducted in a calm and reflective manner.

"This is a judgment that I would much rather not have given. It is not because at the end of the day I have doubts but because inevitably I am going to hurt someone very much indeed by my decision. I would wish to soften the blow if there was any way to do so. But I have to say that after much deliberation I have come to the clear conclusion I should make an adoption order in the circumstances of this case."

A's natural mother, the daughter of a civil servant and a social worker, contacted a voluntary adoption agency when she found she was pregnant and began arrangements for A to be adopted soon after birth.

He was born on February 3, on February 5 he was placed with foster parents and on April 24 he was placed with the couple approved as adopters, who also have an adopted girl aged four. The mother and her mother met them beforehand.

The judge said that by July last year the mother had changed her mind about adoption and began moves to get the baby back. Refusing her application, he said he was satisfied that it was now best for the baby, who was "much loved" by all the parties, to stay where he was.

Last night Felicity Collier, chief executive of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering, said there was a delicate balance between making sure that children were not unsettled when they had formed attachments to new families, and the child and the mother's right to have a relationship.

"There's much interest at the moment in adoption being used more quickly for small children, but we must always remember that the time after birth for young mothers is a very difficult one," she said. "They are sometimes not clear about the decisions they make, and decisions made quickly have life-long implications. The most important thing is always the long-term welfare of the child."

Nick Glanville, project manager of the Adoption and Fostering Information Line, said: "When an adoption order is made the viewpoint is that it's irrevocable, and in most cases which come to be challenged that's often the view that's held by the judge. It's the view that prevails.

"Adoption is a process whereby parental rights are transferred to an adult or couple and are terminated from another. You could have lots of children who are adopted by families in a state of almost constant limbo, with the prospect of their birth parents coming back after a period of time saying they have changed their minds. That just can't be done, other than in obscure circumstances."

webTitle: New arbitrator made name putting anti-union cases

fields.headline: New arbitrator made name putting anti-union cases
fields.trailText: The high court judge chosen to arbitrate between trade unions and employers over the new legal right to union recognition made his name presenting anti-union cases in the most controversial industrial disputes of the Thatcher years: the miners' strike and the Wapping lockout.
fields.body:
The high court judge chosen to arbitrate between trade unions and employers over the new legal right to union recognition made his name presenting anti-union cases in the most controversial industrial disputes of the Thatcher years: the miners' strike and the Wapping lockout.

Sir Michael Burton, picked by the government to chair the beefed-up central arbitration committee which can rule on contested union claims for the right to negotiate for members, represented working miners during the 1984-85 coal dispute and News International in its 1986 confrontation with the print unions.

The appointment, yet to be formally announced, comes after months of argument between the government, the TUC and the Confederation of British Industry over who should get the crucial post.

The TUC had hoped for George Bain, who chaired the low pay commission on the minimum wage, while the cabinet office minister Lord Falconer argued for his friend Sir Stephen Richards, another high court judge and an Oxford contemporary of Tony Blair. But Sir Stephen was resisted by the unions, who regarded him as one of "Tony's cronies" without industrial relations experience.

Now the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is understood to have settled on Sir Michael - whose industrial relations experience is unlikely to be to the taste of many trade unionists - with guidance from 10 Downing Street.

During the miners' strike, the watershed industrial dispute of the post-war era, Sir Michael was the QC in a pivotal case brought by two strike-breaking Yorkshire miners against the National Union of Mineworkers.

The action led to the strike being outlawed and the seizure of NUM funds. The then coal board chairman, Ian MacGregor, called the case "the key to the solution of the strike".

Sir Michael, 53, also represented Rupert Murdoch's News International against the print unions after the company sacked 5,000 print workers and moved the production of four national newspapers to Wapping, east London.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Vote early, vote often - in Welsh
fields.body:
Vote early, vote often - in Welsh

A mix-up in ballot papers for this week's Ceredigion byelection, caused by Plaid Cymru MP Cynog Dafis resigning, has been found by a Welsh speaker at the Electoral Reform Society.

Welsh speakers among 1,150 postal voters were instructed by a translation error to mark their ballot slip twice - effectively spoiling their vote. A spokesman for the acting returning officer said it was too late to do anything and anyway people knew to vote for one candidate.

Beatles voted best band ever

The Beatles have been declared "best band ever" in a poll of readers of the NME weekly music paper.

At a London awards ceremony last night Blur beat last year's winners, Manic Street Preachers, for best band, a title Blur last won in 1995.

Dome to open evenings

Evening openings on Fridays and Saturdays will start in April at the Millennium Dome, with the doors staying open until 11pm.

Sales of April tickets began yesterday; the month, which includes Easter and school holidays, will be a key one for the dome.

Learn to relax on the job

Employees are to be taught how to avoid back pain - the largest single cause of sickness absence at work.

More than 330 employers applied for government funding, with 19 chosen yesterday to run pilot projects, including staff at St Helens council in Lancashire being taught relaxation, posture and exercise.

Bond passport was for real spy

A passport used by Ian Fleming, author of the James Bond novels, for real-life spying is to be auctioned this month.

During the war Fleming was sent by British intelligence to Gibraltar to spy on fascist Spain in a mission codenamed Operation Goldeneye; he later chose Goldeneye as the name for his house in Jamaica, and it was also used for a Bond film in 1995.

Chat online to a doctor

A website was launched last night giving medical advice and online chat from health professionals, including a psychotherapist and an obstetrician.

GMTV doctor Hilary Jones is to front the site, part of NetDoctor.co.uk, a European network.

Teenagers save baby's life

Kenneth Coyle, 17, and Anthony Edges, 16, saved a six-week-old baby by catching her as she was thrown 20ft from an upstairs window of a burning house in Allenton, Derby.

Charlotte Morris's parents Kirsty Chambers, 31, and Tony Morris, 40, were rescued by firefighters.

webTitle: Ulster peace process plunges back into crisis

fields.headline: Ulster peace process plunges back into crisis
fields.trailText: The government will risk a republican backlash by suspending Northern Ireland's power- sharing executive by the end of the week if the IRA refuses to give a firm commitment on decommissioning weapons.
fields.body:
The government will risk a republican backlash by suspending Northern Ireland's power- sharing executive by the end of the week if the IRA refuses to give a firm commitment on decommissioning weapons.

Amid fears that the peace process is on the brink of collapse, Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, will launch a last-ditch attempt to broker a deal on arms during an intensive round of talks with political leaders over the next two days.

His chances of success, however, appeared to be slim last night when David Trimble, Northern Ireland's first minister, said he could no longer remain in the power-sharing executive after John de Chastelain reported that the IRA was still refusing to disarm.

His warning was immediately rejected by Gerry Adams who spoke of a "real crisis" in the peace process.

Mr Mandelson tried to strike an upbeat note last night when he insisted that there were several "positive" elements in the de Chastelain report, which was passed to the British and Irish governments shortly before midnight on Monday.

Ministers also took heart from an IRA statement which said that it remained "totally committed to the peace process", adding that it had no plans to abandon its ceasefire. The "IRA's guns are silent", the provisionals added.

It is understood, however, that the de Chastelain report falls a long way short of Mr Trimble's demands for the IRA to begin disarming this month.

Mr Trimble insisted yesterday that the power-sharing executive be suspended immediately. He claimed republicans had reneged on a commitment to begin disarming. Sinn Fein insisted that republicans merely gave a commitment in last year's review of the peace process to hold discussions with Gen de Chastelain in line with the Good Friday agreement.

The general yesterday warned the British and Irish governments of the dangers of suspending the executive. It is understood that he told ministers the IRA would boycott his commission - ending any hopes of decommissioning - if the executive were suspended.

Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, reinforced the message yesterday when he warned of "disastrous consequences" if the executive were suspended. However, the British government is expected to take the risk of suspending the executive by the end of the week if the IRA still refuses to begin the process of disarming. It is thought that republicans are unlikely to make enough concessions to prevent such a drastic course. Suspending the executive will be seen as the "least bad option".

Ministers will risk a republican boycott of Gen de Chastelain's commission and a severe backlash from Sinn Fein whose leaders bitterly attacked Mr Trimble yesterday for attempting to impose a decommissioning deadline outside the agreement.

If ministers fail to suspend the executive Mr Trimble would resign over the weekend, taking his party's three other ministers with him. The assembly's complicated voting procedure mean that Mr Trimble would never again be reinstated as first minister, even if there were an agreement on decommissioning.

After suspending the executive, the government would probably announce a review to try to break the five-year deadlock over arms. But with the executive out of action any gesture by the IRA would be highly unlikely.

Mr Trimble and Mr Adams demonstrated the gulf over the arms issue during separate press conferences at Stormont. Mr Trimble said that suspension of the executive was "regrettable but inevitable". He said: "It was made clear to Sinn Fein again and again and again that this risk [by forming the executive] we were taking would be time-limited and would not run beyond the end of January. It's a matter of very great regret to me that this has turned out this way."

Mr Adams said his party had not defaulted on decommissioning. Holding up a copy of the Good Friday Agreement, he said: "You show me in this where our party has defaulted. There is no default by Sinn Fein on this issue."

fields.headline: Kilfoyle condemns London advisers
fields.standfirst:
New Labour 'has become a perjorative term in eyes of many'

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The former minister, Peter Kilfoyle, took up his role of self-proclaimed critical friend of the government last night, warning Tony Blair to focus on improving public services rather than tax cuts for middle England.
fields.body:
The former minister, Peter Kilfoyle, took up his role of self-proclaimed critical friend of the government last night, warning Tony Blair to focus on improving public services rather than tax cuts for middle England.

Whether to cut tax or increase spending on pensioners and the unemployed was a "crunch" decision for Labour in advance of the next election, the Liverpool Walton MP said.

Regarded as a loyalist until his surprise resignation as a junior defence minister on Sunday night, Mr Kilfoyle's tone noticeably sharpened yesterday. He launched a broadside against government advisers for their "wholly London perspective" which led to "very often a lack of understanding" of issues in Merseyside and the regions.

Mr Kilfoyle said yesterday he intended to champion the views of people in his home city "and other places around the country where there are a lot of people who don't think they have an effective voice within the government".

The price of ignoring them, he said, would be an American-style situation where barely half the population voted in general elections.

In BBC interviews, Mr Kilfoyle waded in on the side of those that are urging Mr Blair to be more ambitious and less defensive in his thinking on the next manifesto. "The crunch comes when you're coming into an election, and if there's any suggestion that there is a give-away for electoral purposes, rather than keeping one's nerve, making the structural changes that need to be made in government both nationally and regionally and also living up to your commitments to those people that most need our support, like pensioners, like the unemployed," he said.

"We have to keep pressing on with ensuring that we deliver for them and not be tempted down the road in my view of increased tax cuts that may placate Middle England but will lead to some kind of diminution of public services."

Though he once signed Mr Blair's nomination papers for Labour leader, Mr Kilfoyle said in an interview New Labour had become "a perjorative term in many people's eyes" which he no longer used. "What I am is a great fan of attempts to modernise both the country and the Labour party, that dosen't mean you have to affect all of the things which are associated with New Labour." He insisted he still remained friendly with the prime minister but added: "A decent friend surely would act as, if you like,a conscience of sorts reflecting the views of those who otherwise might not get a decent hearing."

Though many people thought him disappointed when he was pushed out in 1997 from the high-profile schools job he held in opposition and given lowly ministerial jobs in the cabinet office and then defence, Mr Kilfoyle said his resignation was "nothing about sour grapes".

He had resigned because the conflict between being a constituency MP and minister had become "unmanageable", he said in a letter to the Liverpool Echo. He confirmed his interest in the job of mayor of Liverpool, though urged ministers to "take a leap of imagination" and give the post more clout that has been allowed in London.

fields.headline: Hague's gift of poisoned chalice
fields.standfirst:
Portillo well placed to be next Tory leader but first he must do battle with Brown

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo is perfectly placed to be the next Tory leader after being appointed shadow chancellor last night. William Hague knows that but appointed him anyway.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo is perfectly placed to be the next Tory leader after being appointed shadow chancellor last night. William Hague knows that but appointed him anyway.

Part of Mr Hague's calculation is straightforward: general elections are won and lost on the economy and he needed a big personality in the shadow chancellor's job. But the decision is not as simple as that. There is a machiavellian side to it. He wants Mr Portillo to share responsibility for the general election defeat, hoping this might make him a less attractive alternate leader.

And by pitting him against the chancellor, Gordon Brown, probably the most successful member of the Labour cabinet, he has given Mr Portillo a formidable task. While Mr Hague will hope that Mr Portillo can dent Labour's reputation for competent stewardship of the economy, he will not be too upset if it is Mr Portillo's reputation that ends up dented.

Mr Portillo, 46, replaces Francis Maude, who was an embarrassment to his own side, regularly coming off second best in his encounters in the Commons with Mr Brown. He often left the impression of being uncomfortable with economics, in command of neither the detail nor the big picture.

Mr Hague said of Mr Portillo last night: "We have got here someone who is an already proven political heavyweight." But will he be any more successful than Mr Maude?

What Mr Portillo needs is a recession and there is no sign of one. The economy is in good shape, with the predictions of a slump following the collapse of the Asian markets failing to materialise.

Mr Portillo is rightwing on economics, a Thatcherite free marketeer, but Labour has occupied some of that territory. Mr Brown has continued to cut income tax, which has proved generally popular, even if not with Labour traditionalists.

Labour's most recent private polling confirms disillusionment among its core vote, but party headquarters is working on a strategy that it hopes will see it pick up more voters from the centre ground happy with the economy. On current polling Labour can expect another three-figure majority at the general election.

Mr Brown's decision to make the Bank of England independent within days of the 1997 general election is generally judged to be a success, to the extent that the Conservatives, initially hostile, are now reviewing their position. The new deal, which also met with scepticism, is now seen as delivering jobs.

There is not much room for manoeuvre for Mr Portillo. He cannot readily accuse Labour of heading for "boom and bust" economics, given the performance of the Tory government of which Mr Portillo was part.

Mr Brown does rigorous research on his opponents and there is plenty of material with which to attack Mr Portillo, who was a member of the notorious No Turning Back group of about 20 young Tory MPs committed to Thatcherism, avidly embracing the ideas spilling out of rightwing think tanks in the 1980s. He was an advocate of the discredited poll tax.

Since the general election defeat Mr Portillo has attempted to reinvent himself as a caring Conservative. But he cannot outbid Mr Brown on compassion. Mr Brown's politics were shaped by his upbringing in a Church of Scotland manse and the old-fashioned Scottish Labour party commitment to equality. Mr Brown has established a reputation for competence in the economy while acknowledging his socialist background through reduction of third world debt and, at home, redistribution of wealth through the backdoor.

Mr Brown will not be unhappy at the prospect of taking on Mr Portillo, given the fact that the latter is identified in the public mind with the last Tory government. It is one of the oddities of this reshuffle that Mr Hague has ditched shadow cabinet members such as John Redwood because he reminds the public of the last government and yet appoints Mr Portillo, the epitome of rightwing Conservatism, the prime hate figure of many who despised the Thatcher and Major regimes.

The one big Labour weakness that Mr Portillo will seek to exploit is Europe. The Conservatives believe this is the issue that could eat into the government's huge majority. That might be wishful thinking but Labour is sufficiently worried to try to avoid fighting the next election on Europe.

Mr Brown wants to fight on his competent running of the economy but other ministers, such as the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, think it is unsustainable to go into the next general election without giving a clearer indication of where Labour stands on the single currency. It is a division that could be to Mr Portillo's advantage.

The government will stick to its formula that a decision on the single currency can be left to a referendum some time in the future.

Mr Portillo, a passionate Eurosceptic, can challenge the government's extremely flexible five conditions for entry and attempt to tie it down on the timing of the referendum.

Mr Portillo has a gut dislike of the direction the European Union is going. The issue will ensure explosive contests between the chancellor and his shadow.

Mr Portillo can explore in detail Mr Brown's ambiguous position on the single currency. The chancellor is said to be still committed to the single currency but to have cooled on the timing of entry, preferring to go in later rather than earlier.

But Mr Portillo too is vulnerable on Europe, on which at times he has verged on xenophobic.

Mr Hague is taking a huge risk. Mr Portillo may be beaten on a regular basis by Mr Brown, who will prove to be a difficult target, but at least Mr Portillo has the charisma that Mr Hague lacks. Even a Portillo dented by Mr Brown will hold more appeal for many Tories than Mr Hague.

The Tory leadership is within Mr Portillo's grasp. The only real question is when. Before the general election would be seen as treachery. But the putsch should not be too long after polling day.

fields.headline: Portillo rises to the surface
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The appointment of Micheal Portillo as the shadow chancellor of the exchequer was the outstanding element of interest in the small reshuffle of the Opposition front bench team. The beleaguered William Hague has effectively elevated Mr Portillo to the second most important post on the Tory frontbench within two months of the former defence secretary's re-election to the Commons.
fields.body:
There was a spring in the step of Michael Portillo yesterday morning. Although his face was composed with an appropriate mixture of deference and respect as he entered St Margaret's Church, Westminster, he still looked confident and relaxed as he took his place among the ranks of Conservative MPs for the memorial service in honour of his predecessor as Conservative MP for Kensington and Chelsea, the late Alan Clark. It was not until later in the day that it emerged that Mr Portillo had good reason for this air of suppressed optimism.

His appointment as the shadow chancellor of the exchequer was the outstanding element of interest in the small reshuffle of the Opposition front bench team. The beleaguered William Hague has effectively elevated Mr Portillo to the second most important post on the Tory frontbench within two months of the former defence secretary's re-election to the Commons.

Since the departure of Peter Lilley, there has been no deputy leader within the Tory party and Mr Hague did not make an appointment to that post yesterday. What he did manage to achieve, however, was a confirmation of the alternative official position of leader-in-waiting; in doing so, he appears to have made the most extraordinary political misjudgment.

It was not difficult yesterday to imagine with what mischievous delight - and despair - that great diarist in the sky, Alan Clark himself, would have made of it all. By any reckoning, Hague's leadership is doomed. The Conservative party is in despair. Even in the short period of time recently when there has been no Tory cause célèbre and the government has been suffering in the prints, Mr Hague's opinion poll ratings have continued to fall.

There is open discussion among Tory MPs of the need to replace him before the next election, largely on the grounds that it would be difficult for anybody to do any worse. And at this point, having whipped the Conservative party up into a frenzy of rightwing Euroscepticism, he chooses to promote as shadow chancellor the one rightwinger from whom he has most to fear.

But in what can only be interpreted as an attempt to demonstrate some sort of political balance, Mr Hague has sacked John Redwood, a rightwinger, and John Maples, who is arguably on the left. In both cases he has made a mistake.

He caused anxiety on the set because the grimaces he was making led the film crew to believe he was about to be sick. It turned out he was practising how to smile.

fields.headline: Business interests could cause conflict
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Archibald John Norman has a reputation as one of the best businessmen of his generation, but his many interests are bound to lead to charges of conflict of interest in his new role on the environment and transport beat.
fields.body:
Archibald John Norman has a reputation as one of the best businessmen of his generation, but his many interests are bound to lead to charges of conflict of interest in his new role on the environment and transport beat.

The Tories' new transport spokesman, for instance, is a director of Railtrack, which is regularly criticised for under-investment and the impact that could have on safety. The association is not a new one. Mr Norman was a member of the British Rail board before privatisation.

He will also be monitoring environment matters - after nearly a decade of running supermarket giant Asda, whose huge out-of-town stores have attracted widespread criticism for the damage they have caused to greenfield sites and the impact they have had on local community shops.

It is not as though Mr Norman's business ambitions are in the past. He recently became chairman of Manchester-based textiles company French plc and is also leading a group of four high-profile businessmen who have pledged to take over an ailing store group and turn it around.

Recently there has been speculation that Mr Norman was refuelling his business career after becoming disillusioned with politics and dissatisfied with the influence he had.

fields.headline: No room for 'old school' pupil
fields.standfirst:
Maples Failed to hit the jugular

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Nice guys finish last, they say in the kind of business school in which John Maples was trained. Last night he paid the price for failing to do the shadow cabinet's business against Frank Dobson, George Robertson and Robin Cook.
fields.body:
Nice guys finish last, they say in the kind of business school in which John Maples was trained. Last night he paid the price for failing to do the shadow cabinet's business against Frank Dobson, George Robertson and Robin Cook.

It was not that the Tory MP for Stratford-on-Avon failed to understand the issues or to put in as much work as most of his shadow colleagues, except the Stakhanovite John Redwood. What he lacked was an instinct for the jugular.

Worse, he was by temperament a moderate Tory of the old school - Marlborough College in his case - having to work in an increasingly immoderate party. He loyally peddled the Hague line against the euro and EU integration, but his heart never quite seemed in his work.

It looked very different when Mr Maples got back to Westminster in May 1997 after losing marginal Lewisham West in 1992. A junior minister under John Major, he missed the years of Tory disaster and looked set to go far.

There was a red light over his career in those years in which he hunted for a byelection seat: Maples wrote a candid report on the Tories' weaknesses under Major. Silence was the best policy on the NHS, he suggested. It was promptly leaked.

A Cambridge and Harvard business school graduate (a barrister too), he had made a modest pile as a management consultant and married Jane Corbin, a tough and glamorous TV reporter, before becoming an MP in 1987.

He hammered Labour weakness over NHS waiting lists, but the bruiser in Frank Dobson saw him off. Kosovo was a near-impossible policy to attack from anything but the far right.

Now he has had to make way for Francis Maude to do better. "Sometimes there just aren't enough seats at the table," one colleague said sympathetically last night.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The uphill task of teaching small children about life's vast and confusing rule book preoccupies Kirsty Wark and Professor Helen Haste, her guest in Tuning Into Children (11.0am, Radio 4). Their interviews with 5 to 9-year-olds illustrate the confusion that children can experience when apparently black-and-white adult commandments suddenly become greyish. The youngsters learn to cope with such inconsistencies - but retain a rigorous view of whether they are fair.
fields.body:
The uphill task of teaching small children about life's vast and confusing rule book preoccupies Kirsty Wark and Professor Helen Haste, her guest in Tuning Into Children (11.0am, Radio 4). Their interviews with 5 to 9-year-olds illustrate the confusion that children can experience when apparently black-and-white adult commandments suddenly become greyish. The youngsters learn to cope with such inconsistencies - but retain a rigorous view of whether they are fair.

Origins (9.0pm, Radio 4), the series which tracks the development of life on earth, now reaches the parting of the ways. The Neanderthals, though they had large brains and may have used fire and tools, still marched resolutely up an evolutionary blind alley. Or did they? The discovery of a child's skeleton, apparently a cross between a Neanderthal woman and homo sapiens, shows they lived together. So Neanderthals may have been the earliest victims of ethnic cleansing.

fields.headline: Big is beautiful
fields.standfirst: The producers of a new bio-pic about footballer George Best have only three months to get it into cinemas, thanks to a bizarre deal they made with Sky Premier.  Keely Winstone  reports on fraught times at the film channel
fields.trailText: While Sky's top execs were busy sharpening their movie know-how at the Sundance Film Festival last week, back home their relations with the UK's indie film scene had taken a knock. The makers of Sky Pictures' bio-pic of 60s footballing hero George Best won a High Court injunction, preventing Sky from broadcasting the film.
fields.body:
While Sky's top execs were busy sharpening their movie know-how at the Sundance Film Festival last week, back home their relations with the UK's indie film scene had taken a knock. The makers of Sky Pictures' bio-pic of 60s footballing hero George Best won a High Court injunction, preventing Sky from broadcasting the film.

At least, until cinema-goers get a chance to see it first. After months of wrangling, producer Mary McGuckian and her actor husband John Lynch (who plays Best) have got three months to sign with a distributor and get it into the multiplexes - after that, Sky is free to show it on Sky Premier as planned.

To the outside world, Best had looked like a mainstay in the first slate of UK films Sky was teeing up for "release" on Premier. Using the model of US pay-channel HBO (which carries no advertising and the slogan "it's not TV, it's HBO"), Sky wanted to create a prestige channel where discerning subscribers could get the very best of new British.

Other films off the blocks with Best included the Brit-Pack Tube Tales, with strands directed by Ewan McGregor and Bob Hoskins, black comedy Milk, starring Dawn French and James Fleet, and the upcoming Saving Grace with Brenda Blethyn. All were described as "feature films" - nicely side-stepping the made-for-TV label - and they were being made by film (rather than TV) writers, directors and producers who could then sell them theatrically overseas. Never one to turn down money, the British film industry welcomed the cash-injection; as Best producer McGuckian says, "it looked like a positive proposition".

Behind the scenes, though, her film was already starting to rock the Pictures-Premier boat. Whereas Sky had full control of most of its films commissioned for Premier (on TV and at the cinema), a smaller stake in Best meant it only had a say in what happened on UK TV. Eager to stay at helm of the film's destiny, the film makers had passed up their fees so they could hang on to cinema rights. They wanted their film to go to the big screen first, while Sky was committed to its subscribers.

But there's little patience to be found when a film tries to work the awkward line between cinema and TV. If it airs on TV and then later tries for a cinema release it's forever tainted by the "TV film" tag, and if there's a film on TV that film-goers don't recognise as having made it to the cinemas, it doesn't have the feature film kudos and is dismissed as "made-for-TV" or "straight-to-video".

Despite these unwritten rules, with McGuckian still pushing to get Best in the cinemas and Sky not wanting to break its Sky Premier first policy, the idea of a simultaneous release was hatched. Sky Premier would get to broadcast the film once during the opening weekend at the cinemas, in exchange for backing the cinema release. McGuckian even had a distributor interested.

But with tradition against it, the idea wasn't destined to last long. Exhibitors are always going to be at best frosty to a film that's on TV (even if it is only once) at the same time that it's showing in their cinemas. After all, it's the current release pattern (cinema, video, TV) that fuels the box office and keeps them in jobs.

Sky's ambition to make Premier Britain's answer to HBO quickly moved beyond original films anyway. Big-budget drama series like The Tenth Kingdom, from the writer of TV's Gulliver's Travels, and The Stretch, reuniting ex-EastEnders duo Anita Dobson and Leslie Grantham, were being lined up, while David Baddiel was given the go-ahead on a new sitcom.

And these were to fill a hole in Premier's content which opened up with news that sister-company and distributor 20th Century Fox wanted to put "selected" Sky Pictures into UK cinemas - before the Sky Premier premiere. Putting some producers out of their misery with the chance of a cinema outing, but looking like a volte-face on Sky's part, the change of plan was shrugged off with "as we evolve, our strategy evolves". (Not fast enough, however, to let Best into the new theatrical loop and off a TV airing...)

The big question now, though, is whether Sky can sustain a premier premiere channel while it hands over the first-run of its movies to the cinema and, at the same time, looks like losing its entertainment and drama to Sky One - which is upping the ante as it prepares for battle with Channel 4's entertainment channel E4.

Channel 4 is looking fierce, having snatched first-run Friends and ER from Sky One, so it's predicted that the likes of The Stretch and Baddiel's show will move across to bolster the channel. Talk of Sky Premier's commissions being swiped is naturally being played down by Sky, with promises of re-doubling commitment to home-grown shows on Sky One. Either way, with multi-channel viewers increasingly impatient at the constant rebranding and repositioning of niche stations, it had better make up its mind soon.

fields.headline: Hague's big gamble
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague last night astonished Westminster with a snap reshuffle of his top team which pitted his heaviest hitter, Michael Portillo, against the most formidable minister in Tony Blair's government, the chancellor, Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
William Hague last night astonished Westminster with a snap reshuffle of his top team which pitted his heaviest hitter, Michael Portillo, against the most formidable minister in Tony Blair's government, the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

But the real shock for most Conservative MPs was Mr Hague's decision to sack John Redwood as shadow environment spokesman - and official scourge of John Prescott - to make way for his long-time intimate, the multi-millionaire management consultant, Archie Norman.

Hague aides denied that Mr Portillo had been consulted though they admit the two men now have "a lot of contact".

It prompted some shadow ministers to suggest last night that the man widely tipped to succeed Mr Hague one day had demanded Mr Redwood's removal. Bad blood exists between the two ambitious rightwingers since Mr Portillo flunked calls to run against John Major in 1995. Mr Redwood stood instead.

Labour's propaganda machine immediately denounced "a leader with no judgment appointing a shadow chancellor with no judgment", and described the new top team as "the most extreme right wing" ever. Mr Norman's extensive business interests also came under fire.

The musical chairs, known to only a handful of Hague aides until teatime last night, also saw the moderate John Maples dropped as shadow foreign secretary to make way for Francis Maude, the man bumped to bring Mr Portillo into the treasury shadow.

The hyperactive Mr Redwood was said to be "enormously surprised" when his leader called him into his office, praised him for being both loyal and effective in opposition - then told him it was time to make way for a new blood.

Many Tory MPs, even those who suspect he is overrated, were pleased to see Mr Portillo back on the frontbench where he has the experience, as an ex-treasury minister, to take on the formidable Mr Brown who has managed to avoid the recession predicted by Mr Maude.

Tory officials were quick to deny that the Hague-Portillo-Maude-Widdecombe team is what Labour called "hardline, rightwing, Euro-sceptic" by pointing out that Mr Redwood, a Thatcherite, had been dropped. That calculation may have sealed his fate, though he is also seen as a too-visible symbol of the discredited Tory regime.

Mr Hague had been planning to bring back Mr Portillo as soon as possible after his by-election victory in Kensington and Chelsea in November, made possible by the death of Alan Clark, whose memorial service Mr Hague attended yesterday.

It binds him into the shadow cabinet as it heads for what most analysts believe will be another crushing election defeat - one which Mr Hague may not long survive. Last night Hague aides said it was another strengthening of the party, "bringing in people of proven ability which intensifies pressure on Tony Blair's failing administration".

Labour replied with some loud raspberries. In a statement Mr Prescott said he had now seen off three shadow spokesmen since 1997 and hoped that Mr Norman "a director of Railtrack, a hypermarket supremo and a member of Lloyds will be able to bring his experience to bear - provided he can find time to turn up".

Downing Street orchestrated a chorus of jibes against Mr Portillo as a media darling with "woeful judgement. The public will not forget his record in office". Hague aides said simply: "William thought he should put one of our most powerful players against one of theirs."

Potentially more fruitful was the Liberal Democrats' concentration on Mr Norman's spectacular past as a McKinsey management guru - he hired Mr Hague - who recently sold the Asda supermarket chain (Mr Maude was on the board) to the US giant Walmart. Planning consents from Mr Prescott's department are hugely sensitive.

Last night Mr Norman, a less than charismatic Commons performer, said he would "resolve any potential conflict of interest that might arise" by bailing out of companies, notably the Knutsford venture capitalist group of which he is a major shareholder, if he has to.

With Mr Redwood promising to fight for the Eurosceptic cause on the backbenches, the Liberal Democrat deputy leader, Alan Beith, said: "Michael Portillo is now positioned to seize the Tory throne when William Hague falls."

Downing Street orchestrated a chorus of jibes against Mr Portillo as a media darling with "woeful judgement. The public will not forget his record in office". Hague aides said simply: "William thought he should put one of our most powerful players against one of theirs." Potentially more fruitful was the Liberal Democrats' concentration on Mr Norman's spectacular past as a McKinsey management guru - he hired Mr Hague - who recently sold the Asda supermarket chain (Mr Maude was on the board) to the US giant Walmart. Planning consents from Mr Prescott's department are hugely sensitive. Last night Mr Norman, a less than charismatic Commons performer, said he would "resolve any potential conflict of interest that might arise" by bailing out of companies, notably the Knutsford venture capitalist group of which he is a major shareholder, if he has to. With Mr Redwood promising to fight for the Eurosceptic cause on the backbenches, the Liberal Democrat deputy leader, Alan Beith, said: "Michael Portillo is now positioned to seize the Tory throne when William Hague falls."

webTitle: The ups, the downs and the outs

fields.headline: The ups, the downs and the outs
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor

Aged 46, darling of Tory right and hate-figure for the left. Educated at Cambridge. Elected as MP for Enfield Southgate in 1984 by-election.

Rose to employment secretary and defence secretary, but ducked standing against John Major leadership in 1995. Famously defeated in 1997 general election, and re-invented himself as socially liberal Tory. Re-elected as MP for Kensington and Chelsea last November.

Archie Norman, shadow minister for environment and transport

Millionaire businessman, 45, who turned around fortunes of Asda. Elected as Tory MP for Tunbridge Wells in 1997 and immediately charged with modernising party structure and organisation.

Quit central office in 1998, disillusioned that William Hague kept him out of inner circle.

Francis Maude, moves from shadow chancellor to shadow foreign secretary

Barrister, 46, became MP for Warwickshire South in 1983, quickly rising to financial secretary at treasury, where he helped sign Maastricht Treaty.

Lost seat in 1992, returned to Westminster in 1997 as MP for Horsham, soon promoted to shadow chancellor, where he failed to dent Gordon Brown over the economy.

John Redwood, sacked as shadow environment secretary

Rightwinger among most combative on frontbench, with attacks on transport policy.

Aged 48, educated at Oxford, followed by successful City career. Became head of Margaret Thatcher's policy unit in 1983 and elected MP for Wokingham in 1987. Within two years, was junior trade minister, ending ministerial career as Welsh secretary, when he stood against John Major as leader in 1995. Lost 1997 leadership contest to Hague.

John Maples, sacked as shadow foreign secretary

Regarded as smooth performer and safe pair of hands, but lack of Eurosceptic credentials rankled with the right. Fifty-six-year-old barrister, became MP for Lewisham in 1983, rising to treasury minister. Lost seat in 1992, later becoming Tory deputy chairman. Returned to Westminster in 1997, took shadow defence post, before taking over as shadow foreign secretary. Graduate of Cambridge and Harvard.
