webTitle: McKinsey Man takes over from the Vulcan

fields.headline: McKinsey Man takes over from the Vulcan
fields.standfirst:
Norman Store whizzkid who stirred up Central Office

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: With the sacking of John Redwood in favour of Archie Norman, William Hague has swapped the Vulcan for McKinsey Man.
fields.body:
With the sacking of John Redwood in favour of Archie Norman, William Hague has swapped the Vulcan for McKinsey Man.

Mr Redwood, tireless in opposition yet suspect as a lone operator, has lost his shadow cabinet environment seat to a former chairman of Asda and advocate of the application of corporate management to politics.

The supermarket whizzkid was hailed yesterday by Mr Hague as one of "Britain's most successful businessmen". Even Mr Norman's closest friends, however, cannot say he is one of the nation's most successful politicians: since election to the safe seat of Tunbridge Wells in 1997 the multi-millionaire has barely been heard in the Commons, even since his promotion to European spokesman.

Mr Hague, however, sees other strengths: Mr Norman is a fellow graduate of McKinsey management consultants - indeed, the Tory leader was once his protege at the firm - and shares a liking for applying business management to politics. Mr Norman was first used by Mr Hague to shake up the party's Central Office headquarters in the wake of the 1997 defeat.

He re-organised the party machine, declared redundancies, and for a while, instituted a clean-desk policy. However, Central Office staff became impatient with the style of a man who revolutionised Asda while wearing a badge declaring "Archie - happy to help", and similar noises have emerged from fellow MPs and his famously "disgusted" constituency party.

Making almost £6m by cashing in Asda share options is no way to endear oneself to colleagues, never mind enemies, and Mr Norman's fumbling performances in the Commons often brought more guffaws from his own side than from the Labour benches.

Mr Hague believes that, with his eye for figures and accuracy, his mentor will be able to catch out the deputy prime minister and transport secretary, John Prescott, who is far from being a details man. In practice, however, the larger than life Mr Prescott is likely to go down better with the voters than the colourless strains of Mr Norman (although the latter's low-key appeal is much higher when he is one-to-one), and few would put money on Man at Asda crushing Two Jags. Labour MPs admit they have been truly alarmed at the skills of the returning Mr Portillo, but most explode with laughter when asked whether Mr Norman presents a threat.

Despite rumours that Mr Redwood's position was vulnerable, he had been looking more secure in recent months, and news of his departure caused surprise last night among Tory aides. "It's a real shock," said one admirer. "John is not ineffective, and he is not a threat - he is one of the most loyal people to William you will find. He just gets on with the job."

Mr Redwood's actions on hearing of his return to the backbenches appeared to justify friends' claims he is "the consummate professional". After being summoned to an afternoon meeting with Mr Hague he phlegmatically returned to his office, consulted his diary, and completed a scheduled series of meetings with business people.

First given the trade and industry brief by the Tory leader, the hardworking rightwinger was the first to recover from the knockout of defeat and get down to effective opposition. While frontbench colleagues floundered, Mr Redwood was churning out press releases, going for the then trade secretary, Margaret Beckett.

Although regarded as somewhat scattergun, some of Mr Redwood's fire hit its target, causing a riled Ms Beckett to stoop to dismissing her opponent (already mocked for his wooden manner and likeness to a Star Trek alien) as a member of the "green ink brigade". Observers commented that Mr Redwood, who retreated to the backbenches in 1995 after challenging John Major for the Tory leadership, had had two years practising opposition against his own party.

Despite scoring points at industry, rumours persisted of Mr Redwood's imminent demotion: not only did the former Welsh secretary have a voter-unfriendly "weird" appearance and uncompromisingly hardline beliefs on issues from welfare to Europe, he was a vivid reminder of the last Conservative regime so decisively kicked from office by the electorate.

He survived early reshuffles with a move to environment, but attempts to exploit Labour weakness on transport were not that successful, partly thanks to Mr Redwood's unqualified enthusiasm for the car as against public transport ("The guy is so obsessed with the rights of motorists he thinks it's an affront to make them drive on the left," said one Labour aide).

Friends last night said Mr Redwood would nurse his wounds with dignity, and remain loyal. Other MPs reluctant to see him go were warning Mr Hague may have done more than lose an old hand; one quoted Lyndon Johnson's famous response, that it was "better to have him inside the tent pissing out, than outside the tent pissing in".

Whether he causes trouble or not, his departure is less due to any failing than a need to make way for others in Mr Hague's fighting force for the next general election.

And by firing Mr Redwood, the Tory leader can reject accusations he has dragged the shadow cabinet to the right by appointing Mr Portillo.

webTitle: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: There's nothing quite like the US judicial system for speedy legal retribution, as Brooke Shields discovered when Mark Bailey, her stalker of 15 years, finally appeared in LA Superior Court last week.
fields.body:
There's nothing quite like the US judicial system for speedy legal retribution, as Brooke Shields discovered when Mark Bailey, her stalker of 15 years, finally appeared in LA Superior Court last week. This particularly tardy chapter of the saga began on January 10, with Bailey's arrest after a four-month letter-writing campaign (most of which included threats, naked photographs, or both); it was only then, however, that the LAPD became aware that Shields first took out a restraining order against her biggest fan in - oh dear - 1985. Having heard Bailey plead not guilty at a pre-trial hearing, Judge Glynette Blackwell promptly (well, sort of promptly) ruled there was sufficient evidence for the case to go forward, declaring the decade-and-a-half of harassment had "obviously taken [Shields] to hell and back". Currently in custody, Bailey next appears in court in a week's time.

Where, it must be said, it's looking increasingly unlikely he'll be joined by Wallace Langham - aka Phil, the head writer in The Larry Sanders Show - who's eager for an out-of-court settlement with the tabloid reporter he allegedly gay-bashed in a LA supermarket late last year. Perhaps predictably, the two parties' recollections of said incident do differ slightly: the anonymous hack claims Langham committed an unprovoked assault while shouting homophobic abuse; Langham argues he was responding to his girlfriend being insulted and, more to the point, is the victim of an extortion attempt. Yet the reported six-figure olive branch may turn out to be an irrelevance, as LA Deputy City Attorney Michael Pizzuti intends to pursue a prosecution anyway. "Our position is to oppose any civil compromise", the upstanding Pizzuti remarked. "First and foremost we have to seek vindication of public justice." Well, well, whatever will they think of next?

webTitle: Random views: What second-hand car salesmen are watching on TV

fields.headline: Random views: What second-hand car salesmen are watching on TV
fields.trailText: Nick Kilman:
fields.body:
Nick Kilman:

"I'm just an EastEnders fan, through and through. They know how to balance older characters and the younger ones. I saw that awful Gormenghast. Load of rubbish, to be frank. I used to watch The Bill and all the Saturday evening stuff before the pub, Blind Date and that, but the missus has got her January health kick going and she keeps trying to get me to get fit with her."

Nicky Piper:

"If there's a person I really hate then it's got to be Michael Barrymore. I can't stand him. He's too energetic, bouncing around, playing the fool. I find it creepy. I like Michael Parkinson, he reminds me of my uncle - very clever. I saw that thing with Posh Spice, she's great, I think. Most people I know don't like her, but I think she's funny, and she seems to be a nice person. I was surprised. You always expect the stars to be up themselves. "

Dave Masterson:

"If there's a gory film then I'll watch it. I like the weekend showings - they had Superman on the other day and even though I've seen that a lot of times I still tune in and watch it. My wife is on at me to get digital, and a new TV with surround sound and the works, but I'm not convinced. It's just more channels filled with nothing in particular. I like Frasier, The Royle Family, and a bit of Friends. I'm sure if I didn't have a TV I'd be three stone lighter, though. I have to have my Pringles on Friday night."

Craig Littlejohn:

"I can't remember if they ever have second-hand car dealers on TV - that sort of thing was more 70s wasn't it? With The Sweeney and Minder and all that. Arthur Daley, "E's alright". You can't be dodgy anymore, too many regulations. It's quite a respectable trade now - wear a suit, do the paperwork. I'm a big LAPD Blue, Homicide: Life On The Streets sort of fan. I even liked LA Law. If it's American it looks good, they put a bit of money in it. The person I most miss on the TV is Eric Morecambe.I loved him."

Sin Pattenden interviewed salesmen at the Car Centre, near Guildford.

fields.headline: On a road to nowhere
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Although Victoria Beckham's recent foray into TV journalism was greeted with a measure of scorn, Posh's programme was worth a Pulitzer Prize in comparison with Geri's World Walkabout (BBC1). In this vacuous, patronising two-parter, the frantically self-promoting Geri Halliwell flutters around the globe on the pretext of "working" for the United Nations as a "goodwill ambassador", whatever that is. Even less use than Kofi Annan asking the Russians if they'd mind awfully withdrawing their troops from that horrid war in Chechnya.
fields.body:
Although Victoria Beckham's recent foray into TV journalism was greeted with a measure of scorn, Posh's programme was worth a Pulitzer Prize in comparison with Geri's World Walkabout (BBC1). In this vacuous, patronising two-parter, the frantically self-promoting Geri Halliwell flutters around the globe on the pretext of "working" for the United Nations as a "goodwill ambassador", whatever that is. Even less use than Kofi Annan asking the Russians if they'd mind awfully withdrawing their troops from that horrid war in Chechnya.

We were barely past the opening credits before Geri was spelling out her importance on the world stage, for anybody not up to speed on OK!, Hello! and Saturday morning children's television. "The last year and a half has been a time of great change for me", she revealed, as gravely as if addressing the assembled G7 finance ministers. "Singing, writing, working for the United Nations, my feet haven't touched the ground!" How marvellous that such a dazzling star had found the time to make a whole programme to show little us.

Geri seems to be grooming herself as a combination of Esther Rantzen and Judith Chalmers, travelling non-stop in her quest for people who lead "extraordinary" lives. In the Philippines, she introduced us to Jessica, who lives on a vast, stinking rubbish dump in Manila. "She refused to be beaten by a poor start in life!" Geri yelled at the camera, never one to be upstaged by her guests. Then she met TV personality Kris Aquino, daughter of ex-premier Cory. "Her life's been full of incredible dramatic twists and turns!" raved Halliwell, desperate to prevent her entire viewership from wandering off to watch something gripping like News 24 instead. Kris's dad had made the mistake of returning to the Philippines from the USA, and was promptly shot dead. Luckily, Geri was on hand to reassure Kris that "his life had meaning!"

So why am I reviewing this self-serving drivel? Because it's another disturbing specimen of the phenomenon whereby the bubble-headed jabbering of any so-called "celebrity", no matter how lightweight, is considered justification enough to build a programme upon, regardless of how ill-conceived or plain stupid it may be. Halliwell's visit to the site of Sachsenhausen concentration camp will be preserved as a timeless moment of brain-dead TV. Having wept over the gas-ovens, Geri struggled for profundity, but could only manage some congealed cliché: "I think it's up to us as individuals with our own sense of morality and respect for human beings to make sure this never happens again!" If they'd sent Geri to Munich instead of Neville Chamberlain, the course of the twentieth century could have been so very different.

And so to Channel 4's A to Z of credit card fraud in Credit Crooks, the latest instalment of Behind The Crime , in which compulsive criminals pass on their hard-earned knowledge. John McKenzie demonstrated the simple trick of standing behind another customer at the cash till, reading their credit card number over their shoulder and storing it in his mobile phone. He also had ingenious tips for persuading hotel receptionists to accept his credit card number even though he didn't have the card. Phil Davidson showed us how to open a fake bank account and withdraw far more money from it than it actually contained, while Nigel Richardson offered a masterclass in how to masquerade as a conference delegate in order to collect a pocketful of his fellow-delegates' credit cards. Despite the fact that the film stressed that each subject had been caught and convicted numerous times, it would be difficult to deny that this series amounts to an Open University of crime.

Body Chemistry (BBC2) kicked off with Hormone Hell, which was full of educative stuff about the nature and function of hormones in the human body, but couldn't decide whether to be factual and hard-hitting or chatty and bland. The real-life tales of menopause or pre- menstrual stress were gruelling, but the background music was exasperating schmaltz and the staged interludes intended to convey a kind of archetypal overview were a complete waste of space. But perhaps a co-production between the BBC and Discovery Channel was doomed to suffer from mistaken identity.

fields.headline: Brussels cash row threatens Michael
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: The row that could bring down the minority Labour administration in Cardiff grew in intensity yesterday as Plaid Cymru said it had no alternative but to press ahead with a vote of no confidence in the assembly's first secretary, Alun Michael, over Labour's handling of European funding for the poorest parts of Wales.
fields.body:
The row that could bring down the minority Labour administration in Cardiff grew in intensity yesterday as Plaid Cymru said it had no alternative but to press ahead with a vote of no confidence in the assembly's first secretary, Alun Michael, over Labour's handling of European funding for the poorest parts of Wales.

Labour warned that its opponents' actions risk plunging the infant assembly into a period of "purposeless instability".

But it was clear yesterday that such strictures had failed to divert the opposition parties from their threatened course as the Liberal Democrats ruled out the possibility of propping up the minority regime.

The issue that has taken the Welsh opposition parties so close to pressing the nuclear button is the need for funding to match the £1.2bn of grants promised by Brussels for the economic regeneration of west Wales and the valleys.

fields.headline: Barney Childs
fields.trailText: The American composer and writer Barney Childs, who has died aged 73, was largely self-taught. Once described as "a square experimental composer", he had the spirit of a west coast pioneer - with a strong sense of European perspective.
fields.body:
The American composer and writer Barney Childs, who has died aged 73, was largely self-taught. Once described as "a square experimental composer", he had the spirit of a west coast pioneer - with a strong sense of European perspective.

As a composer, he had an eclectic approach, and offered a thoughtful reflection of musical trends around him, always with a practical sensitivity. He had great generosity of spirit, especially towards younger colleagues, and a wickedly ironic sense of humour. Unusually for a Californian, he did not drive.

Born in Spokane, Washington state, Childs was a Rhodes scholar at Oxford, and gained his PhD at Stanford. He taught in several universities, and was a past president of the American Society of University Composers. As an editor for Perspectives Of New Music, he learned a healthy scepticism for the "jargon overload" of much critical writing, and, as in his music, pragmatism and wit were much in evidence.

Childs's early works show the influence of Hindemith, Elliott Carter and the grittier side of Copland, but his use of indeterminacy from 1961 marks the significant part of his output. This approach was seen in a number of ways - from purely verbal instructions for pieces (London Rice Wine, 1973, and The Roachville Project, 1967) through performer choice (the Interbalances series, 1960-62) to a type of mobile form that requires traditional chamber music responses from players (Any Five, 1965).

He also explored aspects of sound through modern instrumental techniques, such as the clarinet writing in The Edge Of The World (1981), which reveals his interest in jazz. Several fully notated later works include a return to aspects of a more traditional musical language, although not of ideology.

Perhaps Childs's range of thinking prevented him from following through his ideas to the full. He was, however, the epitome of much that was positive about the 20th century.

 Barney Sanford Childs, composer, born February 13 1926; died January 11 2000

fields.headline: Sir John Lawrence
fields.standfirst: Diplomatic dealings with Russia, India and the church of England
fields.trailText: The diplomat and writer Sir John Lawrence, who has died aged 92, was the nearest to a professional layman that the church of England has ever had - and a good deal more influential than many bishops. He was also right about the Soviet Union. Many years ago he said: "There's no substance in it! Communism will collapse like a house of cards, and I shall live to see it."
fields.body:
The diplomat and writer Sir John Lawrence, who has died aged 92, was the nearest to a professional layman that the church of England has ever had - and a good deal more influential than many bishops. He was also right about the Soviet Union. Many years ago he said: "There's no substance in it! Communism will collapse like a house of cards, and I shall live to see it."

In the circles in which he moved - ecclesiastical, diplomatic and journalistic - such dismissal of communism was not only unfashionable; there was a secret code against such negative attitudes, barring career doors which should have opened to people of such vision. Yet Lawrence's views were not tainted by McCarthyite extremism. They emanated from his profound Christian humanism, resulting directly from his experience of, and love for, the Russian people, the guiding influence in a multi-coloured career.

The second son of Sir Alexander Lawrence of Lucknow, educated at Eton and New College, Oxford, he was always proud to have been born into the Irish family of the "Indian" Lawrences. His interest was divided between the sub-continent and Russia, which goes far to explain the breadth of his outlook.

Lawrence loved travel and other cultures, read in 10 languages and entered the diplomatic service by the most unconventional means - in 1939, he helped set up the BBC World Service European section, from which he was seconded to Moscow. He swam part of the way to his posting after his ship was torpedoed en route to Murmansk in 1942.

As British embassy press attaché, Lawrence forged an alliance with a people cowed and, it seemed, soon to be subjugated, following the 1941 Nazi invasion. He set up and edited Britansky Soyuznik (British Ally), the only uncensored official publication to be produced in the Soviet Union between 1917 and the accession of Gorbachev 70 years later.

He did this with a Russian team, whose loyalty he cemented by the openness of his personality and his identification with the people among whom he worked. It was always a great sadness to Lawrence that his collaborators were arrested after the war, and he was unable to resume contact with the survivors for nearly two decades.

The slamming of that door marked a hiatus in Lawrence's career, but during this time he became a Christian, quickly demonstrating a quality of leadership rare among the Anglican laity. Being of independent means, he could exercise his influence where he thought it would be of most value - and chose journalism.

In 1957, he founded the ecumenical quarterly Frontier, a publication he edited throughout its existence to 1975. He also trained a gifted succession of assistant editors, who went on to make their own mark. In addition, he left a series of diaries for his confidants, recording his extensive travels and encounters with atheists, humble clerics and senior prelates. These were too colourful and honest about the hundreds of church leaders Lawrence met to see print during his lifetime - or possibly theirs - but the material for a great book is preserved and ready to provide a rich source for his literary executor.

Lawrence contributed to the work of the World Council of Churches during its early days, but, after the Russian Orthodox church became a member in 1961, politics intervened and his insights were largely lost to the ecumenical movement. He would have made a superb WCC general secretary, and would have prevented some of the mistakes that it made during the next 30 years.

As it turned out, the British Council of Churches benefited from his wisdom, and he masterminded the committee which, by way of much painful argument, produced the detailed drafts for what became Trevor Beeson's outstanding ecumenical history of eastern Europe, Discretion And Valour (1972).

Seven books on Russia came from Lawrence's pen between 1947 and 1986. His History Of Russia (1970) is still a standard work for the general reader. Russians Observed (1969) brought home the Russian people's humanity - at a time when they could scarcely be encountered because of cold war barriers.

He put his knowledge at the disposal of the research body tracking eastern European religious developments, Keston College (now Keston Institute, Oxford), of which he was the first chairman (1969-83) and then honorary president. His chairmanship of the Great Britain-USSR Association (1970-85) was equally distinguished, as was his work with the Church Missionary Society. He always advocated straight and uncompromised talking with Soviet officialdom and politicised church leaders.

Lawrence's association with India led to The Journals Of Honoria Lawrence (1980) and Lawrence Of Lucknow (1990), which he claimed to be his favourite among all his writings. He often revisited India and Pakistan.

John Lawrence inherited the baronetcy on the death of his brother Henry in 1967. He was twice married; first to Jacynth Ellerton, and after her death to Audrey Woodiwiss, his literary collaborator, whose devotion sustained him in his later days. He had no children.

 John Waldemar Lawrence, diplomat and writer, born May 27 1907; died December 30 1999

fields.headline: Better to hang on
fields.standfirst:
Mandelson should not dissolve the Northern Ireland assembly. Others besides the IRA are defaulting

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Mandelson should not dissolve the Northern Ireland assembly. Others besides the IRA are defaulting
fields.body:
Three vital matters remain to be initiated or completed by the supporters of the Good Friday agreement.

David Trimble pledged to resign as first minister if de Chastelain had nothing positive to report on decommissioning before Trimble met his council members again this February. In setting this deadline he acted outside the terms of the Mitchell Review - as Gerry Adams complains - but he genuinely believed it was necessary to carry his party with him.

The onus, political and ethical, is on republicans to relieve Mr Trimble of his difficulties. Republican difficulties appear psychological: they refuse to bow to Trimble's arbitrary deadline even though he ate many of his previous words to enable Sinn Fein to join the cabinet, and even though he and his party have now delivered on all of their obligations.

Their position appears childish. Republican difficulties may have deeper roots, eg internal dissent, or it may be motivated by hard-ball negotiating - but to what end? Whatever motivates their unwillingness they can't expect sympathy beyond their ranks.

The situation may tempt Mr Mandelson to suspend the assembly - as unionists urge - but that would establish a dangerous precedent: any time either the SDLP or the UUP are unhappy in future they can threaten system-collapse knowing the UK government will step in to carry the can. This was not what was agreed on Good Friday or subsequently - the parties opted for responsible self-government and explicitly denied the secretary of state the right of dissolution. Nor is it right that George Mitchell be expected to be a permanent one-man fire brigade.

Mandelson would be well advised to wait, with draft suspensory legislation ready, until May 22 - when he would have the SDLP's and the Irish government's full consent to suspend the experiment if republicans had not delivered on decommissioning, and, even better, when the SDLP would be politically, ethically and legally obligated to declare Sinn Fein unfit for office under the cross-community parallel consent procedure, thereby obviating the need for any suspension. In the meantime, of course, if the UUP collapse the executive some of the other institutions of the agreement, particularly the north-south ministerial council and the British-Irish council could not function, and public pressure would mount on Sinn Fein to deliver effectively and rapidly on its commitments. Existing and resigning ministers could be asked to perform as caretakers until May.

The letter of the agreement would be preserved. It would not deny David Trimble the moral high ground, nor relieve the pressure on republicans. The international commission would have a short period to engage fully with the respective interlocutors of the loyalists and republicans. Republicans would have absolutely no constitutional excuse if they were in default on May 22, and their political isolation would be even greater then than now. Moreover, and this is a point to which unionists pay insufficient attention, a suspension now, or later, would mean that the British-Irish inter-governmental conference would revive in significance, thereby further antagonising the rejectionist unionists.

Mr Mandelson certainly requires a cool head, as will others. Militant republicans cannot have failed to register that Sinn Fein cannot expect further electoral gains, North or South, or enjoy the sustained fruits of office, without rapid decommissioning by May 22.

Republicans are entitled to observe that two other tasks remain to be completed by other parties. But one of these, demilitarisation, is entirely dependent upon their own conduct. No UK government is going to initiate the removal of troops without evidence of authentic decommissioning.

The last task is a different matter. The criminal justice review established under the agreement was to have been completed by autumn 1999. So where is it? The Patten commission on policing was published on time, and is being implemented almost to the letter - a model of a government delivering on its obligations.

By contrast, the criminal justice review required much less work. It has been done, and a long time ago. Why has it not been published? It is believed that the lord chancellor and leading Northern Irish judges are opposed: it proposes an in dependent judicial appointments commission to ensure that Northern Ireland has a representative judiciary in charge of protecting the new human rights culture promised by the agreement.

It would be a terrible irony if future historians write that only three groups failed to deliver on their obligations under the Good Friday agreement: the Provisional IRA, the UVF/UDA, and Lord Irvine and the Northern Irish senior judiciary. Mr Blair and Mr Mandelson should direct the lord chancellor to fulfil his duties so that it can truly be said that only the relevant paramilitaries are preventing the full implementation of the Good Friday agreement.

Prof O'Leary is co-author of Policing Northern Ireland.

webTitle: Morocco's reforming king rouses fundamentalist wrath

fields.headline: Morocco's reforming king rouses fundamentalist wrath
fields.standfirst: Plans to give women more rights have infuriated the old guard
fields.trailText: The girls call him M6, and give him the rock star treatment from the side of the road. The boys sport copies of his sunglasses and ask the barber for his close-shaved military crop. Even old men like Abraham Serfaty, who spent 17 years in jail and eight in exile, smile at the mention of his name.
fields.body:
The girls call him M6, and give him the rock star treatment from the side of the road. The boys sport copies of his sunglasses and ask the barber for his close-shaved military crop. Even old men like Abraham Serfaty, who spent 17 years in jail and eight in exile, smile at the mention of his name.

Six months into his reign, Mohammed VI of Morocco carries with him the hopes of most of a nation. "Everything seems possible now," said Rabea Bourkia, a 19-year-old student. "It's a wonderful moment to be in Morocco. It's like the springtime of a country."

In a country where 4m people still live on less than a dollar a day, the official unemployment rate runs at 20% and some 45% of the population cannot read or write, a huge burden of expectation hangs on the young king's shoulders.

But so far Mohammed VI, 36, who took over following the death of his father Hassan II last July, has shown no sign of ducking the tasks he set himself: to loosen the authoritarian regime he inherited and force radical change.

His first acts have encouraged Moroccans to believe that he means what he says. While Hassan II introduced some timid democratic reforms at the end of his 34-year reign, he earned a reputation for despotism in the 1970s, when thousands of opponents were jailed or disappeared.

One of his son's first steps was to release some 8,000 prisoners. Then in September, he invited the ailing Mr Serfaty, a remarkable Jewish leftwing activist, to return to Morocco with his wife, Christine.

In early December, he welcomed home the widow and four children of Mehdi Ben Barka, one of Hassan's most virulent opponents, after 36 years in exile. And at the end of last year, he sensationally sacked Driss Basri, the interior minister who for more than 25 years had been Hassan's right-hand man and bully-boy.

"I don't think there's any doubt that we are at the beginning of a new era," an emotional Mr Serfaty said last week. "The changes are significant. This is a king who wants and is ready to construct a modern democratic country."

In an attempt to heal some of the wounds of the past, the king is closely involved with a new commission - unique in the Arab world - which is charged with investigating some 4,000 cases of political injustice and repression and compensating the victims and their relatives. On his insistence the most needy are being given cash advances.

Helped by a team of young advisers whom Mohammed has installed in key civil service posts, he is also working to push through reforms in education and justice tabled by his prime minister, Abdel Rahman Youssouffi, a Socialist who spent 15 years in exile.

But the ride promises to be rough for the man dubbed "the king of the poor" by an ecstatic local press. One reform in particular, aimed at raising the social and legal status of women, is meeting potentially catastrophic opposition from traditional Muslims.

The reform programme, introduced by a particularly courageous family affairs minister, Said Saadi, seeks mainly to improve women's rights in education and employment, and is widely seen as essential if the country is to advance. Some 62% of women - 80% in rural areas - are illiterate.

But the reform also includes hotly disputed legal changes that will raise the minimum age of marriage for a woman from 15 to 18, outlaw a husband's repudiation of his wife as an accepted form of divorce, and give divorced women equal rights to property.

"Unless the government handles it right, this could lead to civil war," Mr Serfaty warned. "The fundamentalists have lost ground to the king in the fight against poverty, and they've seized on this. They will fight as hard as they can."

While observers are confident that most Moroccans are willing to back the reforms, many feel that the ferocity of the fundamentalists' opposition has turned the issue into the biggest single challenge that the king and "commander of the faithful" now faces.

"He'd better succeed," said Samira Sitail, a leading woman journalist. "There's a saying here now: before, we were afraid of our king. Now we are afraid for him."

webTitle: French strike against shorter work hours

fields.headline: French strike against shorter work hours
fields.trailText: Lorry drivers blocked motorways, ports and border crossings yesterday, and only 50% of trains on the Paris metro were running as militant French trade unions stepped up their protest against an enforced cut in working hours.
fields.body:
Lorry drivers blocked motorways, ports and border crossings yesterday, and only 50% of trains on the Paris metro were running as militant French trade unions stepped up their protest against an enforced cut in working hours.

The Socialist-led government's controversial bill to limit the legal working week to 35 hours became law at midnight, although larger companies have a year to put it into effect and smaller companies have until the end of 2002.

But many firms are struggling to implement the change without also cutting salaries, prompting the strike action among lorry drivers and public transport workers. Hospital staff and post office employees are planning similar walk outs later this week.

The lorry drivers, many of whom earn less than £1,000 a month, mounted some 70 roadblocks around the country for a second day running to demand either the right to work longer hours to maintain earnings, or an increase in hourly rates and bonuses.

They are also angry at concessions road-freight bosses won from the government last month, exempting them from fully adopting the new law. "I don't know how we're going to get out of this bind," said Roger Poletti of the militant Force Ouvrière union, promising that the action would continue "until we have the guarantees we need".

Some 150 lorries stopped British trucks from using the Calais ferry terminals, while other barricades caused miles of tailbacks at strategic points on the country's motorway network. Private cars were allowed to pass, but faced long delays.

Bus and metro employees joined the lorry drivers in a 24-hour protest yesterday in many large cities. The Paris regional transport authority said only half the metro trains and buses were running in the capital.

The shorter working week is aimed at reducing France's stubborn unemployment by forcing companies to hire new staff. But the law has been heavily criticised by French business leaders, who insist the government is interfering too much with the economy and that the move will inevitably damage French firms' competitiveness.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Wiranto refuses to resign
fields.body:
Wiranto refuses to resign

Former Indonesian military chief General Wiranto refused to step down from the cabinet yesterday despite a presidential call for his sacking, but military sources said a coup was unlikely.

Gen Wiranto called a news conference in Jakarta after President Abdurrahman Wahid said on Monday he would ask the general to step down from his new ministerial position in the government. The general told reporters he would not act until he had sought clarification. Reuters, Jakarta

More bodies found in Turkey

Police exhumed four more bodies in south-east Turkey yesterday, the latest grim finds in a string of at least 53 murders blamed on Islamic Hizbullah guerrillas.

The trail began two weeks ago after a shootout at an Istanbul villa where two senior Hizbullah leaders were captured, along with documents and computer files. Since then, the interior ministry has detained 938 people in a nationwide crackdown in which it also seized hundreds of weapons and explosives. Reuters, Diyarbakir

Nato's actions OK in Kosovo

Chief UN prosecutor Carla Del Ponte said yesterday that so far there is no evidence that Nato's bombing campaign in Kosovo violated international treaties on the conduct of war.

"Our work is not done, but what we can say is that up until now we have no indications that we should open an inquiry," she said after meeting the foreign secretary, Robin Cook. Mr Cook said British forensic experts will return to Kosovo this year to search for more evidence of war crimes. AP, London

Bin Laden not free to attack

Suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden is under close scrutiny and will not be allowed to make attacks from Afghanistan, an Afghan leader said yesterday.

But Taliban President Mullah Mohammed Rabbani reiterated that the group would not accede to US demands to extradite Bin Laden. "We are a free country where Osama is living as a guest," said Mr Rabbani. "This is reality. And it's up to the world to accept it or not." AP, Islamabad

Israel retaliates for killings

Israeli warplanes raided suspected guerrilla positions in the al-Botum hills, southern Lebanon yesterday, a day after pro-Iranian Lebanese guerrillas killed three Israeli soldiers. There were no immediate reports of casualties. Reuters, Tyre

webTitle: Waiting in vain  US search teams fail to find crash survivors

fields.headline: Waiting in vain  US search teams fail to find crash survivors
fields.trailText: Despite a massive search involving more than 300 coastguard officers and dozens of vessels and helicopters, no survivors of the Alaska Airlines flight 261 that crashed on Monday afternoon into the Pacific Ocean off the California coast have been found. Eighty-three passengers and five crew are feared to have perished.
fields.body:
Despite a massive search involving more than 300 coastguard officers and dozens of vessels and helicopters, no survivors of the Alaska Airlines flight 261 that crashed on Monday afternoon into the Pacific Ocean off the California coast have been found. Eighty-three passengers and five crew are feared to have perished.

At least 30 of the passengers were employees of the airline and their families and friends who had boarded the flight on standby in Puerto Vallarta in Mexico. The plane was en route for Seattle via San Francisco when it ran into trouble.

The pilot had indicated that there was a problem with the MD-83's stabiliser and had requested permission to make an emergency landing at Los Angeles. The plane disappeared from the radar at around 17,000 feet before plunging into the sea off Oxnard, around 40 miles north of Los Angeles.

A flotilla of coastguard, US navy and squid fishing vessels recovered bodies throughout the night as divers searched the water.

webTitle: Nuclear leak worse than first feared

fields.headline: Nuclear leak worse than first feared
fields.standfirst: More than 400 were exposed to radiation in Japan
fields.trailText: Japan's worst nuclear accident exposed nearly five times as many people to radiation as was originally thought, the government said yesterday.
fields.body:
Japan's worst nuclear accident exposed nearly five times as many people to radiation as was originally thought, the government said yesterday.

The sharp upward revision of the impact of the uncontrolled chain reaction on September 30 is a fresh blow to public confidence in a nuclear industry that has suffered a series of accidents and cover-ups over the past few years.

Japan's science and technology agency revealed that 439 people were exposed to neutron rays during the 20 hours in which the nuclear fission took place at a uranium processing plant in Tokaimura, 80 miles northeast of Tokyo.

In its initial report, the agency said only 69 people were affected. The accident occurred when plant workers used buckets to mix nearly eight times the correct amount of condensed uranium.

According to the agency's revised figures, the resulting fission exposed 119 residents, plant workers and emergency service staff to more than one millisievert of radiation, which is the annual permissible level.

It is the first time that an accident in Japan has affected more than 100 people to such an extent.

One worker who battled to halt the chain reaction suffered as much as 38 millisieverts and ambulance crews who arrived without being told they were visiting a nuclear accident site were exposed to high levels of radiation.

The agency played down the health implications of its findings, saying that the risks of cancer only increased significantly with a dose of more than 50 millisieverts. It said the revised figures were higher because the later assessment included local residents.

"This makes the number look bigger than the original figures we reported," an agency official told reporters.

Anti-nuclear groups, however, said the data under played the seriousness of the accident.

"We still don't think this is an accurate figure. It doesn't include any people passing through the area at the time or those who were working in nearby fields," said Kazue Suzuki of Greenpeace Japan.

The average incidence of leukaemia is 0.66% in Japan. According to the International Commission of Radiological Protection, the risk increases by 0.05 points for every 10 millisieverts of exposure.

The new figures are likely to add to public concern about the safety of the nuclear industry. Since the chain reaction, several local governments have halted or cancelled nuclear energy projects.

In the atmosphere of increased safety consciousness, British Nuclear Fuels Ltd has lost contracts as a punishment for supplying reprocessed fuel with falsified safety data.

Health officials have offered to monitor 120 people affected by radiation.

webTitle: Taiwan candidates snuggle up to China

fields.headline: Taiwan candidates snuggle up to China
fields.trailText: Taiwan's presidential candidates are competing to see who can sound most reasonable about China as they run a close race for next month's election.
fields.body:
Taiwan's presidential candidates are competing to see who can sound most reasonable about China as they run a close race for next month's election.

The independence leader, Chen Shui-bian, has upped the stakes by suggesting that Beijing's "one China" policy could be included in talks if he wins on March 18.

"We are willing to discuss any issues," Mr Chen, the Democratic Progressive party candidate, said. "That includes the concept of one China."

Mr Chen qualified his proposal by insisting that "Taiwan is already a sovereign state". But he said that he would not declare independence unless China threatened invasion.

Even to suggest discussing Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China signals that Mr Chen hopes to do business.

"We want to position ourselves as potential partners in dialogue [with Beijing]," says Mr Chen's international spokeswoman, Hsiao Bi-khim. "We need to show our own people, too, that we are a party which can talk with China."

Despite his strong independence credentials, Mr Chen may have even more room for manoeuvre in dealing with Beijing than his opponents. He is backed by Taiwan's middle class, who do business with China and would welcome more dialogue.

"We realise the Chinese need some time to work out their position, and we know that Mr Chen is not their first choice," said Ms Hsiao. "But they have to face the reality that we may win."

The other two main candidates have also redefined their China policies. Each hopes to satisfy the vast majority of pro-independence Taiwanese while not upsetting Beijing.

The breakaway candidate from the ruling Nationalist party, James Soong, who is neck-and-neck in the polls with Mr Chen, has proposed a "quasi-international" arrangement between Beijing and Taiwan, similar to the European Union. He says this relationship would be "neither domestic nor international".

"We have to find a way forward," says Mr Soong's spokesman, Raymond Wu. "No one in Taiwan wants to fight for independence - but no one wants China's 'one country, two systems' [the formula for Hong Kong and Macau] either."

Mr Wu says that Mr Soong will also want to talk to Beijing. But he will first call an all-party conference in Taiwan to establish a national consensus on "pragmatic steps" to improve relations with Beijing.

Lien Chan, the official Nationalist candidate, who has lagged behind in several opinion polls, needs to distance himself from the current president and Nationalist party chairman, Lee Teng-hui.

Mr Lee enraged Beijing last year by announcing that China and Taiwan have a special "state-to-state" relationship.

Mr Lien, currently vice-president, this week proposed a "zone of peace" in the Taiwan strait, but failed to deliver a promised fuller statement on policy towards China.

The positions of the main candidates are similar - and still unacceptable to China. But they do reflect an important shift of public mood.

"Everyone is trying to sound moderate now," says Antonio Chiang, editor of the Taipei Times. Whoever is elected, Mr Chiang believes, a new momentum has been created for dialogue with China.

But it is uncertain whether China may be tempted into a compromise dialogue.

China's president, Jiang Zemin, insists that Taiwan can have as much autonomy as it wants - so long as it accepts it is part of China.

webTitle: FBI's bizarre Lennon files come to light

fields.headline: FBI's bizarre Lennon files come to light
fields.standfirst:
US rights group goes to court to unveil more details of investigation into former Beatle after book's revelations
www.bagism.com/ John Lennon site (includes page on Jon Wiener's Lennon FBI files)
fields.trailText: The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) will go to court next week in an attempt to find out further information about the FBI's investigation into John Lennon for his involvement in the peace movement.
fields.body:
The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) will go to court next week in an attempt to find out further information about the FBI's investigation into John Lennon for his involvement in the peace movement.

A new book examining the FBI's files on the former member of the Beatles charts a bizarre, covert security operation that included logging a parrot's subversive remarks and attempting to get municipal police to arrest Lennon on drugs charges.

Since 1981, Jon Wiener, a professor of history at the University of California, Irvine, has been attempting to get access to the FBI's files on Lennon through the Freedom of Information Act. He has published his findings in the book, Gimme Some Truth, the John Lennon FBI Files.

"What is most interesting is the immense triviality of a lot of the information gathered," said Prof Wiener yesterday.

Lennon was known by the FBI as a major contributor to radical causes on both sides of the Atlantic, where he assisted in paying the fines for those arrested during anti-apartheid demonstrations and funding financially troubled underground newspapers.

Another action that irked US authorities was his involvement with an organisation that attempted to register young voters opposed to the Vietnam war, which at the time was at its height.

The politically minded Lennon also considered attending the August 1972 Republican convention in Miami, which turned into a massive anti-war demonstration where more than 1,000 people were arrested.

At the time, the FBI director, J Edgar Hoover, alerted President Richard Nixon to the fact that Lennon was "a former member of the Beatles singing group". As such, there was concern that, as Nixon was running for election against Democrat George McGovern, a candidate more attractive to young voters, Lennon would stage a national concert tour urging young people to register and vote.

Lennon apparently contributed $75,000 to the Election Year Strategy Information Centre to this effect.

Even so, Lennon's expulsion from the US was seen in some conservative quarters as a last resort. Since the musician was at that time seeking to clarify his immigration status, Republican senator Strom Thurmond wrote to the White House advising that "if Lennon's visa is terminated, it would be a strategy counter-measure caution must be taken with regard to the possible alienation of the so-called 18-year-old vote if Lennon is expelled from the country".

Prof Wiener likened the FBI's performance at the time to that of the Keystone Cops. At one stage it even released a photo supposedly of Lennon but in fact of another musician who also had long hair, a beard and glasses.

One of the documents that the FBI sought to protect from public gaze for national security reasons contained the information that "the International Society for Krishna Consciousness was backed by George Harrison and John Lennon. It appears that these individuals are members of the Beatles singing group who reside in England."

One of the key figures in the covert operation was Julie Maynard, an FBI undercover officer who died in 1997, but who had contacted Prof Weiner when she learned about his search for information on the Lennon files.

Maynard had infiltrated the "Yippies" who were planning a major demonstration at the Republican convention. She discovered that a number of rock bands were approached to play at the demonstration but were unwilling to do so because of a lack of insurance. Lennon sent a $40,000 cheque to cover this.

To counter the demonstrations, the Watergate participants and notorious Nixon-affiliated dirty tricksters, Gordon Liddy and E Howard Hunt, had even suggested mugging demonstrators and abducting the leaders, Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin, and smuggling them to Mexico.

The records also disclose that the FBI had suggested that "Miami should note that Lennon is reportedly a heavy user of narcotics. This information should be emphasised to local law enforcement agencies with regard to the subject being arrested if at all possible."

One report, written by an FBI informant in 1972 about a meeting of anti-war activists in New York, that illustrates the often absurd nature of the investigation recorded that "a girl there named Linda" had a parrot that "interjects 'Right on!' whenever the conversation gets rousing".

This gem of espionage wisdom was classified as confidential and not released for 25 years.

Prof Wiener said that the next stage was a civil hearing next week in Los Angeles, where the ACLU will seek details about other information on Lennon being withheld because it involved a "foreign power" (Britain). Currently, the FBI refuses to disclose the name of the foreign government, although it is obvious.

"[Withholding the information] is the same kind of ridiculous action as the actions taken against John Lennon," said Prof Wiener. "It's hard to believe how much effort they put into this."

webTitle: Police on trial for killing that split city

fields.headline: Police on trial for killing that split city
fields.standfirst:
Outcome could affect Giuliani-Clinton senate race

US gun violence: special report
fields.trailText: The most successful US police force is on trial in a case that could have huge repercussions for race relations and Hillary Clinton's political ambition.
fields.body:
The most successful US police force is on trial in a case that could have huge repercussions for race relations and Hillary Clinton's political ambition.

A year ago Amadou Diallo was a Manhattan street trader, selling socks and CDs. Two days later he was dead, a black immigrant shot by four white police officers in the lobby of his block of flats. Yesterday the acrimonious matter of jury selection was concluded and opening statements in the case could be delivered today.

The unarmed 22-year-old from Guinea, west Africa, was hit by 19 of the 41 bullets unleashed by the officers, who are accused of murder and could face between 25 years and life if they are found guilty. They are expected to tell the court that they thought Diallo was reaching for a gun.

Initially, mayor Rudy Giuliani, an ally of a police force whose success in cutting crime has helped to make him a national figure, remained aloof. The vacuum was filled by Al Sharpton, the black activist preacher who mobilised daily protests in Manhattan.

Reverend Jesse Jackson, the movie star Susan Sarandon, former New York mayor David Dinkins, and the Harlem congressman Charles Rangel were among the more than 1,000 people who were arrested for trespass during the protests.

Mr Giuliani, who is certain to contest New York's seat in the senate coveted by Mrs Clinton, said the demonstrations were silly and his poll ratings hit an all-time low. The polarisation created by the shooting was indicated by the contrasting evaluations of Mr Sharpton and Howard Safir, the police commissioner.

Mr Sharpton: "The police shot Diallo like an animal." Mr Safir: "The danger is from criminals, not from police."

Nine years ago, when Mr Dinkins was mayor, 1,605 people a year were killed with guns; in the seventh year of Mr Giuliani's reign the figure is below 400. Mr Safir explains the key to the policy which has helped to create the change by saying: "I don't decide where crime takes place. It just happens that the majority of crime is in communities of colour."

His logic is that, because the police stop-and-frisk policy targets high crime areas, blacks and Hispanics are bound to be more inconvenienced than whites.

The four officers were from a special unit which at the time represented 1% of the city's 40,000 police yet accounted for 40% of gun seizures.

fields.bodyText: The most successful US police force is on trial in a case that could have huge repercussions for race relations and Hillary Clinton's political ambition. A year ago Amadou Diallo was a Manhattan street trader, selling socks and CDs. Two days later he was dead, a black immigrant shot by four white police officers in the lobby of his block of flats. Yesterday the acrimonious matter of jury selection was concluded and opening statements in the case could be delivered today. The unarmed 22-year-old from Guinea, west Africa, was hit by 19 of the 41 bullets unleashed by the officers, who are accused of murder and could face between 25 years and life if they are found guilty. They are expected to tell the court that they thought Diallo was reaching for a gun. Initially, mayor Rudy Giuliani, an ally of a police force whose success in cutting crime has helped to make him a national figure, remained aloof. The vacuum was filled by Al Sharpton, the black activist preacher who mobilised daily protests in Manhattan. webTitle: Protesters reject US cash for bombing Puerto Rico island

fields.headline: Protesters reject US cash for bombing Puerto Rico island
fields.trailText: The US military appeared yesterday to be heading for a clash with protesters camped out as "human shields" on a small island near Puerto Rico, which the US has used as a target range for almost 60 years.
fields.body:
The US military appeared yesterday to be heading for a clash with protesters camped out as "human shields" on a small island near Puerto Rico, which the US has used as a target range for almost 60 years.

Demonstrators in the beach camps on Vieques, two thirds of which is controlled by the US Navy, said they would reject a compromise reached by President Bill Clinton and Pedro Rossello, governor of Puerto Rico.

Under the deal, the navy will resume training soon with dummy bombs for three more years and there will be $40m (£25m) to improve the infrastructure of the island, about eight miles off Puerto Rico, which the Pentagon says is crucial to its ability to remain ready for military action.

But the island's population of 9,300 will also be asked in a referendum whether they are prepared to accept a sweetner of another $50m in aid in return for allowing the Navy to stay indefinitely and return to using live ammunition.

Mr Rossello said: "Today we can be satisfied that we have obtained the empowerment of our brothers and sisters in Vieques. It will be their decision and only their decision, by democratic referendum, to decide their own future."

But Roberto Rabin, who heads the Coordinating Committee for Peace and Justice in Vieques, said: "This is treason. This is a very serious reversal of the position of the Puerto Rican government that there will be no more bombing."

The governor told congress in the autumn that no more bombs should fall on Vieques.

Fernando Martin, vice-president of the Puerto Rican Independence Party, which maintains a camp in the line of fire, said: "We will continue with our civil disobedience. For us, any proposal that supposes the renewal of bombing is unacceptable. What the people want, which is for bombing to stop immediately, doesn't appear in this referendum."

Mr Rossello said Puerto Rican police would help to clear the target ranges if the protesters had not gone by March, when bombing is expected to resume. It was halted in April after years of objections, when a stray bomb killed a security guard and the beach camps, which can be reached only by boat, were set up.

The navy has used napalm and bullets coated with depleted uranium on Vieques, where many blame the military training for 50% unemployment, a cancer rate that is 27% higher than the level on Puerto Rico proper, and damage to the fishing industry and the environment.

The island became an issue in campaigns for the US presidency and the New York senate, when the vice president, Al Gore, and Hillary Clinton both backed Puerto Rico.

Richard Danzig, secretary of the navy, said of the compromise: "Now the people of Puerto Rico and the people of Vieques in particular should embrace a process of reconciliation that is peaceful, law-abiding and doesn't allow for trespassing on the range."

fields.headline:
No: 1569
 Dr Martens
fields.body:
Age: 41.

Appearance: When you buy them they're shiny, black leather boots with an air-cushioned sole. Once out of the box, they take on a different look: graffiti'd and scuffed, untied laces trailing behind.

So people don't look after them? No, the scruffier and dirtier they are, the more they say about the wearer.

Which is? That they are angry: Dr Martens are inextricably linked with aggressive, rebellious types - and, as everyone knows, revolutions are not begun by people in shiny shoes.

Give me some examples of Doc-wearers: Well, among celebrity circles, there's the Pope, the Dalai Lama, Madonna . . .

What have they got to be angry about? I hadn't finished. I was going on to say that Docs are more famous for protecting the feet of skins, punks, mods, new romantics, grungers, indie fans and new-age travellers. Every band worth its cred has worn them on stage at least once - The Who, The Clash, the Sex Pistols, Nirvana . . . basically, everyone born since 1950 has owned a pair at some point.

So what's the problem? Well, the manufacturer, R Griggs, has announced that it's closing its factory in Northampton.

But I thought you said everybody was wearing them? That's just the point. Everybody was.

But not any more? No. The factory is being closed "to reflect market forces", apparently. But that's just a corporate way of telling us that no one's buying them any more.

So where did it all go wrong? Docs, it seems, are a victim of their own success. In the noughties, no self-respecting soul would be seen dead with a pair, as the last time they wore them they were 15 and smoking dope behind the bike sheds.

Not very fashionable any more then? The only people still wearing them are crusties or members of weird cults. To the rest of us they're clumpy, uncomfortable, restricting and take far too long to do up.

Do mention: The golden years, when they were worn by the likes of Kurt Cobain and Sid Vicious.

Don't mention: Trainers.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: After Dr Harold Shipman was convicted on Monday of murdering 15 older women patients, the daughter of victim Kathleen Grundy read a statement outside Preston crown court. Angela Woodruff and her family, long-time Guardian readers, had worked to keep the wording devoid of hate. They asked for medical reforms and expressed admiration for the police, court staff and others who helped them. Much of this we printed. But on a day when heartrending feelings generated an avalanche of words in newsrooms, a phrase from a previously recorded TV interview - where Mrs Woodruff referred to Shipman's conduct as evil - was mistakenly wrapped in with her courthouse statement.
fields.body:
After Dr Harold Shipman was convicted on Monday of murdering 15 older women patients, the daughter of victim Kathleen Grundy read a statement outside Preston crown court. Angela Woodruff and her family, long-time Guardian readers, had worked to keep the wording devoid of hate. They asked for medical reforms and expressed admiration for the police, court staff and others who helped them. Much of this we printed. But on a day when heartrending feelings generated an avalanche of words in newsrooms, a phrase from a previously recorded TV interview - where Mrs Woodruff referred to Shipman's conduct as evil - was mistakenly wrapped in with her courthouse statement.

Our account yesterday on page 4 of the investigations that led to Shipman's arrest referred to the doctor as administering lethal doses of morphine, while a caption said he gave victims diamorphine hydrochloride, which - being heroin - is different. To clarify: both are correct. The police say he used either or both.

Our leader on post-Shipman reforms, page 23, yesterday, harked back to the infamous 1960s case of Bodkin Adams, the last British doctor suspected of killing patients. Except that it was in the 1950s.

In yesterday's first edition, page 36, Sport, Tranmere were listed to play Blackburn Rovers in the FA Cup quarter-finals. Later editions corrected this to show Newcastle as Tranmere's adversary.

William Crosbie, a grand old man of Scottish art, did not live out 1999 to see his name in our Birthdays list as turning 84 on January 31.

A reader asks: "Will there ever be a day when the Guardian spells Kirkcaldy correctly?" Yes, this is it.

webTitle: Air France strikes back at Eurostar

fields.headline: Air France strikes back at Eurostar
fields.standfirst: Airline widens aim as rail takes two-thirds of Paris-London market
fields.trailText: Eurostar has stolen two-thirds of Air France's business between Paris and London but the French state airline is to target other British cities by opening up several new routes to the French capital, it announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Eurostar has stolen two-thirds of Air France's business between Paris and London but the French state airline is to target other British cities by opening up several new routes to the French capital, it announced yesterday.

The company's chief operating officer, Pierre-Henri Gourgeon, said Eurostar was carrying more than 6m passengers a year to London, compared with 1m by Air France.

Mr Gourgeon said there were 14 daily flights each way between the two capitals. One of the problems was the delays to passengers both at Heathrow and Charles de Gaulle airports. "Traffic congestion in Europe's skies is intolerable.

"We are putting enormous pressure on the European union to unify all air traffic control but there is no easy solution because most people fly across France," he said.

The group is planning to open up several new regional centres, such as Aberdeen and Belfast, which it knows Eurostar cannot reach.

Mr Gougeon said the only low-cost carrier Air France feared at home was the railway. "We cannot match their speed and value on short haul routes of up to 400 miles.

"The Paris to Marseilles rail fare is around 50% cheaper than the plane, so we have been forced into tactical, not total, withdrawal on many of these routes."

Carriers such as Air France and BA are constrained from starting flights early because of noise restrictions.

Eurostar, in which BA ironically has a 20% stake, said last night that there had been a 5% increase in traffic last year. It is now looking at ways of improving its business product.

The cross-Channel train operator said the investigation would be completed by the summer - with big changes for business travel probably coming during the autumn - and that some of the changes could lead to more services.

 British Airways losses may not be as high as the £250m estimated by some City analysts, it emerged yesterday.

Cuts and comments from BA chief executive Bob Ayling indicating that it plans to cut operating costs by 25% by the end of 2002 produced a sympathetic City reaction.

Some analysts believe that BA's losses could be nearer £100m. Its share price rose by only 2p to 333p yesterday.

Unions reacted angrily to rumours that BA would lose 6,500 jobs over the next three years. They will be voluntary, but Mr Ayling has never denied that it will have to accept further cuts beyond the 1,000 due by the end of March.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Fourth term for Greenspan
fields.body:
Fourth term for Greenspan

A committee of the US senate approved Alan Greenspan's fourth term as chairman of the US central bank yesterday - a day which marked the longest economic boom in US history.

The US economy has expanded for 107 consecutive months, an unprecedented period of prosperity, after beating a record set in the 1960s. Mr Greenspan, who has presided over US monetary policy as chairman of the federal reserve since 1987, has attracted widespread praise for his management of the economy.

Yesterday, the senate banking committee voted to approve his appointment for a fourth term, a decision which clears the way for the full senate to vote on the nomination tomorrow.

Bug upsets growth figure

Growth in the manufacturing sector slowed sharply in January as firms ran down supplies stockpiled when it was feared that the millennium bug would disrupt the economy.

The monthly snapshot of the sector published yesterday by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply showed that growth was at its slowest for nearly six months.

The figures suggest that growth in the final three months of last year was boosted by millennial concerns. If that is the case, the Bank of England might be content with a smaller increase in interest rates than the market expects.

S&N sells pubs to Royal Bank

Scottish & Newcastle, Britain's biggest brewer, yesterday came under fire after selling off 481 of its leased pubs to Royal Bank of Scotland for £180m in cash. The move, which meets competition requirements following the brewer's takeover of Greenalls pubs and restaurants, was attacked by the Campaign for Real Ale.

The office of fair trading will be asked by Camra to look at the issue in a review whose terms of reference are expected to be published any day now.

S&N, whose brands include Fosters and Kronenbourg lagers, will continue to manage the properties on behalf of Royal Bank.

Benetton on track

The Benetton family is trying to increase its grip on Italy's transport network. A group led by parent company Edizione Holding is expected to win a bid to manage 13 of Italy's biggest railway stations.

The family, whose name appears on 7,000 clothing outlets worldwide, was part of a group that bought a 30% controlling stake in the highway firm Autostrade. It will also bid for the Rome airport operator Aeroporti di Roma.

Highbury pays with rights

Highbury House, the trade and consumer magazine publisher, announced yesterday that it would make a £40m rights issue to fund the acquisition of Nexus Media Communication, which almost doubles its number of titles.

The 11-for-20 rights issue of 60p a share, is Highbury's fourth in as many years, with it being two-and-a-half times oversubscribed by institutions.

Highbury, which publishes Sports Illustrated in the UK, will see its number of titles increase from 90 to 150.

webTitle: Ex-HSBC chief had share in failed TransTec

fields.headline: Ex-HSBC chief had share in failed TransTec
fields.trailText: Keith Harris, former chief executive of HSBC's investment-banking arm, was a director of an offshore company with an interest in more than 6% of TransTec, the now-collapsed engineering company founded by former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
Keith Harris, former chief executive of HSBC's investment-banking arm, was a director of an offshore company with an interest in more than 6% of TransTec, the now-collapsed engineering company founded by former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, the Guardian has learned.

HSBC was then TransTec's main banker and was owed up to £66m when the company appointed receivers in December. It is not known if Mr Harris was aware of the shareholding during his time on the board of First Britannia Mezzanine, the Amsterdam and Dutch Antilles company that is the ultimate beneficiary of 6.1% of TransTec, worth £13.5m at the company's peak value in 1997. He retired from the investment bank last year.

HSBC would say only that it had guidelines on the holding of external directorships and that Mr Harris had adhered to them. It refused to say whether or not Mr Harris had joined the First Britannia board at the bank's request, possibly to keep an eye on HSBC's interests.

TransTec collapsed last year, owing up to £200m, after it emerged that, after Mr Robinson's departure in May 1997 to join the government, the company concealed a claim from Ford motor company, a customer, for £12m. Department of trade and industry inspectors are investigating the collapse, and a separate DTI team examining claims that TransTec falsely claimed government grants in the 1980s.

In a notification to the London stock exchange in February 1998, Ducroire SL - a firm based in Madrid - gave First Britannia Mezzanine NV as its ultimate holding company. First Britannia is based in Amsterdam with a sister company in the Dutch Antilles.

First Mezzanine's British solicitors are the top City law firm of Norton Rose, which represented First Mezzanine in May 1998, when it sold its controlling interest in British Printing Company to the investment fund Investcorp.

Since his retirement at the age of 45, Mr Harris has become involved in projects including a financial services company Talisman House and chairmanship of Radio First, a vehicle for investment in underperforming radio stations.

He was, during his time at HSBC investment bank, also a director of HSBC's European private equity arm, and it may be his First Mezzanine directorships were required in the interests of the bank.

First Britannia Mezzanine in Amsterdam refers calls to Mezzanine Management of London, which is owned 50% by Marigot Investments and Portage Lake, which is based in Alderney in the Channel Islands.

Another large shareholder, the $1bn Baupost group, based in Cambridge, Massachusetts - with about 10% of the shares - said it had bought the stock during the mid-1990s at a time when the UK smaller companies sector seemed undervalued. Despite TransTec's connection with the late Robert Maxwell, whose Hollis group sold TransTec's important assets in the early 1990s, Baupost's own TransTec holding was unconnected with its holdings of paper issued by Maxwell Communication Corporation.

fields.headline: United Utilities to cut 620 jobs
fields.trailText: United Utilities yesterday announced plans to cut 620 jobs and hinted that its supply business - worth up to £400m - could soon be sold.
fields.body:
United Utilities yesterday announced plans to cut 620 jobs and hinted that its supply business - worth up to £400m - could soon be sold.

The multi-utility, based in the north-west of England, is also to increase the size of its non-regulatory business with an early flotation of its Norweb Telecom arm.

United also said it had made two small acquisitions in the fast-growing telecoms sector.

Around 400 of the redundancies will be made in the water business, and the remainder from electricity as part of a plan to save £400m over five years.

United is hopeful that the job cuts, which represent 10% of staff, are expected to be made voluntarily or through natural wastage.

The cuts are blamed on regulatory reviews of the water and electricity sectors.

John Roberts, United's chief executive, said controlling costs for regulatory targets, maximising synergies and developing non-regulated business were "priorities for growing shareholder value".

Asked at an analysts' meeting whether it was to dispose of its supply business, Mr Roberts replied: "All options are being considered."

But an analyst said: "United needs to double or treble in size and it's doubtful it wants to contribute the necessary investment to do this."

Norweb Telecom has bought Intercell and Intercell Communications with a combined turnover of £14m at a price it was not willing to disclose.

Analysts believe this move should come within a year but note that stock market ratings for similar ventures such as Scottish Power's Thus have been dragged down by negative views of the parent.

United's shares ended the day up 4p at 600p.

fields.headline: Cementing unfriendship
fields.trailText: The French assault on Britain's building materials sector was renewed yesterday when Meyer International fell to a £1.04bn recommended offer from France's Saint-Gobain and Lafarge launched a long-awaited £3.4bn hostile bid for Blue Circle.
fields.body:
The French assault on Britain's building materials sector was renewed yesterday when Meyer International fell to a £1.04bn recommended offer from France's Saint-Gobain and Lafarge launched a long-awaited £3.4bn hostile bid for Blue Circle.

The 515p cash offer from French glassmaker Saint-Gobain for Meyer represents a 61% premium to the closing price on January 28, the day before its first approach. It creates Europe's largest building merchants group.

Meyer, which acquired Harcros in 1997 and Graham Group 12 months later, is Britain's largest builders' merchant, with 539 branches operating under the Graham and Jewson banners.

Blue Circle, the country's leading cement maker, rejected as "wholly inadequate" the 420p-a-share bid from Lafarge - which bought Redland for £1.8bn in 1997. The market pushed its stock up 23p to close at 437.

At Lafarge, the world's biggest building materials producer, the chairman, Bertrand Collomb, said most analysts agreed with its valuation.

Meyer shares last night surged 18% to finish the day at 505p, up 77p. Saint-Gobain brokers ABN Amro had earlier entered the market to buy up 29.9% of Meyer's shares.

The deal gives Saint-Gobain a strong British base and access to Ireland and the Netherlands. The French company's chairman and chief executive Jean-Louis Beffa said: "This combination has a compelling industrial logic and we are confident and enthusiastic about its future."

Insiders said there should be no need for job cuts - a point reiterated by Mr Collomb, who is planning Euros1.6bn of disposals and promising Euros125m in synergies from 2001.

Lafarge, which is to finance the deal through debt and equity, said the enlarged group would be the world's largest cement producer, offering better prospects of sustained returns than Blue Circle.
