webTitle: Battle between the literate and the numerate

fields.headline: Battle between the literate and the numerate
fields.standfirst: NatWest versus Scottish banks
fields.trailText: NatWest versus Scottish banks
fields.body:
NatWest appeared to have made a conscious effort yesterday to avoid dismissing the competing offers from Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland as "derisory" and in the process reminding the besieged bank's shareholders that they are the ones that have learned the meaning of the word over the past 12 years or so.

Instead, NatWest gave us four paragraphs subtitled "Financial Stretch," "Merger Risks," "Management Stretch" and "New NatWest."

As bid defence documents go, this was a piece of top quality prose, carefully aimed and tightly argued. It reeked of professionalism.

One could almost imagine Sir David Rowland at the board meeting called to discuss whether or not to reject the latest terms moving his finger slowly around the table eliciting clear and unswerving backing from each of his boardroom colleagues.

This is one collective corporate face which was set firm three months ago and is not going to crack now.

Professional fund managers, of course, have memories of a crumpled bank: the scandal-cum-farce of the Blue Arrow affair, the investment banking hokey-cokey, the options black hole, and even the Legal & General U-turn of last September. It might be unfair to lump the abortive takeover of a top-quality insurance company into such a list of cock-ups. But it serves to illustrate what the major institutions already know - that "New NatWest" is a very young creation indeed and only the latest in a series of new NatWests which seem to pop up every two to three years.

Meanwhile, strategy U-turns and exploding bombs in the accounts have proved to be a rarity in the world of Scottish banking. In short, the management teams at both would-be suitors have decidedly better records.

It is said that the financial sector as a whole is seeing the same trend of what is described as "value transfer" in market circles - a trend which last year near enough throttled several well-known retailers. Investors, waking up to the fact that the internet can ratchet up price competition and crush margins, are switching into sector members with credible web strategies or backing new banking up-starts. This is why, despite being in the middle of the first hostile battle among banks in five years, NatWest saw its share price at one stage fall 30% from its high.

It can be argued that in a period of such intense change, the institutional battalions should be lining up behind one or other of the Scottish banks if only from the prospective of reducing risk. But somehow, even though most fund managers are waiting for just one little extra excuse to floor Sir David and his expensively acquired seconds, both Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank are still giving off the impression they are fighting too far above their weight. There are now just a dozen, furious point-scoring days ahead.

Piece of the pizza

It can only be a matter of time before the chancellor, overwhelmed by the spending demands of his cabinet colleagues but determined not to throw the public finances off kilter, slaps a windfall tax on Luke Johnson. This entrepreneur, the son of newspaper columnist Paul Johnson, made two names for himself in the first half of the last decade: first as the man who guided Pizza Express to the stock market and made its shareholders fat, and secondly as the man who ventured into a string of other small companies (Blakes Clothing, Millgate, AB Ports, and others) and made most of his shareholders thin.

At the same time, Johnson Jnr managed to make no name for himself at all as a nightclub magnate - a career which peaked with the opening of the Climax Club on London's Fulham Road, circa 1995. (It was shut down by the police on the opening night at 11pm as the premises did not have a late-licence.)

But times have changed, and in the eyes of the mad punting public at least, Mr Johnson now stands as Britain's premier serial e-entrepreneur. Hardly a week goes by without another internet investment company or joint venture or plain old cash shell with cyber-potential linked to Mr Johnson - New Media Spark, e-Xentric, Lionheart, just2clicks, and so on. And every time the news breaks, the relevant shares head towards the moon.

Yesterday, we had another example - tea specialist Whittards of Chelsea unveiled its planned web-ification and announced that Mr Johnson was a backer. The shares went up 40%. City pundits refer to this phenomenon of asset-free companies achieving eye-popping valuations as the "capitalisation of human talent". In the case of Mr Johnson, investors seem to think his talents stretch like soft toffee. Mr Brown should get in there quick. And at the current growth of Mr Johnson's wealth, a one-off tax might soon surpass the £400m Nigel Lawson took off the banks 19 years ago.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: London share prices ended modestly higher after a volatile afternoon. As dealers tried to track a switchback of sentiment on Wall Street the FTSE 100 came to rest 22.4 points higher at 6,290.9, having dropped as low as 6,232 soon after lunch.
fields.body:
London share prices ended modestly higher after a volatile afternoon. As dealers tried to track a switchback of sentiment on Wall Street the FTSE 100 came to rest 22.4 points higher at 6,290.9, having dropped as low as 6,232 soon after lunch.

In the United States, investors are still trying to guess what action the Federal Reserve is likely to take after the open market committee meeting.

Volume was impressive, with close to 2bn shares traded - swollen by another splurge of arbitrage business in Vodafone Airtouch and the move from France's Saint Gobain to pick up just under 30% of the British bid target, Meyer International. Close to 500m shares in Vodafone moved through the market as the share price zoomed 21p to 360p, making it increasingly likely that German target Mannesmann will now fall to the British group.

In a busy construction sector Blue Circle was in demand, up 23p at 437p as speculators guessed that a white knight might emerge for the group after the rejection of a 420p a share offer from Lafarge.

In a sector largely overlooked in recent weeks United Utilities ticked 4p higher to 600p after progress on the early float of Norweb Telecom offset an expected £140m cut in revenues attributed to regulatory controls.

Positive broker comment after yesterday's results lent support to Arm Holdings, up 183p at £38.69.

BAA climbed 39p to 425p as analysts at Warburg Dillon Read moved the stock to a "strong buy" from its previous "hold" recommendation after Monday's robust third-quarter figures.

But Anglo-Dutch steel group Corus - formerly British Steel - slipped 4p to 119p as CSFB joined the growing list of banks issuing downgrades. Followers are worried about the effect of the strong pound.

Reed International, down 12p at 486p, was affected by news that its American subsidiary, Matthew Bender, is embroiled in a legal battle in New York.

Imperial Tobacco shed 21p to 429p, with investors unmoved by a reasonably bullish statement at yesterday's annual meeting.

Cable & Wireless lost 22p to £12.34 amid vague rumours suggesting that talks between Hong Kong associate HKT and SingTel of Singapore had failed.

But the talk was dismissed by most brokers, who pointed to the likelihood of profit-taking after the stock's strong recent run.

Sugar group Tate & Lyle saw directors' share-buying propel the stock some 28p higher, to 282p.

fields.headline: Thou shalt not rot
fields.standfirst: Phoebe Traquair's stunning murals seemed destined to decay. Then something wondrous occurred.
fields.trailText: Forget the upturned saucer at Greenwich. The truly inspiring millennial space will shortly be revealed 300 miles north of London on a street corner opposite a laundrette and a wholesale fruit merchants.
fields.body:
Forget the upturned saucer at Greenwich. The truly inspiring millennial space will shortly be revealed 300 miles north of London on a street corner opposite a laundrette and a wholesale fruit merchants. A century ago an energetic middle-aged mother of three, Phoebe Anna Traquair, was completing a remarkable work of art. Barely taller than an altar table, Mrs Traquair spent the best part of eight years decorating the interior of an Edinburgh church in anticipation of the imminent return of Christ. Now, many disappointed decades later, the Heritage Lottery Fund and various other angels are stepping in with over £4m to preserve her extraordinary greetings card - roughly 15,000 square feet of tableaux illustrating the travails of the human soul, episodes from the Old and New Testaments and, on the huge west wall, Christ's majestic return to Earth. Ecstatic layers of beasts, cherubim, saints and the saved hover in throbbing blues and reds about the 66ft high chancel arch.

Artist and patron were made for each other. Mrs Traquair, the Dublin-born wife of an Edinburgh museum official, was a gifted disciple of William Morris's Arts and Crafts movement, equally convinced that beauty transformed lives (particularly those of the poor) and that God ran human affairs.

The Catholic Apostolic Church was established in the 1820s by mystics certain that the French Revolution presaged Armageddon and that it was their mission to unite the Christian faiths in preparation for the spiritual millennium. The Apostolics built a cathedral in Gordon Square in London, then, in 1872, commissioned the distinguished Edinburgh architect Robert Rowand Anderson to design an appropriately exalted structure for a site half a mile north of Princes Street, in Mansfield Place.

Depending on which version you prefer, Mrs Traquair either wandered into a service by chance and begged for a commission, or was formally contracted by the Catholic Apostolics to provide the finishing touches to their prestigious divine reception centre. Either way, Mrs Traquair was an inspired appointment. She worked devotedly at the project between 1893 and 1901, for much of the time perched on a giant wooden scaffold "just like what the artists have in Paris", she chortled to her nephew Willie in one of the letters preserved by the Scottish National Library. Ninety-nine years and several cultural shifts on, her output still overwhelms the visitor. Only Stanley Spencer's first world war frescoes at Burghclere can match it in scale and lyrical intensity.

The tiny Mrs Traquair was forced reluctantly to employ a male assistant for some of the tricky bits. "[He has] no more sense of feeling than wood," she groaned to Willie in April 1896. "I felt inclined to push him off the scaffolding a day or two ago for injuring the profile of two angels." Mrs Traquair's own figures have the fragile, translucent beauty found in Botticelli and the corridors of superior nursing homes. "When potential donors walk in, you see their jaws drop," says Rosemary Mann, secretary of the Mansfield Traquair Trust, which for the past seven years has been fighting to rescue the murals for posterity. In many ways the trust's achievement has matched Mrs Traquair's. After the Catholic Apostolics vacated the building in 1959, it fell into the hands of the Baptists and then the Edinburgh Brick Company, which wanted to turn it into offices. In a splendid irony the developer's architect, Stewart Brown, swapped horses and began campaigning for the building's preservation.

A 16-month programme to convert the church's sizable basement into a headquarters for the Scottish Council for Voluntary Organisations begins in late spring. The main body of the church will become an exhibition and performance space. Restoration of the murals will begin once the walls have dried out.

Mrs Traquair's reputation as a brilliant miniaturist - a book she illuminated recently sold for £33,000 - has hitherto overshadowed the public art to which she attached so much importance. In 1891 she complained bitterly to Willie about the local Sick Children's Hospital's plan to demolish the exquisite consolatory mural she had painted five years earlier for its mortuary. "They, the horrible Edinburgh little handful of bigots who form the directors of the hospital want to pull it down," she wrote. "I feel as if my pet child was to be murdered."

The directors did relent, and the plaster panels were painstakingly transported by horse and cart to the new mortuary, where they remain available for inspection today. Or almost available. Modern hospitals must contend with modern sensibilities. Mrs Traquair's sweet souls whizzing in tiny firepods past sinister snakes and soft-skinned angels are now shrouded by white curtains. "Too many parents found them traumatising," a hospital spokesman shrugs.

Phoebe Traquair's murals can be seen by prior arrangement with the Mansfield Traquair Trust (0131-557 1856).

fields.headline: The jetset director
fields.standfirst: Most artistic twentysomethings would be happy running a cutting-edge theatre like London's Gate. Not Mick Gordon.  Michael Billington meets the Belfast boy who's about to hit the big time
fields.trailText: Mick Gordon leads a strange double life. In London the 29-year-old director runs the award-laden Gate Theatre in Notting Hill, which he eloquently describes as "a stupid room above a pub that does magic things". In Buenos Aires, meanwhile, his new production of My Fair Lady is about to open, joining his existing productions of Art and Closer. Nice to think that Argentina - "Very like Ireland," says Gordon, "except hotter and everyone's better-looking" - is indirectly subsidising a key slice of the London fringe.
fields.body:
Mick Gordon leads a strange double life. In London the 29-year-old director runs the award-laden Gate Theatre in Notting Hill, which he eloquently describes as "a stupid room above a pub that does magic things". In Buenos Aires, meanwhile, his new production of My Fair Lady is about to open, joining his existing productions of Art and Closer. Nice to think that Argentina - "Very like Ireland," says Gordon, "except hotter and everyone's better-looking" - is indirectly subsidising a key slice of the London fringe.

Gordon is the latest in a long line of young directors - starting with Lou Stein and including Stephen Daldry, Giles Croft, Laurence Boswell and David Farr - who have made the Gate the most trail-blazing theatre in London. They have done this by exploring the international repertory and constantly re-inventing the space - all on a virtual shoestring. But there's more to Gordon than a total dedication to the Gate's survival: there's a mixture of charm, chutzpah and a great desire to learn. In the next 12 months he'll be working alongside his illustrious mentors, Peter Brook and Peter Hall, on major projects. Above his desk, you even a find a picture of him with the two Peters, looking like their mischievous grandson. Needless to say, it was Gordon who set up the photograph.

But who exactly is Mick Gordon? Like Kenneth Branagh, he comes from Belfast Protestant stock and even at 17 saw the potential in both taking advice from his elders and seizing the initiative. "I started acting at school," he says. "I got into the National Youth Theatre and at the same time was asked by Unesco to go and teach in Poland. My headmaster told me there was going to be a revolution in Eastern Europe and that I'd be mad not to go. So I did and worked with a theatre teacher who took me everywhere from Krakow to Gdansk. That's when I fell in love with Polish theatre.

"I came back, got a great first in history at Oxford, and was asked to do academia. But I love being with people - I'd go insane being by myself in libraries. I didn't do mainstream theatre at Oxford. Instead I got my eccentric friends together to do a jazz Alice in Wonderland and a musical blending The Jungle Book and the case of Rodney King [the young black man filmed being beaten by police in LA]. We did this at the Oxford Playhouse after I left in 1992, where it was seen by someone from Welsh National Opera. They asked me to work on a Cinderella project."

Gordon claims he suddenly found himself described as a director without knowing what the term meant. His answer was to lock himself away and read all the theories he could lay his hands on. "I fell in love with Peter Brook's soul-searching, as many people have done," he says. "I love all that stuff in search of a god. I thought 'I've really got to meet this man', so I moved down to London."

In 1996 - after a hectic few years directing with a small opera company in Holland Park and Hong Kong, and using his salary to subsidise his own fringe projects at BAC - he won the first bursary as director on attachment to the National Theatre Studio. That brought him even closer to his heroes.

"While I was working at the Studio, Peter Brook called up and summoned a very elite posse of directors - Simon McBurney, Katie Mitchell, Deborah Warner, Gerry Mulgrew - to come and do some workshops in Paris. I was working with Simon at the time on The Caucasian Chalk Circle and asked if I could come.

"On the train over I was very frightened about meeting Brook. I think it was in case I met him and realised I'd never be as good as him. But when we did meet I realised that jealousy is nonsensical. He taught me that the only thing you can do excellently is be yourself. That's where your work will come from.

"I was the naughty grandchild. I got away with blue murder. We were talking about film and I said to Peter: 'You wanted to be George Lucas and Steven Spielberg but you were no good at it. You happen to be just the best theatre director in the world. Well done. Hard luck.' But what I love about Peter is his ceaseless questioning and his enlightened selfishness - his belief that everything must be dedicated to the task in hand."

Gordon's own outstanding productions since taking over the Gate in the summer of 1998 - including La Tempte, Volunteers, Intimate Death and Marathon - have certainly had a distinct Brookian stamp. But he had to discover for himself how to run the theatre. "My great dream was to open up the Gate, which is why we took Salome on tour," he says. "I looked into the possibilities of buying the pub and taking over the Coronet Cinema in Notting Hill Gate, as Stephen Daldry had done before me. But it came to me one night that if it's not this pocket-sized passion-machine over a pub, then it's not the Gate any more. I had to go round the world to fall in love with the girl next door, but that's the truth of it."

Instead, Gordon has squeezed more money out of the London Arts Board (the grant is now £53,000) and temporarily found a way of paying actors by launching a five-play season - Remembering the Future - in partnership with the Royal National Theatre Studio. Even so, the Gate runs on the tightest of budgets. Its permanent staff of five each earn £7,000 a year; Gordon's Argentinian work means he has gone off salary, enabling them to employ an extra director. But the Gate still has to raise £170,000 a year, and this year it's £20,000 short. Like all the directors I've interviewed recently - including Ian Rickson at the Royal Court and Jonathan Kent and Ian McDiarmid at the Almeida - Gordon spends a lot of time taking potential benefactors out to dinner. Directing now seems to be as much about eating as it is about putting on plays.

Gordon's astonishing season takes in Hawaiian, Australian, Turkish-American and Argentinian plays. He even has Peter Hall directing an Italian play, Cuckoos, about a man and woman stuck in a sexually compromising position; having early in his career directed a play about a couple eternally waiting, Sir Peter is now doing one about a pair endlessly coming. "Rude and naughty" is how Mick Gordon describes it. In return for Hall working at the Gate, Gordon will assist Hall on the 10-play John Barton marathon, Tantalus, which opens this autumn in America before touring Europe.

Gordon, who will leave the Gate in mid-2001, claims he doesn't have a career plan - he's no Michael Heseltine sketching out his future on a dinner napkin. All the same, this year alone he'll be directing in Notting Hill and Buenos Aires, working with Hall in America and with Brook on a new Shakespearean project in Paris. He also has a film idea in development. But, if he is a rising directorial star, it is partly because he has the ability to learn from the right masters: he has absorbed Brook's notion of theatre as an unending spiritual quest and Hall's mix of organisational skill and textual fervour. I'd lay odds that Mick Gordon will be soon be a major international player.

webTitle: All the fun of the fair

fields.headline: All the fun of the fair
fields.standfirst: Squealing tyres, flashing lights, heavy breathing: Wall of Death combines the best elements of Hollywood car chase and fairground attraction.  James Hopkin  goes for a spin
fields.trailText: In his short story The Chase, Italo Calvino presents a car chase with a difference. Both vehicles are stuck in a long line of traffic, yet the Italian master contrives a drama with all the momentum of a full-speed pursuit. "In this world of interchangeable appearances," he concludes, "the pursuer-pursued relationship continues to be the only reality we can rely on."
fields.body:
In his short story The Chase, Italo Calvino presents a car chase with a difference. Both vehicles are stuck in a long line of traffic, yet the Italian master contrives a drama with all the momentum of a full-speed pursuit. "In this world of interchangeable appearances," he concludes, "the pursuer-pursued relationship continues to be the only reality we can rely on."

Video artists Graham Ellard and Stephen Johnstone would probably agree. Their latest installation, Wall of Death, also sets out to subvert the conventions of the traditional chase. And there are two key aspects to its composition.

The first is the wall of death itself. At three metres high and 12 metres in diameter, this wooden-panelled replica of the perilous fairground feature, where a motorcyclist must maintain a certain speed to prevent his bike dropping from the wall, provides, says Ellard, "an architectural space within which you're trapped, immersed within the work".

The structure also serves as a 360 cycloramic screen, and thereby invokes the early cinematic practices of the Lumière brothers in the late-19th century. Inside, a dual video-projector, the second key component, whirs overhead. As it revolves, it beams two diametrically opposed ovals of light around the walls from left to right. In the darkness, they look like searchlights. They are, in effect, moving screens.

Suddenly, engines rev, sirens wail, and a shout is lost beneath squealing tyres, as footage from classic 70s film car chases is shown within the ovals. (I spotted extracts from The Driver, The French Connection and Vanishing Point.)

"The car chase seems to us to be an exemplary moment within the history of cinema as spectacle," says Ellard. "And, prior to Jaws or Star Wars, there was a period when the car chase was what cinema seemed to be doing particularly well."

Each sample has been carefully treated in terms of resolution, brightness and contrast, and then edited in order to isolate the subject and object of the pursuit. One screen shows the pursuer, the other the pursued. And they stalk each other around the walls.

"It's difficult to watch both screens and impossible to track them simultaneously," says Ellard. "So there is an act of selection, of trying to keep up." You're not helped by the fact that the six speakers alternate the wheel-spins and engine noises between the two screens. "In a sense," says Ellard, "the viewer is involved in the chase."

It's quite disorienting, this complicity, especially as there are other people shuffling about beside you trying to fathom their own approach. Even if you do manage to glimpse the two screens in quick succession, don't expect to piece together a continuous narrative.

"Although the films sometimes got the better of us," says Ellard, "our intention was to show the pursuer and the pursued going round the same corner at the same time."

Which should confuse you even more. For here, as in Calvino's story, "neither pursuers nor pursued can be distinguished". The effect is unsettling, and there are many eerie moments in the 14 one-minute loops (seven per screen).

In one sequence, you see a ruby-red pick-up truck in an underground car park. It is stationary, its lights off. You track it around the walls as it remains still. This combination of movement (the film, and you following it) and stasis (the vehicle) is uncanny.

Meanwhile, on the opposite screen, a flame-licked sports car screeches round the same gloomy car park, seemingly oblivious to the other vehicle's whereabouts. Then the truck's headlights come on and it creeps forward. It accelerates and both vehicles speed around their own screens. You provide the link that unites them in a chase.

It's a sequence that exploits the full dramatic potential of the dual-screen format, while meeting the artists' aim of creating "a non-narrative spectacular". Wall of Death challenges our assumption of a space-time continuum - just as the Lumière brothers' head-on film of a train pulling into a station apparently prompted those in the front row to jump out of the way.

The prolonging of suspense is central to Wall of Death, both here and in the fairground original. Ellard agrees that both projects are about "the deferral of conclusions. If not death-defying, then the defying of gravity or logic or the expectation of what is possible."

Only once in the sequences do the pursuer and pursued appear in the same frame. To show the denouement of the films - usually a fatal crash or shooting - would be to go against the existentialist spirit of the piece: to keep going without purpose or resolution.

The pursuits, though, are not all confined to vehicles. One of the best sequences shows a sweaty Gene Hackman chasing a man on foot down side-streets and subways. You hear agitated mumblings, heavy breathing, the rap of urgent footsteps on concrete. These sounds are sometimes slowed down or echoed to give a chilling feel of a fugitive urban existence. And it's quite alienating as you stand there in the darkness, somewhere in a city yourself.

The artists' most recent project opened at the end of last year. It's a permanent public sculpture for the A13 in Barking. At a major traffic intersection, at the height of a flyover, they have erected 75 tall, stainless steel needles peaked with runway landing lights. The idea, says Ellard, is to give drivers the impression that they are "skating across the surface of a blue plateau of light".

It sounds enticing, though presumably you aren't encouraged to chase the car in front.

Wall of Death is at the Paper Bag Factory, 165 Childer Street, London SE8, from February 4-27. Details: 0171-831 7753.

fields.headline: Net bosses push 'cannibalism'
fields.standfirst:
Softbank
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Traditional firms facing the "e-business" challenge should split off their net-based activities and encourage them to devour the parent, an internet investor said yesterday.
fields.body:
Traditional firms facing the "e-business" challenge should split off their net-based activities and encourage them to devour the parent, an internet investor said yesterday.

Masayoshi Son, president and chief executive of Softbank, whose own stock has soared through investments in net firms, said he saw "pure play" net firms beating those mixing "clicks and mortar".

Mr Son told the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, that firms should take the "crazy" option: "Assign a totally different chief executive and tell them to go kill this sister company.

"I don't have enough confidence to [enter] this new revolution with only one step - I need both of my feet to compete," he said, of the option of trying to stay ahead in both the traditional business world and net culture.

The net has bosses of many established firms scratching their heads as they watch entrepreneurs capturing the net's potential for low-cost, high-service rivals on a relatively low initial outlay.

Among executives discussing the problem in Davos were the leaders of two companies which have illustrated that point - Dell and Compaq.

Compaq, the world's largest personal computer maker, is fighting back after seeing its market leadership threatened when Dell wired into the net's cost-cutting potential to sell direct and assemble computers on demand.

Dell's founder, Michael Dell, said that the first stage many firms go through on the net is to do old things using new means. "The real power comes when you do new things using the new medium," he said.

Michael Capellas, who has reshaped Compaq to meet Dell's challenge, agreed. "The one message of the net is cannibalise before someone cannibalises for you." Reuters

fields.headline: Say hello, wave goodbye
fields.standfirst:
Say cheese

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: How long do you give a new job before deciding that your reluctance to get out of bed for it is not down to sloth, late-night telly or fear of the fax machine, but confirmation that it is wrong for you? Anecdotal evidence puts the settling-in period at between one and three months, but survey results released this week show a more decisive pattern. Bad first day? Then why go back? One in 10 people questioned by online recruitment service totaljobs.com admitted to walking out after their first day; 14% gave it a week, 17% a month. This is either a positive indication that workers won't tolerate being miserable, or a sign of the shameful dilettante attitude undermining the workforce.
fields.body:
How long do you give a new job before deciding that your reluctance to get out of bed for it is not down to sloth, late-night telly or fear of the fax machine, but confirmation that it is wrong for you? Anecdotal evidence puts the settling-in period at between one and three months, but survey results released this week show a more decisive pattern. Bad first day? Then why go back? One in 10 people questioned by online recruitment service totaljobs.com admitted to walking out after their first day; 14% gave it a week, 17% a month. This is either a positive indication that workers won't tolerate being miserable, or a sign of the shameful dilettante attitude undermining the workforce.

What is certain, with 84% wishing they could try another job for a day, is the likelihood that when the prima donna finally settles, he or she will still be dissatisfied. Nevertheless, the Campaign for Learning has seized on this figure to launch a National Job Swap Day. On May 25, employees will be able to swap places with someone else in their department. The radical option, of course, would have been to let them swap with people in other sectors, but when 64% of staff surveyed believe they are in the wrong jobs, what manager would risk it?

Tubehell.com, the internet forum for disgruntled tube users, is hosting an energetic dispute after one commuter casually referred to a member of London Underground staff as a Nazi. A hurt message came back, pleading: "Don't call LUL staff, or anyone except a Nazi, a Nazi" inviting the inevitable reply: "If we can't call them Nazis, can we call them bastards?" The debate then dovetailed into a study of the sexual imagery in tunnels/trains, before nudging into a thread about the likelihood of Knightrider beating Streethawk, if it came to a ruck. Last word, at the time of printing, comes from a tube user with powerful rhetorical skills and the unanswerable line: "I am Cheeseman and I have the power of cheddar."

fields.headline: Supermarkets in the clear
fields.standfirst: Customers not suffering from abuse of monopoly, says competition commission
fields.trailText: UK supermarket chains each belong to at least one monopoly but have been largely cleared of abusing their position and profiteering at the expense of shoppers and suppliers.
fields.body:
UK supermarket chains each belong to at least one monopoly but have been largely cleared of abusing their position and profiteering at the expense of shoppers and suppliers.

After a nine-month inquiry the competition commission said in its preliminary report that food prices were rising at a slower pace than general retail prices and European food prices, and that shoppers reported "high levels of consumer satisfaction" with local outlets.

The commission added that there was little evidence of "excessive profitability".

Over the past year the supermarket groups' squeaky clean image has been under attack. Consumer groups demanded to know why shoppers appeared to pay more for food in the UK than Europe and farmers claimed that supermarkets were driving them to the brink of bankruptcy.

Yesterday the grocery groups, which began a round of price promotions when the inquiry started last year, seized the watchdog's report as evidence that there is no such thing as "rip-off Britain".

The watchdog, which was asked to investigate the £90bn market after an inquiry by the office of fair trading, cleared 19 of the biggest chains, including Iceland, Marks & Spencer, Waitrose and Lidl, of operating against the public interest.

It will now summon the big five - Sainsbury, Tesco, Safeway, Asda and Morrisons - which account for 75% of the market - to give more information about how they work.

The grocery sector has been operating under a cloud for 18 months as consumer watch dogs have carried out their inquiries, which many supermarket executives believe have been politically motivated.

There were suggestions that the watchdogs might order store sell-offs, relax planning rules to allow more stores to be built, encouraging competition, or ban supermarkets from selling at below cost price for promotional purposes. But analyst Ian MacDougall of Williams de Broe said: "This is as good as they could have hoped for. It is not ordering them to do anything but carry on."

The commission said there were two complex monopolies: one in relation to the pricing of groceries and the other deriving from the relationship between grocers and suppliers, but they were not automatically operating against the public interest.

But Terry Leahy, chief executive of Tesco said: "The commission has found no real evidence of excessive profits. It has found prices have fallen in real terms and that the trend here is lower than overseas. There is no monopoly. This is a fantastically competitive industry." He dismissed as "technical" the findings that two complex monopolies are operating.

Shares in the big groups, which underperformed the market by 20% last year, rose as the commission's findings were published. There has been speculation that a round of consolidation would be unleashed once the watchdog's findings were known.

At the markets' close all but Safeway and Sainsbury's shares were down on their opening prices and Tesco was up only 1p. "This is good news for the retailers," said Clive Black at Charterhouse Securities. "The share price reaction shows just how out of favour this sector has become."

 Waitrose is launching three online services to sell organic food, flowers and books, videos and CDs. The group has 4,000 shoppers registered on its site, but does not believe home delivery can be profitable and has opted to make bulk deliveries to customers at work.

Questions the chains still have to answer

Market power The commission wants to find out whether individual stores exercise local market muscle - and whether shoppers using stores where there is little or no competition pay more

Prices The commission wants to see

 if price competition is confined to a small range of regular purchases and at stores with little local competition

 if price changes by suppliers are passed on rapidly and fully

 if loss-leaders produce only short term benefits for shoppers and ultimately distort competition and choice

Efficiency Supermarkets will have to spell out their costs and the economies of scale they can achieve

Land & location The commission wants to know how much supermarkets pay for land and how it compares with the price of land for other development. If supermarket land costs more, the watchdog wants to know whether the cost is met by high grocery prices. It also wants to know whether supermarkets try to restrict rivals' access to suitable sites

Suppliers Crucially, the commission wants to know if the supermarkets have too much buying power, whether they pass that purchasing muscle on to shoppers as lower prices and whether they allow suppliers a decent return.

Other issues

 internet and home shopping

 the entry of Wal-Mart into the UK

 access to grocery stores by less mobile, lower income groups

 effect on local communities of out-of-town developments

fields.headline: Dreams of lost love
fields.standfirst:
Ballad of Yachiyo
Gate Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Ballad of Yachiyo
Gate Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Drama is a form of anthropology, and one of the pleasures of this play is that it admits us to a totally unfamiliar world: that of Japanese immigrants in the Hawaiian islands in 1919. It takes time to get one's bearings but, once one does, a poignantly lyrical ballad unfolds.

The writer, Philip Kan Gotanda, based the play on his aunt, who here becomes the storyteller. Yachiyo lives among the cane-cutters on a remote Hawaiian island (Hawaii, one should remember, was annexed by the United States in 1898 and heavily populated by Asian immigrants). Her family is extremely poor so they send the 16-year-old to stay with a potter and his wife on a neighbouring island, to learn a trade and possibly find a husband.

Yachiyo, who has a boyfriend back home heavily involved in militant protests against the American landowners, falls in love with the elderly Japanese potter, with foreseeably tragic consequences.

Gotanda's 75-minute play, as I see it, is about a heroine caught between two violently contrasting worlds and traditions. Back home she cuts dresses out of a mail-order catalogue and supports her unionist boyfriend. Once she goes to live with the aged Takamura and his wife, however, she is involved in Japanese tea ceremonies and reverence for the ancient art of ceramics. Yachiyo suffers the classic plight of the immigrant caught between two cultures: even her thwarted love for Takamura seems like a nostalgic throwback to her ancient Japanese roots. What strikes one is the gentle, faintly ironic tone of Gotanda's writing, and the sense of cruelly impending fate. Throughout the play Takamura's neglected wife tells a story, with the aid of dolls, of a beautiful young girl destroyed by love: in effect, the same story we see enacted in real life.

James Kerr's production, played out on a slatted, wooden stage lit from below and against a background of oriental screens, has the quality of a remembered dream.

The doubling of roles initially causes confusion, but there are powerful performances from Inika Leigh Wright, making her professional debut, as the love-smitten, yearning Yachiyo, from Togo Igawa as the stern, grizzled, spiritually weak potter, and from Helene Patarot as his wife, who has suffered a lifetime's betrayal and humiliation.

It is a strange play, but one that paints a moving picture of female isolation and that gradually enfolds one in its tragic lyricism.

Box office: 0171-229 0706. Until February 19

fields.headline: Back to the apocalypse
fields.standfirst:
The The
The Garage, London
***
fields.trailText:
The The
The Garage, London
***
fields.body:
Discounting Hanky Panky, a downright bizarre collection of Hank Williams covers released in 1995, it's been seven years since The The's last album, Dusk, but, standing inside the Garage, you'd never know it. Leader Matt Johnson has spent the past two decades constructing a personal cocoon of claustrophobia laced with venom that will enable him to exist outside of time as the rest of the music world measures it, and tonight it seems to finally be complete. It's hard to imagine that just outside the door there's an apathetic pop scene on the verge of collapse.

The The's fanbase has the dedicated, male, slatternly, eternally student core that it's always had - slightly younger than The Fall's, slightly older than The Auteurs', but with essentially the same genetic make-up. These are people who've learned to be patient with Johnson (he's only made six albums of original songs in 20 years), but who've also learned that he won't let them down with even the slightest concession to fashion. They expect integrity, and, if Johnson slips, they'll let him know about it. After one less than indulgent guitar solo I hear someone shout, "He's turned into a wanker!"

On the whole, the old guard seem pleased with the new material from The The's forthcoming The Naked Self album - a heavier, more bustling affair than Dusk but with the oppressive clamour emanating from Johnson's troubled psyche, as opposed to his studio technology. Unlike his sound, Johnson's sidemen change from record to record, but tonight their tightly wound angular riffs had the chime of Television and early Roxy Music, and on Dogs of Lust and This is the Day Johnson's voice resonated with an industrial soulfulness that suggested a roll of corrugated steel wrapped around his larynx. This could be 1986. Or 1993. Or 1980. Yet it still feels like the future.

But I'm troubled by a couple of questions: The The have hardly changed in sound or lyrical preoccupations since the new-wave era, so why does their vision of apocalyptic doom seem so much more vivid and futuristic than that created by the most outlandish electronica, and why does Johnson always sound so in tune with the political troubles of the time (genetically modified foods, globalisation)? And why, despite the precision of their playing and the conviction of Johnson's anger, are The The never a truly rousing live band? Thinking about this is a bit like trying to add seven to two and make 12, so I content myself with the thought that, if you exist outside of time, you must exist outside of maths too.

webTitle: Abbey Life new sales go to Allied Dunbar

fields.headline: Abbey Life new sales go to Allied Dunbar
fields.trailText: Abbey Life, the insurance unit of Lloyds TSB, is to be closed to new business and its 1,300 direct sales force sold to Allied Dunbar. The announcement yesterday ends long-running speculation about the troubled operation. The bank will make a £98m provision in its accounts for the loss on the sale.
fields.body:
Abbey Life, the insurance unit of Lloyds TSB, is to be closed to new business and its 1,300 direct sales force sold to Allied Dunbar. The announcement yesterday ends long-running speculation about the troubled operation. The bank will make a £98m provision in its accounts for the loss on the sale.

Allied Dunbar, part of Zurich Financial Services, is buying the sales force for £100m, of which £20m is conditional on sales targets being met in the next two years. The acquisition will create the largest single direct sales force in Britain.

Other insurance groups are closing their sales forces, but Zurich chief executive Sandy Leitch insisted the group intended to expand its capacity. "It's very difficult to find sales people. Salesmen vote with their feet. They work for the company they admire," he said.

Allied Dunbar, which already has 4,000 sales people, expects to hire approximately 70% of the Abbey Life sales force with their access to Abbey's customer base. Lloyds TSB said there would be some job losses at its administration centre in Bournemouth.

Lloyds TSB said Abbey Life would retain and administer the £1.2bn-worth of policies already sold to 1.5m customers.

Lloyds TSB bought the 38% of Abbey Life it did not own in 1996 for £1.7bn. It had to prop it up last year after pension misselling provisions caused it to slip below treasury standards. Lloyds TSB, due to report next week, said it expected Abbey Life to report pre-tax profits, excluding pension provisions, of £158m.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Suzanne Wilson, 48 sales executive
fields.body:
Suzanne Wilson, 48 sales executive

I work for a sales company and have a personality clash with one of the salesmen. He's very chauvinistic and I'm the only woman in the office, so he never listens to anything I say. This has happened to me before and I've resigned, but this time I'm not giving in. I won't give him the satisfaction of knowing he's won. I just get on with my job and the results I get show I do it well. When things are really bad, I list in my head all the good jobs I've done and let his comments go in one ear and out the other. I've toughened up.

John Ferguson, 28 art director

When a colleague in a new job was very friendly, I should have heard alarm bells because he was clearly unpopular. At first we were pals but then he started making snide remarks. I tried to be pleasant and professional, but it got to the point where he kicked me as I passed his desk. I complained and he was warned to leave me alone. He'd still mutter abusive things under his breath, but I just ignored him.

Catherine Stevenson, 26 IT consultant

I had to share a desk with someone who worked the late shift. He was very territorial and when he came in and saw me sitting there, he would be a seething mass. I could have avoided him by leaving just before he arrived, but I didn't see why I should. I sussed out he was the sort of person who'd eventually get really angry and make a scene, which is what he did, in front of the whole office. My boss had a word and he was shamed into being nicer to me. It worked out well because I didn't complain, I just waited for him to screw up.

I worked with a woman who had different ideas of what was important and complained about me when I asked her to do things as thoroughly as I like them done. Eventually I realised she was insecure and saw me as a threat. I backed down for several months; the work we produced wasn't of the highest standard, but it was more important to find a long-term solution to our clash. Then one day she just clicked, decided I was her best friend and gradually started taking my suggestions on board.

Anthony Lewis, 48 marketing director

I used to work with a woman whose panicking drove me up the wall. Confrontation made things worse, so I made a point of getting to know her, finding out what made her tick. I complimented her on her success because she was good at her job - and found she wasn't the harridan I'd thought. Working with her was still difficult, but she began to trust my judgment, so things got better.

fields.headline: Reject inadequate bids, says NatWest
fields.standfirst: Split vote may save besieged bank as scramble for support starts before St Valentine's Day deadline
fields.trailText: An undignified scramble for the support of NatWest's major shareholders began yesterday as the bank urged rejection of the "inadequate bids" by its two Scottish assailants.
fields.body:
An undignified scramble for the support of NatWest's major shareholders began yesterday as the bank urged rejection of the "inadequate bids" by its two Scottish assailants.

With neither of the final offers from Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland regarded as a "knock-out blow", executives from all three banks will spend the next 10 days locked in presentations with the 25 leading investors who will decide Nat West's fate.

The hopes of the two Scottish banks appeared to fade last night, as NatWest's chairman and chief executive Sir David Rowland insisted: "Neither offer adds real value and both would leave the offeror financially stretched". BoS, however, urged NatWest "to give a lead to shareholders" now that neither of the bidders are able to revise their offers under takeover rules.

Led by chief executive Peter Burt, BoS accused NatWest of seeking stalemate among its shareholders for "deliverance".

Mr Burt was reflecting the views of some bankers who believe NatWest might escape on a split vote among investors, preventing either bidder reaching the 50% hurdle for a successful takeover.

Bankers are also struggling to interpret the movement in the share prices of all three banks. NatWest ended at 1,158p, down 30p and still 14% below the BoS offer and 18% less than the price being offered by Royal Bank's shares.

Recommendations to shareholders from some of the few remaining "independent" analysts in the City yesterday appeared to indicate there is still all to play for before the St Valentine's Day deadline by which shareholders must make their decision.

Analysts at Commerzbank have already urged shareholders to give NatWest one last chance; the team at Salomon Smith Barney backed Royal Bank of Scotland while Robert Fleming and Paribas both recommended BoS.

Preventing a "split" vote will require the management of the three banks to build up a a body opinion by the major institutional investors who own shares in NatWest. While all three banks have come up with as much "cash" as possible to pay NatWest shareholders, they will now be trying to win the support for their management teams who will determine the value of the shares investors will be left holding.

All of the camps will be anxious to win the support of Huw Jones, the quietly powerful head of corporate finance at Prudential, NatWest's biggest shareholder. Surrounded by controversy recently after the Pru's management clinched a deal with BoS to sell insurance in NatWest's branches if its bid succeeds, the fund management team at the Pru is expected to guard its independence zealously.

Mercury Asset Management and Schroders, the next two largest and potentially influential shareholders in NatWest, were also keeping close counsel last night. However, Standard Life, the fifth largest investor with a 2.66% stake, was prepared to reveal that it is unlikely to support NatWest's revamped management team.

The votes from "index-tracking" firms Legal & General - which had it not been for the two bids would now be part of NatWest - and Barclays Global Investors will also be key. They own around 2.6% of NatWest each and had been the subject of speculation that they might end up backing any consensus view which emerged. However, L&G insisted last night that it had not yet decided which of the outcomes to back.

Marian Collins, the director responsible for corporate governance at Barclays Global Investors, refuted any market speculation that as an index tracker any charm offensive by the three camps would be wasted on her. "We will make a truly active decision on what is in the best interests of our shareholders," she said.

Even at Phillips & Drew, where the fund managers have been taking an active role in shaking up the boards of underperforming companies, a director was prepared to admit that they had been "impressed" at the defence NatWest had put up.

It has never made a secret of its admiration of Bank of Scotland, however, as it was once the owners of a 15% stake bought when Standard Life reduced its holding four years ago. The director would give nothing away as to whether that might count for something in the way P&D cast its vote.

 Changes to Barclays' management team emerged yesterday Gary Dibb joins the executive committee as director of strategic planning and corporate development. Tim Shepheard-Walwyn joins in Marchfrom Swiss bank UBS as group risk director, replacing Alan Brown who is retiring.

fields.headline: Crying silently into loo paper
fields.standfirst: Behind the scenes in a sexual harassment case
fields.trailText: "It's a good offer. We won't do better if we go into the tribunal."
fields.body:
"It's a good offer. We won't do better if we go into the tribunal."

Jane, my client, is looking at me with a look I see every few months. It's the look you wear when you've steeled yourself to leave the job where the jokes are always about slappers or blowjobs or your tits and you're never going to get promoted. And you've taken your courage in your hands and brought the claim and then listened for months to the equivocations and forebodings of your solicitor. And you've come to the tribunal in the smartest of the suits you used to wear to work and your boyfriend has taken the day off to hold your hand.

And you realise the tradeoff for all the anger and the pain is a company cheque and a bland reference.

She shakes her head. "I know you said the tribunal couldn't order them to do anything about Mr P or Mr M, but if other people from the company saw what they were like, if they heard my story..."

She stops because she knows what I'm going to say. I've said it already - that the tribunal can't undo what's been done, can't change the men she worked with, can't really give her the justice she wants.

The boyfriend is looking anxious. They've spent a lot of money on this case and settlement is the no-risk option. "Do you want me to leave you two alone together for a little while to talk about it?"

I go outside and walk a little way down the wind blown Croydon streets, uniformly grey under the white winter sky, and wish I still smoked.

When I get back to the waiting room, Jane is crying soundlessly into some loo paper and trying to smile at me.

"Do you know what you want to do?" "Well, I thought about it and I thought about how maybe I would feel better seeing them suffer a bit in there. But Simon and I talked and we can't really afford it and I'm not sure men like that suffer anyway."

"I think you're doing the right thing. I'll go and tell their counsel and we'll just have to draw up the agreement. Then we go into the tribunal briefly and it'll be all over."

As we're leaving, Jane puts a white hand on my arm and says: "It's not your fault it's like this." Which makes me wonder what my face was doing.

Back in Chambers, barristers who are not in court are eating their lunchtime sandwiches in the conference room. One of the silks is telling a "humorous" story about a feminist solicitor who stopped instructing him after he referred to her as a lady. Everyone laughs at this and someone remarks that it's a good thing there are no "ladies" in Chambers. Whatever that means.

I suddenly can't be bothered to go "heh heh" at this. I put my sandwiches back in their bag and eat them at my desk.

webTitle: P&U offers to scrap $600m GM plan research

fields.headline: P&U offers to scrap $600m GM plan research
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Pharmacia & Upjohn, the drugs group, has offered to axe a $600m research and development budget for genetically modified foods in an attempt to pacify shareholders unhappy about its takeover of Monsanto, the US biotechnology company.
fields.body:
Pharmacia & Upjohn, the drugs group, has offered to axe a $600m research and development budget for genetically modified foods in an attempt to pacify shareholders unhappy about its takeover of Monsanto, the US biotechnology company.

The offer was made by Fred Hassan, P&U's chief executive, at the start of an investor roadshow designed to sell the unpopular merger.

In a further sign that the new company wanted to distance itself from the GM business, it announced last week that it would drop the Monsanto name. It will be called Pharmacia if investors approve the deal.

Shares in both companies have fallen sharply since the deal was announced in December as shareholders criticised the decision to keep Monsanto's controversial GM business.

Tim Ghriskey, senior fund manager for Dreyfus Corporation, said the offer had been made to appease investors. "I don't think anybody wanted to hear that they were going to spend $600m a year researching and developing a business that right now has a somewhat questionable future," he said.

As part of the merger, the combined group decided to keep about 80% of Monsanto's GM business while spinning off the rest. Horrified at being saddled with the controversial business, investors have sold shares in both groups.

Since the merger announcement P&U's share price has fallen to $47 from more than $60 while Monsanto was trading at $37 yesterday, down from $41 on the day the deal was announced.

In an interview yesterday, Mr Hassan revealed his concessions to investors. "If agricultural biotech goes south, that research and development will be cut," he said.

The comments were designed to bolster ambitious growth targets for the group, which is expected to have combined annual sales of $17bn and a drugs research and development budget of $2bn.

A spokesman for the company said yesterday that Mr Hassan, who will head the combined group, is "assuring shareholders that we are going to meet growth targets and that we have some place to turn to if we need extra resources to meet those targets".

The company's decision to sacrifice its GM research budget contrasts with Mr Hassan's bullish comments when announcing the merger. He said that the long-term prospects for the industry were good while admitting that an "education" campaign was needed to overcome its "PR problem".

P&U has also indicated to investors that it would consider further takeovers within the drugs sector to bolster its efforts to become a "pharmaceuticals powerhouse".

Analysts said yesterday that these comments underlined the group's desire to further reduce the importance of the agricultural biotechnology business. One possible takeover candidate would be American Homes Products, Mr Hassan's former employer and the US drugs company involved in several previous takeover attempts.

The consumer backlash against GM foods started in Europe and hit Monsanto's market and its plans to create a global life sciences business last year.

webTitle: CBI adjusts its stance on euro

fields.headline: CBI adjusts its stance on euro
fields.standfirst:
Single currency on road to recovery

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Exporters could live with a pound valued at the equivalent of nearly three marks if Britain were to join the euro, Confederation of British Industry leaders said yesterday.
fields.body:
Exporters could live with a pound valued at the equivalent of nearly three marks if Britain were to join the euro, Confederation of British Industry leaders said yesterday.

Sir Clive Thompson, the CBI's president, said business had been forced to live with a strong pound for most of the last two-and-a-half years and had accepted it.

Setting out the CBI's agenda under its new director-general, Digby Jones, Sir Clive said business now accepted that it had to plan for a pound valued around DM2.80 or 2.90 - just under the rate fixed when sterling entered the exchange rate mechanism in 1990.

This is a higher level than the previous estimates the CBI has made of a fair exchange rate but it is still some 40 pfennigs lower than the pound's current dizzying levels. Sterling closed in London last night at 60.21p to the euro, equivalent to around DM3.24. Only last July, the employers' body argued for an entry rate to the eurozone of DM2.70.

There was some relief yesterday for sterling as the battered single currency recovered from record lows against the pound and the dollar set in overnight trading on Monday night.

After hitting a lifetime low of 96.74 US cents overnight, the euro bounded back above the 97 cent threshold yesterday to close at 97.27 in London trading.

The euro has managed to take back about half its declines for the week but is still 16% below its debut value and could face further falls today, if the US Federal Reserve raises interest rates as expected.

An increase in borrowing rates in the US would attract further inflows of capital, pumping up the greenback further and placing the European Central Bank in a very delicate position at its meeting tomorrow. The ECB's head, Wim Duisenberg, hinted earlier this week that the bank was concerned that the euro's fall could bring inflation. But the governing council is likely to be reluctant to raise rates to defend the currency this month, while Europe's economic recovery is still precarious.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers last night repeated his denial that the government was cooling off on entry to the single currency zone.

webTitle: Slimmer pickings for new Lady Luck

fields.headline: Slimmer pickings for new Lady Luck
fields.standfirst: Camelot names cut-rate successor as chief executive
fields.trailText: Lottery operator Camelot will install a new chief executive if it retains its franchise to run the National Lottery later this year - and pay her 30% less than the present boss.
fields.body:
Lottery operator Camelot will install a new chief executive if it retains its franchise to run the National Lottery later this year - and pay her 30% less than the present boss.

Dianne Thompson will take over the top job from Tim Holley on July 1 if Camelot is re-awarded the lottery licence. Mr Holley earned £482,000 last year, including all bonuses and benefits, but Ms Thompson will be paid £337,000.

The company said it was acting in response to widespread public concern over boardroom pay at the company. The issue is bound to be highlighted by rival licence hopefuls - which include Richard Branson's People's Lottery, and bids from Carlton and Littlewoods - during the forthcoming bidding process.

Chairman Sir George Russell said: "We have taken this opportunity to put in place a new remuneration scheme which is appropriate to the next phase of the lottery's life.

"Director's packages will be reduced and the special bonus scheme for directors abolished."

Three years ago Camelot faced calls for its lottery licence to be withdrawn. The lottery's huge success in its first years had generated huge windfalls for the company's top executives and they were carpeted by Chris Smith, the culture and media secretary. Eventually the senior executives in the firing line - including Mr Holley - promised to give large chunks of their bonuses to charity.

Ms Thompson, 49, who has a marketing background, is currently Camelot's commercial operations director. After running her own advertising agency she became managing director of a Swedish steel tools company. She was then appointed marketing director of Woolworths and later joined jewellers Signet to rebuild and rebrand H Samuel and Ernest Jones after the Ratners debacle.

Yesterday she said: "Camelot is now into its second phase. Tim had the ideal skills mix for a start-up operation, but now the job is about developing the brand."

Camelot's bid, along with all the others, must be submitted by February 29. It will include plans for new games for internet and interactive television lottery participants.

The winner of the franchise will be announced by the end of June.

fields.headline: The end of the tribunal
fields.standfirst:
You've brought your case and won. Congratulations! But what happens once the euphoria has ebbed and the money has been spent? Sally Weale finds out

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you were a bit on the cynical side, you might think it's easy to bring a discrimination case. The media is full of them: race discrimination, sex discrimination, massive pay-outs, bosses at the mercy of the "compensation culture".
fields.body:
If you were a bit on the cynical side, you might think it's easy to bring a discrimination case. The media is full of them: race discrimination, sex discrimination, massive pay-outs, bosses at the mercy of the "compensation culture".

But Aisling Sykes didn't find it easy. Earlier this month, she won her case of unfair dismissal against a leading City bank whose lawyers tried to ruin her reputation. Belinda Coote had to fight leisure giant Granada for more than six years just to get a reference. Bhaggie Patel almost lost her baby because of the stress of bringing a race discrimination case. Try telling these women that going to an employment tribunal is easy.

Coote, 38, first brought a sex discrimination case against Granada Hospitality in September 1993 when she lost her job as general manager of a bowling centre after getting pregnant. The claim was settled and she left by mutual agreement, but when she started to apply for new jobs and employment agencies wanted a reference, Granada failed to supply one.

She took them to a subsequent tribunal, claiming their refusal to give references was in retaliation. Initially her claim failed but she took it to the European Court of Justice which ruled in her favour in 1998; last week she finally won what is a landmark case and £195,000 in compensation. The scars, however, will take a long time to heal.

"It was something I had to do," Coote says. "I could not get a reference, so I could not get a job. One of the reasons I settled the first case was because I didn't want to jeopardise my career by being labelled a trouble-maker. I still wonder if I'm in a no-win situation." She has never returned to the leisure industry. "Granada is such a big part of it, if you're knocked out, how do you get back?" She has moved into business development, but believes she has not been as successful as she should have been.

"It has changed my life completely," she says. "I still have a facade of confidence, but it's very brittle. I'm not as sure as I used to be. You can't go for six or seven years with someone questioning your integrity and ability without it having a lasting effect. I have lost years of my career path. I was doing an MSc, I wanted to get into a more strategic position. I suspect I will never make up that ground."

Would she advise others to pursue a claim? "If you feel strongly enough, you should damn well do it. But be prepared for a very rocky road."

Many of us do feel strongly enough, it seems. As employees have become increasingly aware of their rights, the number of claims before employment tribunals has shot up, from 48,817 in 1989 to 146,630 for the period from September 1998 to August 1999. Around 40% are settled by the conciliation service Acas, 30% are withdrawn and the rest go to tribunal. A raft of new legislation, including the introduction of the minimum wage, has increased pressure on an already creaking system.

Aisling Sykes, 39, lost a claim for unlawful indirect sexual discrimination but last month won an unfair dismissal case against City bank JP Morgan, after being sacked soon after she became pregnant with her fourth child. She had been warned it would be tough, but hadn't realised quite how tough. "It's intensely personal. What you are hoping is that people will believe you. What they are trying to do is a character assassination."

Lawyers even contacted nanny agencies she had used in order to gather information on her. "Halfway through the cross-examination," she recalls, "I sat there thinking, why don't I just get up and walk away? They will rake over everything, trawl through performance reviews for every year you've been there. It's horrible, a massively uneven fight."

The day she won, she told the press she had committed "professional suicide. You have to think you are not going to get the same job again."

Would she discourage others from going to tribunal? "You have to be incredibly confident about what you are saying. If you are trying to spin a lie, do not even attempt to go in there. It's very hard to win any case. You have to be a strong character and incredibly patient. It's a huge strain and it involves your whole family."

While sex discrimination cases get a reasonably sympathetic hearing in the media, there is still suspicion around race discrimination cases. The Daily Mail, for example, has highlighted the story of Tahir Hussain who, after being turned down for jobs, has made a series of claims to employment tribunals, in a strategic attempt to expose widespread discrimination.

According to Chris Myant of the Commission for Racial Equality, however, no one who has been through a race discrimination case would willingly do it again. "We do not publicise a lot of cases because the people have gone through hell in the first place, hell in the tribunal reliving it, having their word doubted and their reputation smeared. They can't take going through the same thing in the media."

Bhaggie Patel, 38, would definitely do it again. She brought a case of racial discrimination after a job for which she was better qualified was given to a white woman. The tribunal ruled in her favour and she was given £2,000.

Fair compensation? It is hard to say: the first day of the tribunal, Patel, who was seven months pregnant, was rushed to hospital after her waters broke. Her daughter was born two days later, weighing just 3.5lb, and spent a month in an incubator. The doctors put it down to stress. "It was never easy," Patel says. "But if you believe you've been discriminated against, I'd say pursue your case."

Bolton is a small place and as Patel adds: "I knew a lot of those involved. The woman who got the job was my colleague's partner. It was like challenging all these people and not knowing if the system would work."

There have been professional consequences, too. Patel feels she now has a label - a bit of a trouble-maker. "It's there in the background. But I've got to make the most of what I've got and get on with my life." She is now manager for a social care agency.

It's not easy to bring a discrimination case. Your life will be put under a microscope, your career may be blown out of the water. But these women shared a sense of moral outrage that propelled them into court. We should be grateful such people exist.

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Something you learn in this job is that, while perhaps 75% of cases are about something bad that has happened at someone's work, the remainder are about something bad that has happened in someone's head. Like Miss P this week. She came to chambers for a conference with her solicitor, bone thin, in long clothes, the fingers holding her coffee cup like twigs. She told her tale in a breathless stream. There were people involved in it at work and outside of work as well. People in her home town who had been influenced by the people at her work. Things happened, break-ins at her house, where objects were moved, just enough to make her notice, so she would know they had been there. And there were people who followed her to work and home again. They didn't say anything, they just followed her.

There were people involved in it at work and outside of work as well. People in her home town who had been influenced by the people at her work. Things happened, break-ins at her house, where objects were moved, just enough to make her notice, so she would know they had been there. And there were people who followed her to work and home again. They didn't say anything, they just followed her.

It took a while before I could break into the torrent to ask what her job was. There was no easy answer to this. It was not the job she'd have wanted, of course; she had a degree. I mustn't think she would have taken this job if she hadn't been desperate, but people had been against her. After 10 minutes, she admitted she worked part-time as a waitress in a cafe.

The solicitor, a rosy, clubbable soul from a three-man high street firm, was having a hard time with his facial expressions. Half his face was cocked at Miss P in sympathy, the other half telegraphing to me that he knew what he'd brought me, but what could he do? What indeed? I tried to concentrate Miss P's mind on specifics, something that had actually happened, some facts.

Before I could come to any understanding of why Miss P was sacked, there was a further swamp of words to wade through. First I must understand about how these people had been tracking her. They belonged to an organisation Miss P could not name: "But there are powerful individuals involved, whose names you have heard of."

Three cups of coffee later, it finally became apparent that she had confronted a customer, accused him of following her, of writing down what she said. There was a scene and the manager said he'd have to let her go. But Miss P was complaining of sexual harassment as well: "Before he sacked me, he stripped me bare with his eyes. They were bedroom eyes."

I said what I had to say, that it was all a matter of evidence. While naturally I believed her, I was not sure a tribunal would. And so they departed, the solicitor in a flurry of grateful smiles, Miss P with dark eyes, betrayed again.

fields.headline: Mannesmann bid hits £100bn
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Vodafone's bid for Mannesmann, the German telecoms group, broke through the £100bn barrier as investor confidence that it would win its battle sent its shares and those of its prey soaring, writes David Gow.
fields.body:
Vodafone's bid for Mannesmann, the German telecoms group, broke through the £100bn barrier as investor confidence that it would win its battle sent its shares and those of its prey soaring, writes David Gow.

Nearly half a billion Vodafone shares changed hands, enabling the stock to close 6% up at 359.25p. In Frankfurt Mannesmann shares also closed almost 6% up at €296.30 (£178).

The "see-thru" value of Vodafone's bid is €321, not far short of the €350 value placed on the group in its current form by chief executive Klaus Esser.

fields.headline: Nokia's WAP lead pays off
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, yesterday said it was shipping "hundreds of thousands" of internet enabled handsets a week to meet intense demand as it reported record pre-tax profits for last year of 3.8bn euros (£2.3bn).
fields.body:
Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, yesterday said it was shipping "hundreds of thousands" of internet enabled handsets a week to meet intense demand as it reported record pre-tax profits for last year of 3.8bn euros (£2.3bn).

Chief executive Jorma Ollila predicted replacement handsets would account for up to 80% of sales next year compared to 40% in 1999 as interest in wireless access explodes.

Nokia has stolen a march on rivals with its 7110 model wireless application protocol or WAP phone, which has been in short supply since its launch last November. The handsets retail for around £129.99.

Pre-tax profits for the full year at Nokia, Europe's largest company, were up 57% on sales of almost 20bn euros - 48% ahead of the previous year.

Mr Ollila said he expected the number of mobile phone users globally would break the 1bn barrier by the end of 2002, compared with 480m at the end of last year.

The company said that of the 275m handsets sold globally in 1999, 78.5m had been pro duced by Nokia, representing a market share of 28.5%.

American manufacturer Motorola sold 50m phones last year and Ericsson 31m. Ericsson is expected to launch its first WAP phone in Britain in the next few months.

Nokia, however, is expected to come under added pressure from manufacturers outside the big three as other firms identify the opportunities in the market.

Siemens, Philips, Samsung and Mitsubishi are expected to make inroads, according to a note from investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

Increasing competition would weigh heavily on margins, which would fall from last year's 20.5% as Nokia jostles for share, the group said.

Mr Ollila also confirmed a recent meeting with Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corporation, to discuss ways of stimulating the market for wireless internet access.

The Helsinki-based company, however, would not become directly involved in the provision of content. "We have our plate full of stuff, there is no way we would go into the content side," Mr Ollila said.

Nokia also announced the $335m (£208.1m) acquisition of California-based Network Alchemy, which provides a software platform for secure online trading.

The group's mobile handset division showed operating profits of just over €1bn - up from 581m euros a year ago.

fields.headline: Tale of three tenors
fields.standfirst:
Otello
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText:
Otello
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.body:
Rossini's Otello, premiered in Naples in 1816, is an opera with a notorious reputation: the libretto is a grotesque distortion of Shakespeare; the opera is twaddle when put beside Verdi's much later version; and it requires no fewer than three star tenors (plus the best soprano you can find), all of whom have to sing some of the most impossibly gruelling music ever written.

The revelation of the Royal Opera's new production, however, is that most of the charges flung at the opera are erroneous. Shakespeare is not so much travestied as cogently distilled along neoclassical lines - aptly so for a composer who, though regarded as a Romantic, was largely drawn to the theatre of Voltaire and Racine. As for the three tenors, Covent Garden has unquestionably found them - and boy can they sing.

Glamorisation of the tenor voice was what both Verdi and Rossini were about when it came to giving the Moor of Venice musical flesh, but where Verdi demands clarion lung power, Rossini lets his Otello seduce, enchant and rave over the fearsome extreme of two-and-a-half octaves. Bruce Ford negotiates this terrifying range with consummate ease and minimal showiness, underpinning his vocalism with a sense of volcanic emotion.

It's a strong performance, but he's not ultimately the star of the show. Pride of place goes to the Peruvian tenor Juan Diego Florez. He's cast as Rodrigo, a conflation of Cassio and his Shakespearian namesake. Rossini endows the object of Otello's jealously with a vocal allure and prowess that exceed his own. The tessitura is implacably high, the coloratura treacherous. Florez spins it out with a staggering perfection of tone. A very great tenor has finally arrived. Octavio Arevalo's Iago completes the triumvirate. His music is less florid, its punchy simplicity an apt catalyst for his victims' spectacular emotionalism. Arevalo is impressive, reedily serpentine, a nasty piece of work.

Hearing this trio in action is imperative, but you have to put up with inequalities elsewhere. Mariella Devia's Desdemona isn't in their league. A once great bel canto singer, she's now past her best. Her phrasing remains unfailingly sensitive, but the tone is acidic. An ill-judged, interpolated top note in the act two finale was a horrid shriek, as if someone had put electrodes on her. The conductor, Gianluigo Gelmetti, is elegantly refined, but rarely intense enough. The production, by Pier Luigi Pizzi, badly misjudges the piece. Rossini keeps the action in Venice throughout, though the libretto, incorporating quotes from Dante, aligns the city's concentric canals with the circles of the Inferno and reminds us that this is a drama of lost souls played out on the brink of an abyss. Venice and Hell are both conspicuous by their absence, however. All we get is a series of insipid tableaux vivants against a backdrop of monotonous grey colonnades. Rossini - and those three glorious tenors - deserve something better.

Until February 17. Box office: 0171-304 4000

fields.headline: Bernie and Clive
fields.standfirst:
Battersea Arts Centre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Bernie and Clive
Battersea Arts Centre, London
***
fields.body:
Cartoon de Salvo, a young company with just three shows to its credit, is one to watch. Its latest is a rough piece of comic visual theatre in the early Reject's Revenge style. It displays more flair than skill, but has so many good visual gags that you can't help falling for its crazy charm.

It is the US during the Great Depression. Arriving separately in New York on an ocean-liner, immigrants Bernie and Clive discover that life is no bowl of cherries. In fact getting enough to eat is quite a problem, so they head off across country in the hope of bettering themselves and their stomachs. Unfortunately another similarly named pair of outcasts are doing the same: Bonnie and Clyde are wreacking terror across the nation.

This comedy of mistaken identity is slight, and the three performers need a lot more discipline to pull it off. But they make inventive use of Becky Hurst's simple, advent-calendar-style set, constantly teasing the eye to look in one place so that a surprise is in store when you glance in another.

The show's surface is always light-hearted, but what makes it interesting is the subtext bubbling underneath in which food, loneliness and sex all get thrown into the cauldron.

It's not so much moving as a fast-moving evening, and evidence that Cartoon de Salvo may really be going places.

Till February 6. Box office: 0171-223 2223.

fields.headline: The Winter's Tale
fields.standfirst:
Salisbury Playhouse
***
fields.trailText:
The Winter's Tale
Salisbury Playhouse
***
fields.body:
Since Declan Donnellan's production for the Maly Theatre, I've found it impossible to think of this late play as one with a romantic resolution. Donnellan gave the play a hard ending: when Hermione's statue came to life there was no forgiveness, only a bitter recollection of the wasted years.

Making her Playhouse debut, new artistic director Joanna Read goes for a traditional production with an uncluttered, unradical account of the play. Final redemption is not just possible but certain. It has more intelligence than inspiration, but it looks handsome with a clever design by Nancy Surman. The wood-panelled walls of the court are suddenly split by lightning when the king, Leontes, defies the oracle and persists in believing that his wife, Hermione, has committed adultery with his friend Polixenes. The cloven wood is neatly transformed into the jagged mountains of Bohemia.

There are some nice performances, even if some of the cast approach the verse as if it is an express train. Fergus McLarnon's quick patter as the wily Autolycus suggests he is fresh from the panto season. The best performance is Katharine Barker's Paulina, a redoubtable woman quite capable of converting heathens and taming lions in her spare time. No wonder Leontes is so scared of her as she forces him to confront his folly.

It is in the quiet moments of observation that Read's production excels. When Leontes ponders on what he believes is his wife's betrayal, shadows appear on the walls: it looks as if he is imprisoned. None of the courtiers want to touch the indictment of Hermione; after the oracle has proved Leontes' suspicions to be unfounded they turn away from him, as if they can't bear to have this tainted tyrant near them.

More like this, and Read would have a production not just of straightforward honesty but one with real emotional depth.

Till February 19. Box office: 01722 320333 .
